\_sh v3.0 400 MDF 4.0

\lx -ah
\ps suffix 
\de in, at, on
\re in ; at ; on
\do 
\sf
\co After words ending in r, l; see,g,ammar and -Dah. 
\xv Y:Sha: Woodenbongah 
\xe 'at Woodenbong' 
\rfg Y:Sha
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx -an.ga-, -angga-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de be, become
\re be ; become
\do 
\sf
\co -wehn imperfect aspect, often where English would use past tense; suffixable to nouns and adjectives etc, to make verb. Occasionally found as wana-/wan.ga-, from which -an.ga- is derived. Past tense -wehn.
\xv Y:Sha: Ngulungmay waring-an.gahla. 
\xe 'It's getting cold./It will get cool.' 
\xv Y:Holm: Gumbinywehn nyula. 
\xe 'That was the end of him.' 
\xv Y:Sha: Jangan.gehn gidjung. 
\xe 'The old man is no good.' 
\xv Y:Sha: jangwany
\xe 'something bad'
\xv M:Liv: Dagayanah! 
\xe 'May you die!’ 
\xv M:Liv: Dagayan.gahny
\xe '(I) will kill myself/go to death.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Holm; M:Liv
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx -ay
\ps suffix 
\de subjunctive?
\re subjunctive?
\do 
\sf
\co Livingstone states 'This may be called the subjunctive, but the verb does not take this form in all positions where we might expect a subjunctive to be used'; he further states 'The Subjunctive, i.e., the form which the verb takes when compounded with Auxiliary Verbs'. 
\rfg M:Liv 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 22/Mar/2015

\rfk Cas:Smy eib-a, eibalen

\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx ba-
\ps verb transitive
\de say, utter, tell
\re say ; utter ; tell
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Usually not alone, but added to nouns of sound or speech to form a verb Wa; most (but not all) nouns that refer to noises may be verbalised with this verb root; can be added to nouns to make verbs involving saying something; e,g, nyariba- 'to name' , ngihnba- 'to ask' , nyangba- 'to call/name' (literally 'say what/something') nyulabal 'way of talking'; minyangbal 'Minyangbal (dialect)'; see also ma- Gd. 
\xv Wa: “Wanahwar nganyi yiralingahyumah” bani wihnyi. 
\xe “Don't speak to me in English” you were told.' 
\xv Gd: Mahdja baygalni gidjah balehn 
\xe 'the boss was saying to the man, "Tell me!"
\xv Gd: nguhr balehla 
\xe 'is growling'
\xv Gd: yarehng balehla 
\xe 'is screaming'
\xv Gd: buruhng balehla 
\xe 'is snoring'
\xv Gd: Baygal jabuhngi "yanah" bani. 
\xe 'The man said to the boy "Go away!"'
\xv Gd: "Yagambeh" badjahn mahdjayu. 
\xe '"No," said the boss.'
\xv Gd: Jabuhngayu wadjanggu nyule,g, "yaway" balimahn. 
\xe 'The boy's mother made him say "yes."' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm ba-, -ba- 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx -ba
\ps suffix 
\de,g,eater intensity of action
\re intensity of action, greater 
\do 
\sf
\co Understood as 'do by choice' by Geytenbeek; cannot be followed by the imperative Gd.
\xv Gd: Baygal galgabalehn jali. 
\xe 'The man was persisting in chopping down trees.' (Geytenbeeks translate 'by choice')
\xv Gd: Ngagambu gahdjabalehla jimbang. 
\xe 'The dog is persistently chasing the sheep.'
\xv Gd: Mahdja baygalni gidjabalehn muna. 
\xe 'The boss persisted in telling the man about that.' 
\xv Wa: yaruhma- 
\xe 'swim'
\xv Wa: yaruhmaba- 
\xe 'swim faster'
\xv Wa: naba 
\xe 'pelt'
\xv Wa: nababa- 
\xe 'pelt harder'
\xv Wa: dunga- 
\xe 'cry'
\xv Wa: dungba- 
\xe 'cry louder'
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx -ba
\ps suffix 
\de make, cause to
\re make, to ; cause to
\do 
\sf
\co See ba-, e,g, nyariba- 'give a name (cause to be named)'. 
\xv Cas: yanbihba 
\xe 'cause to go'
\xv Cas: wadjuba 
\xe 'make speak'
\xv Cas: ayba 
\xe 'make the exclamation 'ei', exhibit surprise'
\xv Cas: yagambehba 
\xe 'make 'no' 'refuse, be unable or unsuccessful'
\xv Cas: nyariba 
\xe 'cause to be named, give name to'
\xv Cas: Ngay gale wangah gawang - balehn nyule. 
\xe 'I am your uncle - said he.'
\xv M:Liv: Munu waybaru gandjilinibahny ngubu. 
\xe 'That fire will be lighted (made to burn) tomorrow'. 
\xv M:Liv: ba 
\xe 'cause to be'
\xv M:Liv: nyarri-ba 
\xe 'give a name, cause to have a name'
\xv M:Liv: kunjillianneban 
\xe 'will be lighted' 
\rfg 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy -b-a, janbi:ba, wadjuba, eiba, jogombeba; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx babang
\ps noun
\de father, father's brother
\re father ; father's brother ; uncle (paternal)
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Cf biyang; most have bidjang or biyang, but Geytenbeek had babang from Culham, baba(ng) also given by Weizel; Watson and Prior's form suggests biyal.

\dt 22/Mar/2015

\lx badji-
\ps verb transitive 
\de hit, punch, hit with any kind of object, cut, strike
\re hit ; punch ; hit (with any kind of object) ; cut ; strike
\do 
\sf
\co e,g, open or closed fist, hand held object, thrown object, or falling object (such as rain); hitting can be accidental or on purpose, can also refer to noise made by hitting; it is the most general verb of hitting; Ga? badjinyi 'to hit'. Cf also bayi-. 
\xv Wa: guwang badji- 
\xe 'rain hard' 
\xv We: badjilehla 
\xe 'hitting' (also bayi-) 
\xv Various: Ngadju wihnyi badjehny mala wahlu nganyah bargan gahngganyi. 
\xe 'I will hit you if you take my boomerang.'
\xv Various: Yagambeh bayahny badjilehny. 
\xe 'It won't rain today.'
\xv Various: Maliyu nganyi badjini mumguhlu. 
\xe 'He punched me (hit with fist).'
\xv Various: Maliyu baygalu nugalu badjidjahn malahni. 
\xe 'The man slapped her on the face.'
\xv Various: Gala yangwehn wambaruga badjinibeh-nguy wihnyi.
\xe 'He would have come with a stick and hit you with it.'
\xv Various: Wihnyi baginydja badjini. 
\xe 'You nearly got hit (by a thrown boomerang).'
\xv Various: Wanah bawur badjeh malahya dawgaydja. 
\xe 'Don't bump your head on the rock.'
\xv Various: Mayu-mayu ngihn badjilehla. 
\xe 'Who is that knocking?' (where the person can't be seen but the noise can be heard)
\xv Various: Guwan badjilehla. 
\xe 'Rain is falling' (guwan We)
\xv Cas: Badjeh guruman jununggu. 
\xe 'Hit the wallaby with your club' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy badj-e, badje: ; Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn ; 
\rfr Ga:Sha:Turnbl badji, badjinyi to hit; Gd:Geyt; Gn:Mathew batyer strike 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx badjili-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de to rain
\re rain, to
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co From badji- 'hit, strike' with -li antipassive/reflexive.

\xe 'It will rain.'
\xv Cas: Gale badjilehla. 
\xe 'It is raining.'
\xv Cas: Nyang gale badjilehny bayahny?
\xe 'Is it going to rain today?'

\dt 22/Mar/2015

\lx baga-bagah
\ps place name
\de Mt Barney
\re Mt Barney
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co bagah = 'shield'; Mt Barney is considered shield shaped. Another name budjurguhmu was recorded in Gd, and another source lists it as Boogah-Boogah 'go away', but the language is not necessarily Yugambeh. 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm baga bagah; Sunday Mail Color Magazine 10/10/71 Boogah-Boogah
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx bagah
\ps noun
\de Coral-tree, bat tree or cork tree or shield made from this wood, wood of corkwood or bat tree 
\re Coral-tree ; tree, Coral- ; bat tree ; cork tree ; shield made from wood of corkwood or bat tree ; wood of corkwood or bat tree
\do1 pl
\do2 art
\sf Erythrina vespertilio (Gresty)
\co cf, also gundul 'bark'. 
\xv Y:Watsn: bagah 
\xe 'shield made from cork tree'
\xv Y:Watsn: wundal 
\xe 'bowl made from cork-tree' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm baga cork or bat tree, bagah shield; Y:Allen baga shield; Y:Watsn bÃ¢gÃ¢, wunÂ´dal cork-tree or bat-tree; AT:Curr:Prior,O'Conn buga; GC:Coomera:police bugar; Tw:Curr:Bray buggar; GC:Nerang:Fowlr bugga shield; Ng:Gresty bukkabukka; Y:Hanln bug-gah shield 
\rfb
\rfk

\lx bagal, bagul
\ps noun
\de brown snake, tiger snake, deadly snake (taipan?) 
\re snake, brown ; snake, tiger ; snake, deadly (taipan?)
\do rep
\do 
\sf
\co Given as 'tiger snake' (Y:Allen), 'giant tiger snake' (Ng:Gresty), same,g,ven for 'brown snake' (Yw), 'taipan(?)' (Y:Sha:Culhm), 'deadly snake (taipan?)' (Y:Sha:Culhm). 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm bagal deadly snake (taipan?); Y:Allen buggull tiger snake; Y:Watsn bÃ_gÂ´gel, bugÂ´gÃ_l brown snake; Ng:Gresty boggul giant tiger snake; Y:Hanln buggool brown snake; (Y:Allen), 'giant tiger snake' (Ng:Gresty), same,g,ven for brown snake (Yw), taipan(?) (Y:Sha:Culhm), deadly snake (taipan?) (Y:Sha:Culhm).

\rfk

\dt 22/Mar/2015

\lx bagar
\ps locative 
\de beyond
\re beyond
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Locative case form bagarah in Y:Hanln. Possibly bagahr, bagahra (loc); Livingstone and Hanlon spellings suggests second syllable stressed (i.e. Has a long vowel). Gundeh 'over there'; bagar-djang-djang 'further and further' (Ng:Gresty). 
\xv M:Liv: Gundeh bagarah 
\xe answer to 'Where is the tomahawk?' 
\rfg M:Liv kunde bukkora; Ng:Gresty buckrachungchung; Y:Hanln buckra
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\re kurrajong, prickly 
\do pl
\do

\dt 22/Mar/2015

\lx bagar
\ps locative 
\de over there, distant, far side
\re over there ; distant ; far side
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Must take same case marking as the noun it qualifies. 
\xv Wa: gila bagarah dubay 
\xe 'that woman out there' 
\xv Wa: Mahnyulu galgahla baygalu bagarahgu gimbalahgu. 
\xe 'Those men are cutting (wood) for them out there.'
\xv Wa: Ganngah manyihni yarbilehla bagarah burambah nguhmbinydjah.
\xe 'Listen to those singing behind the house out there.'
\xv Wa: Ganngahla ngadju balahyanah gahri bagarah. 
\xe 'I hear that the one over there died.'
\xv Wa: Mala nguhnyba walanggiwahla bagar. 
\xe 'The snake is crawling away.' 
\xv Gd: Bagardjahnggu ngay gabalgu. 
\xe 'I am going to the far e,g, of the scrub.' (beyond-intens-goal) 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl over there, distant 
\rfr Gd:Geyt far side 
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx bagar
\ps adverb
\de too, often, too much
\re too ; often ; too much
\do 
\sf
\co cf, bagar, bagar, similar in broad meaning. 
\xv Cas: Gale-war bagar nguwuny. 
\xe 'This is too hot.'
\xv Cas: Nyule yangguwahla yagam bagar gagala. 
\xe 'He doesn't come here too often.'
\xv Cas: Yanah ngali bagardjahng. 
\xe 'Let's go further.'
\xv Cas: Yalgan gale bagar dandur yanbihgu. 
\xe 'The sun is too hot (strong) for walking.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy bagar
\rfr
\rfo

\lx bagar(a)-wan-
\ps verb
\de pass, win (as in a race)
\re pass ; win (as in a race)
\do 
\sf
\co Literally 'to pass by and leave alone' (Y:Allen), as 'win' (Y:Allen). Probably literally 'beyond-leave' (Sharpe), so read as bagar, not bagir. 
\rfg Y:Allen pr buggerrawunna, p -wunani, pf -wunnandian, f -wunnala; Y:Watsn bÃ_gera-wÃ_nna; bÃ_gera-wÃ_nÂ´anÃ®; bÃ_gera-wÃ_nÂ´andian; bÃ_gera-wÃ_nÃ¢la pass , win as in a race

\lx baginy, baginydja
\ps adverb
\de nearly
\re nearly
\do 
\sf
\co Implies state or action of sentence was nearly attained but not quite realised; cf, dagal - there is no apparent difference between these in use. 
\xv Wa: Julur baginydja mahny banggiwahla. 
\xe 'The boils are nearly bursting.'
\xv Wa: Wihnyi baginydja badjini. 
\xe 'You nearly got hit (by a thrown boomerang).' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr
\rfo

\lx bagul
\ps noun
\de bark (of tree) (Gd), canoe, boat
\re bark (of tree) (Gd) ; canoe ; boat
\do1 art
\do2 pl
\sf
\co Plural bagul-gali, see also gundul, gandul, bawul (?), and cf, wundal 'bowl made from corkwood tree' (Watsn). 
\xv Gd: Ngadju gahny mandahny bagul malahya jaliya. 
\xe 'I'll scrape the bark off the tree.'
\xv Gd: Bagul mala burah gadji yehnbi ngay. 
\xe 'Pull off the bark so I can sit here.'
\xv Gd: Nganyah gala bagul gawarehla bugalungahla wangahnyi 
\xe 'My canoe,g,es better than yours.'
\xv Gd: Mala bagul garinggahni. 
\xe 'The canoe sank.'
\xv Bj:Sha:Turnbl: Ngay bandjani gala waybar bagulu. 
\xe 'I cover my house with bark.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm gundul bark of tree; Y:Allen gundul; Y:Watsn gundÃ»l bark of a tree; M:Liv bagul; Tw:Curr:Bray yoolin (lit. Skin); AT:Prior barou; AT:Curr:LandsWh koonjool; AT:Curr:O'Conn burwool; GC:Nerang:Fowlr condool ; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl bagul, bagulu; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, bagul; Wi:Lism:Curr boekall bark; Wi:Curr:Richmd bagool; Wi:Curr:Richmd burcool 
\rfk Wa:Crowl bark, canoe; We:Gordn bark ; Cas:Smy bagul; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt bark of tree; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce bargool bark ; 
\rfo Cop:Hargrv buggal boat ;

\lx bahbany, bahbuny
\ps noun
\de,g,andmother, mother's mother, mother's sister, granddaughter, grandchild
\re,g,andmother ; mother's mother ; mother's sister ; granddaughter ; grandchild
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Also female cousin of mother's mother or mother's father Gd; plural baybanygir; also bahbanydjargan, plural bahbanygirgan Wa; in southern dialects mother's mother; Y:Allen, Y:Watsn and M:Liv, as well as all other dialect lists except for Casino (Smythe) give as mother's mother, but Y:Sha:Culhm and Casino dialect give as father's mother; reciprocal term (M:Liv), i.e. Daughter's child. 
\xv Y:Holm: nganya bahbany
\xe 'my grandchild'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm bahbiny grandmother (father's side); Y:Holm:GCurry; Y:Allen barbun; Y:Watsn bÃ¢rÂ´bÃ»n, bar bÃ»n; M:Liv baibung mother's mother, daughter's child; Y:Hanln barbung 
\rfb

\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce barbin grandmother;

\lx -bahma
\ps suffix 
\de in
\re in
\do 
\sf
\co Rare noun suffix, but with meaning 'in' when used; 'long' form with life nouns -bahma. 
\xv M: Wahlu dalbangga balunma! 
\xe 'You jump in the river!'
\xv M: Wahre baygalbahma gunu. 
\xe 'Carry this with the man.' 
\rfg M:Liv ma, baima
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr

\dt 22/Mar/2015

\lx bahn-, bahna-, bahn.ga-, bahrwa-, baya-, barga
\ps verb intransitive 
\de arrive, arise, rise, get up, happen, appear, come out, stand up, eme,g,
\re arrive ; arise ; rise ; get up ; happen ; appear ; come out ; stand up ; eme,g,
\do 
\sf
\co Motion verb, irregular. Come up, come out, rise, eme,g,, bleed, hatch out, come through, arrive, wake up, get up, i.e. To come into sight or existence from where previously invisible or non-existent Wa; rise, appear, arrive Gd; can be reduplicated: babahna-/babahn.ga- Wa; bahna imperative; bahnbigi 'come out', bahn.gala 'come out' (Y:Holm); irregular verb, two forms; bahn.ga- etc, in other lists (Gd:Geyt, etc.); rise, get up, blow (of wind); irregular; imperative bahna; can be used of wind rising/blowing. Holmer also lists baya-, bayi- 'come out, up, forth, get out, away'; probably belongs here - Holmer does not always mark vowel le,g,h. 
\xv Wa: Ngagu dagam babahyanibu babara. 
\xe 'Dark clouds came from up there again.'
\xv Wa: Mala mihngbal bahn.gany. 
\xe 'The storm will come.'
\xv Wa: Mahny baygal bahyani mununu bubehngu gulungbaliwahla. 
\xe 'The men came out of the dust coughing all the time.'
\xv Wa: Janguy bahyanibeh munah guruhmbil gehrbinah mahnyulu jahdjambu. 
\xe 'She,g,t angry (her anger emerged) because the children spilt the milk.'
\xv Wa: Mala yalgan bahn.gala numgir malangu gibamdjubunydja. 
\xe 'The sun comes out in the day and then the moon comes out at night.'
\xv Wa: Mala ngulahr bahrwala yang 
\xe 'the flood is coming here.'
\xv Wa: Yuh mahny nyamul bahn.gany.
\xe 'Later the baby (turtles) will hatch out.'
\xv Wa: Ngay bahn.gala jubunydjahbu. 
\xe 'I get up early.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu badjini gumar bahnbi. 
\xe 'He hit me till I bled.'
\xv Wa: Bahrwala mala bidjanggay. 
\xe 'The baby is waking up.' 
\xv Gd: Bahyanah ngay nyahleni nyahni budjigehnbu. 
\xe 'When I got up and looked I saw only a cat.'
\xv Gd: Nyahnybu ngali gadji bangilehnydje ngarihngbilnu baygal.
\xe 'We will see the men again when they arrive here from overseas' (another+country-from)
\xv Gd: yalgan behni 
\xe sunrise'
\xv Cas: Yawahr gale jehr bahn.gala. 
\xe 'A big corroboree is starting.'
\xv Cas: Gawalang bahna. 
\xe 'Come outside.'
\xv Cas: Yalgan bahn.gala numgirnu. 
\xe 'The sun rises daily.'
\xv Cas: Buhnyi dugun mulih bahn.gala. 
\xe 'The tips of the Bunya Mountains appear.'
\xv Cas: Ngay balahn.gahny bahn.gahnybu. 
\xe 'I shall die and rise again.'
\xv Cas: Bugwani nyule jagun, bayani gung. 
\xe 'He speared the,g,ound and a stream of water appeared.'
\xv Cas: Yan.gahny ngali yalgan bayanah. 
\xe 'We'll go after the sun has risen.'
\xv Cas: Ngay bayani ngumbiynyu.
\xe 'I came out of the house.'
\xv Cas: Bahna wuya! 
\xe 'Get up!'
\xv Cas: Wanah bahna! 
\xe 'Don't get up!'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,,Turnbl: Burginy barwahla. 
\xe 'The wind is rising, coming up, blowing.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngaydju nyulangi bahnbinymani yawahrgu. 
\xe 'I got him up for the corroboree.'
\xv Bj:Holm:Fe,g,: Juhm gila bahn.galah.
\xe 'Smoke is coming up there.'
\xv Bj:Holm:Fe,g,: Gibam bahn.galah. 
\xe 'The moon is rising.'
\xv Fe,g,, Turnbl: Burginy bahn.galah . 
\xe 'The wind is rising.'
\xv Fe,g,, Turnbl: Bahn.galehla mamala jugaligal.
\xe 'He is sneaking drink.' 
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Bahna jahna! 
\xe 'Stand up!'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wahlu bahna! 
\xe 'You come out!'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wahlu bahnbigi. 
\xe 'You want to come out.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: gugarnu bahn.gala 
\xe 'coming out of the hole'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: yalgan bahnggilah (sic) 
\xe 'east'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bahrgilahla yalgan. 
\xe 'The sun is rising.'
\xv Y:Holm: Gung gubung bayani. 
\xe 'A waterhose came up.'
\xv Y:Holm: Gila/Nyula bayini. 
\xe 'He came out.'
\xv Y:Holm: Gahmu dubay bayini. 
\xe 'Those (two) girls got out (or got away).' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Holm bahna, bahn.ga, Y:Holm:Logn bahrwula come out 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, barwa-, prog. Barwala, ba:nga-, prog. Ba:ngala. Bj:Holm ba:na-. Ba:na, ba:nbinymani got (someone) up; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy ba:n-a, ba:n.gala, ba:na, ba:n.gainjbu baij-a, baijani, baijana: 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce yalgan beannie sunrise ; 
\rfo

\xe 'It's under the tree.'

\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx balun
\ps noun
\de river, creek, Milky Way
\re river ; creek ; Milky Way
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Plural balun-gali; in We, locative suffix vowel can vary to /i/: balunda/balundi 'in the river'; possibly balin/baluny in Cop; Y:Sha:Culhm; reduplicated balun-baluhn (Y:Allen); also 'waterhole' in Y:Hanln; cf, the Balonne River, Queensland (Holmer). 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Yehni mala balunbu. 
\xe 'It went along the river.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Madji bagara ngihrgila yehna balunda. 
\xe 'Sit down over there on the river bank.'
\xv Gd:JThomas: balun daarim 
\xe 'day creek'
\xv M:Liv: Wahlu dalbangga balunma. 
\xe 'You jump in the river.' 
\rfg M:Liv ballun river, balunma into the river; Ng:Sc:Cudgn3/1903 balon river; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn bolloon; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray bullum; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn barloam lake; Ng:Sc:Mur4/1903 balun river
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl balun; Bj:TMcD:Cowl balun; Bj:Holm-Fe,g,, Turnbl balun; Bj:Sc:Coraki4 ballum river; Bj:Sc:Coraki baloon river; Bj:Sc:Coraki4 baloon gully
\rfk Wa:Crowl river, Milky Way; We:Gordn river; Cas:Smy balun river; Wu:Calley ba:lun river ;
\rfr Gd:Geyt river, creek; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce bal-loon creek, chunim river, balloon tarrim day creek
\rfo Cop:Hargrv ballin

\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx banahm
\ps noun
\de female's brother, male's younger brother, etc,
\re brother, female's; brother, male's younger
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co (a) female's brother, male's younger brother; also 'greatgrandson' (M); includes many male relations on the same,g,neration level (methods of calculating who is in banahm relationship differ according to whether ego is male or female); (b) great grandson Gd; male's younger brother and male cousin, female's brother and male cousin, great-grandfather, great-grandson Wa; often used today reciprocally between 'brothers'; Wi:Lism:Curr, Wi:Sc:Richmd and Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray list as (older) brother, Turnbull says younger brother; probably man's younger brother, woman's brother as in other dialects banahmdjar 'cousin' (Holmer:Fe,g,). Livingstone has accurate list, but AT:Curr:LandsWh, AT:Curr:O'Conn list as female's younger brother, Watson as younger brother. Also 'great-grandson'. 
\xv Bj:Holmer: nganyah banahm 
\xe 'my brother'

\do

\lx bandahn
\ps noun
\de tomahawk, stone axe, small axe, a rock, stone for tomahawk, stones
\re tomahawk ; axe, stone ; axe, small ; rock ; stone for tomahawk ; stones
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Stone AT, Y:Hanln. Used for 'hail, ice' (Y:Hanln); possibly bandan; budiny or buriny in one list (Tw:Curr:Bray); also bandahl; cf, gulman, bandjang, karang, manal. 
\xv M: Ngayu ginahny jinang bandahn.gu. 
\xe 'I will make a handle for the tomahawk.'
\xv M: Burah jinang bandahnda 
\xe 'Pull the handle out of the tomahawk' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgahla ngayu wuginymahla bandahndu. 
\xe 'I chop quickly with the axe.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu jambamani galgayah jali, bandahn jang. 
\xe 'I tried to chop the tree but the axe was blunt.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu ginahny jinangg bandahngu. 
\xe 'I will make a handle for the tomahawk.'
\xv M:Liv: Burah jinang bandahnda. 
\xe 'Pull the handle out of the tomahawk.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm bandahn axe, tomahawk; Y:Holm bandan stone axe, tomahawk; Y:Allen bundahn tomahawk; Y:Watsn bÃ_ndÃ¢n, bun'dÃ¢n; gul'man stone axe or tomahawk, bun'dÃ¢n stone for tomahawk; Y:Watsn mÃ_n'al; bÃ_n'dan a rock; M:Liv bundan tomahawk, bundango for, bundanda out of; -dj e,g, -dj dat, -no abl1, -dj abl2; Mur:Hargrv bundan tomahawk; AT:Prior,jo bundan, pondan; AT:Curr:LandsWh bunding stone Tw:Curr:Bray bunday (prob. \lx banggi-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de explode (Gd), open up, flare up or brighten suddenly, burst, blaze, come out (of sun), shoot
\re explode (Gd) ; open up ; flare up or brighten suddenly ; burst ; blaze ; come out (of sun) ; shoot
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Can refer to noise of sudden opening up or flaring up Wa; inherently singular, does not take completive or repetitive suffixes except in combination with ma- 'cause' Gd. 
\xv Wa: Waybar mala banggehn. 
\xe 'The fire was blazing.'
\xv Wa: Waybar mala banggi-banggehn. 
\xe 'The fire flared up in sparks.'
\xv Wa: Gala yalgan banggehn. 
\xe 'The sun burst out (from behind a cloud).'
\xv Wa: Mala banggehny mundu malahna. 
\xe 'his stomach will burst!'
\xv Wa: Julur baginydja mahny banggiwahla. 
\xe 'The boils are nearly bursting.'
\xv Wa: Banggilimah mala ngagam duluhlbiyu nganyahyu. 
\xe 'Shoot the dog with my rifle.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx bang-, bangga-
\ps verb transitive 
\de kick, tread on, stamp on to make strong impact with the feet, leave a mark (as a footprint)
\re kick ; tread on ; stamp on to make strong impact with the feet ; leave a mark (as a footprint)
\do 
\sf
\co Irreg; cf, banga-; Livingstone lists this under ban- 'fall', saying 'if imperative ends in a' (bangga, not bungge), it has this meaning; see also bang-. It appears to be a different verb; note Hanlon attests this form, but suggests bunggahn for 'a kick'. Wa has bangga- 'kick, stamp on', and C has banga- 'tread, tread on, trample'; Holmer gives as 'shoot', but in Yugambeh and Gidjabal it is 'kick, stamp'; Holmer's example,g,ves meaning 'shoot', but it could be an extension of meaning. 
\xv Wa: Ngadju banggahny malahni ngagami. 
\xe 'I will kick that dog.'
\xv Wa: Banggahla ngadju ngayal jinanggu. 
\xe 'I'm stamping on the,g,ound with my feet.'
\xv Bj: Ngadju banggilimani bulguni, jangmani. 
\xe 'I shot a wallaby but it got away.' 
\rfg M:Liv bungge; if imperative ends in a it has meaning kick, stamp, leave a mark as a footprint; Y:Hanln bungah kick, boongahn a kick, bingah kick 
\rfb Bj:Holm banggilimani ; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt , banga- irreg, like dung- 'cry' also listed as motion verb 'to arrive at' irreg; prob. Erronious identification with ban- 
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx ban-, ban.ga-, bi- (Holm), ban-, bangga-, barwa-, banggi- (M:Liv)
\ps verb intransitive 
\de fall, disappear, go away, drop 
\re fall ; disappear ; go away ; drop 
\do 
\sf
\co Irreg., past behn (Holmer), bin- in Wa; if imper. Ends in /a/ (bungga) it means 'kick, stamp, leave a mark' as a footprint (Livingstone); bana-, ban.ga- irreg (Ng); Y:Alln ban.gehni past, ban.gehn past indef, ban.gehla pres/fut. 
\xv Bj:Holm: banbi balundah 
\xe 'to fall into the river'
\xv Bj:Holm: (Wanah) banah! 
\xe '(Don't) fall!'
\xv Bj:Holm: Guwang ban.gahla. 
\xe 'Rain is falling.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Mala jahdjam behn jalingu. 
\xe 'That child fell from the tree. 
\xv M: Yindji banggiluru mibiny garahlbu wayrabu? 
\xe 'Where have all the blacks been this long time?'
\xv M: Nyangga banggehn. 
\xe 'The sun has set.'
\xv Gd: ban.gihn-mani 
\xe 'dropped it'
\xv Gd: Jali behn. 
\xe 'The tree fell.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wana bana/ban.ga 
\xe 'Don't fall'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Jinang behn. 
\xe 'A foot came off.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Mih behn. 
\xe 'An eye fell out.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: gila behn 
\xe 'wherever they fell off'. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngumbiny all banggehn. 
\xe 'The house will fall down (sic).'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Ban.gehn ngaw. 
\xe 'I fell down.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wunah gawari ban.gahny wahlu.
\xe 'Don't run, you might fall.' 
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Gurubu; ban.gehn. 
\xe 'Alright; now he's dead.' 
\rfg M:Liv bungge; bunggeloro; bunggen; Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray bungen he's dead ; Y:Sha:Culhm fall ban.ga; Y:Holm:Logn bana, ban.ga fall beh- fall; Y:Allen v pr bunngen, p bunngeni, pf bunngian, f bunngeila drop (as burst); Y:Watsn bÃ_n'gen; bÃ_n'genÃ®; bÃ_n'gian; bÃ_ngÃªÃ®la drop; Y:Watsn bungen drop; Mur:Hargrv bungan born 
\rfb Bj:Holm bana-, bana, banbi; banga-, prog. Bangala; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, bi, bin; 
\rfk 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ;

\lx bar
\ps connective particle
\de particle
\re particle
\do 
\sf
\co Holmer states that a syllable closing /n/ occasionally tends to become /r/ , and he assigns this to ban. 
\xv Bj: Ngihnbar mala? 
\xe 'Who is that?'
\xv Bj: Nyangbar mala? 
\xe 'What is that?'
\xv Bj: Nganyahbar mala nyamul. 
\xe 'That is my baby.’
\xv Bj: Minyangbar? 
\xe ‘What is it?’
\xv Bj: ngalibar 
\xe ‘we all’ (or ‘it is we all’)
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, bar
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx baray

\lx barung(bah)
\ps noun
\de a large boomerang (Tw:Bray:Sc)
\re boomerang, large (Tw:Bray:Sc)
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Probably place name Burringbah, place of baring, the non-returning boomerang (barung attested from Gd and Wa for non-returning boomerang, the killer boomerang); Mur:AndFr notes extension of meaning to name the number 7. MRs10 states 'Burringbar (long boomerang, from Burring, a long boomerang for hitting with, like a sword)'. 
\rfg Mur:AndFr burrungbah an implement of war, Tw:Bray:Sc burringbah a large boomerang; Mur:Sc10 Burringbar long boomerang
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr

\lx bawur
\ps noun
\de head
\re head
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Plural bawur-gali; usual word for 'head', but sometimes given for hair of head. 
\xv Wa: Bawur ngay gala jangurwahla wahnydjarinyun. 
\xe 'My head got dizzy from spinning round.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu dunmani mala dawgay bawuru. 
\xe 'He (a mythical hero) split the rock with his head.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu jahdjambu jangmani malahni bawur dunganahyu. 
\xe 'The child made her head ache by crying.'
\xv Wa: Jangwerwahla nganyah bawur. 
\xe 'My head is aching.'
\xv Y:Holm: bawurah jigay 
\xe 'a headache'
\xv Gd: Mugimah bawur girur gawarehla. 
\xe 'The axe head is slipping (smooth runs).'
\xv Cas: Bawur ngay jang. 
\xe 'I have a headache.'
\xv Cas: Gadjahla nganyah bawur. 
\xe 'My head aches.'
\xv Cas: Nyule bawur-jangwan.gahlabe. 
\xe 'He has a bad head, headache, is insane, etc,' 
\rfg M:Sc:Brunswk bower head or hair; Ng:Curr:Bray bowra hair of head; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray powra hair of head; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn bowah hair of head 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl bawur; Bj:McDon:Cowl bawur head; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, bawur, bawura jigai 'a headache'; Wi:Lism:Curr pooera, poora hair of the head; Wi:Curr:Richmd bowra; Bj:Sc:Coraki, Bj:Sc:Coraki5/1903 baur head; Ny:Curr:Ballina bowrra hair of head; Ny:Sc:Ballina5/1903 bowra head; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy bour ; Wu:Calley bo:urd; Wa:Sc:Tabulm:Hargrv pow-wa; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; Gn:Mathew bauru ; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce bowra head; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng boural; 
\rfo

\lx bawur, bawul, bawru
\ps noun
\de head, face, hair of head
\re head ; face ; hair of head

\co Pronounced [bo:r] (Y:Sha:Culhm); Y:Hanln top of head; cf, baru; see also baru, bawar, guhndan 'hair of head'. 
\rfg Y:Holm: bawur gudjin 'red hair, ginger.' \lx bayahny
\ps adverb
\de now, today, today still
\re now ; today ; today still
\do ti
\do 
\sf
\co Can be heard as bayahdn: after a long vowel in a stressed syllable the oral closure happens before the nasal air escape begins; Holmer suggests possibly originally the imm. Form of bay a- (q.v.; hence meaning (the sun) on the point of rising?). 
\xv Gd: gale bayahny
\xe 'today' 
\xv Gd: Gale bayahny ngubuh ngubuhwar ngaleh yanbihgu. 
\xe 'We intend to go today, tomorrow, and the next day too.' 
\xv Wa:Sha(?): Ngay gale,g,bing bundahng bayahny. 
\xe 'I'm sick today.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: yan.giwanybu bayahny
\xe 'will come again today' 
\xv M: Bayahny-djang nguhn. 
\xe 'It's warm today.'
\xv M: Gabir ngay bayahny. 
\xe 'I'm hungry today.' 
\rfg M:Liv baian( -jung), paian; M:Sc:Brunswk byan day, today; Ng:Curr:Bray barn to-day, biarn to-day, Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn nunger day 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl baya:nj; Bj:Sha:Turnbl,LWilson bayahny today/now; Bj:Holm:Fe,g,,Turnbl bajany; Wi:Lism:Curr piiyan; Wi:Curr:Richmd byan; Bj:Sc:Coraki byang numgurru to-day; Bj:Sc:Coraki5/1903 byong numgurra to-day; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; ; Wu:Calley ba:ian, bayany; Cas:Smy ba/Ã_ijÃ_nj (accent over Ã_), baija:nj;

\lx baygal
\ps noun
\de dark-skinned man of any race, Aboriginal, Aboriginal people
\re man, dark-skinned of any race ; Aboriginal ; Aboriginal people
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Plural baygal-djahli Gd; [be,g,l], plural baygal-baygahl Wa, Cas plural baygalbir; baygalnah is used for 'Aboriginal language' Wa; pronounced be,g,l, baygal; can be used as adjective 'Aboriginal' (with possessive,g,nitive); baygalnah (Yugambeh) language; ATpr gives mibiny & baygal for 'The Blacks', cf, mibiny [mibin]; accusative form bayganyi?, possibly bayganah, bayganahgal 'from the man' (M:Liv); cf, also guri. Mibiny more commonly used in Yugambeh; baygal in southern dialects (Bundjalung); used of themselves by the Ballina blacks (Ny) ; baygalu (e,g,), baygalbahnyi (advers.); accusative form bayganyi?, possibly bayganah, bayganahgal 'from the man' (M). 
\xv Wa: Mala baygalwen.gahla / baygal-werwahla. 
\xe 'He has grown up (has become a man).'
\xv Gd:Sci: gumbi baygal 
\xe 'the blacks'
\xv Gn: Yila baygal? 
\xe 'Where are the blacks?'
\xv M: Burah munu juwan baygalbaya. 
\xe 'Pull that spear out of the man.'
\xv M: Ngay wanyi ngulung baygal. 
\xe 'I am older than you (I am a man before you).'
\xv Y:Holm: baygalgali 
\xe 'woman who is 'after' a man or fond of men'
\xv M: Burah munu juwan baygalbaya. 
\xe 'Pull that spear out of the man.'
\xv M: Ngay wanyi ngulungbayga(h)l. 
\xe 'I am older than you (I am a man before you).' 
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Gala baygalu bumani gurumani ngubu warbu. 
\xe 'The man killed a kangaroo yesterday.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Gala baygalu wayehni jabuhngi galgaya gale jali. 
\xe 'The man told the boy to chop the tree.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Gala baygalu nyahni gurumani. 
\xe 'The man saw the kangaroo.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Gidjuhny gala baygal. 
\xe 'That man is big.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Gala guruman durulehla baygalbanyi. 
\xe 'The kangaroo is afraid of the man.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Baygalu nyangani. 
\xe 'The man made it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: baygalnah nguyay 
\xe 'Aboriginal talk, the Bandjalang language' 
\xv Bj:Sc:Coraki: gala baygal <kolla bygal> 
\xe 'Aborigines.'
\rfg Y:Holm baigal; Y:Holm:Logn baigalgali; M:Liv paigÃ¥l, mibin, baigÃ¥l: acc. PaigÃ¥nnye, gen. PaigÃ¥nna; paigÃ¥nna-gÃ¥l; paigÃ¥l-baima with; pagÃ¥lbaya out of; pagÃ¥lbai in; paigÃ¥l-bano from; AT:O'Conn bigul; GC:Nerang:Fowlr bagal, AT:Prior mibin, bigall; Y:Hanln man over 20 years bargul and mibbinmen (sic, prob. Baygal and mibiny 'men') ; Ng:Curr:Bray mibbin the blacks, yabbru mibbin a blackfellow; Ng:Sc:Cudgn meebeen man; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn maibin man
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl baygal, baygalu, baygalba:nji; Bj:TMcD baygal Aboriginal man; Bj:Holm baigal, baigalu Fe,g,, baigalna Turnbl; Wi:Curr:Lism bygal the Blacks, a Blackfellow; Wi:Curr:Richmd baygul the Blacks, a Blackfellow; Bj:Sc:Coraki, Bj:Sc:Coraki5/1903 bygal male, Black man, kolla bygal the blacks; Ny:Curr:Ballina bygle a blackfellow; Wi:Curr:Lism bygal the Blacks, a Blackfellow; Wi:Curr:Richmd baygul the Blacks, paiglznna-gal; paigal-baima with; pagalbaya out of; pagalbai in; paigal-bano from; Ny:Curr:Ballina bygle a blackfellow; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 bugguls the blacks at Ballina call themselves; Ny:Sc:Ballina5/1903 bugguls (sic] the blacks, buggul a black man; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 buggul blacks at Ballina call themselves; 
\rfk Cas:Smy baigal, bÃ_igal, be,g,l ; Wa:Crowl, We:Gordn; Wu:Calley be,g,l, bei:gal; Wa:Sc:Tabulm:Hargrv goombe-bigal 'the blacks', bigal 'black man'; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gn:Mathew baigal; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng bigol; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce bigot;

\lx -beh, -be, -beh
\ps suffix 
\de intensifier (mild)
\re intensifier (mild)
\do 
\sf
\co Often translatable as 'very', or 'only' (in the sense of 'exclusively'); occurs in word classes that -djahng and -bu occur on, and also occurs on responses and adverbs and on guram 'perhaps' Gd; Crowley says of Wa that it only occurs on nouns and verbs, on nous usually 'only', on verbs indicates completive aspect, often has little meaning; -be following a syllable with a long vowel. Holmer claims as shortened form of -bari 'having', on yugambe/yugumbe 'having no', and apparently in bariyahnbe (q.v.); however it is more probable that the older form was -bir (Watson). 
\xv Wa: baygalbeh 
\xe 'only one man'
\xv Wa: yunahlabeh 
\xe 'only sleeping'
\xv Wa: yunahnybe 
\xe 'will only sleep'
\xv Wa: Yaburbeh dubay yehn.gala. 
\xe 'Only one woman is staying behind.'
\xv Wa: Galgahbu muna bidjangbeh gunu waybar. 
\xe 'Keep on chopping, there's only a little bit of wood.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu mala nyabay jugahnybe. 
\xe 'He will drink up all the water.'
\xv Wa: Ngali yehn.ganybeh wahngwenbibeh guhlbe. 
\xe 'We will stay just to work gold.'
\xv Wa: Guyir ngay mahnyi juruhmbilnyi, bahnybiny mala gumarbeh. 
\xe 'I'm frightened of leeches, but they only suck your blood.'
\xv Wa: Wulah nganhi mala wangah dugul-duguhl ngali-ngu yangahnybe 
\xe 'give me that dilly-bag of yours before we,g,' (and only then will we go)
\xv Wa: Muhwa gahnyu yan.gihbe-nguy. 
\xe 'Pick these up so we can go.' 
\xv Gd: Nganyah-bubeh male. 
\xe 'That is mine now.'
\xv Gd: bugalbeh 
\xe 'very good' (also used as greeting)
\xv Gd: gadjibeh 
\xe 'right here'
\xv Gd: Buruhrbe,g,nini. 
\xe 'only two did it'
\xv Gd: Badjiliwahlabeh guwang dagalbeh.
\xe 'It certainly is raining.'
\xv Gd: Yehni-beh nyule ngayban. 
\xe 'He went and so did I.'
\xv Wu:Calley: Baygal gale mahraganmanibe. 
\xe 'The man is initiated (initiate-made).'
\xv Wu:Calley: yagambe 
\xe 'no, not'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm -beh; Y:Holm:Curry,Logn; Y:Watsn â€“bir;

\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wu:C alley be

\lx berang
\ps adjective 
\de little
\re little
\do 
\sf
\co Can be reduplicated bera-berang, same in We,Wu; gender suffixes in Wu: m -gay, f -ahgan, arb -ah; Smy small, little, piece of; m beranggali, beranggay, f berangahgan, arb berangah. Bidjang in other dialects. Bera-berang nyugan 'small hill'; berang ngumbiny 'hut' (small house). 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk We:Gordn small; Wu:Calley; Wa:Sc:Tabulm:Hargrv bel-rung; Cas:Smy berang, beranga:gan, berangah; 
\rfr
\rfo Cop:Hargrv beriberong nugun small hill, berongumbi 'hut'

\lx bidjang
\ps adjective 
\de small, little, some
\re small ; little ; some
\do 
\sf
\co bidjanggay 'small, some' Wa; with -nyi bidjangganyi can contract to bidjang ganyi Wa; Gd gender suffixes; f -gali, m -galang, arb -ahn, neut -gay, pl -gam; cf, berang We, Wu, Cop, Gn. 
\xv Gd: Maliyu mahmidjargandu wulani malahni bidjangganyi guruhm. 
\xe 'The mother gave the baby some milk.'
\xv Gd: Gala mani jehr galangu burbi bidjanggaywahr. 
\xe 'A kangaroo is big but a koala is small. (The kangaroo is bigger than the koala).'
\xv Gd: bidjanggalang, bidjanggali baygal 
\xe 'small man'

\lx bidjang (Wi), biyang (M, Ng)
\ps noun
\de father
\re father
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Holmer lists as grandfather, but probably father, as in other dialects; also bidjangbihny, bidjangdjar, pl bidjanggir (Wa). Bj:Holm bidjang, cf, Kattang biyang 'father'.

\xe 'This father is standing here.'
\xv Wa: Gahny bidjangdjar jajahnala gadji. 
\xe 'These fathers are standing here.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: nganyah bidjang 
\xe 'my grandfather' 
\xv M: Ngayu juwan ginahny jabugay biyanggay ngeringgay. 
\xe 'I will make spears for both the boy and the father.' 
\rfg M:Liv bia ng gai for the father; - nom, -go e,g, -ge acc, -ga gen, -gai dat, -bano abl; M:Sc:Brunswk bienny father; Ng:Curr:Bray beung father

\lx bidjang, bidjanggalang
\ps noun
\de little, a part, small
\re little ; part, a ; small
\do 
\sf
\co Allen lists bidjungann (probably bidjangahn) as 'sapling' (probably arboreal form of bidjang 'small'); Livingstone defines as 'small, like a point', and Watson lists bidjanggalang as 'least, smallest', bidjanggay as 'less, smaller'; bidjanggalang 'small' (Y:Holm:Fogty), bidjanggali 'small' (Y:Holm:Logn); Livingstone has gender forms, probably bidjangbin (masc.), bidjangahgan (fem.), bidjanggalang (animals and places), bidjangnahn (things). 
\xv Y:Hanln: gundur bidjanggalang 
\xe 'mouse' (i.e. Small rat)
\xv Y:Holm:Monsl: jehng bidjang 
\xe 'little mouth'
\xv Y:Holm:Long: bidjang(galang) jabu 
\xe 'little boy'
\xv Bj:Coraki:Sc: bidjangi dugan 
\xe 'small hill'
\xv Bj:Coraki:Sc: bidjangi buyuhl 
\xe 'knob or hillock' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm bidjang little; Y:Holm:Monsl,Long,GFogty; Y:Allen bijung part (= little), bijÃ_ng little adj & adv, bijungann sapling; Y:Watsn bi'djÃ_ng; sm Y:Watsn bi'djing part, small portion M:Liv bijung, bijung-bin(m), bijung-na-gun (f), bijung-gÃ¥lung (n), bijung-nan (arb.);M:Evans pidjung little; AT:Prior bigaut little; AT:LandsWh peechanggullan; AT:O'Conn bitcha-gul-ung; GC:Nerang:Fowlr bijungalung; Tw:Curr:Bray pidjung; Y:Hanln beejungalung little, small, less, bijungalung, beejungalung less; Y:Hanln bijoon little, sharpened ; M:Sc:Brunswk pidjung little; Ng:Curr:Bray pidjung little
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl bidjang(galang); Bj:Holm:Fe,g, bidjanggalang small; Wi:Curr:Lism beechang little; Wi:Curr:Richmd bidung little; Bj:Sc:Coraki betung little; Bj:Sc:Coraki pjung dujan ship (little mountain Sha); Bj:Sc:Coraki bethungidugan small hill, bethungibooyal nob [sic] or hillock; Ny:Sc:Ballina5/1903 pidung little; Ny:Curr:Ballina biguong little 
\rfk Wa:Crowl, Wu:Calley bidjunggai little thing (of children and anything else?)
\rfr Ga:Smy bidjangalang small; Gn:Mathew bityunggalung thin

\lx -bihny
\ps suffix 
\de place where something is or happens
\re place where something is or happens
\do 
\sf
\co Place characterised by the activity of a verb stem or the quality of a noun stem; Gd: place, affair, place of, used mainly with nominalised verbs and derived nouns. 
\xv Gd: ngahribihny
\xe 'place where children are playing'
\xv Gd: wahngbiny
\xe 'work-site'
\xv Gd: waguhybiny
\xe 'place of vines'
\xv Gd: jalibihny
\xe 'place with a lot of trees'
\xv Gd: nyabaybihny
\xe 'place with a lot of water'
\xv Gd: yiralingahbiny
\xe 'English' (place where there's a lot belonging to the whiteman)
\xv Gd: ngalingahbiny
\xe 'Bundjalung' (place with lots of ours)
\xv Gd:Geyt: Mindjihbiny bumilehn nyulangam. 
\xe 'They were fighting over that time he laughed (nastily).'

\rfk Wa:Crowl

\do2 ti

\xe 'I fell out of the tree.'

\xe 'It's raining out of that cloud.'

\xe 'The sun is setting.'

\xe 'frost formed here on the,g,ass.'
\xv Cas: Ngay behn gawundjanu. 
\xe 'I fell out of the tree.'
\xv Cas: Ngay numbuhngginybu bulahbu gibam behni. 
\xe 'I shall return (when) two moons have fallen.'

\lx bin.gihng
\ps noun
\de river turtle ; generic turtle (Gd)
\re river turtle ; turtle, river ; turtle (generic) (Gd)
\do fsh
\do 
\sf
\co Plural bin.gihng Wa; see also bin.giny, binggihng. 
\xv Wa: Mala bin.gihng birah waybara. 
\xe 'Throw the turtle onto the fire.'
\xv Wa: Yuh mahny nyamul bahn.gany. 
\xe 'Later the baby (turtles) will hatch out.'
\xv Wa: Wahlu namahla bin.gihng jahnanyun mala nyabay. 
\xe 'You can catch turtles in still water.'
\xv Wa: Mahnyulu bin.gihnggu balbangmahla munduyu guygum. 
\xe 'The turtles flatten the sand with their stomachs.'
\xv Wa: Gilah ngay ngalawalehny bin.gihng. 
\xe 'I will go turtle hunting there.'
\xv Wa: Bin.gihng mala gan.galehn madji gawalungga. 
\xe 'The turtle has finished (laying e,g,) out there now.'
\xv Wa: Mala bin.gihng numbuhnggila nyabaygu. 
\xe 'The turtle is going back to the water.' 
\rfg Y:Kombum-CWillms binkihng 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wu:Calley b ? ng ? ng; Cas:Smy bin.ging turtle (river), tortoise; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gn:Mathew pin-gee,g, Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce bingin turtle; 
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\do fsh

\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx bira-
\ps verb transitive 
\de throw away, throw, fly away, spit out or throw something whether or not a target is actually aimed at or hit
\re throw away ; throw ; fly away ; spit out or throw something whether or not a target is actually aimed at or hit
\do 
\sf
\co Idiomatic uses: badjay bira-, jahny bira- 'to answer, retort', buhwi bira- 'to breathe' (literally 'eject breath'), ganyahl bira- 'go fishing' (literally 'throw fishing line'); throw, fly away, fish (throw line); 'cast through' (M:Liv). Wa; also 'to answer' Gd; badjay bira- 'to answer', buwi bira- 'to breathe', jahny bira- 'to retort', ngahny bira- 'to yawn', guyuhng bira- 'to toss up into the air' (swing throw) Gd; bira, birala, birani 'throw' (Y:Holm); 'cast through' (M:Liv); bihra 'throw'?, cf yaruh-; cf, jahdjam bira-/bura- 'give birth', jalum bira- 'to fish'. See also bawa-, dalba-, naba- and for sense 'fly', see also yaruh-, yaruhli-. 
\xv Wa: Mala nyahngandu birani waybara. 
\xe 'She threw it into the fire.'
\xv Wa: Birah mala darigan. 
\xe 'Throw the bones away.'
\xv Wa: Birahny ngadju gahny jehngga. 
\xe 'I'll spit them out of my mouth.'
\xv Wa: Ngabarmah wahlu malahni jahny birah. 
\xe 'Answer him quickly.' 
\xv Gd:Geyt?: Mala buhwi biralehlabu. 
\xe 'He's still breathing.'
\xv Gd:Geyt?: Birah mala ganyahl. 
\xe 'Go fishing!' 'Throw a fishing line.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gila baygal biralehla. 
\xe 'There is a man fishing.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Biralehla-bar-nguy 
\xe 'while (I) am fishing'
\xv Bj:Holm: Guway ngali yanah biralihgu jalumgu. 
\xe 'Come, we will go (or let's go) fishing'
\xv Bj:Holm: biraliyah, biraliyahn, biralinyun (the latter plural) 
\xe 'fishing' 
\xv M: Ngayu bumani nganduhrunibyu, nganduhr birani. 
\xe 'I killed a number (of ducks and white cockatoos), and some flew away.'
\xv M: biriyahlen ngaring 
\xe 'crossed over'
\xv M: Ngayu bumani nganduhrunibyu, nganduhr birani. 
\xe 'I killed a number (of ducks and white cockatoos), and some flew away.'
\xv M: biryahlen ngaring 
\xe 'crossed over'

\xe 'They threw a spear but didn't hit (it).'

\xe 'Birds are flying.' 
\rfg M:Liv birra, berranne; birre; birryalen ganig ; Y:Sha:Culhm bira- throw, bihra fly-; Y:Allen pr bira, p birani, pf biranian, f birala throw; Y:Watsn bi'ra; bir'anÃ®; bir'anian; bir'Ã¢la throw; M:Liv birra, berranne, birralen ngarring fly away; 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g,,Turnbl bira-, prog. Biralila, biraligu, biralija, biralijan, biralinyun; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn biralehla throwing; Cas:Smy bir-a, bira:, bira:ni, biralen, biralela throw, fish;

\lx birihn (berin?)
\ps locative 
\de south, south people
\re south ; south people
\do1 loc
\do2 pp
\sf
\co cf, gugin 'the north, the north people', also see ngawgay. Richmond River Aborigines call the Clarence River 'berrin' and the Tweed 'kokin'; Tweed R. People call the Richmond 'berrin' and the Logan 'kokin'; also ngawgay Y:Allen,Yw.
\xv M: birinbah 
\xe 'to the south'
\rfg Y:Allen ngaugai; Y:Watsn ngau'gai; pir'in south; M:Liv berrin, berrinba to the south; Ng:Gresty bireen no meaning given; Y:Hanln pireen south
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx birihn (berin?)
\ps locative 
\de south, south people, Birihn tribe,g,oup (Holmer)
\re south ; south people ; Birihn tribe,g,oup (Holmer)
\do1 loc
\do2 pp
\sf
\co cf, gugin 'the north, the north people'. Richmond River Aborigines call the Clarence River berrin and the Tweed kokin; Tweed R. people call the Richmond berrin and the Logan kokin birinbah 'to the south'; Turnbull almost certainly has given wrong meanings; L Wilson can use Biri(h)n Banydjalang for the Coraki dialect, contrasting with Widjebal Banydjalang, the Lismore,g,oup. 
\xv Bj:Holm:Turnbl: janangmahm dubajihn birihn 
\xe 'boys and girls together'
\xv Bj:Holm:Turnbl: yirali banijargan birihnbu 
\xe 'the white man and his wife together' 
\rfg M:Liv berrin, berrinba to the south 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl biri:nj a few, two or three. Biri:n Turnbl. Biri:nbu Fe,g, together; Bj:Holm:Fergn,Turnbl biri:n Biri:n tribe/group; 
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx bu
\ps suffix

\do 
\sf
\co No certain meaning; however is regarded as a mild intensifier in Gd.

\xe 'two'

\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx bu
\ps suffix 
\de again, now, still (Gd)
\re again (Gd) ; now (Gd) ; still (Gd)
\do 
\sf
\co General word suffix - can occur on different types of words, with meanings again, now, still (with verbs); merely, only (other word classes); reflexive (pronouns); 'at the time of .. Still' (following a location suffix); along (some nouns, + vb. Of motion); Wa: along, back, reflexive; various functions: on nouns 'along' or occasionally instrument, on pronouns marks object of a reflexive verb, with motion verbs 'back', with other verbs 'again'; Cas: again, back on self; Holmer says again, back, just, self, own. 
\xv Bj: Yan.giwahnybu bayahny. 
\xe '(He) will come again today.'
\xv Bj: Nyula yan.giwanibu. 
\xe 'He came back.' 
\xv Bj: mabehrbu 
\xe 'they all'
\xv Bj: munahbu 
\xe 'just there'
\xv Bj: nyan.ganabu 
\xe 'her own'
\xv Bj: nyulangabu 
\xe 'his own' 
\xv Gd: Wahlu nganyah banamgirbu. 
\xe 'you are merely my younger brother'
\xv Gd: Gale mugim dumunybu. 
\xe 'This axe is blunt again.'
\xv Gd: ngalibah-djambebu 
\xe 'before our time'
\xv Gd: Nyulebu gawgani junguru. 
\xe 'He cut himself with a knife.'
\xv Gd: Balunbu yehni nyule. 
\xe 'He went along the creek.'
\xv Gd: Yarbilehnbu jahdjam. 
\xe 'The child sang again.'
\xv Gd: Male yiririhny miringbungan. 
\xe 'That bird is still alive, poor thing.'
\xv Wa: Yehni mala balunbu.
\xe 'He went along the river.'
\xv Wa: Yanah ngali Burigalingah jinangbu. 
\xe 'Let's go to Pretty Gully on foot.'
\xv Wa: Ngay galgalehn nganyibu. 
\xe 'I cut myself.'
\xv Wa: Mahny bulahbu dabahy yingalehla nyulamangibu. 
\xe 'Those two dogs are biting each other.'
\xv Wa: Ngay galgalehn nganyibu. 
\xe 'I cut myself.'
\xv Wa: Mahny bulahbu dabahy yingalehla nyulamangibu. 
\xe 'Those two dogs are biting each other.' 
\xv Wa: Ngali yangahnybu Burigalingah. 
\xe 'We'll go back to Pretty Gully.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu bumgahlabu nyahngani. 
\xe 'He's hitting her again.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju yagambeh jahnybu. 
\xe 'I won't eat any more. '
\xv Wa: Mala yunahlabu. 
\xe 'He's still sleeping.'
\xv Cas: Nganyibu banggilimaleny. 
\xe 'I'll shoot myself.'
\xv Cas: Nyule nyulangibu banggilimalehny. 
\xe 'He will shoot himself.'
\xv Cas: Nyule behnbu. 
\xe 'He fell down again.
\xv Cas: Ngadju gawanibu bilahr. 
\xe 'I broke my spear again.'
\xv Cas: Ngadjubu nyangani. 
\xe 'I myself did it.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g,,Turnbl bu, mabir bu, muna bu, etc,;
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy -bu
\rfr Gd:Geyt;
\rfo
\dt 11/Apr/2015

\lx budjarbiny, budjarbin(y)

\re flower
\do pl
\do 
\sf
\co cf, budjur 'soft' Wa, budjar 'love' Gd; JThomas spelling suggests an older form could have been bundjarbiny, although it is also possible oo was read as on; flower (daisy), green; ' sweet/ soft' + -bin(y). See also gunang budjarbiny 'small intestines' (Y:Allen, Y:Watsn).

\xe 'Pick that flower.'

\lx buga-
\ps verb transitive 
\de poke, peck, sting, stab, spear, write
\re poke ; peck ; sting ; stab ; spear ; write
\do 
\sf
\co i.e. To poke with a sharp object, whether or not action involves piercing, can also refer to pain caused by poking; can be reduplicated (Wa); poke, pierce, write', gim buga- 'to wander around aimlessly' (poke around) Gd; pierce, poke, spear; possibly bawa- in Tw:Curr:Bray; pierce, poke. 
\xv Wa: Maliyu wurguluhmbu bugani malahni baygalni munah gabuny maliyu gahnganah. 
\xe 'The magpie pecked the man because he stole its e,g,.'
\xv Wa: Bugani nganyi. 
\xe 'I got stung as I was climbing down from the tree.'

\xe 'Now I'll spear him.

\lx bugal
\ps adjective 
\de,g,od, pleasant, beautiful, nice, quiet
\re,g,od ; pleasant ; beautiful ; nice ; quiet
\do 
\sf
\co good or pleasant; sometimes bugwal; good, well; possibly bawgal in Y:Allen, Y:Watsn and older sources, see bawgal; also means 'well' (Yw); Y:Watsn states 'at Tweed Heads bunyarra'; cf, banyar, banyahr. Bugalwen.gahla / bugalun.gahla / bugaln.gahla 'is good' Wa; bugalma- 'to do well, do carefully' Gd; does not take,g,nder suffixes (Wu:Calley). 
\xv Wa: Mala dabahy bugal namalihgu mahny mani. 
\xe 'That dog is good at catching kangaroos.'
\xv Wa: Bugalmah mala guybah bulang. 
\xe 'Cook the meat properly.'
\xv Cas: Nyanggur male bugal jabihgu? 
\xe 'Is that alright to eat?'
\xv Wa: Gale bugaldjang malahnyi. 
\xe 'This is better that that.'
\xv Gd: Mahnyu bugalngehn baygal. 
\xe 'They are,g,od men.'
\xv Gd: Bugal-wanah nguy ngali gunugahl. 
\xe 'From now on let us be,g,od!'
\xv Y:Holm: Bugal nyula mali. 
\xe 'That fellow is good.' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bugal mamali bargan. 
\xe 'That boomerang is new.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Bugal mala jugalihgu. 
\xe 'That's good to drink'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: bugalah 
\xe 'in a good place'. 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm bugal; Y:Holm; Y:Allen good, well baugull, comparative baugull-gulle, superlative baugull-bungil; Y:Watsn baugul, bau'gÃ_l good, well; AT:O'Conn bowgal 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl bugal good; Bj:TMcD:Morgn bugal; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, bugal, bugala good; Bj:Sc:Coraki. Bj:Sc:Coraki5/1903 bogal good or pleasant; Wi:Curr:Richmd boogol good; Ny:Sc:Ballina5/1903 bowwall good. Bowrall pleasant; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn good; Wu:Calley bogal; Wa:Sc:Tabulm:Hargrv bo-well good, boo-well pleasant; Cas:Smy bogol good, bogoldjan;g 
\rfr Gd:Geyt good, pleasant, beautiful, nice; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng booal; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce bowgul good; Gn:Mathew bokal, bogal good, quiet; 
\rfo

\lx buhmbi-
\ps verb transitive 
\de blow, smoke, blow something, including cigarettes (Wa)
\re blow ; smoke ; blow something (including cigarettes Wa)
\do 
\sf
\co cf, buhy(i)/buwi 'breath' Gd; Smythe also to breathe. 
\xv Wa: Ngadju mala buhmbiny waybar.
\xe 'I'll blow the fire'
\xv Wa: Wurahng mahnyu malahya jaliya buhmbila mala ngahnydja. 
\xe 'The leaves high in the tree are blowing.'
\xv Wa: Wanah mahny buhmbi. 
\xe 'Don't smoke (cigarettes).'
\xv Cas: Ngay buhmbilehny. 
\xe 'I'll blow, I'll have a smoke.'
\xv Cas: Nganyi wehlu wulayi buhmbigi? 
\xe 'Can you give me something to smoke?'
\xv Cas: Malewahr buwiyan buhmbilehna burugahrgu guwang badjilehny.
\xe 'If this wind blows towards the sea it will blow up rain.'
\xv Cas: Ngay buhmbilehla. 
\xe 'I am breathing.'
\xv Cas: Ngay buhmbilelha juhm. 
\xe 'I smoke.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn bumbilehla 'blowing' (of wind) ; Cas:Smy bu:mb-i, bu:mbilenj, bu:mbigi, bu:mbile:na, bu:mbilela; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\do 
\sf

\xe 'pulling'

\lx buhyi, buhyi-an.ga-
\ps verb
\de breathe, pull, tire 
\re breathe ; pull ; tire 
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co rest, breath or knocked up(?) (Yw); breath (Y:Hanln); possibly buhwi or buhyi. GC:Meston lists as 'lung'. See also buhyi-.

\xe 'He talks and talks and never gets tired.'

\xe 'I got tired.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Buhyi jarang nganyah bar(a)galehn. 
\xe 'I'm tired, my legs (are) sore.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wahlu buhyiyehn. 
\xe 'You had a long spell.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm breathe, pull, tire; Y:Watsn bÃ»-Ã®; GC:Meston booee lung; Y:Hanln booee, boo-i-ee

\re you (plural)
\do 
\sf

\xe 'You eat it.'

\xe 'That house is yours.'

\lx bulah
\ps adjective
\de two
\re two
\do 
\sf
\co also bulabu, bularu (Y:Holm); bulayli and bulayli-gan sometimes used for dual personal pronouns (M:Liv); also 'you two' in Gn; bulayli and bulayili-gun sometimes used for dual personal pronouns (M:Liv). 
\xv Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray: bula mibiny 
\xe 'two blacks.'
\xv M: bulahndin 
\xe 'halves'
\xv M: bulahnday(gan) 
\xe 'twins'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: nybulah(be) mibiny, bularu baygal 
\xe 'two blacks'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: bulabu dubay, bularu dubay 
\xe 'the two girls or women'
\xv Y:Holm: bulabu ngagam(i), ngagam bularu 
\xe 'the two dogs'. 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm bulah; Y:Holm:Logn bula; Y:Allen bulÃ¡; Y:Watsn bÃ»la; M:Liv bula, bulai; bulairy (m), bulairi-gun (f), bula(n), bula-na (adj); bula-nden halves; bula-n-dai(gun) twins; M:Evans bulla; AT:Prior bulabe; AT:LandsWh budla; AT:O'Conn boolaroo; Tw:Curr:Bray bulla; GC:Nerang:Fowlr boolara ; 
\rfb Wi:Curr:Lism bulah
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx bulah-bulah
\ps adverb

\re together
\do 
\sf

\lx bumili-
\ps verb
\de fight, kill
\re fight ; kill
\do 
\sf
\co bumilehla 'fighting, killing'; from bum-; takes object, but has antipassive/reflexive suf -li; Cas to fight, reciprocal form of bum- 'kill'; fight, murder; = bum(a)- + -li; Y:Holm has bumali- as variant of bumili-; note GC:Coomera:Sc suggests bumina-; fight together; see buma- (buma- + -li). 
\xv Wa: Mahny baling-balihng bumilehla bayahny.
\xe 'The young men today fight among themselves.'
\xv Cas: Gahny baygal bumilehlabe.
\xe 'These men are fighting.'
\xv Y:Holm: Wana bumili (Wanah bumileh). 
\xe 'Don't fight.'
\xv Y:Holm: Bula bumilila (Bulah bumilehla). 
\xe 'The two are fighting.' 
\xv Y:Holm: Bumilir bayahny 
\xe '(I) will fight right now.'
\xv Ng:Bray: bumalehn.gi 
\xe 'want to fight'
\xv Ng:Sc:Cudgn: bumalehla 
\xe 'fighting.'
\rfg Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray boomale,g,e fight; Y:Holm:Logn; Y:Allen fight pr bumilun, p bumilen, pf bumilian, f bumileila; Y:Watsn bum'ilen; bum'ilen; bum'ilian; bum'ilÃª'la; GC:Coomera:Sc boomenallah murder
\rfb Bj:Sc:Coraki; bumalehla gawan 'fight or battle'; Bj:Holm bumili-; Bj:Sc:Coraki boomelairda cowan fight or battle; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wu:Calley bum ? l ? ; Cas:Smy bumil-e, bu:milelabe; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gn:Mathew bamilela to fight ; 
\rfo

\lx bum-, buma-, bumga-, bumbi-
\ps verb transitive 
\de hit, strike, kill, kill by fighting, beat, destroy
\re hit ; strike ; kill ; kill by fighting ; beat ; destroy
\do 
\sf
\co irreg.; vt kill, flog, thrash, bash; Wa: to hit with the hand, of something held in the hand, kill, punch, affect (of weather); fight, kill by fighting, kill, hit, beat, destroy, irreg.; bumali-/bumili- 'fight (together)', buma-, bumbe- 'fight, kill'; bumi 'a very severe hit' (from buma-) (Y:Hanln). Gn list shows bami-, q.v.; imp. Bumah, imm bumgahyn, prog bumile, complete bumani; hit bumgahnye; cf,  Kattang bungga-; Holmer also lists bungga-. 
\xv Cas: Nyang nyulamanggu wulimani bumilehnini? 
\xe 'Have they found the murderer?'
\xv Cas: Maleyu bumani baygalni. 
\xe 'He killed the man.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju nyulagay bilahrmani bumbih nyulayu ngadjah mahni.
\xe 'I made him a spear so he would kill a kangaroo for me.'
\xv Gd: Wanah nganyi bumah wahlu. 
\xe 'Don't kill me!'
\xv M:Liv: Bumahny ngayu wanyi marandanggu. 
\xe 'I will beat you with a club.'
\xv Y:Holm: bumgala 
\xe 'hitting' = bayila
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bumilehla ngagam. 
\xe 'Dogs are fighting.' 
\xv Td:Bray: Ngayu bumgahla ngubu. 
\xe 'I will kill him tomorrow.' 
\xv Bj: Gala baygalu bumani gurumani ngubu warbu.
\xe 'The man killed a kangaroo yesterday.'
\xv Bj: Galahyu wulbani nganyi bumani. 
\xe 'He hit me.'
\xv Bj: Bumah galahni. 
\xe 'Hit him!'
\xv Bj: bumgahnye wanyi jaliya 
\xe 'to hit you with a stick'
\xv Bj: bumile 
\xe 'fight!'(?)
\xv Bj: Galahyu wulbani nganyi bumani. 
\xe 'He hit me.'
\xv Bj: Bumah galahni.
\xe 'Hit him!' (Turnbl)
\xv Bj: bumani malahni 
\xe 'killed him'
\xv Bj: ganar bumilehn 
\xe 'fought a tribal war'
\xv Bj: Gahmu buruhr bumilehla (or) Buruhr (ma)mahnyu bumilehla. 
\xe 'These/those two are fighting.'
\xv Bj: juwandu bumgahny
\xe 'will spear (him/it)'
\xv Bj: Bumgahny ngay wanyi wambaru. 
\xe 'I will hit you with a stick.'
\xv M: bumahla/bumalehla 
\xe 'hitting'
\xv Bj:TMcD:Morgn: bumgahla 
\xe 'fighting'. 
\rfg Y:Allen pr buma, p bumani, pf bumian, f bumgala kill; Y:Watsn buma, bum'a; bum'anÃ®; bum'ian; bum'gÃ¢la fight, kill; Y:Watsn bumalen; bumalen; bumalian; bumalÃªla fight; bum'a, bum'bÃª fight, kill; M:Liv vt buman will beat; buma beat; Y:Beaudst:police boongarla; Y:Beaudst:Sc boomgarla; M:Cudgn:Sc boomelala fight; Tw:Curr:Bray bÃ´Ã´mar strike, bÃ´Ã´marnee,g,ve a beating, pumgarlo will kill; Y:Hanln boonmah kill ; M:Liv vt buman will beat; buma beat; Ng:Curr:Bray strike bÃ´Ã´mar, give a beating bÃ´Ã´marnee
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl buma; Bj:TMcD:Morgn buma hit, bumala/bumalela hitting, bumgala fighting; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, buma-, term. Bumani, r.-r. term bumilin Turnbl, progr. Bumilila, imm. Bumgany; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, bumga- , imm. Bumgany; Bj:Holm bungga- to hit; 
\rfk Cas:Smy bum-a, bumilÃ©nini, bumani, bumbi:; Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\lx -bur
\ps suffix 
\de little, a little one
\re little ; little one
\do 
\sf
\co e,g, dugunbur 'little hillock' from dugun 'hill, elevation.'; tiny, diminutive, third order suffix; change of vowel length is often associated with -bur, either of the preceding syllable or in the suffix itself. 
\xv Gd: ngagambur 
\xe 'little dog'
\xv Gd: bargahn-bur 
\xe 'toy boomerang'
\xv Gd: buhn-buny-buhr 
\xe 'tiny whirlwind (coil-type-diminutive)
\xv Gd: nangany-galiganbur 
\xe 'little,g,rl fond of food.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm â€“bur ; 
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx bura-
\ps verb transitive 
\de pull out, take out, take off, peel, pull down, release, undo or skin (something), remove, remove from inside or outside something
\re pull out ; take out ; take off ; peel ; pull down ; release ; undo or skin (something) ; remove ; remove from inside or outside something 
\do 
\sf
\co jim bura- 'to be brief' (remove end) Gd; cf, jahdjam bura- 'give birth' (probably jahdjam bira-, literally 'throw child'). 
\xv Wa: Mahny warah burah munduya.
\xe 'Take the intestines out of the stomach.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu buradjahn munah nyangbu banmanyun. 
\xe 'He used to take his clothes off.'
\xv Wa: Yalany mala wanah burah. 
\xe 'Don't stick out your tongue.'
\xv Wa: Bagul mala burah gadji yehnbi ngay.
\xe 'Pull off the bark so I can sit here.'
\xv Wa: Gahba ngali yulany burani maniya. 
\xe 'We skinned that kangaroo.'
\xv Cas: Burahga male. 
\xe 'Take that out (please).'
\xv Cas: Yagambe,g,djihny buralehn. 
\xe 'The red paint was not taken off, removed.'
\xv Cas: Ngaywar balahn.gahny darigan buralehny.
\xe 'I'll die and my bones will be stripped.'
\xv Cas: Buralehn gile buwihni nyulayu.
\xe 'He loosened it and pulled it out.'
\xv M: Burah jinang bandahnda. 
\xe 'Pull the handle out of the tomahawk.'
\xv M: Burah munu juwan baygalbaya. 
\xe 'Pull that spear out of the man.'
\xv M: Burah jin ngayabaya mihya. 
\xe 'Take the speck out of my eye.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g, Burah! 
\xe 'Take it (out of the mouth)!'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Burah jehngu. 
\xe 'Take it out of the mouth.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: jurbihl burani 
\xe 'opened the cave' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu yulany burani
\xe ...'I skinned'... 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm to skin (something); Y:Allen pr bora, p borani, pf borian, f borala pull out; Y:Allen pr burâ, p burani, pf buralian, f buraleila undo; Y:Watsn bu’ra; bur’anî; bur’alian; bur’alêîla undo; M:Liv bura vt take out, pull out
\rfb Bj:Holm bura-, imp. Bura (Fe,g,), term. Burani (Turnb;); 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy bur-a, bura:ga, buralen, buralenj; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx buram
\ps locative 
\de out of way, behind, outside, back, rear
\re out of way ; behind ; outside ; back ; rear
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Must take same case marking as the noun it qualifies Wa; 'rear, back of object' Gd; same in Gn dialect (Warwick area); buram(bih) in Y:Sha:Culhm probably shows past tense locative case, cf buramba in Gn locative. 
\xv Wa: Buramu jalingu 
\xe 'from behind the tree'
\xv Wa: Ganngah manyihni yarbilehla bagarah burambah nguhmbinydjah. 
\xe 'Listen to those singing behind the house out there (and who I haven't seen yet).'
\xv Cas: Guyahny jalehla wurahng buramba ngumbinydjah. 
\xe 'The possum is eating leaves behind the house.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: burambi jahnalah 
\xe 'standing at the back' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm buram; Y:Allen burum; Y:Watsn bu'rum 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy buram(ba) ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gn:Mathew buramba outside (prob. Has loc case (Sharpe) ; 
\rfo

\lx burgar
\ps noun
\de beach, sea
\re beach ; sea
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co burgal also recorded in Y:Sha:Culhm; bunbar also (Y:Allen); M:Evans and M:Cudgn:Sc also gives meaning 'bay'; other form burugar, q.v. 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm burgar (burgal) ocean; Y:Allen bunburra; Y:Watsn bun'bÃ_rra, borru'gura beach; Mur:AndFr burrogooro the sea beach; Mur:Hargrv boora gurra sea;M:Evans boorogurah sea, a bay; M:Cudgn:Sc boorogurah sea, a bay; GC:Coomera:police brokera; Y:Hanln borroogurra ocean beach, booroogurra, booroogra seaside
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\do ne
\do

\lx burur
\ps adjective
\de two
\re two
\do 
\sf
\co Takes case suffixes, e,g, buruhru (erg.), buruhrgu (allative) (used in sense 'two together'), yaburni buruhrni (acc.) in sense 'each other'. 
\xv Bj:Holm: buruhrbu jambay 
\xe 'two hands' (also used for 'ten')
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngali buruhr yehn.galah 
\xe 'we two are sitting'
\xv Bj:Holm: buruhrgu 
\xe 'together'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gahmu buruhr bumilehla (or) Buruhr (ma)mahnyu bumilehla 
\xe 'These/those two are fighting.' 
\xv Wi:Curr:Richmd, Ny:Curr:Ballina: buruhr baygal
\xe 'two Aborigines.' 
\rfg
\rfb Ny:Sha:DCook burur; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, burur, burur bu. Bururgu; Wi:Curr:Richmd booroora baygul 2 Blacks; Bj:Sc:Coraki. Bj:Sc:Coraki5/1903 burura two; Ny:Curr:Ballina barroro bygle 2 Blacks, barroro boelly 
\rfk 
\rfr

\lx dagal
\ps adverb
\de nearly, almost
\re nearly ; almost
\do 
\sf
\co implies state or action of sentence was nearly attained but not quite realised; cf, baginy(dja) - there is no apparent difference in these in use. 
\xv Wa: Dagal nganyi bumani ngadjangbinydju bargandu. 
\xe 'Grandfather nearly hit me with a boomerang.' (ie he threw it, but missed);
\xv Gd: Dagal nganyi nabani gilang bunini. 
\xe '(The log) almost killed me, killed me thoroughly.'
\xv Gd: Yabur jahdjam dagal behn. 
\xe 'One child almost fell.' 
\rfg Y:Allen duggull nearly; Y:Watsn duggel 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy dagal almost; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt almost; 
\rfo

\lx dagargan, dawargan

\lx dagay
\ps noun
\de corpse, European, white man, dead, ghost of dead Aboriginal man, spirit, body or skeleton of man
\re corpse ; European ; white man ; man, white ; dead ; ghost of dead Aboriginal man ; spirit ; body or skeleton of man
\do1 pp
\do2 lg
\do3 bp
\sf
\co Plural dagay-bihny Wa; dead, dead Aboriginal man (corpse, ghost?), older meaning but now used most commonly for 'white man'; cf dagaray; cf, wagahy; dagay believed to be white and harmful, hence 'white man.'; and cf, dawaragun 'dead woman', dagari 'white man', garabi 'white working man'; dagayma- 'kill' (M:Liv) ); Ng also gives meaning 'death'; Y:Watsn also gives jagay, and states 'lit. A black man's ghost, Y:Watsn says 'The first white man seen by the Aborigines was believed by them to be a ghost, and this word became commonly used by them to denote a white man.' Listed as 'stranger' by Gresty (Ngr). See also dagayu. 
\xv Cas: Dagay-gay ngali ngahrin. 
\xe 'We danced for the Europeans.'
\xv Cas: Jehny galahna dagaynyah bayahny ngali duwanahna. 
\xe 'The mouth of the corpse we buried today.'
\xv Cas: Nyaligur gale buwiyan dagay? 
\xe 'When will this wind die (be dead)?'
\xv Cas: Bumgahnybe nganyi dagay wangahgal. 
\xe 'He will kill me dead because of you.'
\xv Y:Holm: dagaydjin 
\xe '(some) white people'
\xv M:Liv: Gili dagayehn. 
\xe 'He was dead.'
\xv M:Liv: Dagahanah! 
\xe 'May you die,g, to death!'
\xv M:Liv: Dagayan.gahny ngay. 
\xe 'I will kill myself/go to death.' 
\rfg Y:Allen dugai dead, duggai ghost (of native, see 'white man') ; Y:Watsn dug'ai or dja'gay, djugai ; Y:Sha:Culhm dagay; Y:Holm dagai white man, dagaidjin (some) white people; M:Liv dukkai, -bin (m.); touara-gun, dukkai-gun (f); -gin-gun, -gun ; -bin (arb.), dukkai dead, dukai- ma kill; Tw:Sc:Bray tooki a white man, tooki milbury white woman; Tw:Curr:Bray tuckki, tÌÈkki; GC:Meston tuggi death; Ngr:Gresty dukkai stranger; Ng:Cudgn:Sc tucki death or dead; Y:Hanln dokkai dead, white man ; Ng:Curr:Bray tÌÈkki, tuckki dead man, white man; Ng:Sc:TwHds tooki a white man; Ng:Sc:Cudgn tuki death or dead ; M:Liv dukkai, -bin (m); towara-gun, dukkai-gun (f); -gin-gun, -gun-bin (n); -, -bin (arb; M:Liv dukkai dead, dukai-ma kill ; AT:Curr:LandsWh daggie; AT:Curr:O'Conn tugi ; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl dagay white man ; Bj:TMcD dagay whiteman//ghost? ; Wi:Curr:Richmd tucki white man 
\rfk Cas:Smy dagÌ_i, dagÌ_igÌ_i, daganjah ; Wa:Crowl 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce durri white man

\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx dagayu, dagayiyu
\ps noun
\de white man
\re white man ; man, white
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co See dagay; this is possibly e,g,tive (transitive subject) form of dagay, and is a name for early white settlers in southern Qld. Watson states: 'applied when they were exploring in search of grazing country, the inflection '-iyu- indicates irregular movement, and the whole word means 'Travelling, or walkabout, white man'. Phonetically pronounced in English the word is jug-ai-ee-oo, spoken quickly, but has by white people been corrupted to jackaroo,' 
\rfg Y:Watsn dÌ_gai-Ì¨ÌÈ 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx dalibadjir
\ps noun
\de,g,od fishing ground
\re fishing ground, good
\do1 loc
\do2 ff
\sf
\co Possibly jalibadjir, and probably Tallebudgera (place name). Y:Hanln states: 'It was popularly understood that this name (Tallebudgera) meant 'good fishing', but this was not so, as the local dialect has 'punyarra' for 'good', and 'tchalIom', for fish. 'Budgery' - good is an importation from some N.S.W. Dialect (Sydney?). It was introduced by the early timber-getters and became current among the natives as a whiteman's word.' 
\rfg Y:Holm-aj dalabadjari; GC:Talleb:Sc tallebudgera; GC:Talleb:police tallebudgera; Y:Hanln maybree Tallebudgera 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx darigan
\ps noun
\de bone
\re bone
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Includes stinging bones in fins of catfish, also 'shell' listed in Wa, also 'lead, guide, landmark' (Mt Durigan named for this) (M:Fingl); bone, rib bone; Holmer also has jarigan, but this rejected by LWilson; before an r, Holmer says the initial j tends to a dental or interdental stop; e,g, jarigandu; Wi:Curr:Lism form could be dadjiru, but mostly Wi:Curr:Lism agrees with other lists; also lead, guide, landmark; Mt Durigan named for this (Fingal).
\xv Wa(?): Walmirah mala darigan 
\xe 'breastbone' (bone in the chest)
\xv Wa:(?)Galgahny mahnyulu darigandu djinang.
\xe 'You'll cut your feet on the bones.'
\xv Cas: Ngaywar balahn.gahny darigan buralehny. 
\xe 'I shall die and my bones will be stripped.' (that is, I shall die in the usual manner.)
\xv Bj:Sha:Turnbl: jarigan nyumba 
\xe 'show the bone (bone him)' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm darigan; Y:Allen tarregunn; Y:Watsn tar'regon, tar'regon; M:Sc derigun bone; M:Fingl Durigan; Ng:Cudgn:Sc bungun chargon bone; Ng:Sc:Cudgn bungun chargon bone ; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr terragun; Tw:Curr:Bray turragun; M:Fingl Durigan; Y:Hanln turragun ; M:Sc:Brunswk derigun bone; M:Fingl Durigan; Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray turragun bone;
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl darigan; Bj:Holm djarigan, e,g, djaringandu; Wi:Curr:Lism dutcheroo; Wi:Curr:Richmd derrigona; Bj:Sc:Coraki3/1903 dairegun, Bj:Sc:Coraki5/1903 duregan bone; Ny:Curr:Ballina dadigun; Ny:Sc:Ballina5/1903 durongong bone; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Cas:Smy darigan; AT:Curr:LandsWh durrigan; AT:Curr:O'Conn taregun;
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng derigun ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx -Di 
\ps suffix 
\de in, at, on , past locative case
\re in ; at ; on ; past locative case
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Final consonant assimilates to match final nasal on noun. Holmer noted that dj probably assimilates to match final nasal on word; Holmer assumed ngumbinydji was for ngumbiny di. 
\xv Y:Holm: balundi 
\xe 'on/at/in the river (in the past)'
\xv Y:Holm Duwani jagundi. 
\xe '(They) buried (them) in the,g,ound.'
\xv Y:Holm: wanani ngumbindji 
\xe 'left at home'
\xv Y:Holm: Ngaw yaruhlen gunggi balundi. 
\xe 'I swam in the (water in the) river.' 
\rfg Ydict â€“Di; Y:Holm:Logn
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx diman, jiman
\ps noun
\de camp, a group of ngumbiny or huts (Watsn)
\re camp (a group of ngumbiny or huts) (Watsn)
\do 
\sf
\co cf, ngumbi, ngumbiny, mimi. The form diman seems more widespread. AT:Curr:Prior gives waybar ('fire') for 'camp', as is found in southern dialects; the basic meaning of diman seems to be 'ashes', at least in other dialects. 
\xv Y:Allen: Nyule yan.gahla dimanba(h) ngubu. (neule yangala dimunnba mobo) 
\xe 'He will go to the camp to-morrow.' (ordering of words unimportant); 
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Jaburaba jalgany dimanda(h).
\xe 'One woman is at camp.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Allen dimunn; Y:Watsn dhi'mun camp (a group of ngumbin or huts); Mur:Sc:Hargrv dimin hut; Tw:Sc:Bray dimmon a house; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr dimmun; Tw:Curr:Bray demmon; GC:Coomera:police temmum; AT:Curr:LandsWh teemun; AT:Curr:Prior wybara; GC:Coomera:Sc camp temmun; Y:Hanln djimmun and kurrul a collection of huts, jimmun and other words, mi-mi 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx -dja 
\ps suffix 
\de own relation (singular)
\re relation, own (singular)
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co used with nouns specifying human kinship. 
\xv Gd: banidjar 
\xe 'own husband'
\xv Gd: nyule,g,h mahmangdjar 
\xe 'his own father'
\xv Gd: nganyah yirbungdjar 
\xe 'my own cousin.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx -dja 
\ps suffix 
\de past tense (new analysis Sharpe)
\re past tense (new analysis Sharpe)
\do 
\sf
\co listed as second hand information in Gd:Geyt, remote past in Wa:Crowl. 
\xv Gd: Nyule mani nabadjahn.
\xe 'He killed a wallaby (so I was told).'
\xv Gd: Nyulangam nyadjan jungun. 
\xe 'They saw a rain-cloud (so I was told).'
\xv Wa: yarbilidjahn munah dandaygambihn. 
\xe 'The old man used to sing'
\xv Wa: Yurginy-badjahn mahny
\xe 'Those (dingoes) used to be called "yurginy"
\rfg 
\rfb Wa:Crowl
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx -djahli
\ps suffix 
\de plural 
\re plural
\do 
\sf
\co For certain nouns specifying human kinship; a characteristic of a clan or tribe; some speakers use -djahli for any human statues noun, but this may be due to influence from another dialect. 
\xv Gd: baygaldjahli 
\xe 'men'
\xv Gd: bamaydjahli 
\xe 'plains people'
\xv Gd: manaldjahli 
\xe 'cooked (country) people (of the people of the Beaudesert area, said to be a hard-baked country, certainly much drier than the NSW side).' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx -djahng
\ps suffix 
\de very (implying intensity)
\re very (implying intensity)
\do 
\sf
\co on adjectives. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yalgan nguhndjang guybahla nganyi. 
\xe 'The sun is too hot for me.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gamahdjahng male. 
\xe 'That's too big.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: bidjanggalangdjang 
\xe 'too small.' 
\rfg Ydict -dhahng; Y:Watsn dhÃ_ng; Y:Hanln intensity, expressed by adding the termnal djong 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx -djahr
\ps suffix 
\de exactly like
\re exactly like ; like, exactly so
\do 
\sf
\co syntactic suffix.
\xv Gd: Gale malahdjar. 
\xe 'This one is exactly like that one.'
\xv Gd: Gahngalehny gaybe nyulangahdjar. 
\xe 'I will get another one exactly like his.'
\xv Gd: Jagun gunu nganyah wahngbinydjahr. 
\xe 'The country here is exactly like the place where I work.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\re very ; more
\do 
\sf
\co Ga variant of -djang.

\lx -djal 
\ps suffix 
\de with
\re with
\do 
\sf
\co 'dual comitative', i.e. A person with someone else. 
\xv Y:Holm: biyangdjal muyumdjal 
\xe 'father and son'
\xv Y:Holm: dubaydjal 
\xe '(with) a woman'. 
\rfg Ydict -dhal; Y:Holm:Log; 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx -djam, -jam
\ps suffix 
\de without or having no...
\re without ; having no...
\do 
\sf
\co can also occur on verb forms in northern dialects especially; yugam-djam emphatic negative; circumlocutions are more commonly used in Wa. 
\xv Gd: Gungdjam 
\xe 'without water'
\xv Gd: nyahbidjam 
\xe 'without seeing'
\xv Gd: nyuledjam 
\xe 'without him'
\xv Gd: Nyula dalahndjam. 
\xe 'He has no white ones.'
\xv Gd: ngalibahdjambebu 
\xe 'before our time.' 
\xv Wa: dirangdjam 
\xe 'having no teeth'
\xv Wa: dubaydjam 
\xe 'having no wife'
\xv Wa: Mala jahdjam guyir malahnyi dandaygambahnyi dirangdjambahnyi. 
\xe 'The child is frightened of the man with no teeth.' (contrast with Mala budjigehn jugalehla, yagambeh malahna yarany. 'The cat without any whiskers is drinking.')
\xv Wa: Mala budjigehn jugalehla, yagambeh malahna yarany.
\xe 'The cat without any whiskers is drinking.'
\xv Cas: magidjam 
\xe 'stre,g,hless, weak'
\xv Cas: janguydjam 
\xe 'anger-less, amiable, good-tempered.'
\xv M:Liv: Yili ngagam-djam baygal? 
\xe 'Where is the man without a dog?'
\xv M:Liv: ganngalehdjam 
\xe 'without knowle,g, (of)'
\xv M:Liv: nyah(bi)djam 
\xe 'not see'
\xv GC:Nerang: Ganngahdjam. 
\xe '(I) don't know.'
\xv GC: nyahbidjam 
\xe 'can't see (it)'
\xv Y:Holm: gungdjam 
\xe 'without water'
\xv Y:Holm: bulangdjam 
\xe 'without meat'
\xv Tw:Bray: Yugam ngayu nyahbidjam 
\xe 'I have not seen (your spear).'
\xv GC:Nerang:Fowlr: ganngaydjam 
\xe 'don't know.'
\rfg Ydict -jam/-dham; Y:Sha:Culhm -jam; Y:Holm; Y:Allen jumm (e,g, gwongjumm); Y:Watsn dhÃ_m; Y:Watsn without, minus dhong; M:Liv yilly noguÂ°mjuÂ°m baigÃ¥l where is the dog without a master; GC:Nerang:Fowlr cunitchum don't know
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy â€“ djam
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx -djang

\de more, very
\re more ; very

\xv Cas: Galewar ngumbiny bugaldjang malahnyi.

\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx -djang, -djahng
\ps suffix 
\de intensifier, very
\re intensifier ; very
\do 
\sf
\co a little bit more Wa, very, strong intensifier Gd; Geytenbeek calls it a general word-level suffix which occurs on all word classes; in conjunction with -nyi it occurs on adjectives and verbs for comparison; Wa examples on time and locative words, more (comparative), too, very (strong internsifier; seems to intensify meaning a little; used in comparisons also. 
\xv Wa: Ngay yan.gahny yuh, ngay yan.gahny yuhdjang. 
\xe 'I'll be,g,ing later on.'
\xv Wa: Gahnyu juwi yehni bagardjahng. 
\xe 'They went further down.'
\xv Wa: Malahna jambay jehrdjang nganyahnyi. 
\xe 'His hand is bigger than mine.' 
\xv Gd: Wabandidjahn nyule,g, motorbike jaligu-djahng. 
\xe 'The motorbike headed him straight for the tree'
\xv Gd: Nyule-djahng wan.gahla. 
\xe 'He is being very self-important.'
\xv Gd: Yalgan nguhndjang bawurgu. 
\xe 'The sun is too hot for your head.'
\xv Gd: babarah-djang 
\xe 'straight above'
\xv Gd: yuh-djang 
\xe 'much later'
\xv Gd: Gahnyu bugal-djahng mahnyunyi. 
\xe 'These are better than those.'
\xv Gd: Nyule,g,rahyilehn-djang nyulangam-bahnyi. 
\xe 'He hurried faster than they did.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl djahng 
\rfr Gd:Geyt -djahng ; 
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx -dja(h)
\ps suffix 
\de locative suffix 
\re locative suffix 
\do loc
\do 
\sf

\rfg Ydict
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx -dje
\ps suffix 
\de while, when
\re while ; when
\do ti
\do 
\sf
\co On a verb indicates either a sequence or an overlapping of events in the future; if an event is thought as merely possible the simple indefinite form of the verb is used; if the event is considered quite probable, the repetitive -li is included; if the event is considered as being sure to happen, the definite morpheme may also be included. 
\xv Gd: Galgahnydje male junbal yinggan wan.gahny ngay. 
\xe 'Should he happen to chop down that pine tree I will be angry.'
\xv Gd: Galgalehnydje junbal bin.geh nyule,g,h wuhrbany. 
\xe 'While he is chopping down the tree (I) will hide his hat.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\ps suffix 
\de in, at, on, locative past case
\re in ; at ; on ; locative past case
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co form of -Di after /ny/. 
\rfg Ydict
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx -du 
\ps suffix 
\de habitual action
\re habitual action
\do 
\sf
\co occurs only after incompletive suffix -hn, often also when the verb has -dja in Wa. 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Ngay nganyah jahdjam mabehr yehn.gandu gadji. 
\xe 'My children and I all used to stay here.'
\xv Wa: Mala guriyabu jugalidjahndu ware,g,warehng. 
\xe 'He used to drink beer a long time ago.' 
\xv Gd:Geyt: Wulimahndu gabay jalum namalidjahndu. 
\xe '(We) used to find honey and catch fish.'
\xv Gd: Yan.gahndu gabalgu. 
\xe '(We) used to go to the scrub.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\lx dubay 
\ps noun
\de Aboriginal woman, dark-skinned woman of any race
\re Aboriginal woman ; dark-skinned woman of any race 
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Plural dubay-djahli (Gd); 'wife, woman', also 'girl' (Wa); plural dubaymir 'women' (Wa); Wi:Curr:Richmd possibly dubari; woman, girl, wife (Cas); plural dubaymir, dubaygir, dubaybir; dubaymir (pl.); dubaydjam 'without a woman, having no woman'; dumbaymir 'lots of women'; jalgany more common. 
\xv Gd:Geyt: Dubahygir gah. 
\xe '(That looks like a) woman over there.' (woman-class over there)
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Gidjuhny gala dubay. 
\xe 'That woman is big.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Dubayu nyangani.
\xe 'The woman made (it).'
\xv Bj: dubayngah ngamah 
\xe 'woman's breast'
\xv Bj: dubayngah barahng 
\xe 'a ladies' dress.'
\xv Cas: Nyulayuwar wihrgani (?) nganyah dubay. 
\xe 'He stole my wife.'
\xv Cas: Yihlamanigur dubaydjar? 
\xe 'Where did his wife,g,?' 
\rfg Y:Holm:Logn ; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl dubay (dubuy?); Bj:TMcD-Gomes dubay woman; Bj:Holm dubai. Dubaju, dubainga; Bj:Sc:Coraki, Bj:Sc:Coraki5/1903 doboi female, Black woman; Wi:Curr:Lism toobia a Black woman; Wi:Curr:Richmd doobury a Black woman; Bj:Sc:Coraki, Bj:Sc:Coraki5/1903 doboi female, Black woman; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 tooby woman; Ny:Sc:Ballina5/1903 dewboy a black woman 
\rfk Cas:Smy dubai, dubÌ_i, dubei ; Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn;  Wa:Sc:Tabulm:Hargrv drabi; Wu:Calley du:bai girl ;
