\lx dugun 
\ps adverb, noun 
\de hill, mountain, hillock, knob
\re hill ; mountain ; hillock ; knob
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Holmer also supports high land or island; mountain; plural dugun-duguhn (Wa). 
\xv Bj: dugundah 
\xe 'up (on the hill)'
\xv Bj: dugun.gu 
\xe 'up the hill, the island.'
\xv Ny: nyimbar dugun 
\xe 'small hill'
\xv Ny: gidjuhny dugun 
\xe 'large hill' 
\xv Bj:Sc:Coraki: bijangi dugan 
\xe 'small hill'. 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl dugun; Bj:TMcD-Cowln dugun mountain; Bj:Holm-Fe,g, dgun, dugunda, dugun.gu; Bj:LWilson word not known; Bj:Sc:Coraki: dujun large hill, dugun small mountain; Bj:Sc:Coraki dugan large mountain, bethungi dugan small hill; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 toogun hill; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 toogun nob or hillock, nimbara toogun small hill, kidguan toogun large hill
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wu:Calley du:gun ; Cas:Smy dugun ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce dooggoon mountain; 
\rfo 
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\do

\lx dulung
\ps adjective 
\de afraid, fear (Gd:Thomas)
\re afraid (Gd:Thomas) ; fear (Gd:Thomas)
\do senses
\do 
\sf
\co
\xv Gd: dulung-djam 
\xe 'fearless, brave'. 
\xv Gd: Birah male jaru dulung mayah ngagam 
\xe 'throw that stone to frighten the dog.'
\xv Cas: Ngay dulung gurahr-nyi. 
\xe 'I'm afraid of snakes.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy dulung 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce tolong fear 
\rfo 
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx dumgahm
\ps noun
\de cobbera, teredo worm
\re cobbera ; worm, teredo ; teredo worm
\do ins
\do 
\sf
\co A very long worm; probably as in Yugambeh, a teredo worm that bores into water-logged timber and is a delicacy. 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr
\rfo 
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx dumgan 
\ps noun
\de ocean, open sea 
\re ocean ; sea, open ; open sea
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co one of five language names for landscape features near Fingal (M:Fingl); see damgim also; sea(s), wave(s); Bj:Sc:Coraki records as 'bay', but the meaning of waves, or sea is its meaning in ne,g,bouring dialects; Bj:TMcD:Cowl gives dun. Gam. 
\rfg Y:Watsn tum'gun open sea, ocean; M:Meston toomgun; M:Fingal toomgun; Mur:Sc:AndsnFre tumcot the sea, the ocean; GC:Meston toomgan sea; Y:Hanln toomgun the open sea ; 
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Cowl dungam wave/sea; Bj:Holm:Fe,g,dumgan; Bj:Sc:Coraki doomgonbay 
\rfk Cas:Smy dumgan, dumng?an wave (water) 
\rfr Gd:Geyt wave (of sea); 
\rfo 
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\dt 15/Dec/2014

\lx dung- 
\ps verb intransitive 
\de weep, cry, wail for, mourn
\re weep ; cry ; wail for ; mourn
\do1 bp
\do2 senses
\sf
\co irreg; can refer to child crying from hunger or pain, or adult wailing from sorrow; dungbihnyma- 'to make cry, cause to cry'; dung ba- 'to cry louder'; dung(g)ahla listed in Y:Hanln; past tense form dungehni recorded in Y:Sha:Culhm; ; Livingstone spelling suggests dangga-, Turnbull has dunga-; slightly irreg. 
\xv Wa: Mala jahdjam dungani guruhmbilgu. 
\xe 'The child cried, in order to get some milk.'
\xv Wa: Mala jahdjam dungani guruhmbilgi. 
\xe 'The child cried, wanting milk.'
\xv Wa: Ngali dungani jahdjamgu waranah ngali. 
\xe 'We were wailing over the child we lost.'
\xv We: dunggahla 
\xe 'to cry'
\xv Gd: Ngehndu dungbihn-mani? 
\xe 'Who made him cry?'
\xv Gd: Nyahgu gile jabuh dunggahla? 
\xe 'Why is that boy crying?'
\xv Gd: Jahdjam dungaliwahnbe. 
\xe 'The child cried and cried.' (cry-rep-definite-past-very)
\xv Cas: Dungani nyule,g,wangdjargay.
\xe 'He wailed, mourned, for his uncle.'
\xv M:Liv: garahrayili dunggah 
\xe 'cry very loudly'
\xv M:Liv: nganuwili dunggah 
\xe 'cry very gently'
\xv M:Liv: nungamana dunggah 
\xe 'cry quickly'
\xv M:Liv: Ninganah dunggah! 
\xe 'Stop crying!'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wana duga! (sic, should be wanah dungah)
\xe 'Don't cry!'
\xv Y:Holm: wahlu dungana 
\xe 'if you cry'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wunah dungih wahlu. 
\xe 'Stop crying.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Nyule dungehni. 
\xe 'He cried'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw ganngani nyulangih dungehni nyule. 
\xe 'I heard him crying.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: dungahla 
\xe 'crying'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgalehn dangggan dungani. 
\xe 'She cut her finger and cried.'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm dunga; Y:Holm dunga-, duga-, dugala, dugani pf, dugigi int., dungana acc.; Y:Allen pr dunga, p dungani, pf dungian, f dungala, Y:Watsn dÌÈn'ga; dÌÈn 'ganÌ¨; dun 'gian; dun'gÌ¢la, M:Liv dungga, M:Liv cf, dunggilli-ma cause to cry, karaharai-elly dungga 'cry very loudly', nunnoelly dungga 'cry very gently', nungumma?nna dungga 'cry quickly;, ningma dungga 'stop crying'; Y:Hanln toongahla 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy dung-a, dungani, dungg-a Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Gd:Geyt ;
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx dungguny
\ps noun
\de fingernail, toenail, claw, fishing line
\re fingernail ; toenail ; claw ; fishing line
\do1 bp
\do2 bd
\do3 art
\do4 ff
\sf
\co cf, danggan 'hand', jilang 'the whole bunch of talons' (Y:Hanlon); Watson form possibly dangguny; JThomas also lists something suspiciously like this for fishing hooks. 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm dungguny; Y:Allen dungoing nail of hand or foot; Y:Watsn dÌ_n'gÌ«ing; GC:Meston toongoom nail (of finger); Y:Hanln doongum nail, claw; Y:Hanln doongun a claw 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy dungunj claw, toenail, fishing line ; Wu:Calley dung:goin (v. Short end) nail. 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce dunegen nails, doongoon fishing hooks ; 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx dunma-
\ps verb transitive 
\de split something, split, tear (Wa), split firewood (Y:Sha:Culhm), smash (Y:Hanlon)
\re split something ; split (Wa) ; tear (Wa) ; split firewood (Y:Sha:Culhm) ; smash (Y:Hanlon)
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co cf, galga-, gawa-. 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Maliyu dunmani mala dawgay bawuru. 
\xe 'He (a mythical hero) split the rock with his head.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: dunmahla waybar 
\xe 'split firewood'
\xv Cas: Dumgan wayahlen burur gidjuhnygam dunmani nguy Balugahna bagul. 
\xe 'Two great waves rose up and split Balugahn's canoe.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy dunm-a, dunmani ; Wa:Crowl split something; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt split, tear 
\rfo

\lx duruny, durehny
\ps noun, adjective 
\de fear, frightened, afraid
\re fear ; frightened ; afraid
\do senses
\do 
\sf
\co cf, also dulang; durulehla, duruny wan.gahla; Turnbull also lists as snake, probably in error. 
\xv Bj: Gala guruman durulehla baygalbanyi. 
\xe 'The kangaroo is afraid of the man.'
\xv Bj: Gala jananggan durunywan.gahla man.ganbaya. 
\xe 'That boy is afraid of the snake.'
\xv Bj: Gala jabuh durunywan.gahla gurumanbaya. 
\xe 'That boy is afraid of the kangaroo.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl durunj, Bj:TMcD drehny frightened 
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\do 
\sf
\co duwaba- 'to dig faster'; bilang duwahny 'large bandicoot sp.' (she-oak dug up); possibly juwa- in one occurrence (Y:Sha:Culhm) ; duwahn listed as 'buried' (Ng:Sc:Mur); duwani 'buried' listed (Ny:Sc:Ballina). 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Gahny dam ngadju duwanah malahyamah dugul-duguhla yunamah. 
\xe 'Put these yams that I dug up in the dilly-bag'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Mala ngayal duwah malahgu baygalgu. 
\xe 'Dig up the,g,ound for that man.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Duwah mahnyu julga ngayala. 
\xe 'Dig for some worms in the,g,ound.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Ngadju munah darigan duwani ngayala. 
\xe 'I buried the bone in the,g,ound.' 
\xv We: duwalehla 
\xe 'digging'
\xv Gd: duwalihgubih 
\xe 'a spade.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Duwah gubung. 
\xe 'Dig a hole!'
\xv Bj:Holm: Duwani ngali nyulangi.
\xe 'We buried him.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Duwahla ngali. 
\xe 'We are digging out (a tree).' 
\xv Bj:Holm: juwan duwalihgu 
\xe 'yam stick (lit. Stick to dig with)' 
\xv Wi:Sc: duwani 
\xe 'buried' 
\xv Ng:Bray: Duwani jagundah. 
\xe 'They dug a grave ((for) the dead man).'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Duwani daganda. 
\xe 'They dug a grave (for) the dead (man).'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Duwani jagundih. 
\xe '(They) buried (them) in the,g,ound.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu duwahla jagun damgu(h). 
\xe 'I dug the,g,ound for yams.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Duwahla ngaw jagun. 
\xe 'I dug the,g,ound.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Duwani ngaw. 
\xe 'I dug (the,g,ound).'
\xv Mur:Sc:Hargrv: duwahn 
\xe 'buried'
\xv Ng:Cudgn:Sc: duwarem(?) jagundah(?) 
\xe 'buried' (?) 
\rfg Ng:Sc:Cudgn toarem chuchendah buried; Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray toanee chockunda grave; Ng:Sc:Mur dwan burried (sic) ;  Y:Sha:Culhm duwa; Y:Holm:Logn dua-, duani, duana (accidental); Y:Allen pr duwa, p duwun, pf duwian, f duwala v dig; Y:Watsn du'wa; du'wen; du'wian; du'wÌ_la; Mur:Sc:Hargrv dwan burried (sic); Tw:Curr:Bray toanee chockunda grave; Y:Hanln dig duah; Ng:Cudgn:Sc doarem chuchendah
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, duwa-, duwa, duwala, duwani; Bj:Sc:Coraki dwone buried; Bj:Sc:Coraki dowier burried [sic] ); Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 tooane buried; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Cas:Smy du:w-a; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt to dig; 
\rfo Cop:Hargrv toowalla 'burried' (sic)
\dt 25/Mar/2015

\ps noun

\re bee ; bees ; English bee ; native bee (light coloured or white) ; honey
\do1 ins
\do2 ff
\sf
\co Y:Sha:Culhm says 'small native bee', Y:Watsn says 'native light-coloured bee'; probably same as gabeh, q.v.; English bee, also bee,g,nerally; also see nyugay; gudjeh 'small native bee' also see nyugay; gudjeh 'small native bee'; 'English bee' nugay bargal bargal i.e. The much stinging nugay (Y:Hanln). 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Gabay-ngula yunamah bidjang. 
\xe 'Put a bit of sugar in too.'
\rfg Ydict kabay; Y:Sha:Culhm gabay small native bee; Y:Watsn kab'ai native light-coloured bee ; Y:Hanln kuppai, nugai bee; nugai purragul purragul English bee, i.e. The much stinging bee ; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl gabay bees
\rfk Wa:Crowl small sp. Of bee, honey, sugar 
\rfr Gd:Geyt white native bee, also used by some for honey, European bee; Ga:Smy gabai honey; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce cabbi, goojerrie Native bee (2 kinds), cubbu honey native bee ; 
\rfo

\lx gadji

\re here exact area ; in sight of the speaker
\do loc
\do

\xe 'This father is standing here.'
\xv Wa: Gahny bidjangdjar jadjahnala gadji. 
\xe 'These fathers are standing here.'
\xv Wa: Bagay gadji bin.gahn galahya wudjangga. 
\xe 'Frost formed here on the,g,ass.'
\xv Gd: Gadji yahyani nyule. 
\xe 'He sat down here.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl, Cas:Smy gadji here?

\lx gadjungun
\ps locative demonstrative 
\de here
\re here
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Particular place, invisible (not in view of the speaker) (Gd says in sight of the speaker but example suggests not, cf, madji, gah). 
\xv Wa: Yanah ngali gadjungun namaliyah wagan guram. 
\xe 'Let's go over here to perhaps catch some catfish.' (in the water in this place, where you can't see the catfish)
\xv Gd: Gadjungun yinde,g,nggiwahla nangany? 
\xe 'What is happening here about our breakfast?' (spoken from just outside the house)
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl. 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo

\lx gaguhng
\ps noun
\de male's older brother, male cousin (Wa)
\re brother, older (of male person) ; older brother (of a male) ; cousin, male (Wa)
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Plural gaguhnggir; great-grandfather; brother or male cousin of any great-grandparent a) male's older brother (includes many of male ego's relations on the same,g,neration level), b) male's or female's great-grandfather; brother or male cousin of any great-grandparent, also gawang etc, 
\rfg Ydict kaguhng; Y:Allen kagohn brother (elder); Y:Watsn kÌ¢gÌ«n elder brother; M:Liv kagong; brother: AT:Curr:Prior cagou, AT:Curr:LandsWh kogung, AT:Curr:O'Conn kagoon; M:Liv kagong male's older brother, also great-grandfather 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy gagung elder brother; Wu:Calley gauung, gau: gu ng MFBr, MBr, FFSrS (brother to guning), FFSrSS (brother to yirbang); We:Gordn older brother ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gn:Mathew kagung elder brother ;

\lx gah-
\ps verb
\de,g,
\re,g,
\do 
\sf

\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo

\lx -gah
\ps suffix 
\de associated with tree, suffix on tree names
\re tree name suffix
\do pl
\do 
\sf
\co Calley in particular lists this suffix frequently, while some other sources often leave it off; sometimes specifies a tree rather than its products or another plant with similar features: gihmbi 'stinging nettle', gihmbigah 'stinging tree' (both sting), man.gur 'edible resin', man.gurgah 'wattle tree' (which exudes this resin) (Wa); occurs on many tree names in Gd and Wu and other dialects, eg bigin.gah, bigargah, waygargah, budjagah, bugimgah, buhyigan.gah, bulamgah. 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wu:Calley ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Cop:Hargrv ga 
\rfo
\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx gahba
\ps demonstrative 
\de that yonder (invisible), that known or presumed distant, not in sight of the speaker (Gd), that (distant) invisible (formerly present) (Wa)
\re that yonder (invisible) ; that known or presumed distant, not in sight of the speaker (Gd) ; that (distant) invisible (formerly present) (Wa)
\do 
\sf
\co cf, gunah, munah; with -gan suffix used as temporal demonstrative.
\xv 
\xe
\xv Gd:Geyt: Yaway nyahni gahba jindi. 
\xe 'Yes I saw that nest.'
\xv Wa: Ngay yang giwani gahbanu nguhmbinyu guybanah(nu) wehlu. 
\xe 'I came from the house that you burnt down.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu galgani gahba jali wiya bayjam bibu. 
\xe 'I cut down that tree before you came.' 
\rfg Ydict kahba; M:Liv kaba it, they there 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx gahdja-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de chase, hunt, chase to catch (whether or not you catch it), pursue (with intent to fight)
\re chase ; hunt ; chase to catch (whether or not you catch it) ; pursue (with intent to fight)
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co

\xe 'The woman tried to catch it.'

\xe 'A dog chased him.'
\xv Gd: Ngagambu gahdjabalehla jimbang. 
\xe 'The dog is chasing the sheep of his own accord' (his own choice) (Gd:Geyt, new analysis, persistently chasing the sheep')

\xe 'one fond of chasing'
\xv Gd: gahdjalihbiny
\xe 'a drover'

\lx gahgi-, gahga-
\ps verb
\de descend, come down, go down
\re descend ; come down ; go down ; down, come ; down, go
\do 
\sf
\co possibly gargi-, but M:Liv shows no /r/; cf, also gargi-.
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gahgiwahla yalgan ngandir ngulungmay. 
\xe 'The sun is setting, it will soon be night.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Jalgan (sic) gahgiwahla
\xe 'The sun is going down.' 
\xv Mur:Sc:Hargrv : Gahgala gung 
\xe 'spring, water.' (?) 
\rfg Ydict kahgi-, kahga-; Y:Allen pf gargei, p gargen, pf gargeian, f gargala descend; Y:Watsn gÌ¢rå«ge; gÌ¢rå«gen; garå«geian; gÌ¢rå«gaå«la descend; M:Liv kaga come down; Mur:Sc:Hargrv gargala coong spring, water

\lx -gahl, -nggahl
\ps suffix 
\de after
\re after
\do 
\sf
\co the form is- nggahl after nominalised verbs. 
\xv Gd:Geyt: Ngudjumbuny-gahl bahyani jubare. 
\xe 'after leaving Woodenbong I arrived at Glen Station.'
\xv Gd:Geyt: Guwanggahl gawuny-wehn manyahy. 
\xe 'After the rain I felt refreshed.'
\xv Gd:Geyt: Galgalihnggal nguramahmbil-when. 
\xe 'After the chopping he felt sleepy.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm gal 
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt;

\lx gahm, gahmu, gagahm, gagahmu
\ps demonstrative
\de those distant, visible, they, those, those yonder (probably in sight)
\re those distant, visible ; they, those ; those yonder (probably in sight)
\do 
\sf
\co Cf gahnyu, mahnyu (Wa, Gd); some forms differ for human and non-human (Wa) ); redup. Gagahmu, can be used for 'they'.
\xv Wa:Crowl: Maliyu guybahla bulang gahmgu ngaringgahgu. 
\xe 'He (who I can see) is cooking some meat for those men across there (who I can see)'
\rfg Ydict kahmu, kahm, kagahm; Y:Holm gahmu; M:Liv kamy those, kamo, ka-kamo, sometimes kam that plural; kamgal from there ; M:Liv: that plural kamo, ka-kamo, sometimes kam; kamgal from there, kany
\rfb Bj:TMcD gahmu those (jar); Bj:Holm gam a collective article; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, gamu, gagamu
\rfk Wa:Crowl
\rfr Gd:Geyt
\rfo

\lx gahngun
\ps locative demonstrative 
\de there distant exact area not in sight of the speaker
\re there (distant exact area not in sight of the speaker)
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co cf, gadjungun, madjungun.

\xe 'I saw him there, in the house.' 
\rfg

\dt 23/Mar/2015

\lx gahng-, gahnga-, gahngga- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de catch, take, hold, carry, bring, obtain, to pick up , to remove from one place to another
\re catch ; take ; hold ; carry ; bring ; obtain ; to pick up , to remove from one place to another
\do 
\sf
\co irreg; cf, also mira-; Gn gandi- 'take' is possibly gah(rj) + -ndi. 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Gahnggany ngali waybargubu. 
\xe 'We will take it back to the camp.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Ngadju gahny gahnggany ganggila. 
\xe 'I'll carry these in my arms.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Gahnga mala wahlu. 
\xe 'You pick it up!' 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Munah dabahy janguywehn malahgaya janagan-gahya gahnganah mala darigan. 
\xe 'The dog got annoyed with the boy for taking his bone.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Gahnggany maliyu ngulahru gahri juwi. 
\xe 'The flood will take you a long way down there.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Maliyu wihnyi gahngani jugalimayah.
\xe 'He led you to drink.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Gahnga gilah gurahr jali bagara. 
\xe 'Get a long stick over there.'
\xv Cas: Gahnga male duluhlbi malahya. 
\xe 'Take that rifle from him.'
\xv Cas: Nyang wehlu ngayah gahngani? 
\xe 'Have you brought anything for me?'
\xv Cas: Gahnga gile nyulabahya. 
\xe 'Take that from him.' 
\xv Cas: Gahngabe mahny. 
\xe 'Take those things away.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju gahngani jambanyu. 
\xe 'I took him by the hand.'
\xv Cas: Nyanggur wehlu gahngani wule junam? 
\xe 'Have you caught any fish?'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay gahnggaluru jalum Nungganggay. 
\xe 'I caught fish for Nonggung.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wanah ngayabanyi gahnga!
\xe 'Don't take it from me!'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyula kahngigi. 
\xe 'He wants to take it.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Waybar gahngani. 
\xe '(S/he) got firewood.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gahngalah 
\xe 'Get it!'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: gahngi 
\xe 'might get it'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw gahngani jalum. 
\xe 'I caught a/some fish.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gahngalah janibang(g)u. 
\xe 'They will take it/want to get it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gahnga wahlu jabihgu. 
\xe 'Get something to eat.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gahnga guhng ngayah. 
\xe 'Get me some water.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Bulang gahnga. 
\xe 'Take the meat.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Budjigandu gahngani gundur. 
\xe 'The cat caught a rat.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gandjabalu gahngani baygalni. 
\xe 'The police caught the man.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Gahngala ngay.
\xe 'I am catching (plenty of fish).'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyang gahngalah? 
\xe 'What are (you) getting?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gahngany gandjibalu.
\xe 'The police will catch (you).'
\xv Bj:Holm: gahngilihgu 
\xe 'in order to get' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Gahngilur. 
\xe '(They) used to get.' 
\rfg Ydict k ahng-, kahnga-, kahngga-; Y:Sha:Culhm gahnga, mira- (?) catch, get; Y:Holm:Logn gahva- take; Y:Allen pr kanga, p kangani, pf kangan, f kangala; Y:Watsn kan 'ga; kan 'gan!; kan 'gan; kan 'gala; M:Liv kanggaloro; Tw:Sc:Bray kunghar to hold, take, retain; Mur:Sc:Martin kunghar to hold, take, retain; Y:Hanln gahngah ;  M:Liv kanggaloro 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, ga:nga, ga: ngani, ga: ngan, ga:ngili:gu, ga:ngilur, Bj:Holm:Fergn,Turnbl ga:ngala; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wu:Calley ngjabi gana go get water ; Cas:Smy ga:ng-a, ga:nga, ga:ngani, ga:ngg-a ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; 
\rfo
\dt 25/Mar/2015

\lx gahnye, gahnyi
\ps demonstrative 
\de those, distant not in sight of the speaker (Gd), invisible, not there before (Wa)
\re those distant not in sight of the speaker (Gd) ; those invisible not there before (Wa)
\do 
\sf
\co cf, ganyeh, manyeh; also for reintroduction of a topic (Gd). 
\xv Gd: Gahnye bulah bahngany ngulungmay. 
\xe 'Those cattle will arrive soon.'
\xv Gd: Gahmu gahnye ngagam yanbalehn gudjimbahgan. 
\xe 'Those dogs (previously referred to) were,g,ing after game.' 
\xv Wa: Nyangbuygur gahnyi yehngala Bunalbungga? 
\xe 'How many are those living at Bonalbo (and who we presume were never here at Tabulam)?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl gahnyi 
\rfr Gd:Geyt gahnye, 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx gahnyu, gahny
\ps demonstrative 
\de these persons or things in sight of the speaker, they, these, this near (probably close to the speaker, visible)
\re these persons or things in sight of the speaker ; they ; these ; this near (probably close to the speaker, visible)
\do 
\sf
\co Holmer lists as those, but it is the form for these (close), and recorded as these by TMcD; plural set corresponding to gale, male, gile, cf, mahnyu, gahmu (Wa, Gd); some case forms differ for human and non-human; Holmer lists as those, but it is the form for these (close), and recorded as these by TMcD.
\xv Wa: Gahnyulu baygalu gahngani munah bulang. 
\xe 'These men (who I can see) took the meat away (so that it can no longer be seen).' 
\xv Gd: Gahnyu wudjah.
\xe 'These are for you.'
\xv Gd: Gagahnyu ngali gayihndebeh gungge. 
\xe 'Let's dive into the water.' (these we .. )
\rfg Ydict kahnyu; M:Liv kanyo, ka-kanyo this, it near, here 
\rfb Bj:TMcD gahnyu these; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, ganyu those, they; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy ganj, ga:nju these; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo

\lx gahri
\ps locative demonstrative 
\de there, general area not in sight of speaker (Wa, Gd), in context of present time (Gd)
\re there, general area not in sight of speaker (Wa,Gd) ; in context of present time (Gd)
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co cf, gayu, mayu; when substantivised, this set signifies 'someone', irrespective or present or non-present tense (Gd); redup. Gagahri. 
\xv Wa: Gahriwehn mala dabahy. 
\xe 'The dog disappeared over there.'
\xv Wa: Gahnggany maliyu ngulahru gahri juwi. 
\xe 'The flood will take you a long way down there.'
\xv Wa: Ganngahla ngadju balahyanah gahri bagarah.
\xe 'I hear that the one over there died.'
\xv Wa: Gagahri ngali mala mani buhwini. 
\xe 'We pulled the kangaroo out there.'
\xv Gd: Gahri gabalah nyule. 
\xe 'He is over there in the scrub.'
\xv Gd: Gahriyu gawanggu jawgani nyulegaye.
\xe 'Some uncle sent it for him.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 27/Apr/2015

\xe 'There is a swan about halfway across the lagoon.'

\lx gahya-
\ps verb transitive 
\de chase, catch
\re chase ; catch
\do 
\sf
\co gahyalur preterite; cf, gaya-/gayi-, baya-. Only used by Turnbl in the sense of gahnga- (q.v.), of which it might possibly be a phonetic variant. 
\xv Y:Holm: nyulangi gahyani 
\xe 'chased him'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gayahni 
\xe 'chased'
\xv Bj:Holm: gahyana 
\xe 'where they caught him.' 
\rfg Ydict kahya-; Y:Holm:Logn

\rfk

\do 
\sf
\co cf, gaye, maye. 
\xv Gd: Gahye nurgire man.gargire. 
\xe 'Wait there by the red gum tree!'
\xv Gd: Ngumbiny guybadjahn gahye jabuhyabu. 
\xe 'The house burned down over there when I was still a boy.'

\lx gah, gahgu
\ps demonstrative 
\de over there
\re over there

\sf
\co
\xv Bj: Gah ngay yehn.gilur. 
\xe 'There I used to stay.'
\xv Bj: Yan.gahny gah. 
\xe 'I am going there.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, ga:; Bj:Holm:Turnbl ga:gu 
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\dt 11/Mar/2015

\lx galabal
\ps proper noun
\de Galabal
\re Galabal
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Name of a dialect of the language (probably one of the dialects closer to Wahlubal); 'those who say gala'; gala is 'that' in Wahlubal and southern dialects; it is gale,g,li in Yugambeh and neighbouring dialects. 
\rfg Ydict kalabal; Y:Holm 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx gala, gale (Bj), gali (M, Ng), gagali, gale, etc, (M), galaba (Wi) 
\ps demonstrative 
\de this (one), here
\re this (one) ; here
\do 
\sf
\co Predicate form gali, gagali, gagay/gage, gale, gagale (?; can take past tense suffix) (M:Liv); e,g, galahyu, acc. Galahni, possibly galahna. 
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Galahyu wulbani nganyi bumani. 
\xe 'He hit me.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Bumah galahni. 
\xe 'Hit him!'
\xv Bj Holm: Gala nyula. 
\xe 'Here he is.'
\xv Bj Holm: Gala jananggan. 
\xe 'Here is the boy.'
\xv Bj Holm: Gala yehn.galah. 
\xe 'We are sitting here.'
\xv Bj Holm: Yalgan gala. 
\xe 'this sun'
\xv Bj Holm: Galahyu Babarayu 
\xe 'this one above (God)'
\xv Bj Holm: Yabumi galahni nyangani. 
\xe '(They) painted one another.'
\xv M:Liv: Gagaliyehn ngay. 
\xe 'I was here.'
\xv Ng: Gali nyah. 
\xe 'Here it is (here look)!' 
\rfg M:Liv kully, - (m), mulla-na-gun (f), (n), konno (arb)(?); here ku?lly, ku-kully, kuullai, kuo-kullai; ku?kulliyen was here; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray kulle ; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl gala/gale this, here; Bj:TMcD:Morgn galaba here, galahni this one, gala this; Bj:Holm gala; Bj:Holm gali a masculine adjective; 
\rfk

\lx galbuny, galwuny
\ps noun
\de lyrebird

\dt 24/Mar/2015

\lx galga-
\ps verb transitive 
\de chop, cut, split firewood
\re chop ; cut ; split firewood
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co can be reduplicated galga-galga; cf, dunma- 'split (wood)'. 
\xv Wa: Ngay galgalehn nganyibu. 
\xe 'I cut myself.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu jungur gahnggan galgani burehn. 
\xe 'He took a knife and cut the bread then.'
\xv Wa: Wanah walanggeh maliyu gindilu galganahyu wihnyi min.gahny. 
\xe 'Don't crawl on your knee that you cut or you'll hurt yourself.'
\xv Wa: Galgahny mahnyulu darigandu jinang. 
\xe 'You'll cut your feet on the bones.'
\xv Wa: Galgah mala junguru maliyu. 
\xe 'Cut it with a knife.'
\xv Wa: Mala buybuygah galgahla. 
\xe 'You cut into that (apple-tree) (to get the liquid out).'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal galgalehla waybar. 
\xe 'The man is chopping wood.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu galgani jali waybargu. 
\xe 'He chopped the tree down for firewood.' 
\xv Gd: Gahngaba gahnyu galgalihginy-bah. 
\xe 'Please take these to the axeman.'
\xv Gd: Baygal galgabalehn jali.
\xe 'The man was chopping down trees persistently.'
\xv Gd: Mahdja galgaliwahn jali.
\xe 'The boss was definitely (persistently) chopping down trees.'
\xv Gd: Mahdja nyule,g, galgalimahn jali. 
\xe 'The boss was making him chop down trees.'
\xv Gd: Galgalihngu girihny-wehn.
\xe '(I) became tired through the chopping.'
\xv Gd: Nyule,g,lgalehni jali. 
\xe 'He is the one who chopped down the tree.'
\xv Gd: galgany 
\xe 'carved ornament'
\xv M:Liv: Galgah jali waybargay! 
\xe 'Cut wood for the fire!'
\xv M:Liv: Yili wahlu galga(h)jamgir, wanah. 
\xe 'If you don't like to cut it down, leave it alone.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu wanyi nyahni kalgabalini.
\xe 'I saw you cutting it.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgalehla ngayu/ngaw waybar. 
\xe 'I'm chopping firewood.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgalehn danggan dungani.
\xe 'She cut her finger and cried. '
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamali jabu galgahla jali.
\xe 'That boy will chop the tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgahla jabuyu jali. 
\xe 'The boy is chopping a tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mibinydju giyehni jabungi "galgayah jali".
\xe 'The man told the boy to chop the tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgalehn ngaw danggani/jinangi 
\xe 'I cut myself (in the hand/foot).'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgani jali jabuyu mibinygaye.
\xe 'The boy chopped the tree for the man.' 
\xv We: galgalehla 
\xe 'chopping'
\xv Bj: Galgalehla jali jananggan mabaranggayi.
\xe 'The boy is chopping the tree for the man.'
\xv Bj: galgaya 
\xe 'to chop' 
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Galgah jali waybargay. 
\xe 'Cut wood for the fire.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Galgah bulang. 
\xe 'Cut the meat'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Galgahny mala waybar. 
\xe '(I) will cut that firewood.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Bulang galgah galgalihgu.
\xe 'Cut the meat with the knife.' (literally something to cut with)
\xv Bj: Galgah jali waybargay. 
\xe 'Cut wood for the fire.'
\xv M: Yili wahlu galga(h)djamgir, wanah. 
\xe 'If you don't like to cut it down, leave it alone.' 
\xv M: Ngayu wanyi nyahni galgabalini.
\xe 'I saw you cutting it.' 
\rfg Ydict k alga-; Y:Sha:Culhm galga- cut, chop, split firewood; Y:Allen pr kalga, p kalgani, pf kalgalian, f kalgaleila chop; Y:Watsn kal'ga; kal'ganf; kal'galian; kal'gatela, M:Liv kulga, kulgajumgerry; kulgunne (past), kulgabulenne (saw you) cutting (it) ; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl galga chop; Bj:TMcD:Morgn galga cut; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, galga-, galgaii, galgali:gu; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn ; Cas:Smy galg-a chop, split, cut up; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 24/Mar/2015

\re mulberry bird ; bird, mulberry

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx galgalang, galgurang
\ps noun
\de leatherhead or friar bird, butcher bird 
\re leatherhead (bird) ; friar bird ; butcher bird 
\do bd
\do 
\sf Gymnorhina tibicen
\co Possibly galgulang, gulgurung; cf, galgalan 'mulberry bird', possibly same bird. Ngr:Gresty form suggests gahlgulin(y). 
\rfg Ydict k algalang, kalgurang; Y:Sha:Culhm galgulang jay (chatterbox, not blue jay); Y:Allen gulgulung leatherhead, golgorun buther-bird; Y:Watsn kal'kalimg leatherhead or friar bird, gol'goru'n butcher-bird G. Tibicen; Ngr:Gresty g ahlkulien leatherhead, friar bird; Y:Hanln kalkoolun leatherhead 
\rfb
\rfk

\lx -gali 
\ps suffix 
\de typified by, fond of
\re typified by ; fond of
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Noun suffix, adjective suffix. On adjectives; can occur with all nouns other than personal names, place names, and pronouns Gd;  gender suffix, usually masc (Gd). 
\xv Wa:Crowl: dubaygali 
\xe 'woman-mad' (of men)
\xv Wa:Crowl: jehrgali 
\xe 'particularly big'
\xv Wa:Crowl: ngurahmgali 
\xe 'sleepy'
\xv Wa:Crowl: wadjigali 
\xe 'talkative'
\xv Gd: nanganygali 
\xe 'one fond of food'
\xv Gd: gunuhmbali 
\xe 'place with many stumps
\xv Gd: ngagamgali 
\xe 'dog-lover'
\xv Gd: dalagargali 
\xe 'muddy place' or 'a child fond of mud'
\xv Cas: jeyirgali 
\xe 'large (masc.)'
\xv Cas: wahnggali 
\xe 'liking work (work-type)'
\xv Cas: jarulgali 
\xe 'stony.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy â€“ gali ; Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 24/Mar/2015

\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx gamay
\ps adjective
\de big
\re big
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Also 'thick' (Y:Allen, Y:Watsn); gamay-bin 'big (masc.)', gamanyagan 'big (fem)', gamina 'big (tree)'; mibiny gamay ( M:Liv), gamagay (Y:Sha:Culhm); positive, comparative and superlative gamay, gamay-gali, gamay-bunggil resp. (Y:Allen); Y:Hanln also has 'kongwai'; also name of an old 'king' (Y:Holm); Camoi 'king' buried at Fingal Head. Gn has gamaygal 'heavy'. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gamay mali jabu. 
\xe 'That boy is big.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamali gamagay mibiny/jalgany. 
\xe 'That's a big man/woman.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gamay-djang male. 
\xe 'That's too big.'
\xv Mur:Sc:Hargrv: gamay buyuhl 
\xe 'high mountain, large hill'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngulungmay wamginy mibiny gamay. 
\xe 'By-and-by plenty Blacks will come.' 
\rfg Ydict kamay; Y:Sha:Culhm gamay, gamagay; Y:Holm:Monsl,QLong; Y:Allen gumai big, thick; Y:Watsn gum'ai big; M:Liv kumai, kumai-bin (m), kumai-ma-gun (f), kuminna or kuma i nyon (spears, canoes, logs); Ms cobawnor kumajong big; Mur:Sc:Hargrv cumiboollarge hill; high mountain; AT:Curr:LandsWh kum, AT:Curr:JO'Conn cumi, Ngr:Gresty kumai long (of whiskers); komaijung big, plenty; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr comi, Tw:Curr:Bray kommo; GC:Coomera:police kowine/komine large creek; GC:Coomera:Sc large creek komine; Y:Hanln komai, kongwai large; 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gn:Mathew kumai thick, gumnikal heavy 
\rfo
\dt 24/Mar/2015

\re big toe ; big thumb

\lx gami
\ps noun
\de,g,andmother
\re,g,andmother
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co in southern dialects (except Casino dialect) father's mother; Allen, Watson and Livingstone,g,ve as 'father's mother', but Y:Sha:Culhm and Smythe's Casino listing as 'mother's mother'; reciprocal term, i.e. Also used for 'son's child' (M:Liv); ngami (Y:Holm:QLong).
\rfg Ydict kami; Y:Sha:Culhm gami mother's mother; Y:Allen kumi father's mother; Y:Watsn kumÌ¨ paternal grandmother; M:Liv kummi father's mother, son's child ; M:Liv kummi father's mother 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo

\lx gandji(li)- 
\ps verb
\de kindle, light, make burn, marry
\re kindle ; light ; make burn ; marry 
\do1 ff
\do2 lg
\sf
\co gandjibah (imper), gandjibani (past, compl), gandjibahny (fut, imm). also 'marry'? Probably ganyja- + -li-, but possibly ganydji(li)- (gandji(li)-) ; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 form listed suggested gandjigahn, possibly as noun 'marriage'. Gandjilehn 'married' (Bj:Sc:Coraki); gandjibihn 'marriage'(?) (Ng:Sc:Mur).
\xv M:Liv: Munu waybaru gandjilinibahny ngubu.
\xe 'That fire will be lit tomorrow.'
\xv M:Liv: gandjiligir 
\xe 'desire to burn'
\xv M:Liv: Wahlu giyah malahnyi waybar gandjilah.
\xe 'You ask him to light (it).'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu malahnyi ngubu giyani gandjibani.
\xe 'I asked him to light it yesterday.'
\xv M:Liv: Munu waybar gandjilurubu. 
\xe 'The fire is lighted.'
\xv M:Liv: Munu waybar gandjilinibahny ngubu.
\xe 'That fire will be lighted tomorrow.'
\xv M:Liv: gandji waybar 
\xe 'light a fire' 
\rfg Ydict kanji(li)- ; Y:Allen pr kunjelinn, p kunjelen, pf kunjelian, f kunjeleila kindle, marry, cf, marry (see ‰ÛÏkindle ‰ÛÏ) pr kÌ_njelinn; Y:Watsn kun'dhelin; kun'dhelen; kun'dhelian; kun'dhelÌ»la; M:Liv kunjilinneban will be lighted (made to burn); kundia, kunjeba (imper), kunjebunne (past), kian (fut) Mur:Sc:Hargrv gimgeebean marriage ; Ng:Sc:Mur:Hargrv gimgeebean marriage 
\rfb Bj:Sc:Coraki kunjellan marriage; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 kungheghan marriage

\lx gangga- 
\ps verb
\de call, call out, sing out, call to, shout at, make noise, rumble (of thunder)
\re call ; call out ; sing out ; call to ; shout at ; make noise ; rumble (of thunder)
\do1 lg
\do2 ne
\sf
\co 'A coo-ee' ganggalalah or ganggalulu = call out (Y:Hanln) (possibly ganggaluru?); forms ganggani pf., ganggalur pret. (Y:Holm) ; also refers generally to birds and insects making noises; can be reduplicated ga-gangga- (Wa).
\xv Wa: Gilahni dandaygami ganggah dahrayah nganyi. 
\xe 'Call the old man over to rub me.'
\xv Wa: Ganggalehn mahnyudjubundja. 
\xe 'They were shouting in the night.'
\xv Wa: Mala yirimbahm ganggalehla. 
\xe 'The locusts (cicadas) are making a noise.'
\xv Wa: Mahny marahn ganggalehnbu.
\xe 'The birds are singing again.' 
\xv Gd: Nyule,g,nggalidjahn. 
\xe 'He was shouting (so I was told).' 
\xv Gd:(Geyt translation): Ngehni ganggalehla? 
\xe 'Who is he calling to?' 
\xv Gd:(Geyt translation): Jugidjugi ganggalehla. 
\xe 'The hen is cackling.'
\xv Gd:(Geyt translation): Jugi-jugi ganggandehla mangarehmbu. 
\xe 'The hen is cackling about an e,g,' (being about to lay an egg, i.e. carrying an e,g,
\xv Cas: Ganggah nyahn.gani. 
\xe 'Call her.' 
\xv Cas: Ngadju ganngani muhgar ganggahlinyun. 
\xe 'I heard the thunder rolling.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngehn ganggalehla? - Gehr kanggalehla. 
\xe 'Who is calling? - A white cockatoo is calling.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: ganggalur 
\xe 'called out'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ganggahla nganyi (wanyi) nyulayu. 
\xe 'He is calling out to me (you).' 
\xv Bj:Holm: ganggalinyan mahnyu. 
\xe 'when they are singing out.'
\rfg Ydict kangga-; Y:Holm:Logn gagga- call; Y:Allen pr kunga, p kungen, pf kungian, f kungala call; Y:Watsn call kun 'ga; kun'gen; kunn'gian; kun'gÌ¢la, M:Liv kuggalela; Y:Hanln kungalalah, kungalooloo; M:Liv kunggalela 
\rfb Bj:TMcD-dc gangga sing out; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, gangga-, ganggaia, ganggaiinyan; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy gangg-a, ganga:, ganggÌÁlinjun ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo

\lx ganggar 
\ps noun
\de head
\re head
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Holmer says possibly Paulson's father's language (Blackbutt), but Livingstone, Bray and Martin (both Murwillumbah) give as 'head'; ganggar is 'neck' Wa, 'nape of neck' Gd; bawur 'head' is more common. Possibly should mean 'neck', see,g,nggar. See also bawur 'head' and kanggalgali 'bull'. 
\xv M:Liv: bayganah kanggar 
\xe 'a man's head'
\xv M:Liv: bayganah ganggar
\xe 'a man's head'

\lx gannga- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de hear, know, think, consider, smell, sense, hope, learn, feel, smell, suppose, believe, wonder, muse, worry about, meditate, understand
\re hear ; know ; think ; consider ; smell ; sense ; hope ; learn ; feel ; smell ; suppose ; believe ; wonder ; muse ; worry about ; meditate ; understand
\do senses
\do 
\sf
\co Also notice, worry about (Wa), ganngahla, ganngalehla 'thinking, listening' (can also mean knowing facts) (We); direct object is person (Wu); suffixes -ndji-, -lehn, -liyahn, -lehla; listed as kungulan'dhi 'think' (Y:Watsn); Tw:Sc:Bray & Mur:Sc:Martin attest past definite form kangani; Y:Hanln form kanngaleh imper; Livingstone spelling suggests ganla-/ganli-; 'know, hear, feel' (Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray) 
\xv Wa: Ganngahlini nyulabu yarbila nyula. 
\xe 'He listened to himself singing.'
\xv Wa: Ganngahla ngadju balahyanah gahri bagarah. 
\xe 'I hear that the one over there died.'
\xv Wa: Yagambeh ngadju ganngahla gumbaynggirnah nguyay. 
\xe 'I don't understand Gumbaynggir language.'
\xv Wa: Yagambeh ngadjuy ganngahla nyangbih ngadju. 
\xe 'I don't know what to do.'
\xv Wa: Yagambeh ngadju ganngahla jinggiyah ngay yaruhmala. 
\xe 'I don't know how to swim.'
\xv Wa: Yagambeh mahnyuni wadji-wadjehnyi yagambeh mahnyulu ganngahny.
\xe Wa: 'If you don't encourage them (to learn), they won't understand anything.'
\xv Wa: Jang ngay ganngalehla. 
\xe 'I feel bad.'
\xv Wa: Mala gannga-ganngalehla gibing mala banidjarni. 
\xe 'He is thinking about his sick wife.'
\xv Wa: Wanah ngalingi ganngaleh ngaliwahr gahny bugalbeh. 
\xe 'Don't worry about us, we're alright.'
\xv Wa: Ganngahla mahnyu gabuny gawalunggi guygumba. 
\xe 'I think the e,g, are outside on the sand.' 
\xv Gd: Dubay male,g,nngalehn dirahngganbu gile ngadjah. 
\xe 'The woman thought "that witch (will come) again for me."'
\xv Gd: Yalany nyulangamah yagam baray bugal ganngalihygu. 
\xe 'Their language is not very easy to understand.' 
\xv Wu: Yagambe ngadju wihnyi ganngahlawa.. 
\xe 'I don't understand you..' (not I you hear-continuous )
\xv Wu: Yagambe ngadju ganngahla. 
\xe 'I don't know.'
\xv Cas: Jinganehla wehlu ganngahla? 
\xe 'How do you know?'
\xv Cas: Yagambe ngadju wihnyi ganngahlawar. 
\xe 'I can't hear/understand you.'
\xv Cas: Gugundeh bayahny dirgun ganngahla guyahnya bayahny. 
\xe 'One can still smell the odour of possums there today.'
\xv Cas: Ganngalehnngu mahnyu baygal "ngehndu malahni bumani?" 
\xe 'Those men thought "who killed him?"''
\xv Cas: Yehn.gala nyule,g,nngahlinyun. 
\xe 'He sits thinking, meditating.'
\xv Cas: Yabur male balugahn barahygirdjahn ganngalehn. 
\xe 'One of the youths, the youngest, thought to himself.'
\xv M:Liv: Wanyi ganngalehla ngay.
\xe 'I know you.'
\xv M:Liv: Wanyi ganngalehdjam ngay. 
\xe 'I don't know you, I am without knowle,g, of you.'
\xv AT:Curr:Prior: Yagam ganngahba. 
\xe '(I) don't know.'
\xv GC:Nerang:Fowlr: ganngah-djam. 
\xe '(I) don't know.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay ganngalih-djam. 
\xe 'I don't know.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay malagay ganng(al)ani bugun. 
\xe 'I pity him (I for him smell a bad smell).'
\xv M:Liv: Wiya ganngalangi bugun ngay. 
\xe 'I'm sorry for you.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngay yugumbeh ganngahla gulgun wungah. 
\xe 'I don't understand your language.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wamginy ngulungmay ganngalehla. 
\xe 'She's thinking about coming here soon.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw yugambeh nganngani wahnyi.
\xe 'I didn't hear/understand you.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Yugambe ngay ganngahla. 
\xe 'I don't understand.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Ganngahla ngay wanyi. 
\xe 'I can hear you.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ganngahla wahlu yiralingah nguyay?
\xe 'Do you understand English?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ganngahla ngay nguyaymalinyun mamahnyu baygal. 
\xe 'I hear those men talking.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ganngaleh wuya! 
\xe 'You listen!'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyang wuya ganngalehla? 
\xe 'What are you thinking about?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay Ganngalehla nyahn.gani. 
\xe 'I am thinking of her.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ganngalehn nyahn.gan bawurah. 
\xe 'She thought in her head (i.e in her mind.)'
\xv Bj:Holm: ganngaliyan wuya 
\xe 'when you went to listen' 
\xv M: Ngay ganngalihdjam.
\xe 'I don't know.'
\xv M: Wuya ganngalangi bugun ngay. 
\xe 'I'm sorry for you.'
\xv M: Ngayu ganngahgir yarbil gahm. 
\xe 'I like to hear them sing.'
\xv M: Wanyi ganngalehla ngay. 
\xe 'I know you.'
\xv M: Wanyi ganngalehdjam ngay. 
\xe 'I don't know you, I am without knowle,g, of you.' 
\xv Ny: Yugambe,g,nngahbal (?). 
\xe 'I don't know.' 
\rfg Ydict kannga-; Y:Sha:Culhm gannga hear, know, think; Y:Allen pr kunga, p kung en, pf kung ian, f kungala hear (see ‰ÛÏcall‰Û); Y:Allen pr kungullanji, p kungullen, pf kungullian, f kunguIleila think (let me think); Y:Watsn kun'gÌÈlandhÌ¨, kun'guIlen, gun'gulian, kun'gulÌ»la think, consider; kun'ga, kun'gen, kun'gian, kun'gÌ¢la; M:Liv kunlela know, kunlejuå¡m without knowle,g, (of); M:Liv kunle, kunlejuå¡m; kunlunbe bogon; kunleoro heard, kunlan will hear, kunlunne heard, kunlela hear; Mur:Sc:Martin kungum-ne to hear, know; Tw:Sc:Bray kungum ne to hear, know; Tw:Curr:Bray iller?) (sic); Tw:Curr:Bray cunnarangeeb hear, know, think; AT:Curr:Prior canaba know; AT:Curr:LandsWh niga; AT:Curr:JO'Conn yeleyou I don't know; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr cunitchum not knowing; Y:Hanln kungulay know, kahngah hope ; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl gannga hear, understand; Bj:TMcD:Cowl gannga listen!, Bj:TMcD:Morgn think; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, ganngala ef, ganngali, ganngalila, ganngalin, ganngalijan, Bj:Holm:Turnbl ganngayagu Turnbl ; Ny:Curr:Ballina yucombe nonygumble I don't know 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wu:Calley ganaa:/awa., hear, ganaah/a hear ; Cas:Smy ganng-a, ganngalenngu, ganngÌÁlinjun ;

\ps adjective

\re deaf ; unhearing

\do2 senses

\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx gawa-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de,g,
\re,g,
\do 
\sf
\co possibly related to Livingstone's "kyua", "kankyua", or to gawari- 'run' which (if Livingstone is correct) has a type of continuous suffix -ri, see,g,yuwa(?), gan.giyuwa junimbah, gan.giyuwa warambil, gawari-. 
\xv Y:Holm: Yila wahlu gawahla? 
\xe 'Where are you going?' 
\rfg Ydict kawa-; Y:Holm:Fe,g, gawala 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 25/Mar/2015

\lx gawa- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de break, smash
\re break ; smash
\do 
\sf
\co Break (something), either by accident or on purpose (Wa); buhn gawa -'to coil, roll up', jim gawa- 'to break off' (Gd); cf, also dunma-.
\xv Wa: Munah bilahr nyahn.ganah gawani. 
\xe '(Someone) broke her spear.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu munah bilahr birani baygalu gawalehn-nguy bahm. 
\xe 'The man threw the spear and it broke in half.'
\xv Wa: Gawani maliyu dubahdjaru munah bilahr nyahn.ganah.
\xe 'The,g,rl broke her spear (deliberately).'
\xv Wa: Nganyah bargan gawani.
\xe 'My boomerang broke (acccidentally).' 
\xv Gd: Gile dalahn yaramanah warambahl jarang gawalehn. 
\xe 'That white horse's left hind leg broke.'
\xv Gd: Nyang darnang gawalehn nyulangam?
\xe 'Were they breaking sticks?'
\xv Cas: Gawah male,g,hlgambe
\xe 'Break that right in the middle.'
\xv Cas: Nganyahbu juwan gunah guwalehn? 
\xe 'Is my spear broken?'
\xv Cas: Male,g,nggil gawalehn. 
\xe 'His arm is broken.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju gawani male,g,wundjar.
\xe 'I broke that stick.'
\xv Y:Holm: gawani munjang 
\xe 'broke the net'
\xv Y:Holm: Wanah gawagawa!
\xe 'Don't break (it)!'
\xv Y:Holm: ngagamdjihndu gawagawani. 
\xe 'The dogs broke (the net).' 
\rfg Ydict kawa-; Y:Holm:Thmpsn,Logn gawa-(goh-), gawani (gohni), gohgawa imper., gohgoni pf. (ml), wana gohgawa, gohgoni; Y:Allen pr gowa, p gowalen, pf gowalian, f gowalala, Y:Watsn gowa; gow'alen; go'wiilian; gow'alla'la; Y:Hanln toonmah, kowah smash, kowah kornee to break in two; Tw:Curr:Bray cowin
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy gaw-a, gouw-a, gouwalen, gouwani ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx gawal, gawul
\ps adverb
\de far, long
\re far ; long
\do 
\sf
\co takes loc case suf.; gawal-djang 'further', gawalbanggil 'furthest' (Y:Watsn); gawulah 'far-loc', gawul-djang 'very far' possible meanings from Y:Hanln forms. Cf. Also giwal 'deep': Bray appears to have,g,wal for 'deep', and 'long'.
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yugambeh gawulah ngumbiny. 
\xe 'The house is not far.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: giwul gulgan 
\xe 'long road'

\lx gawandi- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de run with, run away with, take running, go away with
\re run with ; run away with ; take running ; go away with
\do 
\sf
\co Run with something in the hands, run while holding something; from gawa(ri)- + -ndi 'do while carrying' suffix; probably from gawa(ri)- 'run': gawandi- imper., gawandehla, gawandehn term., gawandigi int. Wahlubal Gawandi- 'run with something in the hands', from gawari- + -ndi 'do while carrying'. 
\xv Cas: Ngay gawandehny bilahru. 
\xe 'I'll run away with my spear.'
\xv Cas: Ngaywar gale bigiyu gawandehny gunggu.
\xe 'I'll run with the coolamon for water.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wana wahlu gehlgawani mani. 
\xe 'Don't you go away with the money.' 
\rfg Ydict kawandi-; Y:Holm:Logn gawandi imper, gawandila imperf, gawandin term, gawandigi int go away with, cf, gawa (Holm gawa)
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy gawand-e, gawandenj ; 
\rfr
\rfo

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx gawari-, gohri-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de run, blow (of wind), flow (of water), go round (run?), slip
\re run ; blow (of wind) ; flow (of water) ; go round (run?) ; slip
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co pronounced as though long [o:] gohri-; go round (run?). Gawarima- 'make to run'; also gawari-gawari-(Y:Hanln); gawarindi- 'run away with' Y:Holm).; run (to something or away from something), go (of vehicles), flow (of non-solid substances), extend (of distances), slip (Smy); gawarehla ' running' (We); From Livingstone's work it seems possible that the stem is gawa- with a repetitive/continuous suffix -ri, cf, gawandi- below; gawarima- 'make to run'; Ng:Sc:Mur lists gawagahla gumar gawarehla 'where the blood runs, the veins'. 
\xv Wa: Mani mala gawarehni malahgu jaligu. 
\xe 'The kangaroo ran (hopped) to the tree.'
\xv Wa: Gawande,g, mahnyulu 
\xe 'run with those'
\xv Wa: Nganyah gala bagul gawarehla bugalungahla wangahnyi.
\xe 'My canoe,g,es better than yours.'
\xv Wa: Mala nyabay gawarehla wayganda gudjanda mahnyula. 
\xe 'The water is flowing over the stones.'
\xv Wa: Muru malahna gawarehla.
\xe 'He's got a runny nose.'
\xv Wa: Mala gumar gawarehla malahya jigaydja. 
\xe 'The sore is bleeding.'
\xv Wa: Mala buyan gawarehla wanggahnu.
\xe 'The wind is blowing from the south.'
\xv Wa: Mala guygum nyabaygu gawarehla. 
\xe 'The sand extends as far as the water.' 
\xv We: Nyule,g,warehn. 
\xe 'He ran away.' 
\xv Gd: Mugimah bawur girur gawarehla. 
\xe 'The axe head is slipping.' (smooth runs)
\xv Gd: gawarimal 
\xe 'a thing which may be made to run (eg car)'
\xv Gd: gawarimay
\xe 'a thing being made to run'
\xv M:Liv: Gawarileh waybanu. 
\xe 'Go round the camp.'
\xv M:Liv: Gawarileh baygalbahnu.
\xe 'Go round the man.' 
\xv M: Ngayu nyahni gawarinyun jahdjami.
\xe 'I saw children running away.'
\xv M: Ngay gawarehn garayalehn, wanandehn wanyi.
\xe 'I run fast, you slowly, I am faster than you.' 
\xv Ng: gawagahla guhng 
\xe 'spring, water' (?)
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu nyahni gawarinyun jahdjami. 
\xe 'I saw children running away.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wunah gawareh, ban.gahny wahlu.
\xe 'Don't run, you might fall.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mali guruhman go:riwahla.
\xe 'That kangaroo is running away.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Guruhman gehlgohrehn (kehlgawarehn) jabungi nyahni, duhyindjahgan. Gohre (Gaware) nyula mulimir. 
\xe 'The kangaroo ran away (because he) saw the boy. He runs up the ridge.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu nyahni guruhman buyuhla gawarehn nyula.
\xe 'I saw a kangaroo running in the mountain(s).'
\xv M:Liv: Gawarili (gawarileh) waybanu!
\xe 'Go round the camp!'
\xv M:Liv: Gawarili baygalbahnu! 
\xe 'Go round the man!'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay gawarehn garayalehn, wanandehn wanyi.
\xe 'I run fast, you slowly (I am faster than you).'
\xv Y:Holm: wungan gawarehla ngumbiny
\xe 'running around the house'
\xv Y:Holm: gehlgawarehla, gawarehn 
\xe 'running, ran away (with)' 
\xv Cas: Girur gawarehny wudjeh manydji jaruli.
\xe 'You may (might) slip on those stones.'
\xv Cas: Yangguwah gawareh nyabanyi. 
\xe 'Come away from the water quickly (running).'
\xv Bj:Sha: Gawareh. 
\xe 'Run.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyula gawarehla. 
\xe 'He is running.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyula-nguy nyula gawariyah. 
\xe 'He tried to run.' 
\rfg Ydict kawari-, kohri-; Y:Sha:Culhm gawuri-, gehlgawuri-; Y:Holm:Logn gohrindin run away with, gohri- var. Gawari- Y:Allen pr gauarei, p gauaren, pi gauarian, I gauareila run; Y:Watsn gau'ari; gau 'aren; gau 'arian; gau 'arela run; M:Liv kory (imper), koroally go round, korima make to run; koren run/can run, korenyun; GC:Mestn couree, cowree; Y:Hanln kooran, kowriegowrie ; Ng:Sc:Mur gar gala coong spring. Water (running water?) ; M:Liv koroally we bon-no go round the camp ; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl gawari run, gaware:la pres. &lor cont.; Bj:TMcD:Cowl gawareh run; Bj:Holm gawarila ef, gawariya Turnbl; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn ; Wu:Calley ga?re run ; Cas:Smy gawar-e, gawarenj, gaware: run, slip;

\lx gawunggan
\ps noun
\de Gaunggan, standard female character in Bundjalung stories and legends, and one type of female spirit-being, beautiful young girl ('fairy lady')
\re Gaunggan, standard female character in Bundjalung stories and legends ; Gaunggan, one type of female spirit-being ; female spirit-being, one type of ; Bundjalung stories and legends, standard female character in ; beautiful young girl ('fairy lady') ; young girl, beautiful ('fairy lady')
\do1 lg
\do2 pp
\sf
\co extended to a beautiful woman or to Mary (mother of Jesus); the heroine, also any young good looking girl, plural gawunggan.gir, adj beautiful, nice looking. Wa notes name of heroine. Gd, Wa: 'good looking, beautiful' (adj of woman); Wu: 'mythical heroine, woman seen when you go out'. 
\xv Cas: Nyulangahngu gahmu balugahn.giny gawunggan.gihrgan nyulabahya yahn.gala. 
\xe 'He had his young men and women living with him.'
\rfg
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Cowl gawunggan beautiful young girl ('fairy lady')
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Wu:Calley gaunggan ; Cas:Smy gaunggan 
\rfr Gd:Geyt
\rfo

\lx gayi-, gayeh-

\sf

\xe 'Let's dive into the water.'

\xe 'We were,g,ing into these houses.'

\xe 'The sun has set.'
\xv Wa: Guwang mala gayehla gununu. 
\xe 'The rain is getting in through here.'
\xv Gd:JThomas: yalgan gayehn 
\xe 'sunset'
\xv
\rfg

\lx -gi (Wi), -gir (M)
\ps suffix 
\de want, like, desiring, wanting, wishing for, desiderative
\re want ; like ; desiring ; wanting ; wishing for ; desiderative
\do 
\sf
\co can occur on nouns or verbs (Gd); -bi + -gi 'like, want'; see -bi. 
\xv Gd: burehngibu 
\xe 'wants bread again'
\xv Gd: Nyule nanganygi. 
\xe 'He wants food.'
\xv Gd: Gawarihgi nyule. 
\xe 'He wants to run.'
\xv Gd: Yagambeh wahlu numbuhligibu? 
\xe 'Do you not want to return home again?'
\xv Cas: Nyahgi wudjeh? 
\xe 'What do you want?'
\xv Cas: Nyanggur wudjeh ginyehrgi nanganygi? 
\xe 'Do you desire such food?'
\xv Cas: Yagambe ngadju jahbigi. 
\xe 'I don't wish to eat it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gulgigi (ge,g,?) Wuya mangarehm?
\xe 'Do you want another e,g,'
\xv Bj:Holm: Jabihgi wuya? 
\xe 'Do you want a feed?'/ 'Are you for a feed?'
\xv Bj:Holm: yanbihgi 
\xe 'want to go'/'must go'.
\xv M:Liv: Guwang-gir ngay. 
\xe 'I wish it would rain'
\xv M:Liv: Nyahn minyanggir gung. 
\xe 'She wants some water.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay gila-gir ngumbinygir. 
\xe 'I would like to have that house.'
\xv M:Liv: Yugam ngay malagir jalganygir. 
\xe 'I don't like that woman.' 
\rfg M:Liv -gerry 
\rfb Bj:Holm â€“gi, -bigi; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy â€“ gi
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\dt 24/Mar/2015

\lx gibam 
\ps noun
\de moon, month
\re moon ; month 
\do1 ne
\do2 ti
\sf
\co Also 'month' (Gd). Gibam garandalehn 'full moon' (M:Liv); AT:Curr:Prior lists gibou, probably misread for gibon, AT:Curr:O'Conn probably also misread. Some sources suggest a form giban; Cudgn:Sc:Evans shows the prestopped final nasal /m/. 
\xv Wa: Mala yalgan bahn.gala numgir mala-ngu gibam jubunydja. 
\xe 'The sun comes out in the day and then the moon comes out at night.'
\xv Gd:Sc:JThomas: gibam beranggan 
\xe 'new moon (small moon)' 
\xv Gd:Sc:JThomas: gibam guy/ngy gamay 
\xe 'full moon'
\xv Cas: Ngay yan.gahla gulgihyi gibambi nge galahyi gibambi. 
\xe 'I go every month (last moon and this moon).'
\xv Cas: Ngay yehni gibambi gulgihyi munahyibu.
\xe 'I went last month.'
\xv M:Sc08: gamay gibum 
\xe 'full moon'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Gibam bahn.gala. 
\xe The moon is rising.' 
\xv M:Sc:Brunswk: gibam garandalehn
\xe 'full moon'
\rfg M:Liv gibbum; M:Sc:Brunswk kepbun moon; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray gibbun moon; Ng:Sc:Cudgn kubumb moon; Ng:Sc:Mur gioum/gibum moon; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn kibbum; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray gibbum; Ydict kibam; Y:Sha:Culhm gibam; Y:Allen gibunun; Y:Watsn gibÌ_m; Y:Beaudst:Sc kibbun moon; Y:Beaudst:police kibbum; M:Liv gibbum; Ng:Sc:Mur+ 5/100 kibbum moon; Mur:Sc:AndFrench kepbun; Tw:Sc:Bray gibbum moon; Mur:Sc:Martin moon kibbum; Mur:Sc:Hargrv gibum; M:Sc:Richmd&Tw08 kummi kyibum; Ngr:Gresty keeboon; Cudgn:Sc:Evans kubumb; GC:Coomera:Sc kibbon; GC:Coomera:police kibbon; AT:Curr:Prior gibou; AT:Curr:LandsWh keebom; AT:Curr:O'Conn gireum; GC:Meston kibbun; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr kebum; Tw:Curr:Bray gibbun; Y:Hanln keebum
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Cowl gibam ; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, gibam ; Wi:Curr:Richmd gibom ; Ny:Curr:Ballina nguibom; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 gibbum moon
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wu:Calley gi:bum, gibu¯m ; Cas:Smy gibam

\co M: gibinbaya 'Kibbin has', but feminine suffix added for K has a wife: Gibinbayagan nyubangdjargan. 'Kibbin has a wife.' 
\rfg M:Liv kibbin, -do e,g, -ye acc., -na dat, -gai dat, -bano abl 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 24/Mar/2015

\lx gidja
\ps participle 
\de this/that is the way it happened, introducer, narrative marker
\re this/that is the way it happened ; introducer ; narrative marker
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co (ngeh) gidja can mark the end of a paragraph or narrative with the sense of 'and that is how it happened', 'and that is true'; pronounced with interdental th sound in Gd. 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo

\lx gidjabal
\ps noun
\de Gidabal or Githebul dialect
\re Gidabal or Githebul dialect
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co the dialect of Bundjalung spoken to the north of Tabulam around Woodenbong, those who say gidja 'alright' (reference is to the interdental fricative in the dialect), although non-Gidjabal people usually pronounce it [gidjabal]. 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl gidjabal; Bj:Holm:Turnbl gidjabal 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy gidhabal ;

\lx gidjuhm, gidjulum, gidjam 
\ps noun
\de old man
\re old man ; man, old
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Over 50 years; probably gidjuhm; also mubig, q.v. Gidjuhm listed as 'old woman' (GC:Coomera:Sc, GC:Coomera:police); Y:Holm: also gives as gidjung (kidjung) and gidjun as well as gidjum.
\xv M:Liv: Minyangbu gidjuhma ngagam? 
\xe 'How many dogs has the old man?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: gidjunggin 
\xe '(some) old people'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: mibiny gidjuhm 
\xe 'old man'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: gidjumbu 
\xe 'old man (e,g,)' 
\rfg Y:Holm:Logn,Curry,gc.; Ydict kidhuhm, kidhulum, kidham; Y:Sha:Culhm gijuhm, gijulum; Y:Holm:Logn,QLong,Curry gidjum, gidjumbu, Logn gidjung, gidjuna old man, old men - gidjunggin Logn; Y:Allen human male (over 50 years) gijumm; M:Liv kic'om, mobeg; M:Liv kittomma old man (gen); Mur:Sc:AndFrench kithyonni old man; Mur:Sc:HerbPenneAllen kithyoume an old man; AT:Curr:Prior gidou; AT:Curr:LandsWh keejom; AT:Curr:O'Conn kedjum; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr kidgum; Tw:Curr:Bray kudjune; GC:Meston keejoom man; Ngr:Gresty keejoom old man; GC:Coomera:police old woman kiehum; GC:Coomera:Sc old woman kiehum

\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\xe 'That woman is big.'

\xv Bj:Turnbl: Gidjuhnygali.

\lx gila, gigila (Wi), gile (Wi), gili (M, Ng) 
\ps demonstrative 
\de that distant visible
\re that distant visible
\do 
\sf
\co Listed as 'this, here'; gigila reduplicated form; gilahni acc. Case. 
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Nyang mala? 
\xe 'What is that?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Gila baygal. 
\xe 'That man' or 'There is a man.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Gila mah ngali yehnbi. 
\xe 'Let us go over there to sit.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Juhm gila bahn.galah. 
\xe 'Smoke is coming up there.'
\xv M:Liv: Yili jabalgan gilagubi gandalgubi?
\xe 'Where is the paddle of that (this) canoe?' 
\rfg M:Liv killy, ki-killy (m/f); killa-na-gun (you, she yonder); kundy it there; killagÌ_by for that; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray kille there, killingang who is that, killarney (acc.) who(m) 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl gila this. Here; Bj:TMcD gilahni that one (far). Gile that (far;)Bj:Holm:Fe,g,, Turnbl gila that one, over there; Bj:Holm:Fergn, Turnbl gigila that one. Over there ; 
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\re that distant, in sight of the speaker ; yonder ; that far away

\co gila in Wa; cf, gale, male.

\xe 'That creek is deep.'

\xe 'Who is that?'
\xv Wu: Gile ngihn yanbalehla? 
\xe 'Who is that walking there?'

\lx gili
\ps demonstrative 
\de that yonder, that far away, there far away
\re that yonder ; that far away ; there far away
\do 
\sf
\co i.e. That distant (probably visible); gahny(u) predicate form (M:Liv); gili/gile,g,ven as 'here' or close' by Y:Sha:Culhm, Y:Watsn, but Y:Watsn also gives gali 'here'; gila/gili 'this' or 'here' (Y:Holm); gilagu 'here', gilangu 'from here' (Y:Holm). Tw:Curr:Bray shows accusative,g,lahni. 
\xv M:Liv: Yili jabalgan gilagubi gandalgubi? 
\xe 'Where is the paddle of that (this) canoe?' 
\xv Y:Allen: Ngahna gili? 
\xe Whose is that?'
\xv Y:Allen: Ngahn gili? 
\xe 'Who is there? 
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: gilagu malagu 
\xe 'here and there'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: gilangu 
\xe 'from here' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gili wahlu ngumbiny wungah.
\xe 'That's your house over there.'
\xv Ngr:Gresty: Gili nyah! 
\xe 'Look here!' 
\xv GC:Meston: Mibiny gilidjang yan.gehn.
\xe 'All have,g,ne away.' 
\xv Tw:Bray: Gili ngahn? 
\xe 'Who is that (person)?' 
\xv Tw:Bray: Ngahn gile. 
\xe 'I don't know'. (literally 'Who/someone there?'); 
\xv Tw:Bray: Wahlu nyahni gilahni?
\xe 'Do you see that one?'
\xv Tw:Bray: Minyang gile jalahla? 
\xe 'What (do) they eat?'
\xv Tw:Bray: Ngahn gile jalgany? 
\xe 'What woman is that?' 
\rfg Ydict kili; Y:Sha:Culhm gili/gile this (close); Y:Holm gila, gilagu; Y:Allen gilli that yonder, there far away, nana gilli whose is that; kilei middle; Y:Watsn gil'li there, far away; M:Liv killy, kikilly (m/f); killa-na-gun (you, she yonder); kundy it there; killagÌ_by for that; Mur:Sc:Martin killee he, she, it; Tw:Curr:Bray kille there, that, killingang? who is that Black? (mibbin understood), ang kille who there, killarney that one (obj.); Ngr:Gresty killinya! look here! 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx gimbay
\ps locative 
\de area
\re area
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co weakens specific concept of the word or phrase preceding it; weakens more than ngehr (mild weakening) or nginyehr (moderate weakening); cf, -gimbay. 
\xv Gd: Gadji gimbadje-mah.
\xe 'Put it down here somewhere (near me)!'
\xv Gd: Jali behn nurgire,g,le ngumbiny gimbadje. 
\xe 'The tree fell somewhere near that house.'

\rfk

\rfo

\lx ginda- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de make
\re make
\do 
\sf
\co M:Liv states that it "has all forms of simple suffixes except number 11 (-endem) and many of the compound ones, e,g, ginda-bulela, ginda-galoriby, etc, Sometimes (but rarely) takes the form ginggi- (ginggi-), and as such forms compounds with other verbs, dropping initial consonant, e,g, bo-ale 'be great', bo-indale 'be made great'" (M:Liv). This form also occurs in C. 
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu ginahny jinang bandahngu. 
\xe 'I will make a handle for the tomahawk.' 
\rfg Ydict kinda-; M:Liv kindan, kinan will make; M:Liv kinda, kinda-bulela, kinda-galoroby 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\re do ; make

\co apparently a dialect form of gini-.
\xv Cas: Nganyahyu mahmanggu gindahni. 
\xe 'My father did it.'

\rfk Cas:Smy gind-a, ginda:ni

\lx ging-
\ps verb
\de be quiet
\re be quiet
\do 
\sf
\co Imperative. Possibly ging(i)leh or ginggileh; cf, ging-anga-, ginggi-. 
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Gingli maymalam! 
\xe 'Don't speak!'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Gingle(h) 
\xe '(Be) quiet!'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Gingle(h) muwimuliyam (?) 
\xe 'Don't speak!' 
\xv Ngr:Gresty: Gingil-gingil! 
\xe 'Stop! Stop!' 
\rfg Ydict king-; Tw:Curr:Bray kingle, kingle moi-mul-li-um don't talk; Ngr:Gresty kingilkingil'Stop! Stop! 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx ginggi-
\ps verb
\de happen, become, become like, be like
\re happen ; become ; become like ; like, be
\do 
\sf
\co inherently repetitive (continuous); with yinydje means 'how .. Is'; see also -ginggi-. 
\xv Gd: Yinydje,g,nggehny ganngalehny gurgun malinyun. 
\xe 'How will (we) hear (each other) while they are talking?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 24/Mar/2015

\lx ginggi-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de shut up
\re shut up
\do 
\sf
\co (?), possibly 'do how', and 'shut up' sense from preceding wanah 'don't' in Y:Holm example; cf, ginda- and suffix -ginggi (Y:Holm). 
\xv Y:Holm:QLong: Wana ginggi. 
\xe 'Shut up.' 
\rfg Ydict kinggi-; Y:Holm:QLong,Long 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 25/Mar/2015

\lx -ginggi-
\ps suffix 
\de resemble, act like, be like, be similar
\re resemble ; act like ; like (be) ; similar, be
\do 
\sf
\co See also ginggi-, -ginggi; suffixes to a noun, sometimes in the possessive form, -ginggi creates an intransitive verb meaning 'to be similar to the referent of the stem, or its quality'. 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Mala ngay-ginggehla. 
\xe 'He looks like me.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Mala gawarehla nyabayginggehla. 
\xe 'It flows out like water.'
\xv Cas: Gale,g,wang-ginggehla. 
\xe 'It looks like rain.'
\xv Cas: Nyanggur wudjeh ngay-ginggeny? 
\xe 'Will you be like me? Will you do as I do?'
\xv Cas: Nyanggur wudjeh ngay- ginggehny balahn.gahny? 
\xe 'Will you die the way I shall?'
\xv Cas: Male yarbilginggehla! 
\xe 'That sounds like a song.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy gingg-e; ngÃ¡i-gin.ginggenjg-e, -ginggÃ¨:la, ngÃ¡i-ginggenj, ngÃ¡i-gin.ginggenj
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx gini- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de do, make
\re do ; make 
\do 
\sf
\co to use with yinydje means 'how ... Do'. 
\xv Cas: Ngihndugur gunah ginini? 
\xe 'Who did this?'
\xv Cas: Gale,g,neh. 
\xe 'Do this.'
\xv Gd: Yinydje,g,nini.
\xe 'how did (you) do it?' 
\xv Wu: Wanah gineh. 
\xe 'Don't do that.' 
\xv We: Yihndu ginini? 
\xe 'Who did that?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk We:Gordn; Wu:Calley wana: gine: 'don't do that' (leave do) Cas:Smy gin-e, gin-i, ginini, gine:,gun-i
\rfr Gd:Geyt ;

\dt 26/Jan/2015

\lx ginyehr
\ps adjective 
\de such, similar, like
\re such ; similar ; like
\do 
\sf
\co nginyehr in other dialect lists. 
\xv Cas: Ngihn.gur ginyehr nguyeh wadjelela? 
\xe 'Who speaks such a language?'
\xv Cas: Yagambehwar ngadju ganngahla ginyehr.
\xe 'I never heard such a thing, I never heard anything like that.'
\xv Bj: mangarim ginyehr 
\xe 'like an e,g,
\xv Bj: ngay ginyehr 
\xe 'like me'
\xv Bj: Nyahn.gan ginyehr. 
\xe 'She is like (that is 'she is going to have a baby').' 
\xv Bj: ginyehra 
\xe 'because of that, that is why'
\xv Bj: Ginyehra-nguy ngali. 
\xe 'That is why we ... '
\xv Bj: Yugumi yanbihgi ginyehra. 
\xe 'that is why (she) does not want to go home.'
\xv Bj: gingehrgu 
\xe 'for that, because of that.'
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, ginyir, ginyira, ginyirgu 
\rfk Cas:Smy ginje:r such, talis ; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx -ginyehr
\ps suffix 
\de like, similar to, resembling
\re like ; similar to ; resembling
\do 
\sf
\co Often added to a noun in the,g,nitive form, also nginyehr, q.v.; cf -ginggi- 'to do in a similar way'. 
\xv Wa: Wangah bawur yagam burbingah-ginyer yirali. 
\xe 'Your head is not like a koala's, whiteman.' (Because a koala cannot be taught to talk, whereas this whiteman could; possibly an idiom, or else because Aborigines knew the koala brain was very small!)
\xv Cas: Malewar jahdjamginyehr. 
\xe 'That fellow is like a child.'
\xv Cas: Jahdjam jeyir bidjangdjarginyehr. 
\xe 'The child is as big as his father.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy -ginje:r
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx ginyilgay-an.ga-
\ps verb
\de cough
\re cough
\do bp
\do 
\sf

\lx giwa-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de,g, in an unspecified direction
\re,g, in an unspecified direction
\do 
\sf
\co Must always be accompanied by some kind of direction specifier; e,g, yang giwa- 'to come' (Wa); move in a direction specified by a preceding locational demonstrative or locational word (Gd); variant guwa- (Gd). 
\xv Gd: Ngadju gahmuni wuhnybani yang giwayahbu. 
\xe 'I whistled to them to come back'
\xv Gd: Nyang blaganmir gilahya giwani? 
\xe 'Did you go there?' 
\xv Wa: Yirali yang giwadjahn duluhlbiyu. 
\xe 'The whitemen came with guns.' 
\rfg
\rfb Wi:Smy do, act 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo

\lx giya-
\ps verb
\de speak, talk, ask, tell
\re speak ; talk ; ask ; tell
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co also 'to talk, speak' (M:Liv); forms giyah (imper), giyani (compl), giyahny (imm) ; also giyagi, giyagu intention (Y:Holm); also giyali- (Y:Holm). Gn has giga-, q.v.
\xv M:Liv: Giyah malahnyi bumaliyah. 
\xe 'Ask him to fight.'
\xv M:Liv: Wahlu giyah malahnyi waybar gandjiyah/gandjibah. 
\xe 'You ask him to light a fire.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu giyalehn. 
\xe 'I replied.'
\xv M:Liv: Mali gehr mibiny giyahla. 
\xe 'That white cockatoo speaks like a man.'
\xv M:Liv: Yaburugen ngayabah giyani. 
\xe 'One came (sic) to me.'
\xv Y:Holm:Fogty: Giyah nyulangi! 
\xe 'Tell him!'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Giyani nganyi. 
\xe '(He) told me.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Giyani baygalni. 
\xe '(He) told the man.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyula wahnyi giyahgi. 
\xe 'He wants to tell you.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: yugambe,g,yalehla 
\xe 'never tells' giyalihgi. '(He) does not want to tell me.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mibinydju giyehni jabungi galgayah jali. 
\xe 'The man told the boy to chop the tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw giyehni wahnyi. 
\xe 'I told you.'
\xv Y:Holm: giyaga 
\xe 'to tell'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Yugam nganyi giyaligi 
\xe 'does not (want to tell me).' 
\rfg Ydict kiya-, kiyi-; Y:Sha:Culhm giyi; Y:Holm:Fogty,Logn gia imper., giani/giyani pi, giagi, giyagu intent.; gialigi, gialila (last xpl. Trans. contruction may be incorrect); Y:Allen pr gia, p giani, pf gian,f giala tell; Y:Watsn gÌ¨a'; gÌ¨a'nÌ¨; gi'an; gÌ¨Ì¢la; M:Liv kia, kianne past, kian jut ask; kialela, kyunne speak, talk; Tw:Curr:Bray kaar tell 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx gubung 
\ps noun, adjective 
\de valley, hollow, ditch, hole (Gd), deep, a hollow etc, (Wa), hole (in the ground), deep (Cas)
\re valley (Gd) ; hollow (Gd) ; ditch (Gd) ; hole (Gd) ; deep (Wa) ; hollow, a (Wa) ; hole (in the,g,ound) (Cas)
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co cf, gulih (B), guluny (Wa) cf gubun; Y:Allen, 'deep; a hollow', etc, Wa; gubun; Y:Allen form guwang-gubungah 'water-hole', Y:Watsn gu-gubung(ah) 'water-hole'; cf, also Y:Allen gubun 'hollow', and GC:Coomera:Sc <koofa> bee's nest, guba 'hole'. Y:Allen has two forms: gubun 'hollow' and gubung 'hole', but the distinction may not be correct; see also gugahr, guyiyar; cf, also Gd gubung 'deep' (Gd, Cas) and gubung-gubuhng 'puddle-hole' (Gd).
\xv Wa: Mala nyabay gubung malahgu janagan.gu. 
\xe 'The water is too deep for the boy.'
\xv Cas: Gale nyabay gubung. 
\xe 'This water is deep.'
\xv Bj: Bayani gubungu
\xe '(It) got out of the hole.'
\rfg Ydict gubung, kubung; Y:Allen gubÌ_ng hole, gwong-gubugna (sic) water-hole; Y:Watsn gu'bung hole, hollow, kung gu'bunga, kung-gu'bung water-hole; Mur:Sc:Hargrv gobong gully; Y:Allen kubun hollow; 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, gubung, gubungu hole in the ground
\rfk Wa:Crowl hole; Cas:Smy gubung
\rfr Gd:Geyt
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx gubunggah (gung-gubunggah), gung-gubung
\ps noun
\de waterhole
\re waterhole
\do ne

\co gubung/gubang 'hole, hollow', gung 'water'; stress shows gung gubanggah two words (Y:Watsn), probably 'water in a hollow/hole'; see,g,bang. 
\rfg Ydict gubunggah (gung-gubunggah), kung-gubung, kunggubung; Y:Allen gwong- gubunga; Y:Watsn kung gu'bÌÈnga, kung-gu'bÌÈng

\lx gudje
\ps noun
\de honey
\re honey
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co Plural gudjemir 'plenty of honey'; see also gudjir, gudja.

\xe 'Sweeten that (drink) with this honey.'

\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx gudje(h), gudja
\ps noun
\de honey of large bee
\re honey of large bee
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Allen and Y:Watsn list gaba as 'honey of small bee', gudjeh as 'honey of large bee'; cf, gudji, gudjir. Gudjir is possibly the older form, which has lost final r. GC:Coomera:Sc lists as bee's nest, and GC:Coomera:police form suggests guya. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gudjanguhrgan. 
\xe '(The tree had) honey in it.' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gamay gudja jaliya(h).
\xe 'There was lots of honey in the tree.' 
\rfg Ydict kudhe(h), kudha; Y:Sha:Culhm guja; Y:Allen kujei honey (from big bee); Y:Watsn gaba honey of small bee, gudhe honey of large bee; GC:Meston cooja honey; GC:Coomera:Sc koofa bee's nest; GC:Coomera:police kooya bee's nest; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr kudja honey; Y:Hanln honey goodja, goodjeer small native bee 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx gudjihnbar
\ps proper noun
\de Coojingburra clan
\re Coojingburra clan
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co the Fingal clan of the Ngahnduwal (Minyangbal) dialect, inhabiting the coast between the Tweed and Brunswick Rivers; derives name from gudjin 'red'; where people,g,t red pigment for corroborees including man-making (gibar) ceremonies and ritual fighting adornments. 
\rfg M:Fingl Coodjingburra; Ng:Sc:Cudgn blacks at Cudgen who are called Cudgingberry
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 25/Mar/2015

Kujin-na; M:Meston Cudgen creek; M:Fingl:Jordan; Mur:Sc:AndFrench & Mur:Sc:HerbPenneAllen cudgen red; Ngr:Gresty coogeen red; Mur:Sc1O Coodging (place of Coodging or red clay used by blacks to paint themselves with); Y:Hanln kudjeen; Y:Hanln locnm Coochimudlo;

\dt 26/Jan/2015

\lx gugin
\ps locative 
\de north, north people
\re north ; north people
\do1 loc
\do2 pp
\sf
\co People of Queensland, Queensland, Tweed Heads, any place north of one; cf, birihn 'the north, the north people'. Richmond River Aborigines call the Clarence River 'berrin' and the Tweed 'kokin'; Tweed R. People call the Richmond 'berrin' and the Logan 'kokin'. 
\xv M:Liv: gugin.gahl 
\xe 'from the north'
\xv Cas:Smy: ...ngahriyah ngali Birihndi Gumbanygirgayi nge Gugin.gay.
\xe '... That we might dance at Maclean for the Gumbanggar and Queensland people.' 
\rfg Ydict kÌ_gin; Y:Allen kugin north; Y:Watsn kug'in; M:Liv kokin, kokingÌ´l from the north; Mur:Sc:AndFrench cogin the north pole; Y:Hanln koogin north ; 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy gugin 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx guhn
\ps noun
\de a gunyah, a single humpy
\re,g,nyah, a ; humpy, single
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Watson says "a single 'ngumbin', a single hut". Cf. Gadjin - possibly medial /dj/ lost here, also cf, gunala. Probably long vowel in guhn (i.e. Not gun), as it is only one syllable. 
\rfg Ydict kuhn; Y:Watsn kun one hut; Y:Hanln koon a gunyah, kudjen a camp 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 25/Mar/2015

\lx guhndun
\ps noun
\de hair of head
\re hair of head
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co gam in Wa. Cf, gundur; where there was a possible misreading of n as r. 
\xv Gd: guhndun gawgalihgubih 
\xe 'barber' (hair cut-rep-nom-thing)
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl gu:ndun; Bj:TMcD:Cowl gundan hair; Bj:Holm:Fe,g,,Turnbl gu:ndun; Wi:Curr:Richmd koondun hair of the head 
\rfk B:Crowl; Wu:Calley gilrn:dan hair (on head),  Wa:Sc:Tabulm:Hargrv coon-dor ; Cas:Smy gu:ndun hair; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng coondoon; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce corndoon, woiee, ginderra hair ; 
\rfo
\dt 25/Mar/2015

\lx guhng
\ps noun
\de water
\re water
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co also nyabay; gung in many dialects; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 lists as 'spring water'; Wi:Curr:Lism form suggests a prestopped nasal at the end, very likely after a long vowel.
\xv Bj: Nganyah banidjargan(du) guhng (or gabing) yangina. 
\xe 'My wife will bring me water.' (ef) 
\xv Bj: guhng wudjanggah 
\xe 'dew on the,g,ass'
\xv Bj: Guhnggal munu.
\xe '(There is) dew there.' 
\xv M: Nyahn minyanggir guhng. 
\xe 'She wants some water.' 
\rfg M:Liv kÌ¼ng; M:Sc:Brunswk koong water; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray koong water; Ng:Sc:Cudgn kung water; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn koong; Ng:Sc:Mur coong water; gargala coong spring, water; Ng:Sc:TwHds coon water 
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Cowl guhng water; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, gu:ng, gung; Wi:Curr:Lism koonk; Wi:Curr:Richmd koong; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 koong water; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 koong spring water; Ny:Curr:Ballina cuung ; 
\rfr 
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; 
\rfo
\dt 25/Mar/2015

\lx guhng, guhnggan
\ps noun
\de toddler
\re toddler
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co guhng boy, guhnggan girl; often replaced with behbi/bihbi (from English), possibly in part because of similarity between guhng 'baby' and gung 'water'.

\lx guhrwa- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de surround, go round, encircle, rotate
\re surround ; go round ; encircle ; rotate
\do 
\sf
\co Circle around, curve around an object or area rather than going straight past; also nguhrwa; possibly also nguhrba-. 
\xv Cas: Gilamani nyule wuram guhrwalehn. 
\xe 'He went that way and went round the sleeper.'
\xv Cas: Guhrwalehn nyulayu ngarungdjarganbahnu. 
\xe 'He went round behind his aunt.'
\xv Cas: Guhrwani nyulayu waybar. 
\xe 'He encircled the camp.'
\xv Cas: Numbahnu nguhrbaliwah ngali.
\xe 'Let's creep round (hide) behind.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy gu:rw-a, gu:rwalen, gu:rwani, ngu:rw-a, ngu:rb-a, ngu:rbaliwa:
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx gulehr 
\ps noun
\de honey-stick, sponge for honey
\re honey-stick ; sponge for honey ; honey sponge
\do1 art
\do2 ff
\sf
\co a stick with frayed-out end for eating honey; cf, baybay. Sponge for honey, made of stinging tree bark; described in Gd as a 'piece of bark frayed at one end used for eating honey'.
\rfg Ydict kulehr; Y:Allen kuleirei; Y:Watsn kulere 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy gule:r ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015  Cf. Baybay.

\lx gulgan
\ps noun
\de beaten track, track, road, footpath, spoor, track of a foot, footprint
\re track, beaten ; track ; beaten track ; road ; footpath ; spoor ; track of a foot ; footprint
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Also gulagan (Cas). Possible forms jariya and jirar ngirada listed, q. v.
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: gayuli gulgan 
\xe 'a long road'. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw yan.gehn gurahr gulgan. 
\xe 'I walked a long way.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gulgan mali bugal, gurahr. 
\xe 'That road is good, straight.' 
\rfg Ydict kulgan; Y:Sha:Culhm road. Track; Y:Allen kulgunn road; Y:Watsn kul'gim, gul'gun road, beaten track, defined track, footpath; AT:Curr:Prior goulgan; AT:Curr:O'Conn goolgun; Tw:Curr:Bray kulligau (prob. Gan misread); Tw:Curr:Bray kfole kooligun long road; Y:Hanln koolgun road, track ; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray Hole kooligun a long road; Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray kulligau (prob. Gan misread) track of a foot 
\rfb Wi:Curr:Richmd koolgun track of a foot; Ny:Curr:Ballina kulgau (sic) track of a foot; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn trail, path, road ; Wu:Calley gillgun road ;  Cas:Smy gulagan, gulgan, gulagan ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt track, path, road; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce coolgun track, road; 
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\lx gulgany
\ps noun
\de dilly bag
\re dilly bag ; bag, dilly
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Made of swamp rushes or vine string; Y:Watsn ambiguous about first vowel, whereas Y:Hanln shows /u/ ; Y:Watsn's two forms suggest final /ny/ not /n/ . The word gulgan 'track' suggests this word is distinct and therefore,g,lgany is corrrect. 
\rfg Ydict kulgany; Y:Watsn kul'gan bag of swamp rush; kul'gin bag made of reeds; Y:Hanln koolgun bag of swamp rush 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\lx gulgi
\ps adjective 
\de another, different
\re another ; different
\do 
\sf
\co Wu:Calley; takes gender suffixes: m -h, f -gan, arb -nahgan. 
\xv Bj: Gulgi mala 
\xe 'another one'
\xv Bj: Gulgibar 
\xe 'that is a different one'
\xv Bj: Ngay gulgigi. 
\xe 'I want another.'
\xv Bj: Yugumbe,g,lgigi.
\xe 'I do not want another.' 
\xv Bj: gulgibaya 
\xe 'with another one'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: gulgibaya baygalbaya (or) gulgi baygalbaya 
\xe 'with another man.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, gulgi, gulgigim gulgibaja 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wu:Calley gulgi, gulgi: (masc), gulgihgan etc, ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt, 
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\xe 'It's quiet.'

\co 'language of Grafton' (Wa:Crowl). 
\xv Wa: Yagambeh ngadju ganngahla gumbanggirnah nguyay. 
\xe 'I don't understand Gumbaynggir.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy gumbanjgir 'GumbÌÁinggar tribe'
\rfr

\dt 29/Mar/2015

\lx gumbar, gambar
\ps noun
\de Queensland Nut tree, Macadamia
\re Queensland Nut tree ; Macadamia
\do pl
\do 
\sf
\co Possibly bambar. Said by Hanlon to be the same name and similar form to the Honeysuckle Banksia latifolia; however Hanlon has bumburra in one place, and gumburra in another; the Queensland Nut is remembered as gumbur(a) (Y:Kombum:PO'Conn); see bambar; Yugarabal (Watson's list) shows bambar only for the large banksia (B. Latifolia); he has no listing for Queensland Nut. 
\rfg Ydict gumbur, gambar (poss. Bambar); Y:Kombum:PO'Conn gumburra; Y:Hanln gumburra B. Integrifolia, same for Queensland Nut Tree, bumburra honeysuckle 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\lx gumbaw
\ps noun
\de cobra (teredo) worm
\re cobra (teredo) worm
\do ins
\do 
\sf
\co a grub or teredo, which bores into water-logged wood and which is used as food by the Aborigines. Although it has the appearance of a grub it is really a bivalve mollusc (Y:Watsn); Koomboobah place of cobra (borer) (Y:Allen). Possibly gambu/gumbu; Y:Allen form suggests /u/ in first syllable, and the form is remembered as gumbo/gumba. 
\rfg Ydict kumbaw; Y:Kombum:PO'Conn gumbo/gumba; Y:Allen gumbo cobra (wood-borer), Koomboobah place name (no special transcription) place of cobra (borer); Y:Watsn gumbo, gumbo cobra (teredo); GC:Coomera:Sc cobora combo; GC:Coomera:police combo/co?bo 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\sf

\lx gumbiny
\ps adjective, verb

\re finished ; done
\do 
\sf
\co Pronounced [gumbindj] by Tabulam/Baryulgil people today; as verb gumbiny-an.ga; see,g,mbanya-, probably same stem; Smyth lists as gumbuny.

\xe 'That was the end of him.'

\lx gunah
\ps demonstrative 
\de known or presumed here, but not in sight of the speaker (Gd), this
\re this ; known or presumed here, but not in sight of the speaker (Gd)
\do 
\sf
\co cf, munah, gahba; with -gan suffix used as temporal demonstrative 'this invisible (formerly present)' Wa. 
\xv Gd: Gunah miyigubih gayu ngehr.
\xe 'These,g,asses are somewhere here.'
\xv Gd: Gunahgan nyule,g, nyahni nyulengahye.
\xe 'I saw him recently at this place.' 
\xv Wa: Gandjal gunah jabihgu. 
\xe 'That was nice to eat (and now has been swallowed).'
\xv Wa: Gunah dandaygam balahyani. 
\xe 'The old man has died.'
\xv Wa: Gunah dandaygambihn balabalahyani. 
\xe 'The old people are all dead.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy guna: this
\rfr Gd:Geyt; 
\rfo

\lx gundal, gundul
\ps noun
\de canoe
\re canoe
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Some listings suggest gandu(h)l, see,g,ndul. Y:Hanln notes as mere coincidence the close similarity between the words 'goondool' and gondola; cf, bagul, wundal, galgir, nambargul. Y:Sha:Culhm lists gundul as 'bark of tree'. 
\xv M:Liv: Yili jabalgan gilagubi gundalgubi? 
\xe 'Where is the paddle of that canoe?'
\xv M:Liv: Gugana nganyah gandul(i).
\xe 'Come and see my canoe.'
\xv Ngr:Gresty: Ganduhl gali, ganduhl
\xe 'A boat! A boat!' (children's song) 
\rfg Ydict kundal, kundul; M:Liv kundalgoby for (a) canoe; kunddl nom, -10 e,g, -Ie dat, -no abll. -la abl2; GC:Coomera:police boat coondaal; Ngr:Gresty kundohl boat; M:Liv kundal, kulgerry; AT:Curr:LandsWh koondool; AT:Curr:O'Conn gundool GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr condool; Tw:Curr:Bray cundool; Y:Hanln goondool. Gundool, nambaragool 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015
