\dt 04/Feb/2015

\lx gundeh
\ps demonstrative 
\de that
\re that
\do 
\sf
\co Gd: (1) that distant, general area, in sight of the speaker, cf, gunu, munu; (2) that distant, of mass nouns, e,g, 'water', cf, gunu, munu; with -gal becomes a time word: 'then' (there-after); Wa: there distant general area, invisible.
\xv Gd: Gundeh wudjang darambeh. 
\xe 'That grass is very dry.'
\xv Gd: Gubanehny galgahny muruhn, gunde,g,l yinahny. 
\xe 'First I will chop the wood, then I will lie down.' 
\xv Wa: Gundehnu ngali yang giwani.
\xe 'We came from over there in that area (which you can see).' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; 
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\lx gundeh
\ps demonstrative 
\de there, yonder, then
\re there ; yonder ; then
\do 
\sf
\co
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy gunde:
\rfr
\rfo

\lx gundeh bagurah
\ps locative, demonstrative
\de over there
\re over there
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Answer to 'Where is the tomahawk?' 
\rfg Ydict kundeh bagurah; M:Liv kunde bukkora 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx gunde,g,l
\ps adverb
\de afterwards, after that
\re afterwards ; after that
\do ti
\do 
\sf
\co
\xv Cas: Dubay bardjilehn ngalingi; gunde,g,lngu yan.gehn Balunah. 
\xe 'The women watched us; then we went to Ballina.'

\rfk Cas:Smy gunde,g,l

\dt 29/Mar/2015

\lx gunde,g,l
\ps time 
\de then
\re then
\do ti
\do 
\sf
\co From gundeh 'that distant, general area, in sight of speaker' + -gal 'after'. 
\xv Gd: Gubanehny galgahny muruhn, gunde,g,l yinahny. 
\xe 'First I will chop the wood, then I will lie down.' 
\rfg

\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\re there ; over there ; yonder

\co Probably distant (yonder).

\xe 'How do you do that?'

\lx gundul (gandul?)

\do pl

\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx gundulbunbi, gundulbunbi(-be)
\ps place name
\de Mt Ladybrook (where the two stone dogs are)
\re Mt Ladybrook (where the two stone dogs are)
\do1 loc
\do2 lg
\sf
\co This is Culham's description: "where the two stone dogs are - one faces that way, one this way, talk to the dogs in the lingo if want big rain" - apparent reference to the myth of the dogs. Mt Ladybrook may be a property in the Mt Widgee area (Mt Widgee is visible from Coolangatta airport), as this is where other sources say the two stone dogs are; final syllable /bi/ or /be/. 
\rfg Ydict kundulbunbi, kundulbunbi(-be); Y:Sha:Culhm gundulbunbi(-be) 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx gung, gwong
\ps noun
\de water
\re water
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Allen lists guwang, but guwang is 'rain'. AT:Curr:JO'Conn possibly attests gunggi(r) 'want water'.
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: gung-djam 
\xe 'without water'
\xv AT:Curr:O'Conn: gungge (guhnggir?) 
\xe 'thirsty' ('want water')
\xv Tw:Sc:Bray: Gungga(h) nyula walahla. 
\xe 'He's coming to water.' 
\rfg Ydict kung, kwong; Y:Sha:Culhm guy; Ynh guy water, tea (gf); Y:Allen gwong; Y:Watsn kung; M:Liv kuy; Ng:Sc:Mur:AndFrench  koong; Mur:Sc:Hargrv coong; TWs coon; Cudgn:Sc:Evans kung; Tw:Curr:Bray koong. Koongga to water; AT:Curr:Prior yong; AT:Curr:LandsWh koong; AT:Curr:O'Conn coon water. Coonge thirsty;GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr coong; GC:Meston goong; Y:Hanln n'goong water, rain, also guway; 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gn:Mathew kung water, kungu swim (prob. 'from water') 
\rfo

\lx gunu

\re here

\sf
\co Probably same form in Yugambeh area.

\rfr Gn:Mathew kunu.
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\lx gunu 
\ps demonstrative 
\de here, this 
\re here ; this 
\do 
\sf
\co (a) here, general area, in sight of the speaker, cf, munu, gundeh; (b) this, of mass nouns, such as sand, wind, water, cf, munu, gundeh. here; -gun, gunda. 
\xv Gd: Gunu nguhndjang gundehnyi. 
\xe 'It is warmer here than there.'
\xv Gd: Gudjeyu gunuyu mununi gadjalgahnyma.
\xe 'Sweeten that (drink) with this honey.'
\xv Gd: Yagam gunu nyule. 
\xe 'He is not here.'
\xv Gd: Julunggah gunu gung.
\xe 'Drink this water!'
\xv Wa: Guwang mala gayehla gununu. 
\xe 'The rain is getting in through here.' 
\rfg 
\rfb Bj:Holm; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, gun, gunu; cf, gunda 
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\lx -gur

\de please, deference 
\re please ; deference
\do 
\sf

\xv Gd: Wanah yanah balun.gugur. 
\xe 'Please don't go to the creek.' 
\xv Wu:Calley: Jugur wudjeh mihyunggehn? 
\xe 'Where were you born?' (where you born were)

\rfk Wu:Calley djugur where
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\lx guram
\ps adverb
\de maybe, perhaps
\re maybe ; perhaps
\do 
\sf
\co No apparent difference between guram, ngalgir and wanyi/wahnyi; guram ... Guram used for 'or' Wa; also gurambeh, meaning 'perhaps', 'I suppose'; guram slightly stronger than wanyi; variable in position, and may co-occur with wanyi Gd. 
\xv Wa: Guram guwang badjilehny yuh. 
\xe 'It might rain later.'
\xv Wa: Ngali guram yabur guram bulahbu jubuny yunahny.
\xe 'We would camp for one or two nights.' 
\xv Gd: Ngalingi guram bihbar jawgaliwah. 
\xe 'You should send us a letter, perhaps.'
\xv Gd: Guram wanyi ganngaliwayah gagadji. 
\xe 'Perhaps I will hear (from you) while I am here.' 
\xv Cas: Guram nyule,g,bing. 
\xe 'Perhaps he is sick.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:TMcD guram perhaps(?) 
\rfk Cas:Smy guram ; Wa:Crowl
\rfr Gd:Geyt
\rfo
\dt 29/Mar/2015

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx gurgunma- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de talk (to someone)
\re talk (to someone)
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co gurgun + -ma 'cause to'. Holmer has gurgunmali- talk (reflexive), from gurgun (Holmer gurbun-); see also gulgun. 
\xv Gd: Yindje,g,nggehny ganngalehny gurgunmali-nyun. 
\xe 'How will (we) hear (each other) while they are talking?'
\xv Y:Holm: Gurgunma(h) nganyi! 
\xe 'Talk to me!'
\xv Y:Holm: Ngayu yanggiwani wahnyi gurgunmayah. 
\xe 'I've come to talk to you.'
\xv Y:Holm: Ngubu gurbunmalehn.
\xe '(He) talked yesterday.' 
\rfg Ydict gurgunma-; Y:Holm:Logn 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo

\lx guri
\ps noun

\re Aboriginal person ; person, Aboriginal
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Use of this term in the Yugambeh area is attested back to early this century; it is also recognised as the familiar local form of 'koori' by one person from Baryulgil (Y:Kombum:PO'Conn).

\lx gurubu
\ps adverb
\de long ago, within the speaker's lifetime, 
\re long ago, within the speaker's lifetime ; long ago
\do ti
\do 
\sf
\co Possibly in person's lifetime. Holmer gives meaning as 'all', and Tw:Bray as 'alright', probably both incorrectly translated. Cf, gurihbu, guriyahbu, gurihny. Listed as 'alright' (Ng).
\xv Gd: Gurubu nyahlidjahndu gumbi burbi gaye. 
\xe 'Long ago we used to see many koalas here.'
\xv Y:Holm: bumani gurubu 
\xe 'killed or destroyed all'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu yan.gehn gurubu townmir. 
\xe 'I went to town a long time ago.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Gurubu, ban.gehn. 
\xe 'Alright he's dead (fallen).' 
\rfg Ydict kurubu; Y:Holm:Logn; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray koorooboo alright ; Tw:Curr:Bray koorooboo
\rfb Bj:TMcD gurubu long ago (in person's lifetime)?
\rfk Cas:Smy gurubu ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ;

\lx guruhman, guruman
\ps noun
\de old man kangaroo, wallaby, Grey Kangaroo buck
\re kangaroo, old man ; old man kangaroo ; wallaby ; Grey Kangaroo buck
\do an
\do 
\sf Macropus gigantea 
\co Grey Kangaroo buck (male), often used loosely for the female; cf guranggar, or generically for any species of kangaroo; plural gurumanmir 'a flock of grey kangaroos' Gd.; cf, mani; guruhman more common than guruman, however one at least of the Kombumerri group (Cyril Williams) knows guruman. In general guruman is southern form (when not replaced by mani); initial sound [gh, k, g]. See also mani.
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: yehni guruman.gu 
\xe 'went for kangaroo (kangaroo hunting)'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mali guruhman gohriwahla. 
\xe 'The kangaroo is running (away).'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Nyahni ngayu guruhman. 
\xe 'I see a kangaroo.' 
\rfg Ydict kuruhman, kuruman; Y:Sha:Culhm kangaroo; Y:CWilliams guruhman kangaroo;Y:Holm guruman, var. Goroman; Y:Allen gromun, muni; Y:Watsn gorom'an male (M. Gigantea); M:Liv. koroman; kangaroo, male k.; Mur:Sc:Hargrv caroomin kangarroo; Ngr:Gresty karrohmin; Cudgn:Sc:Evans koorumen kangaroo; Tw:Curr:Bray kroman kangaroo; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr, Tw:Curr:Bray kroman; GC:Coomera:Sc, GC:Coomera:police groman kangaroo; GC:Nerang:Sc karoman; 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy: guruman
\rfr Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce coorooman kangaroo, boyean male k, corandi female k ; Gd:Geyt; Gn:Mathew kuruman male kangaroo
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\de breast, milk
\re breast ; milk

\do2 ff

\xe 'milk.'

\lx guruhny
\ps noun
\de elbow
\re elbow
\dp bp
\do 
\sf
\co Also gingam (gin.gam?); also means any bend. As adjective, 'crooked, bent', etc,, see,g,ruhny. Final vowel in all these words could be /uh/, but Y:Hanln gooroom-gooroon (guruhny-guruhny) strongly suggests the vowel is /u/, not /i/. 
\rfg Ydict kuruhny; Y:Allen gurin; Y:Watsn gurin', kin'gum; Tw:Curr:Bray koorin elbow; Y:Hanln kingum elbow, any bend 
\rfb

\lx guwan
\ps noun
\de black kangaroo doe (Wa), black wallaroo doe and grey faced kangaroo (Wu:Calley)
\re black kangaroo doe (Wa) ; black wallaroo doe (Wu:Calley) ; grey faced kangaroo (Wu:Calley) ; kangaroo doe, black (Wa) ; wallaroo doe, black (Wu:Calley) ; kangaroo, grey faced (Wu:Calley)
\do an
\do 
\sf
\co
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wu:Calley gu:en (schwa for e), go:en (upside down c for o, schwa for e) grey faced kangaroo 
\rfr Gd:Geyt fem Black Wallaroo
\rfo
\dt 04/Feb/2015

\lx guwang
\ps noun
\de rain
\re rain
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Can contract to gwang ([guwong/gwong]); JThomas lists as storm; water, rain; listed as 'wet' (Y:Sha:Culhm); it appears Culham had forgotten the word for 'wet'; see also gung, gwanggum, and jabang.
\xv Wa: Gala buyan wahnydjarehnyi guwang mala yang giwahny. 
\xe 'If the wind changes, the rain will come.'
\xv Wa: Malahya guwang bin.gahla dagamba. 
\xe 'It's raining out of that cloud.' 
\xv Wa: Guwangwehn balun-ngu mala ngulahrun.
\xe 'It rained and the river flooded.'
\xv Wa: Mala mani yehn.gala nguhnmalehla guwanggu malahni bumanah. 
\xe 'The kangaroo is sitting there warming himself because he,g,t caught in the rain.'
\xv Wa: Jang munah mugar gadji gehrbilehn guwang.
\xe 'The storm was bad here and there was a lot of rain.'
\xv Cas: Guwang badjilehny bayahny. 
\xe 'It's going to rain today.'
\xv Cas: Guwang badjiliwahla.
\xe 'It's starting to rain.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Guwang-wehn mulagan. 
\xe 'It rained this morning.' 
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Guwang-wehn, Guwang-wen.gahla. 
\xe 'It is raining.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: garandalehn guwang
\xe 'heavy rain'
\xv M:Liv: Guwanggir ngay. 
\xe 'I wish it would rain.'
\xv Tw:Bray: Guwang ngulungmay. 
\xe 'It will rain by-and-by.' 
\rfg M:Liv kwang, kwog; M:Sc:Brunswk quong rain; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray quong or koong rain; Ng:Sc:Cudgn koung rain; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn quong rain; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray quong ; Ydict kuwang, gwong; Y:Sha:Culhm guwang wet; Y:Beaudst:Sc gual rain; Y:Beaudst:police,g,ah; M:Liv kwÌÁng, kwong; Mur:Sc:AndFrenc quong rain; Mur:Sc:AndFrench coohong rain; Mur:Sc:Hargrv quong; Cudgn:Sc:Evans koung; GC:Meston goang rain; AT:Curr:Prior gwom; AT:Curr:LandsWh quallg; AT:Curr:O'Conn goo-ong; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr quong; Tw:Curr:Bray quong or koong ('water'); GC:Coomera:police quouk; Y:Hanln quong, n'goong 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl guwang; Bj:TMcD:Cowl guwang rain; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, guwang, guwang win; Wi:Curr:Lism koo-ung rain; Wi:Curr:Richmd koong; Bj:Sc:Coraki kuung rain ; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 fuong (sic) rain; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn guwan badjilehla; Wu:Calley guang ;  Cas:Smy gÌÈÌÁng ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt rain; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce,g,-ong storm 
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx guwang-an.ga-
\ps verb
\de rain
\re rain
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co gung Y:Hanln only; garandalehn guwang 'heavy rain'; same as water (Y:Hanln); but probably guwang 'rain', gug 'water', or meaning shift possibly.

\xe 'I wish it would rain.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: guwanggal
\xe 'after the rain'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Guwang bayilehla.
\xe 'Rain is falling.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Guwanggirahla. 
\xe 'It's raining weather.' 
\rfg Ydict kuwang + -anga-; Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Holm:Logn guang, guanggal after the rain, guang bailila rain is falling; Y:Allen n gwong, v pr gwong, p gwongen, pf gwongangan, f gwongangala; Y:Watsn n guon'g; guon'g; guon'gen; guon 'gandan; guon 'gangÌ¢la

\lx guway
\ps imperative 
\de come here!, come on!
\re come here! ; come on!
\do 
\sf
\co Aberrant form from guwa-, variant of giwa- 'to move in a direction specified by a preceding locational demonstrative or locational word'; a one word sentence - sounds like English 'go (a)way', but means the opposite!; given as wamgihny guway by Livingstone.
\xv M: Wamgihny guway 
\xe 'Come here!' 
\rfg Ydict kuway; M:Liv kwe; AT:Curr:Prior guai come on; AT:Curr:LandsWh quowee; AT:Curr:O'Conn gooway; Tw:Curr:Bray qui; Ngr:Gresty kwee, kwee! come, come!; M:Liv Wimbin kwi come here; Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray qui come on ;
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, guwai come, come on, come here Wi:Curr:Lism qua, kurr come on; Wi:Curr:Richmd gouay come on; Ny:Curr:Ballina que come on;
\rfk 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; Gn:Mathew kuai come ; 
\rfo

\lx guwihny, guyahny, guwahny
\ps noun
\de possum
\re possum
\do an
\do 
\sf
\co Big forest possum (guyahny Y:Hanln); others guyan or guwan; possible word from Y:Hanln; Kynnumboon 'place of possums' (on Tweed River) (Y:Hanln); cf, wing, guwin etc, 'ringtail possum', and see,g,lan, gunam, guran, guwany. Possibly the word should be guwiyany. Cf. Also guwin, wing 'ringtail possum'. AT:Curr:Prior and AT:Curr:O'Conn suggest a form nyuwang, q. V. 
\rfg Ydict kuwihny, kuyahny, kuwahny; Y:Sha:Culhm guyahny; Y:Allen guran opossum; GC:Coomera:police cooan; GC:Nerang:police quaan; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr gueyan; Tw:Curr:Bray quam; AT:Curr:Prior noun; A Tlw quini; AT:Curr:O'Conn newung; Y:Hanln gweeahn big forest possum; Y:Hanln Kynnumboon place of possums 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx guyahny 
\ps place name, noun
\de Grey Possum, Mt Possum
\re Possum, Grey ; Mt Possum
\do1 an
\do2 loc
\sf
\co Often used generically for any species of possum (Wa, Gd); also for 'rabbit' (Wa); Turnbull says both general and specific; also gave guyar, and Wi:Curr:Lism has <lcoogan> (possibly gugahny or guyahny).
\xv Gd: Guyahnyu nyule balunbu. 
\xe 'From Mt Possum he (went) along the creek.' 
\rfg Ng:Curr:Tweed:Bray quam opossum; Ng:Sc:Cudgn coan opossum; Ng:Sc:Mur gooan opossum 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl guyar possum; ring tailed possm (sic); Bj:Holm:Fe,g,, Turnbl gujan; Wi:Curr:Lism koogan opossum; Bj:Sc:Coraki kunyan opossum; Ny:Curr:Ballina quean opossum,' Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 fuccan opossum; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy guja:nj ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce,g,-e-an opossum ; 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx guyahny, guwihny 
\ps noun
\de possum
\re possum
\do an
\do 
\sf
\co Big forest possum kuwiyany (?); others guyan or guwan (Y:Hanln); Ngr:Gresty lists as grey possum; possibly word from which Kynnumboon 'place of possums' (on Tweed River) derives (Y:Hanln); cf, Will, guwin, etc, 'ringtail possum', and nyuwang. 
\rfg Ydict kuyahny, kuwihny; Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Holm:Fogty guyany possum, guwany (guany) possum Paulsn,Fogty; Y:Allen guran opossum; GC:Coomera:police cooan; Ngr:Gresty kwayan grey possum; GC:Nerang:police quaan; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr gueyan; Tw:Curr:Bray quam; AT:Curr:Prior noun; AT:Curr:LandsWh quini; AT:Curr:O'Conn newung; Y:Hanln gweeahn big forest opossum, others kooyan or koowan; Y:Hanln Kynnumboon place of possums

\lx guyba- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de burn, roast, cook by roasting or burning
\re burn ; roast ; cook by roasting or burning
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co Cook by placing on top of ashes, or to burn, whether or not something is burnt down; cf, marba- 'to roast, burn' or 'boil'; Holmer lists as intransitive 'burn'.
\xv Wa: Waybaramah mala bulang guybayah. 
\xe 'Put the meat on the fire to be cooked'
\xv Wa: Bugalmah mala guybah bulang. 
\xe 'Cook the meat properly'
\xv Wa: Ngay yang giwani gahbanu nguhmbinyu guybanah(nu) wehlu. 
\xe 'I came from the house that you burnt down.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu guybahla mala wudjang. 
\xe 'He burnt the,g,ass'
\xv Wa: Maliyu waybaru guybani nganyi. 
\xe 'The fire burnt me' 
\xv Wa: Waybarmah madji guybayah mahny bulang.
\xe 'Make a fire to cook the meat (on top of the coals).'
\xv Gd: guybanygir 
\xe 'one who has been burnt.'
\xv Gd: guyban.girgan 
\xe 'woman who has been burnt'
\xv We: guybalehla 
\xe cooking, burning.'
\xv Cas: Bange,g, wudjeh guybahle nangany. 
\xe 'Go and cook your food.'
\xv Cas: Nyule bugalmalehla guybalehla. 
\xe 'He cooks well.'
\xv Y:Holm: guybani jabihgu 
\xe 'roasted to eat'
\xv Y:Culhm: Guybani nyulagandu. 
\xe 'She cooked (it).'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yalgan nguhn-djang guybahla nganyi. 
\xe 'The sun is too hot - it burns me.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Guybalehla ngaw/ngayu nungany. 
\xe 'I'm cooking food.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Guybah nungany jahdjamgu. 
\xe 'Cook some food for the kid.' 
\rfg Ydict kuyba-; Y:Sha:Culhm guyba-; Y:Holm vi burn guiban term., guibani pf, guibalur pret.; Y:Allen pr kwiba, p kwibani, pf kwibalian, f kwibaleila roast (cooking); Y:Watsn kui'ba, kui'banÌ¨, kui'balian, kui'balÌ»la roast, cook; Mur:Sc:Martin quebunnee to burn; Tw:Curr:Bray quebullen burn

\lx -h 
\ps suffix 
\de imperative
\re imperative
\do 
\sf 
\co le,g,h lost if preceding vowel long. 
\rfg all
\rfb all
\rfk all 
\rfr all
\rfo all

\lx -hla
\ps suffix 
\de progressive aspect
\re progressive aspect
\do 
\sf
\co progressive aspect, often used where English would use a present tense; listed as non-past tense (Y:Sha), present tense (M:Liv); preceding vowel is le,g,hened. 
\rfg Ydict has older analysis 
\rfb all
\rfk all 
\rfr all
\rfo all

\lx -hn
\ps suffix 
\de imperfect aspect
\re imperfect aspect
\do 
\sf
\co often used where English would use a past tense. Cf, -ni which implies a completed action.
\rfg all
\rfb all
\rfk all
\rfr all
\rfo all
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx -hngbil, -hngbil, -bil
\ps suffix 
\de plural for all trees
\re plural for all trees
\do 
\sf
\co Also plural for some topographical nouns, the longer allophone is more common, with the loss of the final consonant (if any) of the stem; there is no consonant loss with -bil. 
\xv Gd: buybuy --> buybuhngbil 
\xe 'apple,g,m tree' - 'apple gum trees'
\xv Gd: jarang --> jarahngbil 
\xe 'thigh, bough' - 'boughs'
\xv Gd: garbe --> garbehngbil 
\xe 'gully' - 'gullies'
\xv Gd: waguy --> waguybil 
\xe 'vine' - 'vines' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx -hn, -ni
\ps suffix
\de completive aspect
\re completive aspect
\co see Grammar Notes (-h le,g,hens preceding vowel).
\rfg Ydict has older analysis; Y:Sha:Culhm; YHolm; Y:Allen; M:Liv 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx -i
\ps suffix 
\de when, while
\re when ; while
\do 
\sf
\co Indicates either a sequence or an overlapping of events in the past. 
\xv Gd: Baygal yarbilehni wulbung minydjidjahn. 
\xe 'When the man sang the,g,rl laughed'
\xv Gd: Nyule jaru namahni ngagam gawarehn. 
\xe 'When he,g,abbed the stone the dog ran away.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx ja- 
\ps verb intransitive 
\de eat, drink
\re eat ; drink
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co Irregular, jabay/bah/bih (c'ubbai) (imper); jabinma- 'feed someone' (M); pres. Cont. Jahlelah (Ny); jaliya 'to eat', jalehn 'food'; jahla, jabalehla, jabaleh (Y:Hanlon); others list as 'eat, drink'; forms jah imper., jabigi, jabigu intent (Y:Holm); see also jali-, jahbi-gubi. Jaga- etc, 
\xv Wa: Wanah mahny jah gaygum. 
\xe 'Don't eat raw things.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju wulimahny man.gur jaliyah. 
\xe 'I'll find some resin to eat.'
\xv Gd: jabihnmani 
\xe 'made (him) eat.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Jabihgi ngayu. 
\xe 'I want to eat.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: guybani jabihgu 
\xe 'roasted to eat'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw jahni.
\xe 'I ate it.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Jugi-jugi jalehla. 
\xe 'The chooks are eating.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wahrani guruhmani jiman.gu jaliyah. 
\xe '(They) carried the kangaroo to the fire for eating.' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wahlu jah! 
\xe 'Eat it!'
\xv AT:Curr:Prior: jarbe 
\xe 'teeth'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngali jaliwah. 
\xe 'Let's eat!'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu guybahla nungany jalihgu jahdjamgu. 
\xe 'I'm cooking food to eat for the kids.' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wunah jah, jang mali bugaw nungany, junbar in it. 
\xe 'Don't eat (it), that food is bad, it stinks, there's maggots/flies in it.' 
\xv Tw:Bray: Jabihgu.
\xe 'He's going to eat.'
\xv Tw:Bray: Ngabi jabehla. 
\xe 'Let's eat it.'
\xv Tw:Bray: Ngulungmay ngayu jahny (?) guyahny.
\xe 'By-and-by I will eat opossum.'
\xv M: Wanah jabah. 
\xe 'Don't eat.'
\xv M: Wanah malahnyi jabinmah! 
\xe 'Don't feed him.'
\xv M: Wahlu jah, ngayu.
\xe 'You eat (now), I (will eat) by-and-by.'
\xv M: Wahlu jah, banyarandah. 
\xe 'You eat, (you) will be alright.'
\xv M: jahbigu
\xe 'going to to eat'
\xv M: Ja(h)bila. 
\xe '(Let's) eat (it).'
\xv M: Ngulungmay jalehla. 
\xe 'I'll eat (it) directly.'
\xv M: Minyang gile jalehla? 
\xe 'What do they eat?' 
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Jah gale! 
\xe 'Eat it!' 
\xv Bj:TMcD: Jaleh. 
\xe 'Eat.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Wanah jah! 
\xe 'Don't eat it!' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngaliyu jahni. 
\xe 'We ate it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Jahla ngali mala. 
\xe 'We eat that.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Jalehn wuya?
\xe 'Have you had a feed?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Jalehla ngali. 
\xe 'We are eating.'
\xv Bj:Holm: jalur
\xe 'used to eat'
\xv Bj:Holm: Jabihgu wuya yan.gehn. 
\xe 'You went to eat or have a feed.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Jabihgi wuya? 
\xe 'Do you want a feed?' 
\xv Bj:Holm: jabihgi 
\xe 'want to eat.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm ja-; Y:Holm:Logn jah , jabigi , jabigu , cf, jali-; Y:Allen pr jar , p jarlen , pf jarlian , f jarla eat (as ‰ÛÏdrink‰Û); Y:Watsn dhau , dhau'en , dhaungian , dhau'Ì¢la swallow , eat ,  drink; Ngr:Gresty challilla eat (verb); Tw:Curr:Bray talala eat ,  tubbela (let's) eat , chien will eat; AT:Curr:LandsWh challalla koong, AT:Curr:JOConn coontchabbe ('eat water'); Y:Hanlon tcharla , tchabalahla; tchabullay chew; Y:Watsn mouth dhauba ,  AT:Curr:Prior jarbe mouth ; Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray tubbela let's eat , talala eat , tabbigo he's going to eat ; M:Liv c'a eat , c'ubbinma feed; cf, c'ukka drink
\rfb Wi:Curr:Lism thangeay eat; Wi:Curr:Richmd tallala eat; Ny:Curr:Ballina theelala eat; Bj:Sha:Turnbl dja eat; Bj:TMcD:Morgn jaleh; Bj:Holm-Fe,g, djah- , dja: , dja:ni (Fergn , Turnbl) , dja:la ,  djalin , djalila , djalur , djabihgu , djabigi; djabigi , djabi:gu to eat;

\lx jabam 
\ps noun
\de tree boring grub, grub, witchety grub
\re,g,ub, tree boring ; tree boring grub ; grub ; witchety grub
\do ins 
\co Generic Gd; lives in oak Wa, found in trees and edible (Y:Watsn), Ng:Curr:Fowl and Ngr:Gresty list as 'wood grub', cf, jubar. Witchety grub edible from dead trees (Bj).
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm witchety grub; Y:Holm:Thmpsn witchetty grub; Y:Allen jabumm grub; Y:Watsn dhabum; Ne:Curr:Fowl tabbun; Ngr:Gresty tabbum

\lx jabir
\ps noun
\de club, nulla-nulla, chopper, waddy, fighting stick
\re club ; nulla-nulla ; chopper ; waddy ; fighting stick
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co In sound rather like English 'chopper', a club with a long point on long tapered handle (Y:Watsn); handle (Y:Hanlon); place Tabrajalba ngabiri-galba, place (of) nulla-nulla relics (petrified gigantic nullanulla found here) (Y:Allen); jabir bira ('the waddy throw'), the name of a place (Y:Holm:Fogty). Gn has gabir(i).
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm jabir chopper; Y:Holm jabir (variant jabar) club , nulla-nulla , waddy (Thompsn, QLong) jabam; Y:Allen jabiri nulla; Y:Watsn jab'eri , dha'biri club with a plain pointed head , nulla ,  club, etc,; AT:Curr:LandsWh jabberee throwing stick; Y:Hanlon jabberee a waddy, Y:Hanlon tchabbaree handle 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx jabir-bilam
\ps noun
\de the fighting waddy belonging to the God Javreen or Jabreen
\re fighting waddy belonging to the God Javreen or Jabreen
\do1 art
\do2 lg
\sf
\co (See Legends), name of Little Burle,g, (Y:Hanlon); name over the Bora ring on the highway at Burle,g, (m); cf, jabir 'chopper' (Y:Sha:Culhm); b is optionally v in a few words, this given as example; cf, -bilahm 'has learnt to' (Gd), but only suffixed to verbs or nominalised verbs.
\rfg Y:Hanlon locnm Jabbribillum or Javvribillum

\rfk
\rfr

\lx jabu, jabuh
\ps noun
\de boy
\re boy
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co 1-10 years (Y:Hanlon), pubescent boy 12-15 years old (Y:Allen, Y:Watsn), jabumang 'lot of boys' (Y:Holm:Logn), used by Holm:Curry for son also (his boy/son, my boy/son) Y:Holm:Curry), see also jabul and jabudjil, jabuhgil. 
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu juwan ginahny jabugay biyanggay ngeringgay. 
\xe 'I will make spears for both the boy and the father.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Guruhman duhyinyehn jabuhbar. 
\xe 'The kangaroo is frightened of the boy.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Jabuhngi nyahni.
\xe '(He) saw a/the boy.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgahla jabuyu mali jali. 
\xe 'The boy is chopping the tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamali jabu galgahla jali. 
\xe 'That boy will chop the tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgani jali jabuyu mibinygaya. 
\xe 'The boy chopped the tree for the man.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bidjang(galang) jabu. 
\xe 'The boy is little.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gamay mali jabu.
\xe That boy is big.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm jabu; Y:Holm jabu (nganya , nyulang jabu my , his boy, son (Curry, Paulsn), jabumang lot of boys (Logn); Y:Allen jabo (boy between 12-15 yrs), Tabooba ngabo-ba) place of boys; Y:Watsn dhÌ¢'bu , dhÌ¢bÌÈ boy 12-15; M:Liv c'ubbo; chubbo , -io e,g, -nge acc , -nga gen , -gai dat , -bano abl , c'ubbogay for the boy, M:Sc chubtoo son; Tw:Sc:Bray taboo boy; Mur:Sc:Martn tubbo boy; Mur:Sc:WalkFosb3 jabboo a little boy; Mur:Sc:AndsnFre, Ng:Sc:HerbPennAlln thabbo small , a boy; Mur:Sc:Hargrv jaboo boy; Ng:Sc:Cudgn chabo boy; GC:Mestn taboo; Y:Hanlon tcharjoom, tcharboo masc. Baby , tchaboo boy 1 to 10 years 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo

\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jagay
\ps noun
\de white man
\re white man ; man, white
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co All other sources list dagay; literally 'a black man's ghost'. Watson states 'The first white man seen by the Aborigines was believed by them to be a ghost, and this word became commonly used by them to denote a white man (w). Dagayu name applied by Aborigines to the early white settlers in Southern Queensland when they were exploring in search of grazing country, cf, dagai, the inflection -i u indicates irregular movement, and the whole word means "Travelling, or walkabout, white man." Phonetically pronounced in English the word is dhug-ai-ee-oo, spoken quickly, but has by white people been corrupted to jackaroo' (Y:Watsn).
\rfg Y:Watsn dhÌ_gai 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx jage-jageh
\ps noun
\de woman's apron 
\re apron, woman's
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Probably pubic skirt/covering. 
\rfg Y:Allen jagei-jagei , Y:Watsn dhÌ¢gÌ» dhÌ¢gÌ»

\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\de secret, sacred
\re secret ; sacred
\do lg

\sf
\co Also 'secret ceremony' Wa; jagibah 'private' Gd.

\lx jagun 
\ps noun
\de,g,ound, earth, land, country
\re,g,ound ; earth ; land ; country
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Wu:Calley spelling suggests jaguhn. 
\xv Gd: Nyanggur wanah jagun? 
\xe 'What is your country?'
\xv Ng:Bray: Duwani jagundah. 
\xe 'They dug a grave (for) the dead man).' 
\xv Ng:Sc:Cudgn: duwarehn(?) jagundah 
\xe 'buried (lit. Dug in the,g,ound)' 
\xv Ng:Sc:Mur: yan.gehn jagun 
\xe 'gone to ground'
\xv Bj:Holm: jagundah bala 
\xe 'underneath the,g,ound' 
\xv Bj:Holm: ngalingahgu jagun.gu
\xe 'to our country'
\xv Ny: ngahri jagun 
\xe 'dancing ground'
\xv Ny: buhra jagun 
\xe 'bora ground.' 
\rfg Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray chockun ground , toanee chockunda grave; Ng:Sc:Cudgn toarem chuchenday buried; Ng:Sc:Mur chuckin clay; yanginjackum bora ground
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Morgn jaghun; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, djagun , djagunda , djagungu; Wi:Curr:Lism thackoon; Wi:Curr:Richmd chuckun; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 chokun ground; 
\rfk We:Gordn earth , ground; B:Crowl ground; Wu:Calley djagun , djagun; Cas:Smy djagun land, country; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ground , country , territory ; 
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jagun, jan, -dja
\ps noun
\de country, ground, earth
\re country ; ground ; earth
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Sha:Culhm also has jaguny; Y:Watsn spelling suggests jahgan; jan, ja are abbreviations; ja, as an affix, is commonly attached to the substantive roots of place names to indicate 'Place of' (Y:Watsn). See also jalay. Mur:Sc:Hargrv gives meaning as 'clay'. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngawu Manaljahli, nganyah jagun manal. 
\xe 'I'm Manaldjahli, my country is hard baked.'
\xv Mur:Sc:Hargrv: Yan.gehn jagun 
\xe 'bora ground(?)' (literally 'went ground') 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm jagun , jaguny ground, earth; Y:Holm jagun land ,  ground , place (Logn , Fogty), jagundi 'in the,g,ound' (prob. Past m; Y:Allen chagun earth, ground; Y:Watsn dha'gÌ_n; dhan or dha country; dhÌ¢'gÌ_n (commonly abbreviated to dhaun, dhan and dhÌ¢ land; tyÌ¢gÌÈn, dhÌ¢gÌ_n, dyagun ground, place, country,  derivatives 'tya, dhan, dha, cha, usually found as affixes to place names , when the root of the name is some descriptive object, and the affix means ‰ÛÏthe place of'; AT:Curr:Prior dagom,  AT:Curr:LandsWh chagoon, AT:Curr:JOConn igoon,  Mur:Sc:Hargrv chuckin clay, yang in jackum bora ground;  Ne:Curr:Fowl chuckoon, Tw:Curr:Bray chockun ,  GC:Coomera:police tuckkon earth; GC:Sc:Coomera tuckkon ground; GC:Mestn chakoon ground; Y:Hanlon tchagoom earth , tcharkoon, tchellai surrounding locality 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx jahdjam, jahgam
\ps noun
\de child, children, baby
\re child ; children ; baby
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Child, small child (GC); [djahdham] in Gd; pronounced [djahdjam], [djahgham]; very soft /j/ indicated word medially, possibly jahyam (GC:Sc:Sthpt); AT:Curr:LandsWh lists word for 'son'; M:Liv gives as 'boy'; Y:Hanlon form suggests second vowel /u/. Y:Hanlon says male or fem baby; if sex emphasised, jahdjam-jabu masc., jabuh-yahgari fem.
\xv M:Liv: jahdjamah jinang 
\xe 'a boy's foot'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu nyahni gawarinyun jahdjami. 
\xe 'I saw children running away.'
\xv Y:Holm:Curry: nyulanga jahdjam 
\xe 'his child'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Jahdjam mirah. 
\xe 'Kids might get hold of it.' 
\rfg Ydict jadham , jahgam , jahdhum; Y:Sha:Culhm jahjam child; Y:Holm:Curry; Y:Allen jajumm child; Y:Watsn dha'dhÌ_m; M:Liv taic'um children , baby; taic'umme (acc) , M:Liv taic'umma jennung a boys' foot , M:Sc numah ghum child or children (poss. belongs here); Mur:Sc:AndsnFre , Mur:Sc:Hargrvpa tattham baby or child; AT:Talleb:police children didum , AT:Curr:LandsWh jargum , mooyum , AT:Curr:JOConn tchadum; Ngr:Curr:Prior; Ne:Curr:Fowl charchum , Tw:Curr:Bray chargum; GC:Mestn tadhan baby girlGC:Sc:Coomera tyum small child ,  GC:Coomera:police tyum; Y:Hanlon charjoom (tcharjoom) ,  tchorajoom baby (either sex) , tcharjoom baby , tcharboo masc. ,  tcharboo-yahgaree fem 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jahdjam, jahgam 
\ps noun
\de child, children, baby
\re child ; children ; baby
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Wi:Curr:Lism has recorded jahgam, and Sharpe has heard this variant (Wi:LRoberts Wi:Curr:Lism, M:Liv); Holmer lists jadjalbu as 'little baby', and jahdja as 'baby'; probably both should be jahdjam; e,g, jahdjambu, acc. Jahdjami (Holmer).
\xv Bj:Holm: ngali jahdjam
\xe 'I and the children'
\xv M: Ngayu nyahni gawarinyun jahdjami. 
\xe 'I saw children running away.'
\xv M: jahdjamah jinang 
\xe 'A boy's foot'

\lx jahna-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de stand, stand up, stop (of wind etc,)
\re stand ; stand up ; stop (of wind etc,)
\do 
\sf
\co Inherently continuous Gd; be in the state or act of standing, grow (of plants), be in one place; can be reduplicated jajahna-; jahnama- 'to stand (something)' Wa. 
\xv Wa: Gala bidjangdjar jahnala gadji.
\xe 'This father is standing here.'
\xv Wa: Gahny bidjangdjar ja-jahnala gadji.
\xe 'These fathers are standing here.'
\xv Wa: Jahnanibeh mala madji.
\xe 'He just stood there.'
\xv Wa: Gala ngay jahnany yuh. 
\xe 'I will stand up later.'
\xv Wa: Yuh ngali yanah buyan gala jahnanah. 
\xe 'Let's go later when the wind stops.'
\xv Wa: Jinggehn mahny wudjang jahnani gadji. 
\xe 'How did the,g,ass grow here?'
\xv Wa: Munu gadjalgahny jahnani warahy.
\xe 'The tea has been standing for a long time'
\xv Wa: Wahlu namahla bin.gihng jahna-nyun mala nyabay.
\xe 'You can catch turtles in still water.'
\xv Gd: Jahnadjahn. 
\xe 'He stood still.'
\xv M:Brunswk: Jahna! 
\xe 'Stand up!', 'Stop! (stand where you are!)'
\xv Bj: Wuya jahna. 
\xe 'You stand up.'
\xv Bj: Nyula jahnani.
\xe 'He,g,t up'
\xv Bj: Jahnalah nyula.
\xe 'He is standing.'
\xv Bj: Ngay jahnany. 
\xe 'I will stand up.' 
\rfg M:Sc:Brunswk words transposed , prob. Chanah stop ; Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Holm jahnagi to stand; Y:Allen pr jana , p janani , pf janian , f janala; Y:Watsn dhÌ¢na; dhÌ¢n'ani; dhÌ¢nian; dhanÌ¢la 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl dja:na stand; Bj:TMcD:Cowl jahnanh; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, dja:na- , dja:na , dja:nani , dja:nala , dja:nan; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn jahnalah standing; Cas:Smy dja:n-a ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Calley djana stand up ;
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jalgany
\ps noun
\de Aboriginal woman, Goori woman, 
\re Aboriginal woman ; Goori woman ; woman, Aboriginal
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Sha:Culhm also lists as girl, daugher; AT:Curr:Prior could be dugalgan or jalgany 'Aboriginal woman' or dagaygan 'white woman'; cf, also dubay; Y:Holm:Logn gives dubay also, the form from more southerly dialects. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yugam ngay malagir jalganygir. 
\xe 'I don't like that woman.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Kurahr mamali jalganydjin mumuh. 
\xe 'The (boy) is taller than the,g,rl.' 
\xv Y:Hanln: jalgany-nguhr 
\xe 'married man (literally 'woman-having')' 
\xv Ng:Sc:Cudgn: jalgany yagahri 
\xe 'young (girl)'
\xv Tw:Bray: Jalgany-nguhr Tommy? 
\xe 'Has tommy a wife now?'
\xv Tw:Bray: Wahlu nyahni jalgany ngayah? 
\xe 'Have you seen my wife?' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm jalgany; Y:Holm jalgan woman (Fogty), jalgany woman, girl (Curry, Fogty, JFogty); Y:Allen talgunn woman; Y:Watsn talg'un, dug'algÌ_n, M:Liv c'ulgun(-gerry); M:Sc:Brunswk talgan a black woman; AT:Curr:Prior dugalgan; AT:Curr:LandsWh chalgun; Ng:Sc:Mur+ 5/00 chulgin a young woman; Mur:Sc:Hargrv julgun woman; Ngr:Gresty jalgoon young woman; Ng:Sc:Cudgn chulgun woman , chalgum yagrwy young (sic); GC:Mestn talgan woman, wife; Ne:Curr:Fowl chalgan; Tw:Curr:Bray woolbung ,  chulgun a black woman; GC:Coomera:police tukum woman; Y:Hanlon talgun , jalgun black or white woman , tchalgaingoora married man; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn te,g,n woman 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jali 
\ps noun
\de tree, tree trunk, log, logs, stick
\re tree ; tree trunk ; log ; logs ; stick
\do pl
\do 
\sf
\co Generic term for 'tree'; can take accusative case suffix for emphasis Gd; plural jali-gali, jali-jalih Wa; logs (lying down), firewood, general word for 'tree, wood'; also contrasts with 'top, branches, root, leaves'; Wi:Curr:Richmd possibly gali, which is recorded in Genyan also by a more reliable speller.
\xv Wa: Wanah wandeh ngahny jali. 
\xe 'Don't climb the tall trees.'
\xv Wa: Munu ngayal ngadju wangahyu jaliyu duwani.
\xe 'I dug the,g,ound with your stick there.'
\xv Wa: Ngay behn jalingu malahnu. 
\xe 'I fell out of the tree.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju wandini jali ngubuh. 
\xe 'I climbed the tree yesterday.'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal wandehla munahya jaliya. 
\xe 'The man is climbing the tree.'
\xv Wa: Wurahng mahnyu malahya jaliya buhmbila mala ngahnydja.
\xe 'The leaves high in the tree are blowing.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu galgani jali waybargu.
\xe 'He chopped the tree down for firewood.'
\xv M: Galgah jali waybargay. 
\xe 'Cut wood for the fire.'
\xv Y:Culhm: Galgah jali waybargay. 
\xe 'Cut wood for the fire.'
\xv Y:Culhm: galgaleha jali
\xe 'chopping a tree.' 
\rfg M:Liv c'ulle; Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray tally tree, talley wood, wibra wood; Ng:Sc:Cudgn tulley wood; Y:Sha:Culhm tree, branch, stick; Y:Holm:QLong wood, stick, tree; Y:Allen tullei tree, bridge, tallei wood (tree); Y:Watsn tÌ_lle, tÌÈl'le bridge (lit. Tree; a tree or log used as a bridge); M:Liv c'ulle firewood, logs), tree, tree trunk; Mur:Sc:Hargrv jalley wood; Tw:Curr:Bray talley, wibra wood,  timber; AT:Talleb:police waybara wood; AT:Curr:LandsWh challe, ' AT:Curr:JOConn talle; Ng:Sc:Cudgn talley wood; Ne:Curr:Fowl tchally; Y:Hanlon talee; Ng:Sc:Mur jalley wood ;
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Morgn jeli stick, jali tree;Wi:Holm:Fe,g, djali; Bj:Sc:Coraki tulle (used after all tree names in this list); Wi:Curr:Lism thalby wood; Wi:Curr:Richmd gallee wood; ;  Ny:Curr:Ballina thalley; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 challey wood; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Crowl , We:Gordn tree; Cas:Smy djali; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt tree; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce challae trees ; Gn:Mathew kadli tree, kali wood 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx jalngay 
\ps adjective, noun
\de shiny, bright, lamp, light, light (of fire, artificial light), shine, white, reflection
\re shiny, bright, lamp, light, light (of fire, artificial light), shine, white, reflection
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Allen gives both jalngay and jalngay-an.ga-; could be dalngay, but is jalngay in Gd etc,; cf, jalgay; one of Holmer's informants gives jalgany 'lightning', cf, jalngany.
\rfg Y:Holm djalngai light, sun (Fogty, Jfogty); Y:Allen talngai white,  bright (flame), pr talngai, p talngaien, pf talngaian, f talngaiangala light (shine); Y:Watsn tal'ngai, tal'-ngai white, artificial light; tyal'ngai bright; AT:Curr:LandsWh qangay, AT:Curr:JOConn tchalgi light of fire; talgi 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl shiny; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt shiny , brigh , lamp , light ;
\rfo

\lx jalngay-ngahriyan, jalngay 
\ps noun
\de moth, butterfly, firefly, fireflies, dancing coloured lights
\re moth ; butterfly ; firefly ; fireflies ; dancing coloured lights ; coloured lights, dancing
\do ins
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Watsn comments 'tchelngungai'marim (translated by Mr W.E. Hanlon), is, presumably, a slight corruption of tyalngai-ngarian and talngai-ngarima, meaning "dancing coloured light"' jalngay ngahriyan 'bright play/dance'); cf, jalngay 'shiny', ngahri- 'to play, dance'. Almost certainly (Sha) the term was applied to the large flocks of the Richmond Birdwing butterfly which was common before heavy white sttlement, and is now returning as people plant their food.
\rfg Y:Watsn ban'dhilan; tchelngungai'marim; Ngr:Gresty talgaimarram fire-fly; GC:Nerang:police talgi; Y:Hanlon tchel-n'gnaimarim , tchalln'gnaimahrim moth , tchelngaimarim butterfly; tchellung-nai-marim butterfly , moth , firefly 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jalum 
\ps noun
\de fish (generic), mullet, young mullet, mangrove mullet
\re fish (generic) ; mullet ; young mullet ; mangrove mullet ; mullet, young ; mullet, mangrove
\do fsh
\co AT:Curr:JOConn claims no general term for fish. Y:Hanlon says ‘this word would appear to be the same as the,g,neric “tchaloom” and the standard word for piscine life’. Wa mullet, Jogwar, possibly jehlam.
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu gahngaluru jalum Nungganggay. 
\xe ‘I caught fish for Nonggung.’ 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm jalum fish (generic), mullet (?); Y:Holm jalum (jalam?) fish (Paulsn); Y:Allen jalumm fish (different word given for mullet); Y:Watsn dha’lùm fish (generic), dhal’am fish (generic) also applied to young mullet; Y:Hanlonjelloom mangrove mullet; M:Liv c’ullu; Mur:Sc:Hargrv yallum fish; Tws talum a fish; AT:Curr:LandsWh challoom; Ng:Sc:Cudgn talum fish; GC:Nerang:police lizard talloom; Ne:Curr:Fowl tulum; Tw:Curr:Bray tallum; Y:Hanlon tchaloom, tchalom any fish ; M:Liv c'ullum; M:Sc:Brunswk talum, naugarie or chanah ***listed as stop; **egra or yen bulla as fish, and **beuaragum or bulawan as **go; obviously some transposition of words; Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray tallumfish; Ng:Sc:Cudgn talum fish; Ng:Sc:Mur yallumfish; Ng:Sc:BrayTweed talum a fish
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Gomes jellum fish; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, djalum, djalumbu, djalumgugidjun gam djalum; Wi:Curr:Lism tullum; Bj:Sc:Coraki talum fish; Ny:Curr:Ballina thallum; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 challumfish
\rfk Wa:Smy dje:lum
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarence no word for fish generally; 
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jalum bira-
\ps verb
\de fish with hook and line
\re fish with hook and line
\do ff

\sf
\co Literally 'to throw fish'.

\lx jambay 
\ps noun
\de finger, hand
\re finger ; hand
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Plural jambaybil, jambaygali, Smy also lists as lower arm.
\xv Wa: Namah jambaydju. 
\xe 'Take hold (of it) with your hands.'
\xv Wa: Jargeh gindilu jambaydju. 
\xe 'Get down on your hands and knees.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju jalgahla jambaydju.
\xe 'I'm clapping my hands together.'
\xv Wa: Burbahmaliyu jambaydju mahny junbar. 
\xe 'Wave away the flies with your hands.'
\xv Wa: Jambay nganyah jangwerwahla bugali-nyun.
\xe 'My hand is getting sore from writing.'
\xv Wa: Jambay mahny ganini maliyu baygalu. 
\xe 'The man tied her hands up.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju gahngai jambanyu. 
\xe 'I led him by the hand.'
\xv Bj:Holm: yambayah jigay 
\xe 'a sore in the hand, a sore hand' 
\xv Bj:Holm: jigay jambay 
\xe 'sore hand.' 
\rfg

\lx jambinbin
\ps noun
\de root sucker
\re root sucker
\do pl
\do 
\sf
\co Root sucker of the pandanus tree, which was macerated and used as a chewing rope: 'This rope was immersed in a receptacle containing a mixture of honey, honeycomb, dead bees, grubs and dead or rotten wood, and when thoroughly saturated with this delightful nectar, was chewed and sucked. The chewed end was then directed into a second receptacle of the liquor, ready for chewing back again into number 1, and so on till repletion was attained. It was a contemplative occupation much favoured by the old men of the tribe.' 
\rfg Y:Hanlon locnm Jumpinpin 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx janehn (?)

\re ironbark
\do pl
\do 
\sf

\dt 04/Feb/2015

\lx jang
\ps adjective 
\de bad, badly, sour, harmful, no good, cheeky, badness, rubbish
\re bad ; badly ; sour ; harmful ; no good ; cheeky ; badness ; rubbish
\do senses
\do 
\sf
\co bad, wicked Gd; dirty, sore, rotten, naughty, aching, in a bad mood, bored with, guilty, rough, secret, painful Wa; takes gender suffixes m -gali, f -ahgan, arb -ah Calley; bad (adj.) and badly (adv.) compared the same way: jang, jalng-gali, jang-bunggil Y:Allen; jung in Y:Watsn; Holmer says djak or djag (voiceless form prevailing) often used for 'cheeky person'. 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Jang munah mugar gadji gehrbilehn guwang. 
\xe 'The storm was bad here and there was a lot of rain.'
\xv Cas: Guybah male jang. 
\xe 'Burn that rubbish.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: jang wangal 
\xe 'bad (child)'
\xv Y:Holm:JFogty: Jangan.gehn gidjung 
\xe 'The old man is no good.'
\xv Y:Holm:Fogty: mibiny jang 
\xe 'bad man'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: jang ganngalehla.
\xe '(She) is sad.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: jang malih/maleh 
\xe 'slowly'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: jang yan.ehn
\xe 'went very slow'
\xv M:Liv: banyahr jang 
\xe 'very bad'
\xv Y:Hanln: jung jahmjang
\xe 'very bad' 
\xv Tw:Bray: Mirang jang-jang. 
\xe 'That old woman (is) ugly.'
\xv Tw:Bray: Yugam, jang. 
\xe 'No, he's thin.' (answer to 'It's fat.')
\xv Bj: Jang nyula. 
\xe 'He is no good.'
\xv Bj: Jangbani gundeh.
\xe '(He) said it was bad there.'
\xv Bj: Jang jangmalehla.
\xe '(They) are swearing.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm bad , sour; Y:Holm jangi bad , no good (Logn ,  Fogty); Y:Allen thung bad , badly; Y:Watsn dhung bad , badly; M:Liv bunyarra juv very bad; AT:Curr:LandsWh chang; AT:Curr:JOConn tchung; Ne:Curr:Fowl , Tw:Curr:Bray chung; Tw:Sc:Bray chung bad; Mur:Sc:Martn chung bad; Y:Hanlon tchoong bad , jarm jung very bad; M:Liv jung, Ng:Curr:TwD:Bray chung bad
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl djang; Bj:TMcD:Gomes jang bad; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, djang, djang bani, djag, djak; Wi:Curr:Lism chang bad; Wi:Curr:Richmd thung; Ny:Curr:Ballina yell-yell, thung bad ; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Cas:Smy djagng, djang ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt no good, wicked ; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce chung bad;  Gd:Calley djang bad, no good ; Gn:Mathew tung bad ; 
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jangma-
\ps verb
\de do wrong, do harm, make bad, spoil, ruin, destroy, make a mistake, miss, fail to do, do wrongly or badly, cause to become bad etc, 
\re wrong, do ; harm, do ; bad, make ; spoil ; ruin ; destroy ; mistake, make a ; miss ; fail to do ; wrongly or badly, do something ; become bad, cause to 
\do 
\sf
\co Miss, do badly, literally 'make bad'.
\xv Wa: Jangmani maliyu nabani, wehlu nabani jangmani. 
\xe 'He missed (he threw badly), you (threw it and) missed.'
\xv Wa: Wahlu munah jangmaniwahr 
\xe 'You're wrong.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu jahdjambu jangmani malahni bawur dunganahyu. 
\xe 'The child made her head ache by crying.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju banggilimani bulguni, jangmani. 
\xe 'I shot at a wallaby but missed it.'
\xv Cas: Ye,g, ngaligay gunihnggu jangmani gung.
\xe 'Look out! Mother has made the water dangerous for us.'
\xv Bj: Gibambu nganyi jangmani. 
\xe 'The moon did me wrong or harm.'
\xv Bj: Ngadju banggilimani bulguni, jangmani.
\xe 'I shot a wallaby but it got away.'
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm djangma- , djangmani 
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy djangbim-a, djangm-a, djangmani ; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx janguy 
\ps adjective, noun 
\de angry, quarrelsome, bad-tempered, enemy
\re angry ; quarrelsome ; bad-tempered ; enemy
\do1 senses
\do2 pp
\sf
\co angry Wa, quarrelsom, bad-tempered Gd, from jang 'bad, wicked' Gd. 
\xv Wa: Janguy bahyanibeh munah guruhmbil gehrbinah mahnyulu jahdjambu. 
\xe 'She,g,t angry (her anger emerged) because the children spilt the milk.'
\xv Cas: Janguydjam nyule. 
\xe 'He is good-tempered.'
\xv Cas: Gadji ngali yanah janguydjam.
\xe 'Let's go away peacefully.'
\xv Cas: Ngundalehlabe nguy nyulanngahgu janguygu
\xe 'He's waiting for his enemy.' 
\rfg

\ps verb intransitive - adverb

\do 
\sf
\co Literally 'bad be', do wrongly or badly, be or become bad, etc,; wen- irregular.

\xv Wa: Mala yarbilehla jangun.gahla. 
\xe 'He sings badly.'
\xv Wa: Jangwerwahla nganyah bawur.
\xe 'My head is aching.'

\xe 'My head got dizzy from spinning round.'

\lx jarang 
\ps noun
\de leg (of animal, hind leg), thigh (bone), thigh (or whole leg from hip to foot), claw
\re leg (of animal ; hind leg) ; thigh (bone) ; thigh (or whole leg from hip to foot) ; claw
\do1 bp
\do2 an
\sf
\co Can be used for whole leg, limb or branch of a tree Gd, Wa: thigh, upper leg, confluent river; plural jarangbil; also juruhnbay 'thigh.'; jarang-gir 'drunken person, one unsteady on legs' (probably from 'leg' and English 'drunk'); jarahngbil 'boughs' (arboreal plural) ; derang or jerang listed as 'hips' (Y:Hanlon); also root; also name of a constellation. Cf, jiron ; also branch(es) of a tree, (open palm of the hand, bird's claw, animal's paw, name of a constellation); Ny:Curr:Ballina records gindil, but this is probably 'knee'. See also jilang 'claw'.
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Buhyi jarang nganya bargalehn. 
\xe 'I'm tired, my legs are sore.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm leg , claw , thigh; Y:Holm jarang leg; Y:Allen tharÌ_ng leg (thighbone) , tharung branch of a tree (leg); Y:Watsn dhar'ÌÈng , dher'ang thigh; M:Liv c'errung constellation name ,  palm of hand , paw , claw of bird , branch(es); ; M:Sc:Brunswk terong leg ; AT:Curr:Prior doroo , AT:Curr:LandsWh cherang ,  AT:Curr:JOConn taryung ; GC:Mestn charrang upper leg; Tw:Curr:Bray jurung or terrung, terrung thigh; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray cherrung; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn wyan Y:Hanlon hips kunnim , wahn ,  terrung; Y:Hanlon terrung hips , tcherrung root; 
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Cowln jarang leg; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, djarang; Wi:Lism:Curr tchering; Wi:Curr:Richmd terung; Ny:Curr:Ballina kindle thigh (prob. Knee recorded wrongly) ; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn leg; Cas:Smy djarang, djerang leg; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Calley(?) djer:ang? leg above knee; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce charung thigh , charong branches ; Gn:Mathew tirang thigh ; 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx jarwa-
\ps verb transitive 
\de scrape, carve, trim, sharpen, clean (of fish)
\re scrape ; carve ; trim ; sharpen ; clean (of fish)
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co To scrape something to remove surface or change shape; carve, trim, sharpen, clean (of fish). 
\xv Wa: Mala baygal nguyaymalehla jarwali-nyun mala bargan. 
\xe 'The man is speaking while carving the boomerang'
\xv Wa: Ngadju mala ngayal jarwahla.
\xe 'I'm scraping the,g,ound.'
\xv Wa: Nyang wehlu gumbinymani jarwani bargan?
\xe 'Have you finished making the boomerang?'
\xv Wa: Ngadju bilahr jarwahny.
\xe 'I'll sharpen the spear.'
\xv Wa: Wagany mala ngali jarwahny.
\xe 'We will clean (the scales off) the catfish.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu jarwahny mala jali bilahrmayah. 
\xe 'He will smooth down the wood to make a spear.'

\lx jarwang, jalwang 
\ps noun
\de tullawong, currawong: 
\re tullawong ; currawong
\do bd
\co Black and white bird like a magpie; onomatopoeic (GC:Talleb:police); known as tullawong in Northern Rivers area (from the local word); note Smyth uses final /n/. Jalwang form carried into English as 'tullawong' in the Northern Rivers area and now in Macquarie Dictionary.
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm jalwang , GC:Sc:Talleb cherrawong black and white birds like a magpie GC:police:Talleb cherrawong

\rfk Cas:Smy djarwan ;

\lx jawinywen-, jawunywan- 
\ps verb intransitive 
\de stop (making a noise), become quiet
\re stop (making a noise) ; quiet, become
\do 
\sf
\co From jawiny 'quiet, still'.
\xv Wa: Mala dubay jawinywehn yarbili-nyun. 
\xe 'The woman stopped singing.'
\xv Wa: Mala dubay jawinywenbeh yarbilinyun. 
\xe 'The woman has stopped singing.'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal yehni jawinywenbih mala jahdjam. 
\xe 'The man sat down so the child would be quiet.'
\xv Wa: Malaga jahdjam gahrnga yeni-yendihndi jawinyunbihga mala (djawiny-un .. ). 
\xe 'Carry that child around, so it will be quiet.
\xv Cas: Nyaligur gale buwihyan jawunywan.gahny? 
\xe 'When will this wind stop?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl jawinywan-; Cas:Smy djounjwan-a , djounjwana.gainj
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx jayir(i), jahra
\ps adjective
\de red
\re red
\do cl
\co Dark red Y:Watsn, bright red Y:Allen; possibly a more intense red than gudjin/gudjing. Y:Watsn has gudji ‘light red’; Y:Allen gives gudjin, gudjing ngight red’ (= dark red).Y:Watsn has what seems to be jayir dunggari ‘burning log’. 
\rfg Y:Allen djai-ri bright red; Y:Watsn dhar’ra, dhai’ra, dha’irî dark red 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\xe 'Your sores have disappeared.'

\xe 'He squeezed the sore on his arm.'
\xv Wa: Banydjah mala jigay wurahnggu.
\xe 'Cover the sore with a leaf.' 
\xv Gd: Danggan jigay wehn bugur namaliwahna. 
\xe '(His) hand developed cramp after he had finished hanging onto the rope.'
\xv Cas: Nyan.gana jiyaw jigay-bundahng. 
\xe 'Her eye is badly ulcerated.'
\xv Bj: jigay jambay 
\xe 'sore hand'

\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jigindjay, jiginydjay 
\ps place name

\re Rocky River, name of place along (where a spirit lives) ; name of place along Rocky River where a spirit lives
\do1 loc
\do2 lg
\sf

\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jigini-
\ps interrogative vt-adv
\de do how, do with what, do
\re do how ; do with what ; do
\do 
\sf
\co In some way requires an answer describing the manner of an action; cf, jinggi- which applies to an intransitive action or state. 
\xv Wa: Jiginini wahlu mahny wagany namani? / Jiginini wehlu mahny namani wagany? 
\xe 'How did you catch those catfish?/ What did you catch the catfish with?'
\xv Wa: Jiginehny ngali bumgahny? 
\xe 'How are we,g,ing to kill it?'
\xv Wa: Yagambeh ngadju ganngahla jiginiyah mala mani bumbih 
\xe 'I don't know how to kill a kangaroo'
\xv Wa: Jiginehny galahni wadjehny?
\xe 'How will we tell him?'
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lx jigini-
\ps verb transitive
\de do what, make what
\re do what ; make what
\co
\xv Cas: Jiginehnigur wehlu munah? 
\xe 'What did you do with that? How did you do that?'
\xv Cas: Jiginini wehlu gawgani wangah jambay? 
\xe 'How did you cut your hand?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy djigin-e , djiginÌ©nigur , djigineni
\rfr
\rfo

\lx jinang 
\ps noun
\de foot, feet, handle of implement
\re foot ; feet ; handle of implement
\do1 bp
\do2 art
\sf
\co Smythe also lower leg, also 'thumb, big toe, handle', jinangi acc. (Holmer), plural jinangbil Wa. 
\xv Wa: Yanah ngali burigalingah jinangbu. 
\xe 'Let's go to Pretty Gully on foot.'
\xv Wa: Banggahla ngadju ngayal jinanggu. 
\xe 'I'm stamping the,g,ound with my feet.'
\xv Wa: Jinang nganyah gala bulidjuni mahnyulu gudjandu. 
\xe 'I bumped my feet on the stones.'
\xv Gd: jinang-gubih 
\xe 'shoes'
\xv M:Liv: jahdjamah jinang 
\xe 'a boy's foot'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu ginahny (sic) jinang bandahngu. 
\xe 'I will make a handle for the tomahawk.'
\xv M:Liv: Kaybima junang (sic). 
\xe 'Make another handle.'
\xv Y:Culhm: Mamale dehyu jinanggah 
\xe 'The stone is at/near the foot.'
\xv Bj:Holm: jinang bala 
\xe 'sole of the foot'
\xv Bj:Holm: jinang ngalingah 
\xe 'our feet'
\xv Bj:Holm: jinang bala 
\xe 'sole of foot (lit. Below the feet)'
\xv M:Liv: jahdjamah jinang <taic'uma jennung> 
\xe 'a boys' foot'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu ginahny jinang bandahngu. 
\xe 'I will make a handle for the tomahawk.'
\xv M:Liv: Gaybimah jinang. 
\xe 'Make another handle.' 
\rfg M:Liv jennung; junang handle; M:Sc:Brunswk chinong foot , toes;  Ng:Tw:Curr:Bray chinnung foot; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray chinung; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn chinung ; Y:Sha:Culhm jinang foot , big toe ,  thumb; Y:Holm foot , acc. Jinangi; Y:Allen jenÌ_ng; Y:Watsn foot dhin'Ì_ng , M:Liv jennung , taic'umma jennung a boys' foot ,  junang handle , M:Sc chinong foot , toes , yel yel chinong big toe; AT:Curr:Prior chinang , AT:Curr:LandsWh chinnchinnang ,  Ng:Curr:O'Conn tchenung , GC:Mestn jinno foot; Ne:Curr:Fowl tchinnong , Tw:Curr:Bray chinnung , Tw:Sc:Bray foot chinung ,  Mur:Sc:Martn foot chinung; Y:Hanlon jennung ; 
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Cowln jinang; Bj:Holm djinang; cf, Kattang jina , Th dina; Wi:Lism:Curr tchinnong; Wi:Curr:Richmd chinnung; Ny:Curr:Ballina chinnang; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Cas:Smy djinang foot, lower leg;

\lx jinggi- 
\ps interrogative vi-adv
\de how, do how, do in some way, be how, be in what way
\re how ; do how ; do in some way ; be how ; be in what way
\do 
\sf
\co Be how or in what way; requires an answer describing the manner of an action; cf, jigini- which applies to a transitive action. 
\xv Wa: Jinggehla wudja yunahla mahny wulbili-nyun? 
\xe 'How can you sleep while they're making a noise?'
\xv Wa: Yagambeh ngadju ganngahla jinggiyah ngay yaruhmala. 
\xe 'I don't know how to swim'
\xv Wa: Jinggehn mahny wudjang jahnani gadji?
\xe 'How did the,g,ass grow here?'
\xv Wa: Jinggiwahla wudja? 
\xe 'How are you?' (modern greeting)
\xv Cas: Jinggehn galamani? 
\xe 'How did you get here?'
\xv Cas: Jinggehlabe wudjeh bayahny? 
\xe 'How are you today?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy djingg-e , djinggen , djingge:labe
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 31/Mar/2015

\lx jiya

\de where? 
\re where? 
\do 
\sf
\co

\lx jiyagan 
\ps adverb
\de when?
\re when?
\do 
\sf
\co Holmer saw no difference in meaning between jiya and jiyagan, but other dialects form when by suffixing -gan to where. 
\xv Bj:Holm: Jiyagan bula yan.giwahnybu? 
\xe 'When will you come back again?' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, djijagan 
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 31/Mar/2015

\re where (particular place)
\do 
\sf
\co Corresponds to gadji and gadjungun series. 
\xv Wa: Jiyah mala baygal? 
\xe 'Where is the man?' 
\xv Wu: Jiyahgur wudjeh? 
\xe 'Where-at you (where are you from)?'

\sf

\xv Wa: Mahnyulu bunihnydju nyahla ngalingi jiyawbu. / Mahny bunihny nyahlila ngalingi jiyawbu.
\xe 'The echidnas are watching us with their eyes.'
\xv Cas: Ngadjuwar nyahni nganyahyubu jiyawyubu.
\xe 'I saw it with my own eyes.'
\xv Cas: Burbah jiyawbah mahny junbar.
\xe 'Brush those flies out of your eyes.'

\dt 04/Feb/2015

\lx jubar 
\ps noun
\de witchety grub
\re,g,ub, witchety ; witchety grub 
\do ins
\do 
\sf
\co Large, white, with bluish-tinged rings where segments join, usually found in wattle trees (Wa); grub in wattle (Y:Sha:Culhm) witchetty grub (Y:Holm), also in other dialects, cf, jabam ; witchety grub from wattle tree (edible) (Turnbull), gum tree,g,ub (Gomes).
\xv Wa: Male jubar banydjalahm wan.gahny ngulungmay. 
\xe 'That witchetty will be a butterfly soon.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm jibar (Sharpe thinks jibar is a typo and it should be jubar; Y:Holm:Munro jubar witchety grub ; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl djubar witchety grub from green tree (edible); Bj:TMcD:Gomes jubara gum tree,g,ub 
\rfk Wa:Crowl grub in wattle tree ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Calley ju:ber edible,g,ubs (adjacent to entry jam:ba carpet snake which is yamba) 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx jubar
\ps place name
\de Glen Station
\re Glen Station
\do loc
\co 'Witchety grub.'
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\lx jubuny
\ps noun
\de night, tonight
\re night ; tonight
\do1 ne
\do2 ti
\sf
\co jubuny-djah-bu 'morning' (daybreak to noon) (Gd). 
\xv Wa: Mala yalgan bahn.gala numgir mala-ngu gibam jubunydja. 
\xe 'The sun comes out in the day and then the moon comes out at night.'
\xv Wa: Ngali guram yabur guram bulahbu jubuny yunahny. 
\xe 'We would camp for one or two nights.'
\xv Wa: Munah nyabay baygaywen.gahn jubunydja.
\xe 'The water froze overnight.' 
\rfg
\rfb Wi:Smy djubunj (Wi:abal) ; Bj:Holm djubun tonight
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce choboin night ; 
\rfo
\dt 31/Mar/2015

\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm juga; Y:Allen jogala gullet , v. Pr jogar, p jogarni , pf jogarlian , f jogarla; Y:Watsn dhÌ«g'ala gullet , v. DhÌ«g'Ì¢r; dhÌ«gÌ¢rnÌ¨; dhÌ«'garlian; dhÌ«'gÌ¢rla swallow; M:Liv c'ukka drink; Ne:Curr:Fowl tchienda drink; Tw:Curr:Bray tchoar drink; Y:Hanlon tchoogar drink

\dt 31/Mar/2015

\lx juga- 
\ps verb intransitive 
\de have intercourse, have coition, drink 
\re intercourse, have ; coition, have ; drink
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Literally 'to drink' ; Wi:Lism:Curr form probably fut. Jugahny; jugalehla 'drink' (Wi:Curr:Richmd); M:liv form suggests jaga-; juwa- listed in Ng, possibly just a very soft /g/, but possibly lenited to /w/.
\xv Bj:Holm: Jugah wahlu. 
\xe 'You drink it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Mabehrbu jugalehla.
\xe 'They all drink.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Jugalehla gabing. 
\xe '(They are) drinking water.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Gila jugalihgu yan.gehn. 
\xe 'He went for a drink.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: jugalihgu
\xe 'bucket, drinking vessel etc,'
\xv Bj:Holm: Jugalihgi. 
\xe '(He) wants to drink, is thirsty.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: jugaliyan 
\xe 'having a drink, if you have a drink'
\xv Bj:Holm: jugalihya yugumbe 
\xe 'nothing to drink' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay jugalur. 
\xe 'I used to drink.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Bugal mala jugalihgu. 
\xe 'That's good to drink' 
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Bahn.galehla mamala jugaligal. 
\xe 'He is sneaking drink.' 
\rfg M:Liv c'ukka
\rfb Bj:Hom:Turnbl djuga- have intercourse; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, djuga-, juga, djugalila, djugaligu, djugaligi, djugalijan, djugaliya, djugalur; Bj:Holm:Turnbl djuga- have intercourse; Wi:Lism:Curr chookyan drink; Wi:Curr:Richmd toka/aila drink; Ny:Curr:Ballina thuguong drink (prob. Imminent form jugahyn)
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx juga-
\ps transitive verb
\de drink 
\re drink
\do bp
\co
\xv Wa: Ngadju jugahla nyabay / Ngay jugalehla nyabay 
\xe 'I'm drinking water'
\xv Wa: Jang jugali-nyun 
\xe 'It's bad to drink.'
\xv Wa: Jugah wehlu! 
\xe 'Drink something!'
\xv Wa: Jugalimah wehlu mala jahdjam.
\xe 'Give the baby something to drink.'
\xv Wa: Ngay gala jugalihgi nyabay.
\xe 'I want a drink of water.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu wihnyi gahngani jugalimayah. 
\xe 'He led you to drink.'
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl, We:Gordn jugalehla drinking
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\co Sad, as when speaking of friends who have left. Gd, Cas, Wa have word gidjir/gidjir/gidjahr, possibly variants if angay in the Y:Hanlon form is taken to be -an.ga-. 
\rfg Ydict juhrdhirangay; Y:Hanlon tchoor-tcheerungai 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx julba-
\ps verb
\de jump, spring
\re jump ; spring
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Allen, Y:Watsn forms are julba- + -li antipassive/continuous, or possibly juhlba- + -li-; cf, dalba-; Y:Hanlon has julwa-; see also julbanga- and dulba-; bahm julba-, ngaring julba- 'to butt into conversation'.
\xv Gd: Male yaraman julbandehn.
\xe 'That horse bucked.' 
\xv Cas: Nyule julbani bunbahri. 
\xe 'He jumped over the log.' 
\rfg Y:Allen pr jÌÈlbalei , p julbalen , pf julbalian , f julbala jump (spring); Y:Watsn dhÌÈl'balÌ»; dhÌÈlbalen; dhÌÈ'lalian; dhÌÈlbÌ¢la jump or spring; M:Liv dulbangga- jump

\lx juluhn
\ps noun

\re Common Grass Skink ; Skink, Common Grass ; frilled lizard (?) (Ym) ; lizard, frilled (?) (Ym) ; lizard ; small house lizard ; lizard, small house
\do rep
\do 
\sf Leiolopisma guichenoti
\co Also Copper-tailed Skink (Sphenomorphus taeniolatus); (juluhn 'frilled lizard') probably 'little house lizard', see juluny, juhlam, Gd has juluhn 'Common Grass Skink', or 'Copper-tailed Skink'; (juluhn 'small house lizard') cf, juluhn, julahm.
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm juluhn frilled (?) lizard, juluny little house lizard; Y:Watsn dhulum, dhungon; Mur:Sc:Hargrv jiloon lizard; Ngr:Gresty taloon little house lizard; Ng:Sc:Cudgn chuloow lizard; GC:Nerang:police talloom; Ngr:Sc:Nerang talloom a lizard; Y:Hanlon tchooloon small lizard ; Y:Sha:Culhm; Ng:Sc:Cudgn chuloow lizard; Ng:Sc:Mur jiloon lizard; Ng:Sc:Cudgn chuloow lizard

\lx juluh-, duluh- 
\ps verb
\de downwards
\re downwards
\do 
\sf
\co Form and meaning extracted from juluhgal, duluhwa-, q.v.; it is a root attested in other dialects and in song (the Dunoon Boxer song): juluhya- 'go downwards (Gd, Cas), juluhmalehla ludjangi 'looking down on the loser', and duloa 'go down' (M:Liv). See duluhwa-, juluhgal.
\xv 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx jumgan
\ps noun
\de ocean
\re ocean
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co One of five Bundjalung names for landscape features near Fingal; dumgan 'waves' more probable.

\rfk

\do

Conspicallatus); M:Mestn joongurra; Ngr:Gresty choongarra; Ng:Sc:Mur+ 5/00 choon-gurra-carra-nar-inden-arn the whole name signifies 'the pelican corroboree,g,ound:; from choon-gurra , a pelican. It is the name of a flat-topped hill close to Boyd's Bay , Tweed Heads , and now known as Observatory Hill; Ng:Sc:Cudgn chungarah; Tw:Curr:Bray chungera; AT:Curr:Prior tangara , AT:Curr:JOConn juugara (prob. Jungara misread); Mur:Sc:Hargrvjungera; Ne:Curr:Fowltchungarry; GC:Mestn chungurra; Y:Hanlon tchoongurra

\lx junygan, junygun
\ps noun
\de sky, cloud 
\re sky ; cloud 
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co But cf, junygun, Gd has jun.gun 'cloud', possibly junygan and junygun are the same, Y:Sha:Culhm junygun, Gn possibly juhgan. Cf. Junygan; possibly same word. Gd has jun.gun; GC:Coomera:police form could be for junygany, and GC:Sc:Coomera a misreading of the same original.
\rfg Ng:Tw:Curr:Bray toongoon cloud; Y:Hanlon tchoonagun ; Y:Sha:Culhm junygun; Y:Allen jungun; Y:Watsn dhung'Ì_n, dhun'gun; Tw:Curr:Bray toongoon; GC:Sc:Coomera funguus clouds; GC:Coomera:police funguns; Y:Hanlon tchoongun; 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gn:Mathew dhokan cloud, dhakam rain

\lx jurbihl 
\ps adjective 
\de totem spirit-being (Gd), familiar spirit, spirit being (Cowln)
\re totem spirit-being (Gd) ; spirit, familiar ; spirit being (Cowln)
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Clever, also listed as 'bad place - evil' (Wu), any place with strong mythical associations (Wa), cave (Holm:Turnbl); Turnbull's probably sacred place as generally in the language, not necessarily a cave.
\xv Bj:Holm:Turnbl: Jurbihl burani. 
\xe '(He) opened the cave.'
\rfg
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Cowln jurbhihl spirit being; Bj:Hom:Turnbl djurbi:l cave
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy djurbi:l familiar spirit; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Calley djurbil bad place - evil , clever ; 
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx juwa-
\ps verb
\de drink
\re drink
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Yugambeh uses ja- 'eat' for 'drink'; southern and inland dialects use juga- 'to drink', while Yugambeh uses juga- for 'to swallow'; juwa- has 'lightened' the /g/ to /w/. 
\rfg Ng:Tw:Curr:Bray tchoar to drink 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx juwan 
\ps noun
\de spear, war-spear, two-piece spear
\re spear ; war-spear ; two-piece spear
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Interpreted from more common form elsewhere, cf, bilahr, Curr lists as 'war-spear'; also garfish (Y:Watsn), long-tom fish (Y:Hanlon) 'from its hastate build' (the scientific name belone means 'spear, dart') (Y:Hanlon), Gn lists as wooden spear. 
\xv M:Liv: ngandurnah juwan 
\xe 'some spear, somebody's spear'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu juwan ginahny jabugay biyanggay ngeringgay. 
\xe 'I will make spears for both the boy and the father.' 
\xv M:Liv: Ngayabaya juwan.
\xe 'I have a spear.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngayu nyahny juwan buwahnyi.
\xe 'I will see (one who) will throw a spear.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Yili nganyah juwan? 
\xe 'Where is my spear?'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Niyay bula juwan.
\xe 'Give me two spears.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Dalbani juwandu. 
\xe 'He speared (it).'
\xv Bj:Holm: Juwandu bumgahny. 
\xe '(He) will spear (it)' 
\xv M: Ngayu juwan ginahny jabugay biyanggay ngeringgay. 
\xe 'I will make spears for both the boy and the father.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm spear; Y:Holm juan (djuwan), e,g, juandu (Fogty, Logn); Y:Allen joan spear; Y:Watsn dhÌ«an spear, garfish; M:Liv c'uan; Mur:Sc:Hargrv juan spear; AT:Curr:Prior duan; AT:Curr:LandsWh toowan; AT:Curr:JOConn joan; Tw:Curr:Bray jurne, chu-un; GC:Coomera:police tuan; Y:Hanlon juan any spear, long-tom fish; M:Liv c'uan; Ng:Tw:Curr:Bray jurne , chu-un spear; Ng:Sc:Mur juan spear
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl djuwan; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, djuwan, djuwandu; Wi:Lism:Curr tchuan war-spear; Wi:Curr:Richmd tawung or tewang war-spear; Bj:Sc:Coraki tchowen spear; Ny:Curr:Ballina chuang war spear; Ny:Ballina:Sc3 chuon spear; 
\rfk Cas:Smy djuwan 
\rfr Gd:Geyt spear; Gn:Mathew tyuan wooden spear ; 
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx juwi, juy 
\ps locative 
\de down
\re down
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Can indicate that an action was performed downwards; listed as juy (Gd). 
\xv Wa: Juwi ge,g,ny bulang malahgu mundugu. 
\xe 'The meat will go down into my stomach'; 
\xv Wa: Mala ngulahr juwi ge,g,n ngabarwehn.
\xe 'The flood went down quickly.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce jui-e down creek 
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx juy
\ps locative 
\de down, downwards, below, into
\re downwards ; down ; below ; into
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co juhya loc case 'down, below, down there'; Holmer also lists juhyan.gahl 'where it downs, is down'; juyah loc case; junu probably 'from' (Livingstone).
\xv Cas: Ngay gilah juy. 
\xe 'I'm going down there.' 
\xv Cas: Bunbahr guyuwalehn gilah juy.
\xe 'The log rolled down (the hill).'
\xv M:Liv: Gili juy waybana.
\xe 'The camp is below.' 
\rfg M:Liv below juy, juy, jua, junno down, into
\rfb Bj:Hom:Turnbl djui; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, dju:ja down, below, down there; Bj:Hom:Turnbl dju:jangal where it downs, is down; 
\rfk Cas:Smy djui ; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\ps locative

\re bottom ; lower down ; in ; inside

\sf
\co
\xv Cas: Gale yagam bagar juygundahy. 
\xe 'This isn't too steep.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy djuigundÌÁi
\rfr

\lx juy, juwi
\ps locative 
\de down, below, into
\re down ; below ; into
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Also 'east, eastward, sloping downward', probably because towards the coast; juyah loc case; junu probably 'from below'.
\xv M:Liv: Gili juy waybana. 
\xe 'The camp is below.' 
\rfg Y:Allen djui east , down (i.e. Sloping seaward); Y:Watsn dhu'-Ì¨ down , under (usually given meaning 'down') , east(ward); M:Liv juy below; juy , jua , junno into , down; Y:Hanlon tchoo-ee below

\rfk

\lx -leh
\ps suffix 
\de imperative: repetitive or continuous
\re imperative (repetitive, reflexive or continuous) 
\do 
\sf
\co Continuous/antipassive -li + imperative -h; shortened to -le after a preceding long vowel. 
\rfg all
\rfb all
\rfk all 
\rfr all
\rfo all
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx -lehla
\ps suffix 
\de progressive
\re progressive
\do 
\sf
\co Antipassive/progressive -li + present tense -hla; if long syllable preceding, takes form -lelah (Gd) or -lela (Wa). 
\rfg all
\rfb all
\rfk all
\rfr all
\rfo all

\rfg all
\rfb all
\rfk all 
\rfr all
\rfo all
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx -li, -le
\ps suffix 
\de reflexive, antipassive
\re reflexive ; antipassive
\do 
\sf
\co Basically a reflexive-reciprocal suffix in Wa; also 'antipassive', i.e. the subject of a transitive verb with this suffix is not marked for e,g,tive case (Wa, Gd); vowel /i/ changes to /e/ before an aspect suffix with vowel le,g,h (-hla, etc,); a variant -ri attested by Livingstone; see Grammar Notes. 
\xv Y:Holm: Burbalehn diranggir. 
\xe '(They) hid themselves in a (hollow) log.’
\xv Wa: Mahny dubay bamalehn banyargandu. 
\xe 'The women rubbed each other with fat.'
\xv Wa: Buhwilehn nyula nyabaydja munah. 
\xe 'He pulled himself out of the water.'
\xv Wa: Nyahli wudja madji nyabaydja. 
\xe 'Look at yourself in the water'
\xv Wa: Ngay galgalehn nganyibu. 
\xe 'I cut myself.'
\xv Wa: Mahny bulahbu dabahy yingalehla nyulamangibu. 
\xe 'Those two dogs are biting each other.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Holm
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; 
\rfr 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx -li, -le
\ps suffix
\de continuous, repetitive
\re continuous, repetitive
\co Also antipassive, see,g,ammar, changes from -li to -le before -hla, -hn, -hny, -h.
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx -li(h) 
\ps suffix 
\de nominaliser
\re nominaliser
\do 
\sf
\co Makes participle (go - going, etc,); -li may precede -yah 'to' (infinitive), -h-gu 'for .. -ing'. 
\xv Wa: gandjiliyah 
\xe 'to get married'
\xv Wa: duwalihgu 
\xe 'spade' (for digging) 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\sf
\co See,g,ammar section.

\rfb

\xe 'is doing it well'

\xe 'He is running well.'

\xe 'I dried them.'

\xe 'He made the dog angry.' 
\xv Gd: gurgun malehla
\xe 'is speaking' 
\xv Gd: yaruhm malehla 
\xe 'is swimming.'
\xv Gd: Madji mah male. 
\xe 'Put it down there!'

\lx -ma
\ps suffix 
\de in
\re in
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Rare noun suffix, but with meaning 'in' when used, 'long' form with life nouns -bahma. 
\xv M:Liv: Wahlu dalbangga balunma! 
\xe 'You jump in the river!'
\xv M:Liv: Wahre baygalbahma gunu. 
\xe 'Carry this with the man.' 
\rfg M:Liv ma , baima
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx -ma 
\ps suffix 
\de do, make, make to do something, cause to be or do, causative
\re do ; make ; make to do something ; cause to be or do ; causative
\do 
\sf
\co Suffixed to verb stems, can only be added to an intransitive verb, makes a transitive verb, so any transitive stem must have -li before -ma. 
\xv Cas: galgirma- 
\xe 'build a canoe, build canoes'
\xv Cas: bugalma- 
\xe 'make,g,od, cure, improve'
\xv Cas: jangma- 
\xe 'make bad, spoil, ruin'
\xv Cas: waybarma- 
\xe 'make camp, build fire'
\xv Cas: janbihnyma- 
\xe 'make,g,, send'
\xv Cas: jabihnyma- 
\xe 'make eat, feed'
\xv Cas: jamgalma- 
\xe 'make quick hasten'
\xv Cas: yunama- 
\xe 'make lie, put'
\xv Cas: jahnama- 
\xe 'make stand, put'
\xv Cas: maruganma- 
\xe 'make an initiate, initiate'
\xv Cas: wayma- 
\xe 'cause to be up, put up'
\xv Bj:Holm: yunama- 
\xe 'make lie down'
\xv Bj: gilama- 
\xe 'go there'
\xv Bj: wahngma- 
\xe 'to work'
\xv Bj: jangma- 
\xe 'do wrong'
\xv Bj: nguyayma-, nguyma- 
\xe 'to talk'
\xv Bj: behngguma
\xe 'put into a bag'
\xv Bj: dalangguma- 
\xe 'to paint'
\xv Gd: Mahdja nyule,g, galgalimahn jali. 
\xe 'The boss was making him chop down trees.'
\xv Gd: Nyuleyu jabuh bandjalimaliwahla. 
\xe 'He is (definitely) making the boy cover (the holes).'
\xv We: Jugalimah wehlu mala jahdjam. 
\xe 'Give the baby somethng to drink.' 
\xv Wa: Maliyu baygalu galanmahla mala wagar. 
\xe 'The man is sharpening the axe.'
\xv Y:Holm:Fogty: damburma- 
\xe 'fill up (e,g, with drink)
\xv Y:Holm: gurgunma- 
\xe 'talk'
\xv Y:Holm: buyma- 
\xe 'bother' (lit. 'make tired)'
\xv Y:Holm: wungandjarima- 
\xe 'turn (something) round'
\xv Y:Holm: bugalma- 
\xe 'cure (make,g,od or well)'
\xv Y:Holm: nyariba- 
\xe 'name'. 
\rfg Y:Holm ; Y:Holm ; M:Liv ma make, cause, cause to be there 
\rfb Bj:Holm ma-, imp. Ma:, term. Mani 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Crowl; Cas:Smy -m-a 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo

\lx madji-

\lx madjir
\ps noun

\re mud, sticky ; diarrhoea

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx madjirbah, madjarbah
\ps place name
\de Mudgeeraba
\re Mudgeeraba
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Ge,g,aphically it is (or was) a boggy place, and it was reputed to be a place of a historical massacre (Y:Kombum:YBest). Children were told not to go there (Y:Kombum:YBest). Two meanings given: 'place of child's shit or diarrhoea', or Y:Allen; 'lying ground' (Y:Allen, GC:Nerang:police, GC:Talleb:police, GC:Nerang:Sc), 'place where somene told lies', Hanlon says place where someone told lies and states 'probably an historic tarradiddle' - he could not find its origin, however its bogginess and the first meaning appear to agree. 
\rfg Y:Holm:Jackie madjar liar , madjar(i)ba name of a place (Jackie); Y:Allen Mudgeriba place of infants' excrement; GC:Nerang:police , GC:Talleb:Sc , GC:Talleb:police mudgeraba lying ground , GC:Nerang:Sc mudjuraba lying ground; Y:Hanln locnm Mudgeerabah 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx madjir-madjir
\ps noun
\de diarrhoea
\re diarrhoea
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co See madjir; 'sticky-sticky', literally 'a dirty sticky mess' (Y:Watsn); Mudgeriba 'place of infants' excrement' (Y:Allen).
\rfg Y:Allen mujerri-majiri , Mudgeriba place of infants' excrement; Y:Watsn mut'dherri mut'dherri diarrhoea 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx mahnyu, mahny, mamahny, mamahnyu
\ps demonstrative 
\de those close to hearer (visible), those (visible), those near, they
\re those close to hearer (visible) ; those (visible) ; those near ; they
\do 
\sf
\co Some forms differ for human and non-human (Wa); cf, gahnyu, gahmu, mahnyuni acc., mahnyungah possess.
\xv We: Mahnyulu gulgih.
\xe 'Those there did it.' 
\xv Gd: Mahnyu jahdjam ganggalehn. 
\xe 'Those children were calling out.'
\xv Gd: Mahnyulu bulah gahdjalehn.
\xe 'Those chased the cattle.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamahny mundjah. 
\xe 'Those (kids) are naked.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: mamahny jahdjam 
\xe 'those/the kids'
\xv Bj:Morgn?: Mahnyu wahngmalehla. 
\xe 'They are working.'
\xv Bj:Morgn?: Nyanggur mahnyu? 
\xe 'What are they?' 
\xv Bj:Morgn?: Jahdjam mahnyu ngahrilah.
\xe 'The children are playing.' 
\xv Bj:Morgn?: mamahnyu dumgan 
\xe 'the waves'
\xv Bj:Morgn?: Gidjuhnygam mamahnyu dubay.
\xe 'Those women are big.'
\xv Bj:Morgn?: mamahnyu buruhr buyuhny 
\xe 'those two giants'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm mamahny plural; M:Liv muå¡nyo , sometimes muå¡n this , this here plural ; 
\rfb Bj:Morgn mahnyu those (near); Bj:Holm:Fe,g, manu , mamanu;
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\lx mala
\ps demonstrative

\do 
\sf

\xe 'The dog got annoyed with the boy for taking his bone.'

\xe 'He will hit her.'
\xv Wa: Yehna malahya.
\xe 'Stay with him.'

\lx mala, mamala, male (Wi), mali, mamali, male etc, (M)
\ps demonstrative 
\de that (one), he, there
\re that (one) ; he ; there
\do 
\sf
\co Predicate form mali, mamali, male, mamale (M); acc. Malanyi (M).
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: nyamul mala 
\xe 'that child'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: malahna dubayngah nyamul 
\xe 'that woman's child'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: mamala nguyay 
\xe 'the language, that language'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Bugal malajugalihgu. 
\xe 'That's good to drink' 
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Banygalehla mamala jugaligal. 
\xe 'He (that one) is sneaking drink.' 
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Bumani malahni.
\xe '(He) killed him.'
\xv Bj:Holm Jagalehla ngay malagay. 
\xe 'I am sending to him.'
\xv M: malanyi bayganyi 
\xe 'that man (acc.)'
\xv M: malahyu 
\xe 'he-e,g, 
\rfg M:Liv mully , - (m) , mulla-na-gun (j) , - (n) , monno (arb); there mully , muå¡-mully , mullai , muå¡-mullai; mullanye paigannye that man (acc.) , mullaio he e,g,; Mg:Sc:TweedR:Bray nulle that ,  these; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn mulle that , these , those
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl mala that , there; Bj:Morgn male that (near); Bj:Holm:Fe,g, mala , malagai for him ; 
\rfk
\rfr

\lx male, mala, mali 
\ps demonstrative 
\de that near, in sight of the speaker (Gd), that close, near hearer, visible (Wa)
\re that near (Gd) ; in sight of the speaker (Gd) ; that close, near hearer, visible (Wa)
\do 
\sf
\co Some case forms differ for human and non-human Wa, cf, gale, gile Gd, male (final /e/ in Gd). 
\xv Wa: Maliyu guybahla bulang gahmgu ngaringgahgu. 
\xe 'He (who I can see) is cooking some meat for those men across there (who I can see).'
\xv Wa: Munah dabahy janguywehn malahgaya janagan-gahya gahnganah mala darigan.
\xe 'The dog got annoyed with the boy for taking his bone.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu malahni bumgahny. 
\xe 'He will hit her.'
\xv Wa: Yehna malahya.
\xe 'Stay with him.' 
\xv Gd: Gale baygal namani male mugim. 
\xe 'This man grabbed that axe.'
\xv Gd: Malahyu baygalu galgani gile jali.
\xe 'That man chopped down that tree.'
\xv Gd: Maliyu baygal gahdjalehn gilahni jahdjami. 
\xe 'That man was chasing that child.'
\xv Gd: Malahna mahmanggu bugal-mani ngadjah. 
\xe 'That one's father fixed it for me.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl mala; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv mull-e; Wa:Crowl mala; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt male ; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng mullah thou 
\rfo

\lx mali/male, mamali, male, etc,
\ps demonstrative 
\de that there
\re that there
\do 
\sf
\co 'That (visible), there (indicating a position not far off)' (Y:Watsn); predicate form mali, mamali, male, mamale ; acc. Malanyi, Y:Holm contrasts gali 'this, here', gahmu 'those, gila (kili) 'this' or 'here',  'that' or 'there', malagu 'there, thither'. 
\xv M:Liv: malanyi bayganyi
\xe 'that man (acc.)' 
\xv M:Liv: malahyu
\xe 'he-e,g,'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: gilagu malagu
\xe 'here and there'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Male minyang? 
\xe 'What's that?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamali wahlu? 
\xe 'Are you there?'/Is that you?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Galgahla jabuyu jali mali. 
\xe 'The boy is chopping a tree up there/that tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamali jabu galgahla jali. 
\xe 'The boy will cut the tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamali nyule bugal. 
\xe 'He is expert (good).' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm mali/male; Y:Holm mali this , here , this is, here is, etc,; Y:Holm:Logn malagu; Y:Allen mulli there (not very far off) ,  mamulli there (close); Y:Watsn mÌÈl'li , mam'illi there indicating a position not far off; M:Liv mully , - (m) , mulla-na-gun (j) , - (n) ,  monno (arb); there mully , muå¡-mully , mullai , muå¡mullai; mullanye paigannye that man (acc.) , mullaio he e,g, 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 27/Apr/2015

\dt 03/Mar/2015

\lx manaldjahli
\ps place name
\de Beaudesert
\re Beaudesert
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Manaljahli: Culham gave meaning of 'hard, baked ground', locality group of the Yugambeh situated about Beaudesert, Holmer lists manandjali, malandjali, manaldjali as 1. The name of the Manandjali language, the 'Beaudesert language' or 'Logan river language' (Y:Holm:Curry), 2. Beaudesert (Y:Holm:Fogty). Cf, manal.
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu Manaldjahli, ngay waymalehla manaldjahli.
\xe 'I'm Manaldjahli, I speak Manaldjahli.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu manaldjahli, nganyah jagun mana. 
\xe 'I'm Manaldjahli, my country is hard baked.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm manal , manaljahli , yilbagan Beaudesert 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 01/Apr/2015

\xe 'I am scratching.'
