\lx -mang
\ps suffix 
\de plural
\re plural
\do 
\sf
\co On some nouns, e,g, yaramandjin, yaraman.gin, yaraman-mang 'some horses', jabumang 'lots of boys', jabunmang, jabundjin 'lots of girls'. Geytenbeek lists as plural suffix for jabuh 'boy' and jabun 'girl'. 
\rfg Y:Holm 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo

\lx mani
\ps noun
\de kangaroo (generic), wallaby 
\re kangaroo (generic) ; wallaby 
\do an
\do 
\sf Macropus gigantea (Y:Watsn)
\co Generic; plural mani-ngehn or mani-garah (Gd), Gummow (gamaw) for females only (Y:Hanln), Ngr:Gresty lists as 'paddymelon', Ny spelling suggests muni. 
\xv Wa: Mala mani yehn.gala nguhnmalehla guwanggu malahni bumanah. 
\xe 'The kangaroo is sitting there warming himself because he,g,t caught in the rain.'
\xv Wa: Gahba ngali yulany burani maniya.
\xe 'We skinned that kangaroo.'
\xv Wa: Wulawulanibeh ngali mala mani.
\xe 'We shared the kangaroo around.'
\xv Gd: Yaway yan.gahndu gabalgu manigu. 
\xe 'We used to go to the scrub for wallaby.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Maniyu jahni. 
\xe 'The wallaby ate it.' 
\rfg Y:Holm wallaby (Fogty); Y:Allen muni; Y:Watsn mun'i kangaroo (generic) (M. Gigantea); kangaroo: AT:Curr:Prior ,  AT:Curr:LandsWh munni kangaroo; ATjo money kangaroo; Y:Beaudst:Sc , Y:Beaudst:police maree (prob. Manee misread) kangaroo; Ngr:Gresty munnee paddymelon; Y:Hanln munee ,  munnee kangaroo ; 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Turnbl mani , maniju; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 moonie kangaroo;; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 moeniur kangaroo rat 
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr Gd:Geyt
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx manyeh, manyih
\ps demonstrative 
\de those known or presumed near, not in sight of the speaker
\re those known or presumed near, not in sight of the speaker
\do 
\sf
\co Crowley adds 'not there before', cf, ganyeh, gahnye.

\xe 'Those old men told me that.' 
\xv Wa: Ganngah manyihni yarbilehla bagarah burambah nguhmbinydjah. 
\xe 'Listen to those singing behind the house out there (and who I haven't seen yet).'

\lx man.gar 
\ps noun
\de blue,g,m, gum
\re blue,g,m ; gum, blue (tree) ; gum
\do pl
\do 
\sf Eucalyptus tereticornis 
\co See also 'gum tree'; specifically 'blue,g,m' in some lists associated with Y:Beaudst:police, Y:Beaudst:Sc, GC:Coomera:Sc; note man.gar 'gum tree' in some dialects, man.gur 'resin' in some dialects, Y:Holm gum tree, 'koala gum tree' (Y:Holm:Curry), cf, mangar and man.gur 'resin, gum, edible sap' (Gd, Wa). 
\xv Y:Holm:Fogty: gamay man.gar(a) 
\xe 'a big gum tree'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm mangar; Y:Holm:Fogty, Paulsn; Y:Allen mungera; Y:Watsn mun'gara (E. Tereticornis); Mur:Sc5 Mungurrabah white gum , mungurra a gum tree; GC:Nerang:police mungara; Y:Beaudst:police mungarra , Y:Beaudst:Sc mungarra gum tree; Cudgen:Sc mungarah gum tree; GC:Coomera:Sc mungara; GC:Nerang:Sc blue,g,m tree mungara; Y:Hanln mungurra gumtree , bluegum; Y:Hanln mun-gurra gum (tree?) 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gn:Mathew mangar gumtree ;
\rfo

\lx marun 
\ps noun
\de,g,anna species, Mt Maroon, goanna, sand goanna 
\re,g,anna species ; Mt Maroon ; goanna ; sand goanna
\do1 rep
\do2 lg
\do3 loc
\sf
\co Ground or burrowing goanna (those that dig in the,g,ound) (Y:Hanln), sand goanna (Y:Sha), Mt Maroon (Y:Holm), a giant goanna which features in a myth from Beaudesert - in death turned to stone (as was a giant fresh water turtle also) to form mountains in the Great Dividing Range (M:Fingl:Jordan); listed as 'sand', but position in list shows it must be 'sand goanna' (Gn).
\rfg Y:Holm 1. Sand goanna , 2. Mt Maroon (Curry) , cf, murum; Y:Allen maron ground iguana; Y:Watsn mÌ¢r'ÌÈn ground or burrowing iguana; M:Fingl Maroon goanna; Y:Hanln marroon iguana; M:Fingl:Jordn maroon 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gn:Mathew marun sand (presumably sand goanna from position in list following tree,g,anna); Gn:JMathew marun 
\rfo

\lx mayah
\ps demonstrative 
\de that invisible, not there before (Wa)
\re that invisible (not there before (Wa))
\do 
\sf
\co Previously near, known or presumed moved since last seen by the speaker (Gd), cf, gayah, gahya; mayahgan (with time suffix) is a temporal demonstrative.
\xv Gd: Yindje,g,nggehn mayah jabuh walany wehni. 
\xe 'What happened to that boy who was lost?'
\xv Gd: Mahmang-ngehndu mayah gabal galgadjahn mayahgan. 
\xe 'Our fathers chopped down that scrub at that time.'
\xv Gd: Mayah galahdjar. 
\xe 'That one was exactly like this one.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo

\lx mayu
\ps demonstrative 
\de that near hearer (out of sight), that, there(?)
\re that near hearer (out of sight) ; that, there(?)
\do 
\sf
\co General area, not in sight of speaker, not present before, Geytenbeek states in context of other than present time, cf, gayah, gahya. 
\xv Gd: Wudjang daram mayu. 
\xe 'The,g,ass is dry there.'
\xv Gd: wir wir mayungahnu ngagamu 
\xe 'a flea from somebody's dog' 
\xv Gd: Mayulu baygalu galgadjahn wanyi.
\xe 'Some man chopped it down perhaps.'
\xv Gd: Maye yawahr ngahriny ngubuh.
\xe 'We will dance a corroboree there tomorrow.' 
\xv Wa: Wirgahla mayu nyang. 
\xe 'He (the clever feller) steals things.'
\xv Wa: Mayu-mayu nyang nganydja darehrbelehla?
\xe 'What is that thing rattling up there?'
\xv Wa: Mayu-mayu ngihn badjilehla?
\xe 'Who is that knocking?' (where the person can't be seen but the noise can be heard)
\xv Cas: Yunamah mayu bilahr jadjehyburi ngayali. 
\xe 'Put that spear near the,g,ound.'
\xv Cas: Nyah wangah mayu ngahmar ngayala.
\xe 'Look at your axe on the,g,ound.'
\xv Cas: Nyang wehlu nyahla mayuni wehlu gurihbu nyahnyun?
\xe 'Do you see anyone you knew before?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl , Cas:Smy maiju , maijuni
\rfr Gd:Geyt ;

\lx mibiny
\ps noun
\de Aboriginal man, person, face, know (Wi), Aboriginal(s) (M)
\re Aboriginal man ; person ; face ; know (Wi) ; Aboriginal(s) (M)
\do1 pp
\do2 bp
\sf
\co See also mibiny, primary meaning appears to be 'face' (Gd); 'Aboriginal man' in Yugambeh and Minyangbal, mibiny is 'Aboriginal man' in northern dialects, face in Wa, and 'person, face' in Gd;  Y:Watsn form suggests mibany 'Aborigine, male, elder'; cf, baygal, also attested; jinaba given by AT:Curr:LandsWh probably 'they'; mibinygir 'some or many dark people' (Y:Holm:Logn), mibingirni (acc.), mibinygirna (gen.) (Y:Holm), GC:Nerang:police lists mibiny (mebbon) as 'drowned man', probably 'Aboriginal man', not 'drowned'.
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Jagun gali mibinyal.
\xe 'This land belongs to the dark people.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: mibinyba
\xe 'to the dark men'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mibinydju giyehni jabungi galgayah jali.
\xe 'The man told the boy to chop the tree.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamale,g,magay/bidjanggalang jalgany.
\xe 'That woman is big/small.'
\xv M:Sc: yabur mibiny 
\xe 'a black man'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Windjigu(n) mibiny wamginy? 
\xe 'When will the blacks come here?'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngulungmay wamginy mibiny gamay. 
\xe 'By-and-by plenty Blacks will come.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay mibiny. 
\xe 'I know.' 
\xv Bj: Mibiny ngay malahni. 
\xe 'I know him.'
\xv Bj: Ngay yugambe mibiny-wehn. 
\xe 'I did not know.'
\xv M:Liv: yabur mibiny 
\xe 'one Aboriginal man.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm mibiny Aboriginal man; Y:Holm man (Curry , Logn) , dark man , black fellow , dark people (Logn); Y:Allen maibin aborigine; Y:Watsn mÌ¨'bÌ_n; M:Sc mebbin the blacks , yaberie me,g,n a black man; Tw:Curr:Bray mibbin; Tw:Sc:Bray mebbin man; Mur:Sc:Martn bibbin man (prob. Misprint); f maivin man; Cudgn:Sc:Evans meebeen man; AT:Curr:Prior mibin , bigall; AT:Curr:LandsWh chinaba; AT:Curr:JO'Conn mebing; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr , GC:Mestn mibbin man; GC:Coomera:Sc mebbon man; GC:Coomera:police mebbon drowned mall; Y:Hanln meebin; Y:Hanln bargul and mibbinmen man (sic , prob. Baygal and mibiny 'men') ; M:Sc:Brunswk mebbin the blacks; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray mebbin man; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn bibbin man 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, mibiÌ±, poss. From *mi 'eye' (cf, Dhanggati mi:) and -biÌ±; Bj:Holm:Fergn mibin; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl face; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt face, person, know; 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx midjin 
\ps noun
\de palm tree ('midjim'), midjin cane, bangalow (Tw:Sc:Bray), walking stick palm (Ngr:Gresty), fruit of the midgeon palm
\re palm tree ('midjim') ; midjin cane ; bangalow (Tw:Sc:Bray) ; walking stick palm (Ngr:Gresty) ; fruit of the midgeon palm
\do pl
\do 
\sf
\co In Bray's day 'a great number of the midgeon palms are cut and sent to Sydney and made into walking sticks'; nyaminbah (place of) small 'midjim' palm. See nyamin, nyumin, and also midjin.gam. It appears e has been misread as c in forms midgcon, etc,, and m as w in GC:Talleb:police, cf, GC:Talleb:Sc form under midjin.gam. 
\rfg Tw:Sc:Bray midgeen a stick, a bangalow; Ngr:Gresty midjin walking stick palm; GC:Talleb:Sc midgcon midgcon cane; Y:Hanln Numminbah , should be N'yumminbah ; Ng:Sc:11/1899:Bray mudgeon , but he calls them in English Midgeon palms , prob u is a mistranscription 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\xe 'The man waas rpoud of his horse.'
\xv Wa: Midjungwehn mala mahmidjargan malahgu jahdjamgu

\lx miganbar(i)
\ps proper noun
\de Migunburry clan
\re Migunburry clan
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Locality group of the Yugumbir situated at Christmas Creek (Y:Watsn); a section and language name, the name of the land across the Albert River toward Boonah (Y:Holm:Fogty); 'belonging to migani' (q. V.) (Y:Holm:Logn); probably part of the original Yugarabul country (cf, Nunagal megendjin, migindjin, cf. Migani) (Y:Holm).
\rfg Y:Holm:Fogty , Logn miganbari; Y:Watsn MigÌ_nbÌ_rri , mi'gÌ_nbÌ_r'ri 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx mih-bula-dululbi
\ps noun
\de,g,n
\re,g,n
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Literally 'two-eye-banger' - the early muskets were double-barrelled, and 'their most vivid acquaintance of this firearm, in the early days, was with its barrel muzzles (round like two eyes) pointed at them, followed by a "bang"'. Also dulul(bi), dulubi. 
\rfg Y:Hanln mee-boolai-doolool-pee: mee eye , boolai two , doolool a loud noise or bang , and the terminal pee , cause or agency 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\de kangaroo
\re kangaroo
\do an
\do 
\sf
\co mimi 'kangaroo(?)' + bumay 'flat, plain' 'Kangaroo Flat'; (cf, bamay in other dialects). 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Dr:Sc Mimi boomi Kangaroo Flat
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx mindal
\ps adjective 
\de clever, intelligent, wise
\re clever ; intelligent ; wise 
\do 
\sf
\co m mindalgali, f mindal(nah)gan, no arb form (Calley). 
\xv Cas: Mindal male dubaydjar. 
\xe 'That woman is intelligent.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy mindal intelligent, clever; 
\rfr Gd:Calley mindal clever; Gd:Geyt wise, clever 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx mindji- (nydj) 
\ps verb
\de laugh
\re laugh
\do 
\sf
\co Intransitive, but can be transitive with person or thing laughed at or about as object (Wa); Geytenbeek does not indicate if /nydj/ , mindja imper., mindjila imperf. (Y:Holm). 
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu ganngahny gahm mindjiyeh. 
\xe 'I will hear them laughing.'
\xv M:Liv: Wana mindja! 
\xe 'Don't laugh!'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw mindjehla. 
\xe 'I'm laughing.' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu mindjehn. 
\xe 'I laughed.'
\xv Wa: Mala jahdjam mindjehla. 
\xe 'The child is laughing.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu dandaygambu mindjehn mahny ngahri-yun. 
\xe 'The old man laughed at them dancing.' (dance-while)
\xv We: mindjehla 
\xe 'laughing.'
\xv Gd: Mindjihbiny bumilehn nyulangam. 
\xe 'They were fighting over that time he laughed (nastily).' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm minyji; Y:Holm:Logn minji- (minja-); Y:Allen pr minjei , p minjeini , pf minjeian , f minjeila; Y:Watsn min'dhi; min'dheni; min'dhien; min'dhela M:Liv minjilli-ma make to laugh ; 
\rfb Bj:Morgn minjeh laugh, minjehla laughing; 1 minjilli-ma make to laugh 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn minjehla laughing; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\dt 04/Mar/2015

\lx minyahgu
\ps interrogative
\de what for, why
\re what for ; why
\do 
\sf
\co minyang + -gu; implies Hello, what do you come for? (Y:Hanln); see also minyang, minyanggu, nyahgu. Minyahgu-wahlu listed as Brunswick, a place name (M:Mestn).
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wamginyan.gehn wahlu minyahgu? 
\xe 'You came what for?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Minyahgu wahlu galgani jali? 
\xe 'Why did you chop the tree?' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Holm:Logn; M:Mestn minyahgu-wallu Brunswick; Y:Hanln meenyahgoo hello ; 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, miÌ±ang; 
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx minyang
\ps interrogative
\de what?, something, how, Minyangbal dialect
\re what? ; something ; how ; Minyangbal dialect
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Self name for dialect at Byron Bay and on Brunswick River, those who say minyang (contrasting with those who say nyang), also minyangbu and cf, nyang in more southerly dialects. 
\xv Y:Allen, Y:Holm:Curry: Minyang gali?
\xe 'What is this?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyang ga? 
\xe 'What is that?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyahgu wahlu wardam?
\xe 'What do you want it for?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyahgi wahlu? 
\xe 'What do you want?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Male minyang? 
\xe 'What's that?'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Minyang gile jalahla? 
\xe 'What do they eat?' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm what , who; Y:Holm minyang , nyang , minyanggu ,  minyagu , nyagu , nyagi; Y:Allen minyung what , how , minyung gulli what is this; Y:Watsn min'yÌ_ng how , what; M:Liv minyung Minyangbal dialect; M:Liv minyung , minyungbo what.? ,  something; Tw:Curr:Bray minyung what; Y:Hanln meenyung 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx minyangahnga
\ps interrogative
\de which
\re which
\do 
\sf
\co minyang gangga (?), or minyang + genitive? 
\rfg Y:Watsn min'yunga'nga

\lx minyanga-, minyangi- 
\ps verb
\de do what, do something
\re do what ; do something
\do 
\sf
\co minyanga- (M), minyangi- (Ng).
\xv M:Liv: Minyangalehla wiya?
\xe 'What are you doing?'
\xv M:Liv: Minyangehn? 
\xe 'What is the matter?' (lit. What did)
\xv M:Liv: Minyangalehla ngay.
\xe 'I'm doing something.'
\xv M:Liv: Minyangaluru wiya ngubu? 
\xe 'What did you do yesterday?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Minyingilehla wahlu? 
\xe 'What are you doing?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Minyingilehn wahlu ngubu? 
\xe 'What were you doing yesterday?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wahlu ngubu minyingilehla?
\xe 'What are you doing tomorrow?'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Minyangilehla? 
\xe 'What's she doing?' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm; M:Liv minyungallela , minyungen; minyungoro what is done; Tw:Curr:Bray minyung elala; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray minyung elala what's she doing? 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx minyangba-
\ps verb
\de cause something
\re cause something
\do 
\sf
\co Something happens to, or is wrong with. 
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Minyangbani nganya biyangi? 
\xe 'Has anything happened to my father?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Minyangbani nganya (nyanga sic) ngagami. 
\xe 'Is anything wrong with my dogs?' 
\rfg Y:Holm:Logn 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx minyangbal
\ps noun
\de Minyungbal, name of a language spoken about Tweed Heads (Fe,g,)
\re Minyungbal ; language spoken about Tweed Heads (Fe,g,), name of a
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Self name for dialect at Byron Bay and on Brunswick River (M), language name probably at Tweed Heads and Fingal Point (NSW) (Y:Holm:Logn).
\xv 
\rfg M:Liv minyung ; Y:Holm:Logn 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, minangbal; 
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx minyangbal
\ps noun
\de Minyungbal dialect(s)
\re Minyungbal dialect(s) 
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Those who say minyang 'what'; applying to Yugambeh, Galibal and Wiyabal dialects, but most specifically to the name of the language around Tweed Heads (Fe,g,).
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\re how many? 
\do 
\sf
\co

\xe 'How many dogs has the old man?'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Minyangbu? - Garalbu. 
\xe 'How many (are there)? - Plenty.' 
\rfg M:Liv minyungbo; Tw:Curr:Bray minyungboo 'what?' ; Tw:Curr:Bray minyungboo ; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray minyunboo? what?

\lx -mir
\ps suffix 
\de plural
\re plural
\do 
\sf
\co Plural used on some topographical nouns, some wild foods, some animals.
\xv Gd: gudjemir 
\xe 'plenty of honey'
\xv Gd: gurumanmir 
\xe 'a mob of grey kangaroos'
\xv Y:Holm: mirungmir 
\xe 'old woman'
\xv Y:Holm: waybarmir 
\xe 'camp' 
\rfg Y:Holm:Logn 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx -mir
\ps suffix 
\de to, towards
\re to ; towards
\do 
\sf
\co Motion to the vicinity of; contrasts with -bah motion to, motion towards; unlike -bah it may only occur with inanimate stems; cf, also -mir pluraliser. 
\xv Gd: Nyule yehni jalimir. 
\xe 'He went to a spot near the tree.'
\xv Gd: Yanah ngali ngumbinymir. 
\xe 'Let us go over near the house.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw yan.gehn townmir. 
\xe 'I went to town.'
\xv Y:Holm: Gaware (gohre) nyule milimir. 
\xe 'He runs up the ridge.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Holm
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx mirang, miranggan
\ps noun
\de old woman
\re old woman ; woman, old
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co See also mirung.

\xe '(That) old woman is ugly.'

\xe 'No, (she's an) old woman.' (answer to 'Is she a young woman?')
\rfg Y:Holm:Logn miragan white woman (Thmpsn) , mirangan old lady (Munro) , mirunggan old woman (Logn , Paulsn) , mirungmir (some) old women (Logn); Y:Allen merungunn human female over 50 merungunn; Y:Watsn mer'ongÌ_n; M:Liv merrung; Tw:Curr:Bray old woman merrung , murrungin; GC:Mestn meerunggan old woman; Y:Hanln mirrung old woman , water rail (bird)

\lx miring
\ps adjective 
\de alive of animates
\re alive of animates
\do 
\sf
\co But not of trees or plants (Gd); takes gender suffix m miringgali, f and arb miring. 
\xv Cas: Wangah mahmang miringbu? 
\xe 'Is your father still alive?' 
\xv Wa: Miringbu mala baygal. 
\xe 'The man is still alive.' 
\xv Gd: Male yiririhny miringbungan. 
\xe 'That bird is still alive, poor thing.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wa/Gd:Calley miring; Cas:Smy miring ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx mirung
\ps noun
\de belly, stomach
\re belly ; stomach
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co mung-jalangah 'crop of bird' (literally 'stomach of throat') (Y:Watsn); cf, muhng, gidjir; muhng is more common, possibly reduced from mirung. 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm muhng belly , stomach; Y:Allen mohn; Y:Watsn mÌ«n belly , noung stomach , noung-dhal'un'nga crop of a bird (lit. stomach of throat) , mÌ«'lin stomach , mi'rong belly , ki'dhera stomach; AT:Curr:Prior moun , AT:Curr:LandsWh moo ,  AT:Curr:JO'Conn djulba , GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr , Tw:Curr:Bray moong 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx mirung, miruhng
\ps noun
\de woman (Gd), old woman (Wa)
\re woman (Gd) ; old woman (Wa) ; woman, old (Wa)
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Gd polite form of address for any adult woman, plural mirunggir, accusative miruhngmirni can be contracted to miruhngmini. 
\xv
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl miruhng , mirunggir , miruhngmi(r)ni 
\rfr Gd:Geyt mirung ; 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx mirung, mirunggan 
\ps noun
\de old woman
\re old woman ; woman, old
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co cf, miranggan; forms mirang, miragan, mirungmir also recorded; mirungmir 'some old women' (Y:Holm:Logn). 
\xv
\rfg Ydict mirung , mirunggan; Y:Sha:Culhm mirunggan , mirigan old woman; Y:Holm:Logn , jp , mirungmir (some) old women (ml); Y:Allen merungunn female (over 50 years); Y:Watsn old woman mer'ongun , mer'ingun , M:Liv merruv old woman; Tw:Curr:Bray murrungin , merrung; AT:Curr:Prior merougan; AT:Curr:LandsWh marungan; AT:Curr:JO'Conn merroongun; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr mirrigwun; GC:Coomera:police merrigon old woman 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr

\lx mudjum 
\ps noun
\de one's child 
\re child, one's
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Any related child on that generation level except male's sister's child and female's brother's child; see juguhn, f mudjumdjar-gan, mudjum-gir-gan ('daughter', etc,), plural mudjumgir Wa, mudjumbin Calley. 
\xv Wu:Calley: ngirihmangah mudjumbihny
\xe 'your (plural) sons' (your child-your own)
\xv Wu:Calley: mudjumdjargan 
\xe 'own daughter' (child-own-fem) 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv moo-thum; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce me,g,m son , mergamgun daughter; Gn:JMathew mudyumgira ; Gd:Calley mud:jumb ? n son (poss. Your son);

\lx mugar
\ps noun
\de storm, thunder
\re storm ; thunder
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co cf, migar, migubal, jugal. 
\xv Wa: Jang munah mugar gadji. 
\xe 'The storm was bad here (but has now cleared).'
\xv Wa: Jang munah mugar gadji gehrbilehn guwang.
\xe 'The storm was bad here and there was a lot of rain.'
\xv Ny: jan.gany mugar 
\xe 'lightning and thunder (i.e. Storm).' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm mugara storm; Y:Holm mugar (mugara) storm; Y:Allen mugerra; Y:Watsn mugerra; Mur:Sc:AndFrench moograh thunder; AT:Curr:Prior migobal; AT:Curr:LandsWh moogarra;  Mur:Sc:Hargrv moogera storm and thunder; Cudgn:Sc:Evans magerah thunder; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr moogerer; Tw:Curr:Bray muggera; Y:Beaudst:police moogra; GC:Coomera:polic e mugerra; Y:Hanln moogra storm; Ng:Sc:Cudgn3/1903 magerah thunder; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray muggera thunder , ' Ng:Sc:Mur moogera storm and thunder 
\rfb Bj:Sha mughar thunderstorm; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, mugar storm , thunder; Wi:Curr:Richmnd mogara (o macron); Wi:Curr:Lismore mukkera; Bj:Sc:Coraki muggurra thunder; Ny:Curr:Ballina mograa;  Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 chingun moogra storm; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wa/Gd:Calley mu:gara; We:Gordn thunder 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; 
\rfo Cop:JMathew moograh thunder ;

\lx muhng
\ps noun
\de belly, stomach
\re belly ; stomach
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co cf, mirung, (possibly an older form), mulin, gidjir, julba, also nuwang 'food', Y:Watsn has perhaps misconstrued muhng jalanyah 'crop of bird' (literally 'stomach in throat') as nuwang jalanyah 'food of throat'. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu gabir jalihgi nganyah muhng. 
\xe 'I'm hungry and want to eat (fill my belly).' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm muhng belly, stomach; Y:Holm:Monsl muhng stomach; Y:Allen mohn belly, kijerra stomach; Y:Watsn mÌ«n belly, noung stomach, noung-dhal'un 'nga crop of a bird (lit. Stomach of throat), mÌ«'lin stomach, mi'rong belly, ki'dhera stomach; AT:Curr:Prior moun, AT:Curr:LandsWh moo, AT:Curr:JO'Conn djulba, GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr, Tw:Curr:Bray moong ; 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce moong stomach 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx mul
\ps adjective 
\de short
\re short
\do 
\sf
\co Gender suffixes m -gali, f -ngahgan, arb -ngahn, neut -galang, plural -gam (often mul-mulgam) (Gd); JThomas form suggested an older form might have been murul. 
\xv Gd: mulgalang or mulgali baygal 
\xe 'short man.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Crowl mulbin , mul , mulbuny short ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gn:JMathew mulkalong; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce moril short
\rfo

\lx mula
\ps adjective 
\de hungry
\re hungry
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co cf, mulehng 'vomit' in some dialects. 
\xv Cas: Ngaywar mula bundang 
\xe 'I'm very hungry.'
\xv Cas: gahnga ngali nangany mulagu 
\xe 'Let's get some food for our hunger.'

\lx mulagan
\ps adverb, noun
\de morning (Gd), dawn (Wa), early morning, morning star
\re morning (Gd) ; dawn (Wa) ; early morning ; morning star ; morning, early ; star, morning
\do1 ti
\do2 ne
\sf
\co Shortened to mulgan 'dawn' in Wa. 
\xv Cas: Ngubu ngay mulagan yan.gahny. 
\xe 'I shall go early tomorrow morning.'
\xv Cas: Yehni gawangdjar mulaganbu. 
\xe 'His uncle left early in the morning.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy mulagan ; Wa:Crowl mulgan dawn
\rfr Gd:Geyt mulagan ;

\dt 04/Mar/2015

\lx mulam
\ps noun
\de boy under 12 years
\re boy under 12 years
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Allen gives mulam as 'male (child)', and jabo as male from 12 to 15 years; 12-15 years old (w); cf, 'boy' jabu; cases (Y:Allen); mulamnya 'of a boy (pres), mulamnadjil 'of a boy (past)'; mulamwalul plural (Y:Allen). 
\xv Y:Allen: Gali mulamah gunggung jun(.)gam. 
\xe 'This boy's skull (is) hard.' (refers to the skull of a living boy)
\xv Y:Allen: Gali gunggung mulamnahdjil gabungil.
\xe 'This skull of a boy (is) old.' (refers to the skull of a boy long dead)
\xv Y:Allen: Mulam wahlal yanah. 
\xe 'The boys go.' 
\rfg Y:Allen molumm , human male (child) , boy; Y:Allen molumm male child , molummllya , molummnajil; gulli molummnya konggong jungumm; gulli kong-gong molummnajil kobungil; molumm-wallull yana; Y:Watsn mÌ«l'Ì_m male Aboriginal child; GC:Mestn baby , boy (i.e. Boy baby) 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx mulehnganeh
\ps place name
\de Mallanganee
\re Mallanganee
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Claimed by Geytenbeeks (and an older Aboriginal man in Malanganee) to mean 'place of vomit' - of a mythical dog - the smooth round stones in the creek are said to resemble dog's vomit. 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt

\re vomit
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Holmer says 'the form in -biny (imminent) would denote impulse to vomit.'

\xe 'I am sick.'

\xe 'You vomit.'
\xv Mulehnybiny-mani.
\xe '(I) vomited.'

\de hill, ridge, mountain, back (of animates), small hill
\re hill ; ridge ; mountain ; back (of animates) ; small hill ; hill, small
\do1 ne
\do2 bp
\sf
\co Plural mulimir 'a cluster of hills' (Gd), 'back, backbone, hill', plural muli-gali (Wa), muli-mulih 'small hill' Gd. Cf, buyuhl, buwul; mulinggan 'leaning, sloping' Y:Hanln.
\xv We: Yanbalehla nyule muli yuri dabahydju. 
\xe 'He's going along the hill with his dog.'

\lx mumuhm
\ps proper noun
\de Mommóm
\re Mommóm
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co A brother of Berrung, one of the Three Brothers who came to the land.

\lx munah
\ps demonstrative 
\de that close, invisible (formerly present) (Wa), that known or presumed near, not in sight of the speaker (Gd), that no longer there
\re that close, invisible (formerly present) (Wa) ; that known or presumed near, not in sight of the speaker (Gd) ; that no longer there
\do 
\sf
\co cf, gunah, gahba; with -gan suffix used as temporal demonstrative.
\xv Gd: Yile munah mugim? 
\xe 'Where is that axe?'
\xv Gd: munahgan 
\xe 'recently' 
\xv Wa: Gahnyulu baygalu gahngani munah bulang. 
\xe 'These men took the meat away (so that it can no longer be seen).'
\xv Wa: Yilahwen munah? 
\xe 'Where has he,g,ne?' (he could be seen a moment ago)
\xv Wa: Munah jehrgali balahyani. 
\xe 'That big man died.'
\xv Wa: Nyang bahla munah "sugar" baygalnahnu?
\xe 'What is sugar called in the Aboriginal language?' (I knew it in the past, but don't know now.)
\xv Wa: Jang munah mugar gadji.
\xe 'The storm was bad here (but has now cleared).'
\xv Wa: Gala munahna baygalnah yehna(nah). 
\xe 'This belongs to the man who went away.'
\xv Cas: Wangah munah juwan bugal.
\xe 'Your spear was good (but is now destroyed.)' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\re that

\lx munggulam
\ps place name
\de Monkcollum
\re Monkcollum
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Mountain close to the head waters of Wilson's Creek station, so called on account of a peculiar-looking shale which is found on the top of the mountain, and seems to be peculiar to that mountain, north-east, Mullumbimby. Mur:Sc:Herbne lists as 'a piece of black feldspar'.

\lx munu
\ps demonstrative 
\de that (general area)
\re that (general area)
\do 
\sf
\co Possibly invisible. General area in sight of speaker, of mass nouns such as 'smoke', 'sugar', cf, gunu, gundeh. 
\xv Wa: Mala gawarehla mununu nyabaydju. 
\xe 'He is running from there with some water.'
\xv Wa: Munu ngayal ngadju wangahyu jaliyu duwani
\xe 'I dug the,g,ound with your stick there (in that area where you can see).'
\xv Gd: Munu gulgan ngulunggah jang. 
\xe 'That road is bad just ahead.'
\xv Gd: Mihm-mayah munu guygum. 
\xe 'Should (I) move that sand?'
\xv Gd: Gudjeyu gunuyu mununi gadjalgahny-ma.
\xe 'Sweeten that (drink) with this honey.'
\xv M:Liv: Munu waybar gandjilurubu. 
\xe 'That fire is lit.' 
\xv M:Liv: Munu waybar gandjilinibahny ngubu.
\xe 'That fire will be lit tomorrow.'
\xv M:Liv: Munu bandahn banyar. 
\xe 'That tomahawk is good.'
\xv Bj: Gunggu-mani munu. 
\xe 'It is wet there.' 
\rfg M:Liv munno , monno ; 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, munu 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ;

\lx muru
\ps noun
\de nose
\re nose
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Cas also lists as face, e,g,tive/instrumental muruyu or muriyu, in We locative 'in the nose' can be muruya/ muruyi/ muriya, sometimes used for 'end' (Gd). 
\xv Wa: Muru nganyah bandjani gulungbaydju bawurahyu. 
\xe 'My nose is blocked up with a cold in the head.'
\xv Wa: Gumar yehyani muruya nganyahya. 
\xe 'My nose is bleeding.'
\xv Wa: Nyugum yan.gahla or Muru malahna gawarehla.
\xe 'He's got a runny nose.'
\xv Gd: murugir 
\xe 'person with an injured nose' (nose-class) 
\rfg M:Sc:Brunswk moora nose; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray murro; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn mooroo; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray morro nose 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl muru; Bj:Sha muru nose; Bj:Holm:Fe,g,; Wi:Curr:Lismore muruh; Wi:Curr:Richmond mooro; Ny:Curr:Ballina morrow; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wa/Gd:Calley mur:u? nose; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv moor-a; Cas:Smy muru face, nose; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce , Gd:Sci:Woodnbng morro;  Gn:JMathew muru ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx muru gaya-
\ps verb
\de drown
\re drown
\do 
\sf
\co Literally 'nose dive'; possibly also 'sink, whether or not drowning' (Y:Allen, Y:Watsn); as verb 'drop, burst' (Y:Hanln). GC:Coomera source seems to suggest muru gara-; cf, also muruya-. 
\rfg Ydict muru kaya-; Y:Allen pr moro-gaia , p morogaiani , pf morogaianian , f morogaiala drown (nose-drive sic); Y:Watsn mor'Ì«-gai'a; mo'rÌ« -gai'anÌ¨; mo'rÌ«-gain'ian; mo'rÌ«-gai'Ì¢la drown; GC:Coomera:Sc , GC:Coomera:police murragarra drowned; Y:Hanln mooroogaien 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx muruhny
\ps noun
\de ashes, hot coals (Wa)
\re ashes ; coals, hot (Wa)
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co Suspiciously like muruhn 'firewood'.
\xv Wa: Maliyu mahny dam bundjimahla muruhnydja. 
\xe 'She's cooking the yams in the coals.'
\xv Wa: Madjungun guluny ngalawah gehrbiyah mala muruhny. 
\xe 'Look for a hole there to pour the ashes into.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl hot coals , ashes; We:Gordn ashes; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ashes 
\rfo

\lx -n
\ps suffix 
\de permissive, let (someone do it)
\re permissive ; let (someone do it)
\do 
\sf
\co On some verbs; this suffix is homophonous with the imperfective -hn (when it is shortened) - such verbs tend to be avoided for this suffix. 
\xv Gd: namahn 
\xe 'let (him) hold it'
\xv Gd: yagahlin 
\xe 'let (me) fix it.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo

\lx naba-
\ps verb transitive 
\de hit with a missile, throw at something (whether or not you actually hit it), shoot
\re hit with a missile ; throw at something (whether or not you actually hit it) ; shoot
\do 
\sf
\co nababa 'to pelt harder' (Wa); 'to kill, shoot, hit hard' (Gd). 
\xv Wa: Nabani ngadju mala gawari-nyun mani. 
\xe 'I shot the kangaroo while it was running.'
\xv Wa: Mahny jahdjam naba-nabalehla.
\xe 'The children are throwing things about.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju mala dabahy nabani jaliyu. 
\xe 'I threw a stick at the dog.'
\xv Wa: Yirali yang giwadjahn duluhlbiyu nabayah baygalni. 
\xe 'The whitemen came with guns to shoot the Aborigines.'
\xv Cas: Nabani nyulamanggu nyulangi murndanggu. 
\xe 'They hit him with nulla-nullas.'
\xv Cas: Jananggandu nabani jali, behn. 
\xe 'The boy struck the tree and it fell down.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Juwan nyulamanggu birani, yugumbeh nabani. 
\xe 'They threw a spear (but didn't hit him).' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Nabalehla ngaw. 
\xe 'I'm shooting.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm hit; Y:Allen pr nabun, p nabuni, pf nabunian, f nabala shoot (throw); Y:Watsn nÌ¢'bun, nÌ¢'bunÌ¨, nÌ¢bunian, nÌ¢bÌ¢la 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy nab-a, nabani hit, strike; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 04/Mar/2015

\lx nabali-
\ps verb
\de fight with spear, boomerang (and tomahawk) and shield
\re fight with spear, boomerang (and tomahawk) and shield
\do 
\sf
\co From naba- 'hit' (with missile, e,g, spear, etc,); suffix -li indicates a reciprocal sense, i.e. 'fight each other'. 
\rfg Y:Allen pr nabullen , p nabullen , pf nabullian , f nabulleila fight (with spear , boomerang , and shield); Y:Watsn nÌ¢bÌ_len , nÌ¢bÌ_lian; nÌ¢'bÌ_lÌ»la fight , with spear , boomerang and tomahawk 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx nama-
\ps verb transitive 
\de hold, catch, touch, grab, seize, embrace, grasp, get hold of
\re hold ; catch ; touch ; grab ; seize ; embrace ; grasp ; hold of, get
\do 
\sf
\co Continuous (antipassive) form namali-; cf, nama- 'catch, touch, hold' in other dialects, and namani. 
\xv Wa: Mala dabahy bugal namalihgu mahny mani. 
\xe 'That dog is good at catching kangaroos.'
\xv Wa: Namah jambaydju. 
\xe 'Take hold (of it) with your hands.'
\xv Wa: Wahlu namahla bin.gihng jahna-nyun mala nyabay. 
\xe 'You can catch turtles in still water.'
\xv Wa: Gala ngadju bilahr namahla mala bumbih. 
\xe 'I’m holding this spear to kill that with.'
\xv Wa: Nyahlu wahlu namani wagany? 
\xe 'What did you catch the catfish with?'
\xv Wa: Wanah mahny namah nyurahm mahnyga bilaywe,g,hny. 
\xe 'Don't touch those warts or they'll spread.' 
\xv Gd: Wulimahndu gabay jalum namalidjahndu.
\xe '(We) used to find honey and catch fish.'
\xv Gd: Namalehn gahnyu guyahny. 
\xe '(He) caught these possums.'
\xv Gd: Namalihnggal warahy biranibeh. 
\xe‘After 'holding it a long time he just threw it away.'
\xv Bj: Namahla jambayah. 
\xe '(I) am holding in my hand. '
\rfg Y:Allen pr numala, p numalen, pf numalian, f numalela, Y:Watsn num'alÌ¢, num'alen, num'alian, num'alÌ¢la ; 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, nama- , term. Namani , prog. Namala 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy nam-a ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo

\lx nanahng
\ps noun
\de female's older sister, male's sister
\re sister, male's ; sister, older (female's) 
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co Includes many relations on the same,g,neration-level; method of calculating who is in this nanahng relationship differs according to whether ego (the person whose relative it is) is male or female), also great-grandmother; sister or female cousin of any greatgrandparent; or male's great-granddaughter (Gd); also nanahng-djargan, female's elder sister and female cousin, male's sister and female cousin, great grandmother, great granddaughter (Wa); Smythe lists as man's sister, but also 'woman's older sister' (Sharpe). 
\xv Calley: Nanahng nganyah, nganyah nanahng 
\xe 'my sister(s).'
\xv M:Sc:Brunswk: nganyah nanahng 
\xe 'my sister'
\xv Wi:LRoberts: nanahng nganyah 
\xe 'my sisters (of the Nimbin Rocks).' 
\rfg M:Liv nunnang woman's elder sister, man's sister; M:Sc:Brunswk nunang sister, elder; una nunang my sister; Ng:Curr:Tw:PtD:Bray nunung sister - elder, sister ‰ÛÒ younger ; Y:Sha:Culhm sister; Y:Holm nanang sister (Fogty, JFogty; Y:Allen nanang elder sister; Y:Watsn nann'ang elder sister; M:Sc nunang elder sister; AT:Curr:Prior manou, AT:Curr:LandsWh, AT:Curr:O'Conn nanang, Tw:Curr:Bray nunung, GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr nunong; Y:Hanln nannong sister; 
\rfb Wi:Sha:Turnbl, LRoberts nanahng sister; Bj:Morgn nanahn sister; Wi:Curr:Lismore nunung sister-elder; Wi:Curr:Richmond nanung sister-elder; Ny:Curr:Ballina nanigh elder sister; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn older sister; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv nanyong , nun ya nawong 'my sister'; Cas:Smy nana:ng sister; 
\rfr Gd:Calley nga:nang sister & mother's br. Children???; Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng nannug 'elder sister' , nannanamung 'my sister'; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce nunnung sister; Gn:JMathew nanang 'elder sister' ; Gn:Mathew nunang elder sister

\lx ngagam
\ps noun
\de dog (tame)
\re tame dog ; dog (tame)
\do an
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Hanln = "white man's dog, the domesticated mongrel, cf, ngura(n) 'dog, wild dog'", ngagamdjin 'dogs', ngagamdjindu 'dogs (e,g,)' (Y:Holm), ngagambur 'little dog' (dog-diminutive) Gd. 
\xv M:Liv: Minyangbu gidjuhma ngagam?
\xe 'How many dogs has the old man?'
\xv M:Liv: Yili ngagam-nguhrgan baygal? 
\xe 'Where is the dog's master/where is the man with a dog?'
\xv Y:Holm: Ngagamjihndu gawagawani. 
\xe 'The dogs broke (the net).'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: ngagama bawur 
\xe 'dog's head'
\xv Y:Holm: ngagamdjihn (e,g, jihndu, ace. Jihni)
\xe 'some dogs'
\xv Y:Holm: Nyahani ngagamjin guyba.
\xe '(I) saw the dogs roasting.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bumilehla ngagam.
\xe 'The dogs are fighting.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yingilehla ngagam.
\xe 'The dogs are biting each other.' 
\rfg M:Liv nogu?m, nogum, nogumbo (e,g,), -me acc., -rna gen., -gai dat, -bano abl; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray noggun tame dog; Ng:Sc:Tweed nogam a tame dog ; Y:Sha:Culhm ngagam; Y:Holm ngagamdjindu (pl. \rfb Bj:Holm:Turnbl ngagam; Wi:Curr:Lismore augham tame dog; Ny:Curr:Ballina aggum tame dog;

\lx ngagu
\ps adjective 
\de black, dark
\re black ; dark
\do cl
\do 
\sf
\co Black (Wa), also night (Wu); takes gender suffixes m -gali, f -galigan, arb -nahgan (Wu), pronounced ngaku (Fe,g,), and said to mean black and used as the name of a cat (Fe,g,), probably from Dhanggati or some other language. 
\xv Wa: ngagu dagam
\xe 'a dark cloud' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm ngaku; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, ngagu dark
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wa/Gd:Calley ngago night; Wa/Gd:Calley nga:gu;
\rfr 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx ngahn, ngahnduwal

\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx ngahn, ngehn
\ps interrogative pronoun
\de who?, somebody, someone
\re who? ; somebody ; someone
\do 
\sf
\co ngehn (M), ngahn (Y:Allen, Y:Watsn, Tw:Curr:Bray), ngahna 'whose' (Y:Allen, Y:Watsn), Y:Holm forms ngahn nom, ngahndu e,g,, ngehni acc., ngahna gen., ngahnu 'from', ngahnba loc. 
\xv Y:Allen, Tw:Curr:Bray: Gili ngahn? 
\xe ‘Who is that?' (mibiny understood - Bray)
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngahn gili. 
\xe 'I don't know' (lit. 'who there?', answer to 'who is that'')
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngahn gili mibiny? 
\xe 'Which Blacks?'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngahn gili jalgany? 
\xe 'What/which woman is that?'
\xv Y:Allen: Ngahn(a) gili? 
\xe 'Who is that?'
\xv Y:Allen: Ngahn mali? 
\xe 'Who is there?'
\xv Y:Holm:Monsl: Ngahn mali wahlu? 
\xe 'Who are you there?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Ngahn gali mibiny? 
\xe 'Who is that (this) man?'
\xv Y:Holm:Fogty: Ngahndu wahnyi bumani? 
\xe 'Who hit you?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Ngehni wahlu nyahni? 
\xe 'Who did you see?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Ngahnu wahlu gahngani? 
\xe 'From whom did you take it?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Ngahnba? 
\xe 'To whom (did you go)?'
\xv M:Liv: Ngehn ganggahlen.
\xe 'Somebody callling', 'Who is calling?'
\rfg Y:Holm: ngahn , ngehn; Y:Allen nan who , nana whose , nan mulli who is there , nana gilli whose is that; Y:Watsn nan who , nan'a whose; M:Liv ngen kunggallen Tw:Curr:Bray killingang who is that 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo

\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx ngahri-
\ps noun, verb
\de play, dance, boil, be rough (water)
\re play ; dance ; boil ; rough (water)
\do 
\sf
\co Dance, play (all dialects) (of games and music), ngahri also used as noun, 'dance' transitive, but object 'dance' usually omitted; completive ngahrini can contract to ngahrni, similarly ngahrila to ngahrla 'is dancing' (Wa); inherently repetitive, with or without repetitive suffix; Gn:JMathew form suggests ngahrilah 'dancing'. Y:Sha:Culhm had ngahra 'play'; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr lists as 'corroboree'; Y:Watsn says 'colloquially termed corroboree, which, however, is fore,g,'; Y:Allen and Y:Watsn noun may be verb 'to dance'; Y:Watsn gives form with -yu; Y:Hanln ngahrilah 'dance', present tense form.
\xv Wa: Yawahr madji ngahrin judjah mahnyulu.
\xe 'They danced a corroboree right down there.'
\xv Wa: Mahny jahdjam ngahrini nyabaydja. 
\xe 'The children were playing in the water.'
\xv Gd: Nyahni gumbi jabuhmangi ngahrilinyun balunbu.
\xe 'I saw many boys while they were playing along the creek.'
\xv We: ngahrilah 
\xe 'playing' 
\xv Cas: Nyang male,g,ng ngahrila 
\xe 'Is the water boiling?'
\xv Cas: Ngaliwar mamale ngahrila. 
\xe 'We are playing, joking, together.'
\xv Cas: Ngahrin ngali yawahr. 
\xe 'We danced a corroboree.'
\xv Cas: Galewar ngahrin gung. 
\xe 'This water is rough.'
\xv Cas: Gale ngay jang ngahrindjang. 
\xe 'This is too rough for me.' 
\xv Bj: Jahdjam ngahrilah.
\xe 'The children are playing.'
\xv Bj: Nyula ngahrilah. 
\xe 'He is dancing.'
\xv Bj: Ngali used to ngahriyan. 
\xe 'We used to play (be playing).' 
\xv Y:Watsn: ngahrilihgu 
\xe 'ready, dressed for a dance'
\xv Ng: ngahrilah 
\xe 'dancing'. 
\rfg M:Liv ngarre; Ng:Sc:Cudgn arrellah dancing ground ;  Y:Sha:Culhm ngahra- play , dance; Y:Allen ngareia n. Game (play , dance); pr ngari , p ngarien , pf ngarian , f ngarila dance; Y:Watsn nga'rea n. Game , play or dance; v. NgÌ¢r'io dance; n. Ngar'rimÌ¢; v. ngar'i; ngar'ien; ngar'ian; ngar'fla; ngÌ¢r'fligo ready for a dance; NG:Sc:Cudgn arrellah dancing ground; GC:Mestn gnaree corroboree; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr arri; Y:Hanln n'gahralar ,  Y:Hanln n'garralah , n'garahla play; 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl nga:re , nga:rela: (song); Bj:Holm:Fe,g, nga:ri- ,  nga:rila , nga:rijan; 
\rfk Cas:Smy nga:r-i, ngar-e, nga:rila, nga:rin ; Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn
\rfr Gn:Mathew ngarila dance ; Gd:Geyt ; GnLJMathew ngarila
\rfo Cop:Hargrv gnaribee dancing around
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\dt 11/Mar/2015

\lx ngalawa-
\ps verb intransitive, transitive
\de look for, ask (for), search, hunt, find, ask question
\re look for ; ask (for) ; search ; hunt ; find ; ask question ; question, ask
\do1 ff
\do2 senses
\sf
\co Hunt or search for something whether or not it is found, try to find out something, can be reduplicated ngala-ngalawa-, idiom gudjim ngalawa- 'to go hunting' (Wa), present form ngulawalehla attested (Y:Hanln); Y:Watsn also has gul'lagul'lawa (probably for ngala-ngalawa-, n omitted in error). Listed as 'ask' in context of sentence, probably 'hunt, search for' (M:Liv).
\xv Wa: Ngaywahr jambanggehn ngalawalehn gurihbu wihnyi.
\xe 'I tried to look for you a long time ago.'
\xv Wa: Mahny ngalawalehla malah jawi. 
\xe 'They are looking up there.'
\xv Wa: Gahnyulu nganyi ngalawani. 
\xe 'They were looking for me.'
\xv Wa: Madjungun guluny ngalawah gehrbiyah mala muruhny. 
\xe 'Find a hole there to pour the ashes in.'
\xv Wa: Galiyu nganyi gur ngala-ngalawani bayahny. 
\xe 'He asked me too much today.'
\xv Wa: Gilah ngay ngalawalehny bin.gihng. 
\xe 'I will go turtle hunting there.'
\xv Cas: Ngalawalehn nyule,g,bihnggu. / Ngalawalehn nyulayu gabihng. 
\xe 'He looked for water.' 
\xv Cas: Ngalawani nyulayu malahni baygalni. 
\xe 'He asked that man.'
\xv Cas: Ngay ngara ngalawalehnybu.
\xe 'I'll look again.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu ngalawalehla nunganygu. 
\xe ‘I am asking for/searching for food.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bulahbu jabu yan.gehn gudjim ngalawaliyah.
\xe 'Two boys went out to hunt for bush food/animals.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngalawalehn guruman.gu. 
\xe 'They hunted for kangaroo.'
\xv TD:Bray: Guwah jalum ngalawah(?) - Yugam, jalun, guwahny ngalawah. 
\xe 'Come and fish. - No, let's hunt possum.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyula ngalawalehla wuya. 
\xe 'He is looking for you.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngali yan.gahny ngalawalehny. 
\xe 'We are,g,ing to look for (game), that is hunting.' 
\rfg M:Liv ngullawonne (past); Tw:Curr:Bray nullawalala, narllee, narllee; Y:Hanln n'goola-wool-layla Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Watsn ngul'lagul'lawii; M:Liv ngullawonne (past); Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray nullawalala 's getting ; 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, ngalawa-, ngalawalila, ngalawalin ; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy ngalaw-a , ngalawalen , ngalawani , ngalawali:njbu look for, ask (for) ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt to search, hunt, ask ;
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\xe 'The sun is going down, it'll be,g,tting dark soon.'

\dt 07/Apr/2015

\lx ngaram, nyaram
\ps noun
\de frilled lizard 
\re lizard, frilled ; frilled lizard
\do rep
\do 
\sf Clamydosaurus kingii 
\co Probably only nyaram, though Y:Allen, Y:Watsn usually do not write /ny/ as ng; Y:Geyt:Culhm gives as 'bearded jew lizard': similar lizards, and note shift in meaning of nyaram in other dialects - frilled lizard (Wa), blue tongue (B), and Y:Hanln who says it is 'sleeping lizard' (blue tongue), also loosely used for 'Frilled and Jew Lizard'. 
\rfg Y:Allen ngarun; Y:Watsn ngarum , nga'rum (Cl. Kingii); GC:Nerang:police nurrum , GC:Nerang:Sc nurum frill lizard; Y:Hanln n'yerrum sleeping lizard (also loosely used for Frilled and Jew Lizard) 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\dt 05/Mar/2015

\lx ngarbany
\ps noun
\de betrothal, marriage, place of betrothal or marriage
\re betrothal ; marriage ; place of betrothal or marriage
\do1 lg
\do2 loc
\sf
\co Smythe was doubtful about this word, but it is confirmed through Calley's anthropological work, as the term for a young man who spends time with his possible future in-laws for them to assess him. 
\xv Cas: Gile nguy balugahn yehni babar buhnyibah ngarbanydjahgu dubaygu.
\xe 'Balugahn went north to the Bunya Mountains to become betrothed to a woman.'
\xv Cas: Yagam warahy yehyani ngarbanydji.
\xe 'He didn't stop at the ?betrothal, ?marriage, with his betrothed.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy ngarbanj
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 05/Mar/2015

\lx ngarbany
\ps noun
\de fishing net
\re fishing net ; net, fishing
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Net used for trapping animals in a narrow pass, or for fish (Gd), fishing net (Wa). Y:Hanln lists G'n as like German gn in gnadig, but has instances where it is clear it should be ng. 
\rfg Y:Allen ngarravunn net (for fishing); Y:Watsn ngar'rabin ,  ngar'ravÌ_n fish-net; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr irribull; Y:Hanln arrabin, g'narrabin 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy ngarbanj ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\re resident in a place with expectancy of getting married
\do pp
\do

\lx ngaring
\ps locative 
\de across, on the other side
\re across ; on the other side
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Must take same case marking as the noun it qualifies (Wa).
\xv Gd: Gahmuni yagaybah ngaringgahni. 
\xe 'Ask for them on the other side.'
\xv Gd: Nyahnybu ngali gadji bangilehnydje ngarihngbilnu baygal.
\xe 'We will see the men again when they arrive here from overseas (another+country-from).' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce naringme opposite bank of creek 
\rfo

\lx ngaringbin-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de,g, across, go over
\re,g, across ; go over
\do 
\sf
\co Literally 'across-fall'; includes a form Smythe saw as a location 'away, elsewhere'.

\xe 'He crossed from Ballina on a raft.'
\xv Cas: Nyaligur wudjeh yan.gahny ngaringbina?
\xe 'When are you going away (elsewhere)?'

\do

\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm ngaruny, Y:Allen maren aunt, ngarun uncle's wife; Y:Watsn nga'run, mÌ¢r'en aunt; M:Liv naruå¡n; Y:Hanln g'naroon aunt

\lx ngaw
\ps pronoun
\de I (e,g,tive) 
\re I (e,g,tive) 
\do 
\sf
\co Usual form of ngay used by Culham; see also ngayu and grammar notes. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Nguhn ngaw.
\xe 'I'm hot.'
\xv Y:Culhm: Ngaw jaguhl.
\xe 'I'm a stranger.'
\xv YLCulhm: Gagali ngaw.
\xe 'I'm here.'
\xv Y:Culhm: Ngaw nyahla.
\xe 'I see/watch (it).'
\xv Y:Culhm: Ngaw bumani gurumani.
\xe 'I killed a kangaroo.'
\xv Y:Culhm: Ngaw giyehni jabanggani ngayu bumani gurumani.
\xe 'I told my wife I'd killed a kangaroo.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm 
\rfb
\rfk

\sf
\co Seems reduced to ngihl Gn, cf, ngayil, barangayil, ngihl. 
\xv Wa: Munu ngayalngadju wan.gahyu jaliyu duwani.
\xe 'I dug the,g,ound with your stick there (in that area where you can see).'
\xv Wa: Malaga ngayala yunamah balahyani nyula.
\xe 'Put him in the,g,ound, he's dead.'
\xv Wa: Gala nguhmbiny jihgani ngayal-ngula.
\xe 'The house shook and so did the,g,ound.'
\xv Wa: Banggahla ngadju ngayal jinanggu.
\xe 'I'm stamping (on) the,g,ound with my feet.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju mala ngayal jarwahla.
\xe 'I'm scraping the,g,ound.'
\xv Cas: Guwanggu budjurmani ngayal.
\xe 'The rain has made the,g,ound soft.'
\xv Cas: Bulngaru ngayal dandurmani.
\xe 'The heat has hardened the,g,ound.'
\rfg 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy ngaijel ground, earth, soil, floor (of house); Wa:Crowl ground , dirt , mud; We:Gordn ngayil clay
\rfr Gd:Geyt ngayil clay; Gd:Geyt barangayil light orange colour; Gn:JMathew ngil ground 
\rfo Cop:Hargrv nieal clay

\lx ngeh
\ps interjection, conjunction
\de yes, and
\re yes, and 
\do 
\sf
\co Used by listener in a conversation to indicate 'I'm listening, please go on' (Wa); also used as a conjunction (alternating with ngah) (Wa), see also ngi, yawu.
\xv Wa: Balahn.gan gurihbu. - Ngeh. - Bugaw.
\xe 'It's been dead a long time. - Yeah. - It stinks.'
\xv Wa: Ngay yarbilehn ngeh ngahrin ngay.
\xe 'I sang and I danced.'
\xv Gd: Ngeh gidja yuru nyahbigu jali.
\xe 'Now that is a good looking tree!'
\xv Gd: Ngandur ngulung burahn-i ngeh ngandur juhladjahn-i.
\xe 'Some went ahead and others came behind.'
\xv Gd: Balugahn ngeh nyule,g,h gunyngan yan.gahn miyahrimu.
\xe 'Balugahn and his relatives went from Crown Mountain.'
\xv Bj: wahlu ngeh nyahn.gan 
\xe 'you and she' 
\rfg Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray yo, cam, yoe yes
\rfb Bj:Holm ngi; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn and;
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo Cop:Hargrv nid yes ;

\lx ngehn, ngihn
\ps interrogative pronoun
\de who (singular), someone, somebody
\re who (singular) ; someone ; somebody
\do 
\sf
\co ngehndu e,g,tive (transitive subject); ngahn in Y; ngihn in Wa, Wu.
\xv Gd: Ngehndu dungbihn mani?
\xe 'Who made him cry?'
\xv Gd: Ngehni ginggalehla?
\xe 'Who is he calling (to)?'
\xv Gd: Ngehn mayu ganggalehla?
\xe 'Who is calling out over there?'
\xv Wa: Ngihn.gur wudjeh nyari?
\xe 'What's your name?'
\xv Wa: Mayu ngihn munmuhnbalehla?
\xe 'Who is that murmuring?'
\xv Wa: Mayu-mayu ngihn badjilehla?
\xe 'Who is that knocking? (where the person can't be seen but the noise can be heard).'
\xv Calley: Gile ngihn?
\xe 'Who is that?'
\xv Calley: Gile ngihn yanbalehla?
\xe 'Who is that walking there?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl ngihn; Wa:Calley ngi:n.gur
\rfr Gd:Geyt ngehn ; 
\rfo

\do

\dt 06/Mar/2015

\lx ngihr
\ps noun
\de forehead
\re forehead
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co ngihl is forehead in Wa, ngihr is forehead in Gd, We, B, and ngayal/ngayil/ngayir has meanings clay, 'ground and cliff' in Gd, Wa, We, Wu; so probably both ngihl and ngihr are reduced from this longer form. Cf, also ngihl, yilim. 
\rfg Y:Allen ngiri; Y:Watsn ngi'ri 
\rfb
\rfk We:Crowl, B:Crowl; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv ne-a ; Cas:Smy ngi:r ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng yeerie; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce,g,earrie forehead ; 
\rfo
\dt 07/Apr/2015

\ps noun phrase
\de seasonal change
\re seasonal change
\do1 ti
\do2 ne
\sf

\lx ngihra-

\lx -nginy
\ps suffix, verb suffix
\de dweller, doer on a noun referring to countryside, someone who habitually lives there
\re dweller ; doer ; inhabitant (habitual, of countryside)
\do 
\sf
\co On a noun referring to countryside is someone who habitually lives there; on a verb participle or noun referring to an action, means someone who habitually does that action (Wa); cf, -ngayn (Gd); on a topograhial noun or place name may also mean 'immediate area' (Gd).
\xv Wa: gabalnginy
\xe 'scrub dweller'
\xv Wa: garbehnginy
\xe 'gully dweller'
\xv Wa: bumilihnginy
\xe 'figher'
\xv Wa: wahngmalihnginy
\xe 'worker'
\xv Gd: gung-nginy
\xe 'waterdweller' (eg fish, water-beetle)
\xv Gd: gabal-nginy
\xe 'scrub-dweller' (eg scrub wallaby)
\xv Gd: mulinginy
\xe 'near the hill'
\xv Gd: balunnginy
\xe 'near the creek' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl;
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx nginyehr
\ps adverb
\de similar to, like, approximately (of position)
\re similar to ; like ; approximately (of position)
\do 
\sf
\co cf, ngehr (mild weakening), gimbay (stronger weakening), nginyehr between these two; another meaning 'like, similar to' (Gd), listed as 'blue' in Y:Watsn; possibly the -u(h) ending in Y:Watsn 'like' is e,g,tive case suffix. 
\xv Gd: Ngumbinydje nyahni bargan gale nginyehr.
\xe 'Did you see a boomerang like this one in the house?'
\xv Gd: Malahni gale nginyehre mah.
\xe 'Put that on one like this one.'
\xv Gd: Gaybe baygal yagambeh nyule nginyehr.
\xe 'The other man is not like him.'
\xv Gd: Bargan nginyehru nabani nyuleni.
\xe 'A boomerang-shaped object killed him.'
\xv Gd: Juwan nginyehrgi nyula bugayah gabunu.
\xe 'He wants a spearlike thing to poke through the hole.'
\xv Gd: Nyule,g,h jagun yagambeh ngalingah nginyehr.
\xe 'His country is not like ours.'
\xv Gd: Yagambu nyahni bayahny nginyehr.
\xe 'Never before have I seen a day like today.'
\xv Gd: Jubuny nginyehr gunuyu dubanydju.
\xe 'It's almost like night with this fog.'
\xv Gd Nyahni bidjanggam gudjimi gudjahm nginyehrni.
\xe 'I saw small animals like rats.'
\xv Gd: gahri nginyehr
\xe 'somewhere fairly near there'
\xv Gd: bundagahle nginyehr bahyani
\xe 'appeared fairly close (to me)' 
\rfg Y:Allen ninyeire adv. Like , ninyeiri blue; Y:Watsn nyin'yero like adv. , niny'erÌ¨ blue 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx -ngi, -ngih
\ps suffix
\de and
\re and
\co Apparant free variation between -ngi and -ngih; is suffixed to the second of two conjoined nouns.
\xv Wa: Maliyu jugahla gadjalahny guruhmbilngih.
\xe 'He drinks tea and milk.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu dabahydju nyahni budjigehn gundurngi mala.
\xe 'The dog saw the cat and the rat.'

\rfk Wa:Crowl

\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx ngubu
\ps time 
\de yesterday, tomorrow, one day away (past or future)
\re yesterday ; tomorrow ; one day away (past or future)
\do ti
\do 
\sf
\co i.e. One day removed from the present. Can specify 'tomorrow' using ngubudjang (M:Liv). Gn has ba-ngubu 'tomorrow', ngububu 'yesterday' and bangubu 'tomorrow' (Gn); ngubugan 'morning'. 
\xv Gd: ngubuh gunah 
\xe 'yesterday' (this unseen one day off)
\xv Gd: ngubuhwar 
\xe 'two days away'
\xv Gd: ngubuh-ya 
\xe 'ignorant, greenhorn'
\xv Gd:JThomas: ngubu warbu
\xe 'yesterday'
\xv Gn: ba-ngubu
\xe 'tomorrow'
\xv Gn: ngububu
\xe 'yesterday'
\xv Wa: Gala badjilehnyi yagambeh ngali yan.gahny ngubuhdjang.
\xe 'If it rains, we won't go tomorrow.' (tomorrow-more)
\xv Cas: Ngadjuwar malahni bumgahny ngubu.
\xe 'I'll kill him tomorrow.'
\xv Cas: Ngadjuwar malahni bumani ngubu.
\xe 'I killed him yesterday.'
\xv M:Liv: Munu waybaru gandjilinibahny ngubu.
\xe 'That fire will be lit tomorrow.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Bugadji wudjirbu ngubu.
\xe 'Get up at daylight tomorrow.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngayu bumgahla ngubu.
\xe 'I'll kill him tomorrow.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Wamginy ngubu.
\xe 'Coming tomorrow.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm ngubu yesterday, tomorrow; Y:Holm ngubu Logn, tomorrow Fogty; Y:Allen mobo tomorrow, mobobo yesterday; Y:Watsn mÌ«bÌ«; M:Liv nobo, nobo-jung; nobo, nobo-bo yesterday; M:Sc wobbo to-morrow, yesterday; Tw:Curr:Bray wobbo, woebbo; AT:Curr:Prior mobo; AT:Curr:LandsWhnooboo; AT:Curr:JOconn wooboo; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr obo; M:Liv nobo, nobo-jung; Ng:Sc:11/1899:Bray wobbo yesterday, to-day and to-morrow; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray wobbo(?)(sic), woebbo tomorrow, yesterday; M:Sc:Brunswk wobbo to-morrow, yesterday 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl ngubu; Bj:LWilsn ngubu; Bj:TMcD nguhbu tomorrow(?) yesterday(?); Bj:Holm:Fe,g,, Turnbl ngubu yesterday, tomorrow; Wi:Curr:Lismore nooba yesterday Wi:Curr:Richmond nobau yesterday, nobau tomorrow; Ny:Curr:Ballina wobbo yesterday, tomorrow, wooboo by-and-by; Bj:Sha:Turnbl ngubu warbu
\rfk Wa:Crowl ngubu;Wa:Calley ngubu tomorrow ; Cas:Smy ; ngubu 
\rfr Gd:Sci:Woodnbng noboo; Gn:JMathew bangubu tomorrow , ngububu yesterday; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce noopeboo to-morrow , nooreboo warreboo yesterday ; Gn:Mathew bangubu tomorrow ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx nguhnyba

\re snake, black
\do rep
\do 
\sf

\dt 06/Mar/2015

\lx -nguhrgan
\ps suffix
\de having, with
\re having ; with
\do 
\sf
\co Short form -nguhr, implies presence, sometimes in particularly large quantities, of the referent (Wa), with, has under the control of or in the poessession of some other being (the word suffixed), e,g, dubay-nguhrgan 'having a wife', bilahr-ngurgan 'having a spear'; added to a verbal participle or noun referring to an action, it refers to a person who has completed the action, not a habitual doer of the action. 
\xv Wa: ngahri-nguhrgan 
\xe 'a person who has had a dance'
\xv Wa: bumilih-ngurgan 
\xe 'a person who has had a fight'
\xv Wa: yarbil-nguhrgan 
\xe 'a person who has sung a song' 
\xv Wa:Crowl: Mala bargan-nguhrgan gawarehla. 
\xe 'He is running with a lot of boomerangs.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Ngay malahba yan.gahla baygalbah guhndun-nguhrganbah wadjiyah malahni. 
\xe 'I'm going to the man who's got lots of hair to tell him something.'
\xv Wa:Crowl: Bagay-nguhrgan mala jali. 
\xe 'That tree has got some honey in it.' 
\xv Gd: Nyule ngagamnguhrgan. 
\xe 'He has a dog.'
\xv Gd: Mahnyu jali baling wurahng-nguhrgan. 
\xe 'Those trees have new leaves.'
\xv Gd: Gandjabul nyule-nguhrgan yehni. 
\xe 'The constable took him away.'
\xv Y:Culhm: Yili ngagam-nguhrgan baygal? 
\xe 'Where is the dog's master?' or 'Where is the man with the dog?'
\xv M:Liv: malanguhr 
\xe 'he also'
\xv Y:Culhm: gudja-ngurgan 
\xe 'honey-bearing, having honey' (The tree (had) honey in it.)
\xv Y:Alln: ngadjang-nguhr 
\xe 'pelican' (literally 'got grandfather')
\xv Tw:Bray: Jalgany-nguhr Tommy?
\xe 'Has Tommy a wife now?'
\xv Tw:Bray: Ngayu-nguhr yanbalahla. 
\xe 'I will go to.'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm Y:Allen nyajungnoro pelican; M:Liv -urrugan, urru; mullagurru (sic); Tw:Curr:Bray chulgun noroe Tommy, nio nur-ra yan-ba-la-la 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl , 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx -ngula
\ps suffix 
\de also, too
\re also ; too
\do 
\sf
\co -wula in We, contrasts with -ngi(h) in being more of an afterthought; see also ngule, nguleh. 
\xv Wa: Mala bin.gihng birah waybara mala wagany-ngula. 
\xe 'Throw the turtle onto the fire, and the catfish too.'
\xv Wa: Gabay-ngula yunamah bidjang. 
\xe 'Put a bit of sugar in too.'
\xv Wa: Nganyah-ngula gahny jahdjam gibing. 
\xe 'My children are sick too.'
\xv Wa: Wulimahnyi dam munu nganyi-ngu ganggah-ngula. 
\xe 'If you find some yams there, call me too.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl 
\rfr
\rfo

\ps noun

\re humpies
\do art
\do 
\sf
\co Etchells, or the Second Bluff, Nerang Creek, above Surfers Paradise 'Moombee-moombee'- The Humpies (Hanlon), plural of ngumbiny 'house, humpy'. 
\rfg Y:Hanln Moombee-moombee 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx ngumbinda- 
\ps verb
\de make a house
\re make a house
\do 
\sf
\co Possibly ngumbindja-. M:Liv umbin-da make a house ngumbi(ny) [ngumbi(n)], n. One humpy; see also 'camp', diman, jiman, mimi.
\rfg Y:Hanln moombee , mi-mi 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx ngumbiny
\ps noun
\de camp, house, hut, dwelling, blanket, rag, cover, bark
\re camp ; house ; hut ; dwelling ; blanket ; rag ; cover ; bark
\do1 art
\do2 ne
\sf
\co M:Liv's suffixes show final /ny/, gamay ngumbiny can be used for a large building such as a church, or for a collection of humpies - a town or village, ngumbiny also used for the blankets given to the Aborigines on Queen's birthday, and for a rag tied round the foot (M:Liv). Y:Watsn claims corrupted by white people to 'humpy' or 'umpy'. Y:Hanln forms noomboolalah and noomboolya probably belong with numbuh- 'return'.
\xv M:Liv: Ngay gilagir ngumbinygir.
\xe 'I would like to have that house.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyula bayini ngumbinyu.
\xe 'He came out of the house.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu yagahny ngumbiny.
\xe 'I might build a house, put it up.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm ngumbiny house, ngumban blanket; Y:Holm ngumbiny (ngumbuny Fogty) I. Bark, 2. Hut, house, home; Y:Allen ngum-bin house; Y:Watsn ngÌ_m'bin, ngum'bin, M:Liv ngumbin; umbin, umbin-gerry; -jo e,g, -je dat, -nyo abl1, -ja abl2; Mur:Sc:Hargrv oombin blanket; Ng:Sc:Cudgn humbin hut, humbangaro horse (sic); Y:Watsn n'gumbeen blanket (= a covering), noomboolalah, noombin or noomboolya home; 
\rfb
\rfk We:Gordn camp , house , hall ; Cas:Smy ngumbinj house, dwelling ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt house , hut; Gn:JMathew ngumbin house ; Gn:Mathew ngumbin house
\rfo Cop:Hargrv berongumbi hut (small house) ;
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\dt 06/Mar/2015

\lx ngunda-
\ps verb transitive 
\de wait, wait for, accompany
\re wait ; wait for ; accompany
\do 
\sf
\co Also recorded as nguhnda- (see example), Morgan has mundali-, q.v. Gd 'accompany' meaning appears to overlap with Wa examples of 'wait for'.
\xv Wa: Gadji ngay jugalehny ngaywahr yagambeh nguhndalehny blaganmihni.
\xe 'I'm going to drink here, but I'm not going to wait for you.'
\xv Wa: Gadji ngundaleh ngadjah.
\xe 'Wait for me here.'
\xv Cas: Ngundale,g,r gale guwang wanalehni. 
\xe 'Wait till the rain has stopped.'
\xv Cas: Wadjungdjargan nguhndalehn ngandiri nyahnagayi.
\xe 'The mother-in-law waited for her in the darkness.'
\xv Cas: Wudjah ngay ngundalehn.
\xe 'I have been waiting for you.'
\xv Cas: Ngundalehlabe nguy nyulangahgu janguygu.
\xe 'He waited for/is waiting for his enemy.'
\xv Cas: Ngundani nyulayu balugahni.
\xe 'He awaited Balugahn.'
\xv Bj: Ngundaleh ngay yangiwanyi.
\xe 'Wait till I come.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm ngunda- , r.-r. Imp. Ngundali , term. Ngundalin 
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy ngund-a , ngudale,g,r , ngu:ndalen ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt accompany; 
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\dt 06/Mar/2015

\lx ngurahm
\ps noun, adjective
\de sleep, asleep, sleeping
\re sleep ; asleep ; sleeping
\do bp
\do 
\sf
\co Holmer records murahm; all other dialects and sources suggest ngurahm; ngurahmbil 'sleepy' (M); see also yuna- 'lie down'; sleep ngurahm + -an.ga (Y:Allen, Y:Watsn); yuna- ngurahm Wa, ngurahm yina- Gd 'to sleep'.
\xv Wa: Mahny jahdjam yunahla ngurahm.
\xe 'The children are sleeping.'
\xv Wa: Wahndjarehn mala ngurahmba.
\xe 'He rolled over in his sleep.'
\xv Cas: Ngurahm nguy nyan.gan yunahla.
\xe 'She is lying asleep.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Jahdjam murahm.
\xe 'The children are asleep.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngurahm banah.
\xe 'Go to sleep.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngurahmngurahm banah!
\xe 'Go to sleep (mother to child).'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay ngurahm yunahny.
\xe 'I will lie down and sleep.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngurahm banah!, Ngurahm-ngurahm banah!
\xe 'Go to sleep!' (mother to child)
\xv M:Liv: Ngay ngurahm yunahny.
\xe 'I will lie down and sleep.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yina-, ngurahm; Y:Holm nguram sleepy, sleeping, asleep (Curry, QLong), cf, muram; Y:Allen nguram sleep n., v. Pr nguram, p nguranen, pf nguranian, f ngurane,g,la; Y:Watsn v. ngur'am, ngur'amen, ngur'amian, ngur'ame,g,la; M:Liv woram, woram; Mur:Sc:HerbPenne nooram sleep; Tw:Curr:Bray woram, also seems to have unera, una-ran-gee: nubbe unera Well! go to sleep, kooba nio una-ran-gee by-and-by I'll sleep; Ngr:Gresty woorahm sleep; AT:Curr:Prior moram sleep; AT:Curr:LandsWh woorwan; AT:Curr:O'Conn noram; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr woorum; Y:Hanln n'goorahm sleep ; Ng:Sc:11/1899:Bray wo-ram to sleep; Ng:Curr:TwPt:Bray woram asleep
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl ngura:m; Bj:LWilsn ngurahm asleep; Bj:Cowln ngurahm sleep; Bj:Holm:Fe,g,muram sleep , be asleep Wi:Curr:Lismore newram (?) sleep; Wi:Curr:Richmond wouram sleep; Ny:Curr:Ballina woo ram; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl sleep; Cas:Smy ngura:m ; Wa/Gd:Calley yur:am sleep; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt sleep ; 
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\re sleep
\do bp

\co Inherently continuous/repetitive; yuna- ngurahm in Wa.

\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx nguru wandehn 
\ps noun
\de dead person's spirit, spirit, person recently deceased 
\re dead person's spirit ; spirit ; person recently deceased
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Literally 'a spirit up above, spirit climbed'; all the nguru go to waydjang (from way 'above') where they live on mar(a)bil, a kind of celestial food (cf, Kamilaroi word murraba 'good'), nguru in some dialects means 'dark, night'. 
\rfg M:Liv nguru wanden 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx nguruny, ngurihny 
\ps noun
\de emu 
\re emu
\do bd 
\do 
\sf Dromaius novae hollandiae (Watson) 
\co Gn supports nguruny. M:Liv hints that 'emu' is derived from nguru 'shade, spirit', some possibility this form is implied.
\xv Wa: Ngadju mala nguruny bilahru bugani nyabay jugali-nyun.
\xe 'I speared the emu while it was drinking water.' 
\rfg Y:Allen murun; Y:Watsn mur'on; Mur:Sc:Hargrv oorm; Ng:Sc:Cudgens arcroon (aicroon?) emu; Y:Hanln n'goorun;  Ng:Sc:Cudgn3/1903 arcroon emu; Ng:Sc:Mur oorm emu 
\rfb Bj:Sha ngurihny emu; Wi:Curr:Lismore nurun; Wi:Curr:Richmond ooring; Bj:Sc:Coraki murum emu; Bj:Sc:Coraki vuriu [sic] emu; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 nuring emu; Ny:Curr:Ballina wooring;
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy ngurinj, ngurunj; Wa/Gd:Calley yur:unj;
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce no-u-rin; Gn:JMathew nguruin ; Gn:Mathew nguruin ;
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\do2 cl

\lx nguy
\ps adjective 
\de true, truly, real, actual, indeed
\re true ; truly ; real ; actual ; indeed
\do 
\sf
\co See also -nguy etc,, can follow an interrogative as a reply to a question with sense 'I don't know'. 
\xv Cas: Nyanggur munah nguy bundahng? 
\xe 'Is that true?'
\xv Cas: Ngadjuwar nguy nabani.
\xe 'I really hit him / I hit him indeed.'
\xv Cas: Nyule behn, ganggil nguy gibing-bunggehn.
\xe 'He fell and his arm was damaged.'
\xv Cas: Gahngani gihdjay nyan.gandu, bulbing-mani nguy.
\xe 'She took a possum-skin and made a drum out of it.'
\xv Gd: Gah nguy nyule.
\xe 'There he is' (There truly he)
\xv Gd: Yile nyule? - Yile nguy.
\xe 'Where is he? - I don't know.'
\xv Gd: Nyang nyahni nyule? - Nyang nguy!
\xe 'What did he see? - I don't know.'
\xv Gd: Nyahgu gawalehn mugim? - Nyahgu nguy!
\xe 'Why was he breaking the axe? - I don't know.'
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy ng?i ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\ps suffix
\de topic marker
\re topic marker
\co

\xe 'Where are the Blacks?'
\xv Bj: Yuba-nguy.

\lx nguyayma-
\ps verb transitive 
\de say (something), speak (a language), talk
\re say (something) ; speak (a language) ; talk
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co
\xv Wa: Wanah nguyaymaleh mahnyunah nguyay.
\xe 'Don't speak their language!'
\xv Wa: Maliyu nganyi ngabar-ngabarmahla nguyaymahla.
\xe 'He is speaking quickly.'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal nguyaymalehla jarwalinyun mala bargan.
\xe 'The man is speaking while carving the boomerang.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Wahlu nguyaymah.
\xe 'You say it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Wahlu nguyaymani.
\xe 'You said it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nguyaymaleh nganyi.
\xe 'Say that to me.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngali nguyaymaleh yawundah.
\xe 'We will (or let us) talk in the afternoon.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay nguyaymalehla.
\xe 'I speak (Bundjalung).' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl nguyuyma (nguyma?), nguyuy male:la pres &/or cont; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, ngujaima-, ngujaimali, ngujaimalila, ngujaimani
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; 
\rfr
\rfo

\re speak ; talk
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Ng form probably 'speech', but also see nguyma- and nguy.

\xe '(She) is speaking.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Nyahn.gan yugumbe gala dubayihn nguymalehla.
\xe 'She, my daughter, does not speak (Bandjalang).'

\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx -nguy, -ngu, -ng
\ps suffix 
\de topic change
\re topic change
\do 
\sf
\co cf, also nguy usually indicates change of topic, but sometimes just conjunction; occurs on verb of second sentence (or clause), or the first word of the second sentence, whatever that may be. 
\xv Wa: Mala baygal yarbilehla mala-nguy dubaya ngahrila. 
\xe 'The man is singing and the woman is dancing.'
\xv Wa: Ngihma mala biridju madji mala jugayah-nguy. 
\xe 'Squeeze the honey there so you can drink it (then).'
\xv Wa: Wulah nganyi mala wangah dugulduguhl ngali-ngu yan.gahnybe. 
\xe 'Give me that dilly-bag of yours before we,g,.' (and only then will we go)
\xv Wa: Malahna yiralingah yulany mahnyu budjur baygalnah-ngu malahnawahr gadjangwahr. 
\xe 'A whiteman's skin is soft but an Aborigine's is hard.'
\xv Wa: Guwangwehn balun-ngu mala ngulahrun. 
\xe 'It rained and then the river flooded.'
\xv Wa: Muhwa gahnyu yan.gihbe-nguy. 
\xe 'Pick these up so we can go.'
\rfg
\rfb 
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\re,g, ; come

\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx numbihl
\ps locative 
\de after, behind, back, back (of something), rear
\re after ; behind ; back ; back (of something) ; rear
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Locative case numbihla; numbihla 'behind (it)', see nimbihl, must take same case marking as the noun it qualifies. 
\xv Cas: Jahnani nyule numbihla ngumbinydjah. 
\xe 'He stood behind the house.'
\xv Cas: Dubaydjar gawarehn numbihlgu. 
\xe 'The woman ran back.'
\xv Cas: Yehnaga numbihl-gimbadji malahyi baygalbahyi. 
\xe 'Sit behind that man.'
\xv Cas: Jundahma wehlu numihlgimbanyu
\xe 'You push from behind.'
\xv Cas: Bahnden nyule numbihnubu bidjangdjarbahnu. 
\xe 'He arrived after his father.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, numbi:l, numbi.åála
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy numbi:hl , numbi:la , numbi:nubu ; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx numbuh-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de come back, return
\re come back ; return
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Hanln lists as 'home'; Y:Hanln form noombin 'home' probably ngumbiny, and his other words glossed 'home' belong here; forms numbuhlalah, numbuhliyah; Y:Allen, Y:Watsn have nimbulima 'return', q.v.; cf, also numbali-. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu yan.gahla wamginy ngubuh ngawi ngayu numbuhlelah. 
\xe 'I will go and return tomorrow.'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm return , come back; Y:Hanln noomboolalah , noombin , noomboolya home 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx numbuhnggi-

\do 
\sf
\co nimbihnggi- in We, an example under burung-burung gives a form numguwa-.
\xv Wa: Ngali numbuhngginybu burin.galingah (sic). 
\xe 'We would go back to Pretty Gully.'
\xv Wa: Mala bin.gihng numbuhnggila nyabaygu.
\xe 'The turtle is going back to the water.'
\xv Cas: Numbuhnggina male buwihyan, guwang nguy badjilehny. 
\xe 'When that wind turns it will rain.'
\xv Cas: Ngay numbuhngginybu bulahbu gibam behni.
\xe 'I shall return (when) two moons have fallen.'
\xv Cas: Nyali nyule numbuhngginy? 
\xe 'When will he return?'
\xv Cas: Numguweyalehnbe,g,hbu nyulangahga waybar, ganngalenbe, burung-burung. 
\xe 'He went back to his camp, thought, then went to sleep.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl numbuhnggi-; We:Crowl nimbihnggi- to return ; Cas:Smy numbu:ngg-i , numbÌ¼nggina , numbÌ¼ngginj , numgwejalenbe
\rfr
\rfo

\lx numgir 
\ps noun, time
\de day, midday, daytime, daylight
\re day ; midday ; daytime ; daylight
\do1 ne
\do2 ti
\sf
\co numgir (Y:Geyt:Culhm, AT:Curr:O'Conn); nyanggay (Y:Watsn, AT:Curr:Prior, GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr, Tw:Curr:Bray); cf, yalgan. M:Liv form could be namgir. 
\xv Wa: Mala yalgan bahn.gala numgir mala-ngu gibam jubunyja 
\xe 'The sun comes out in the day and then the moon comes out at night.'
\xv Y:Watsn: gali nyangga 
\xe 'today' (this visible day)
\xv Cas: Ngali yan.gahny numgir. 
\xe 'We'll go at midday.'
\xv Cas: Ngay yehnni bulahbu numgir. 
\xe 'I walked for two days.' 
\rfg Y:Geyt:Culhm numgir daytime ; M:Liv num-gerry daylight, Tw:Curr:Bray nung; AT:Curr:Prior manga day; AT:Curr:O'Conn numagera, GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy numgir day, midday; Wa:Crowl day ; We:Gordn day ; 
\rfr Gd:Calley num:g ? r ? day; Gd:Geyt day ; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng numbeeree day;

\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx nungany, nuwang
\ps noun
\de food
\re food 
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co nangany in more southern dialects and Bj. Y:Holm lists as 'bread and meat, food' (QLong), and nunginy (Thmpsn); Y:Allen & Y:Watsn list nungany as 'animal food', but appears to be not; Y:Allen and Y:Watsn also have form nuwa.ngany; 'vegetable food' in other dialects.
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu guybahla nungany jaligu. 
\xe 'I'm cooking food to eat.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm nungany food , tucker; Y:Calley nu:ngan , nangany in other dialects of the western area. ; 
\rfr Y:Allen noung food , nongunn animal food; Y:Watsn noung food ,  stomach (ki'dhera stomach) , non'gun flesh food; AT:Curr:O'Conn nungun 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfo

\lx -ny

\re thing/person acted on by a verb ; person/thing acted on by a verb

\xe 'things which have been carried'

\xe 'carved ornament'

\xe 'The water is too deep for the boy.'

\xe 'The water is flowing over the stones.'

\xe 'The water froze overnight.'

\xe 'You can catch turtles in still water.'

\dt 08/Apr/2015

\lx nyah- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de see, look, look at, watch, find
\re see ; look ; look at ; watch ; find
\do senses
\do 
\sf
\co Forms from Curr AT:Curr:Prior attest nyahni (past), initial /ny/, and irregular -bi suffix nyahbidjam 'can't see (it)'. Bray's gloss of nyahni as 'see' (a complete action) is one important clue to the aspect system of the verbs, he did speak the language and gave Curr a rich collection of extras words and sentences; Holm term. Nyahni, prog. nyahla, imm. Nyahny, r-r term. Nyahlin, prog. Nyahlilah, ger. Nyahbi (Holm); Wi:Curr:Lismore form probably future nyahlany, Crowl - irregular, can be reduplicated nyanyah-.
\xv Wa: Nyahli wudja madji nyabaydja. 
\xe 'Look at yourself in the water.'
\xv Wa: Jubunydjahbu ngay nyanyahlila. 
\xe 'I look about early in the morning.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju nyahni blaganmini.
\xe 'I can see you all.'
\xv Wa: Mahny yirali nyahlila ngalingi.
\xe 'The whitemen are watching us.' 
\xv We: nyahlelah 
\xe 'seeing'
\xv Cas: Ngadju wihnyi nyahla. 
\xe 'I see you.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju malahni nyahbigi.
\xe 'I wish to see that fellow.'
\xv M:Liv: Nyahdjam ngay, Nyahbidjam ngay. 
\xe 'I do not see.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu wanyi nyahni galgabalini.
\xe 'I saw you cutting (it).'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Nyahla miyiyu.
\xe '(the kids) are staring (at us).'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wahlu nyah.
\xe 'You see or look.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyahbigu (nyabigi) wahnyi. 
\xe '(I have come) to see you.'
\xv Y:Holm:Curry: Ngayu nyahla.
\xe 'I can see (him).'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Duhyiyjah guruhman nganyih nyahna. 
\xe 'The kangaroo is frightened because he sees me.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Nyah malahni jabuhngi jalganyi.
\xe 'Look at the boy and the woman.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Nyahlelah ngaw. 
\xe 'I'm looking.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Wahlu nyahni gilahni? 
\xe 'Do you see that one (woman)?'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngayu nyahni ngubu. 
\xe 'I saw her yesterday.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Gile nyahni ngayu.
\xe 'I see them now.'(lit. 'there see I')
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Nyahni ngayu guruhman.
\xe 'I see a kangaroo.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngayu nyahni bulajalgany. 
\xe 'I see two women.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Hebro(sic) nyahbijam
\xe 'I cannot see his face.'
\xv Ng:Bray nyahbidjam 
\xe 'can't see (it).'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Nyah gale,g,rumani! 
\xe 'Look at that kangaroo!'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: nyahlilah 
\xe 'is seeing'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Yugambe nyahlilah jihyu. 
\xe 'blind'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay nyahni nyulangi. 
\xe 'I saw him.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyahla birilinyun. 
\xe '(We are) watching (them) fishing.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyahny ngay wanyi. 
\xe 'I will see you.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyahlen ngali.
\xe 'We looked.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Jananggan nyahlilah jalum. 
\xe 'A boy is seeing a fish.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyahlaba babar.
\xe '(You) can see it plain.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay nyahla bulangi. 
\xe 'I can see you (plural).'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay nyahla gibam. 
\xe 'I can see the moon.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyahbi wanyi ngubu. 
\xe '(come) to see you tomorrow.
\xv Bj:Holm: nyahbigu 
\xe 'in order to see.'
\xv M:Liv: Nyahjam ngay, nyahbijam ngay. 
\xe 'I do not see.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu wanyi nyahni galgabalini.
\xe ''I saw you cutting (it).' 
\xv Ng: Nyahni ngulung! 
\xe 'Look out ahead!' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm look at , see , watch; Y:Holm nyah- , nyahla; wants to nyabigu , nyabigi; Y:Allen pr nya , p nyani , pf nyayan , f nya-ala find (as ‰ÛÏsee ‰ÛÏ); Y:Watsn nya; nya'ni; nya'yan; nya'Ì¢la find (same as ‰ÛÏsee‰Û) , 'M:Liv vt na see; naijuå¡m ,  nabaijuå¡m not see; Tw:Curr:Bray narlala , nione , nionee ,  narbidgum; AT:Curr:Prior nani; AT:Curr:LandsWh ni-in;  AT:Curr:O'Conn nar; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr nyenda; M:Liv vt na see; naijuå¡m , nabaijuå¡m not see; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray ,  Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn narbil-la to see; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray narlala see , nionee see , saw , nione see , nio-nio-nee I saw , narn will see ,  nar-bid-jum have not seen 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl nja: , nalila: pres &lor cont. , na:ni past , na:nigu (song); Bj:LWilsn nyahla; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, flah- etc, , na:bigu bt; Wi:Curr:Lismore niallan see; Wi:Curr:Richmond narala see; Ny:Curr:Ballina nad see; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn ; Cas:Smy nj-a, nja:la, nja:bigi ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt look, see; Gn:JMathew nya ; 
\rfo
\dt 08/Apr/2015

\sf
\co Literally 'watch-watch, see-see'.

\lx nyang
\ps pronoun
\de what, something, question marker
\re what ; something ; question marker
\do 
\sf
\co e,g, as question marker 'I wonder, whether', etc, (Holmer), Y:Holm variant nyangga; minyang more likely in Y area. 
\xv Cas:Smy: Nyanggur wihnyi yingani?
\xe 'What bit you?'
\xv Cas: Nyang wihnyi yingani.
\xe 'Something bit you.'
\xv Cas: Nyanggur wehlu ginini?
\xe 'What did you do?'
\xv Cas: Wehluwar nyang ginini.
\xe 'You did something.'
\xv Cas: Nyanggur wudjeh yan.gahny bayahny?
\xe 'Are you going today?'
\xv Cas: Nyang male bugal?
\xe 'Is that alright?'
\xv Bj:Holm:Turnbl: Nyang mala?
\xe 'What is that?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyang wan.gahla?
\xe 'What doing?'
\xv Bj:Morgn: Nyang gala?
\xe 'What's that?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyang mala (or) Nyangbar?
\xe 'What is that?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyang wuya wandehny?
\xe 'Will you climb?'
\xv Bj:Holm: nyang ngali gahny 
\xe '(to see) whether we will get (it)' 
\rfg Y:Holm nyan, nyangga (rare in north Sha)
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl njang; Bj:Morgn nyang? what? nyanggala? what's that?; Bj:Holm:Fe,g,, Turnbl nyang ; 
\rfk Cas:Smy njang ; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015
