\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx nyanga-, nyangga-
\ps verb
\de do (what), do something (with), make (something), make what with, paint, do what with, know what to do with
\re do (what) ; do something (with) ; make (something) ; make what with ; paint ; do what with ; know what to do with
\do 
\sf
\co Can substitute for a verb which doesn't come to mind; irregular nyanga-/nyangga- but Crowley states nyangga- required an answer telling what one is doing, final vowel of stem changes to /i/ before -li. 
\xv Wa: Nyanggahla wahlu? - Ngadju bawgahla nguhmbiny.
\xe 'What are you doing? - I'm building a house.'
\xv Wa: Yagambeh ngadjuy ganngahla nyangbih ngadju.
\xe 'I don't know what to do.'
\xv Wa: Nganyah banahmbu bilahr mala nyangani.
\xe 'My brother made a spear.'
\xv Wa: Nyangani gunah ganyahl.
\xe 'What happened to the fishing lines?'
\xv Wa: Maliyu gudjandu nyanggahla mahnyu nangany.
\xe 'She uses a stone to make/prepare the food.'
\xv We: Nyangani nyulayu?
\xe 'What did he say? (What did he do?)'
\xv We: Gumbiyu nyangani?
\xe 'Did they all do it?'
\xv Cas: Ngadju nyangani galgir ngaguyahbu.
\xe 'I made the canoe this morning.'
\xv Cas: Ngay nyangbih.
\xe 'I wish to make it, would like to make it.'
\xv Cas: Nyanggahy ndjur wehlu munah? 
\xe 'What are you going to do with that?'
\xv Cas: Nyanggahnigur nyule yagambe yangguwahla?
\xe 'Why don't he come? (did-what, he doesn't come?)'
\xv Cas: Ngadju nyanggahny male.
\xe 'I'll do something with that, I know what to do with that.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngali nyangani gila.
\xe 'We did it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay nyangahny wanyi. 
\xe 'I will paint you.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyangile,g, wuya yawahrgu.
\xe 'You paint yourself (or get ready) for the corroboree.
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyangilehla? 
\xe 'What are (you) doing?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyangilehla bula may.
\xe 'What are you doing there?'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyangilur mahnyu. 
\xe 'They used to make (it).'
\xv Bj:Holm: Wahlu nyanggah bargan.
\xe 'You make a boomerang.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay wanyi nyanggahny dalanggu.
\xe 'I am going to paint you (with ochre).' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, nyanga- , term. Nyangani , imm. Fiangany , rr-imp. nyangili. Prog. Nyangilila , past hab. Nyangilur; nyangga- , imp. nyangga , imm. Nyanggan 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Cas:Smy njangg-a, njanggÌÁinj, njangga:ni do what with, make what with, do something with, know what to do with 
\rfr Gd:Geyt nyangi- ; 
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx nyangga, nangga-nangga, nyanggar
\ps noun
\de regent bird, regent bowerbird 
\re bird, regent ; bowerbird, regent ; regent bird
\do bd 
\do 
\sf Sericulous chrysocephalus 
\co cf, 'sun' nyangga; the 'sun bird' (nyangga 'sun') because the flashing brightness of this bird suggested the,g,ory of the sun (Y:Hanln); Y:Hanln also gives nyangginyanggi or nyanggay-nyanggay. 
\rfg Y:Allen nunga-nunga regent bird; Y:Watsn nyÌ_n'ga-nyÌ_n'ga regent bird (S. Chrysocephalus) (see 'sun'); M:Liv nyungga the regent bird , the sun; Mur:Sc:Hargrv mungai sun; GC:Nerang:police nunkera regent bird; Y:Hanln nyunga , n'yungi-n'yungie 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr

\lx nyanggi

\co

\lx nyanggur (nyanggul)

\co

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx nyang, nya-, nyah-
\ps interrogative
\de what, something, eh?, can also introduce a question
\re what ; something ; eh? 
\do 
\sf
\co Can also introduce a question. /ng/ lost in compounds nyahgu 'what for', nyahlu 'what-e,g,', etc, (examples below). Gn:JMathew gives nangami - he usually notices /ny/. 
\xv Wa: Nyang blaganmir gilahya giwani?
\xe 'Did you go there?'
\xv Wa: Ngali guriyabu wahngmalehn guhl nyang.
\xe 'We used to work for gold a long time ago, didn't we?'
\xv Gd: Nyang nguhn wehn wahlu?
\xe 'Are you hot?'
\xv Gd: Nyang nyule,g,ngngalehni?
\xe 'Is he the one who was shouting?'
\xv Gd: nyah-le
\xe 'at what?'
\xv Gd: nyah-lu
\xe 'with what?'
\xv Gd: nyang-bu
\xe 'what's-its-name' (of person or thing the name of which eludes the memory)
\xv Gd: nyanginyehr
\xe 'like what?' (cf, nginyehr [1])
\xv Gd: nyah-gi
\xe 'what ... Want?'
\xv Gd: nyah-gu
\xe 'what for? why?'
\xv Wu: Wirgahla mayu nyang.
\xe 'He (the clever feller) steals things.'
\xv Wu: Nyanggur wanah jagun?
\xe 'What is your country?'
\xv Gd: Nyahgi wahlu?
\xe 'What do you want?'
\xv Gd: Nyahgu gile jabuh dunggahla?
\xe 'Why is that boy crying?' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wu:Calley jagun; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gn:JMathew nangami what 
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\re,g,asshopper (generic)

\lx -nyan, -nyun
\ps suffix 
\de while, where, when
\re while ; where ; when

\co Indicates action going on at the same time as another action; -nyun more common in other sources, q.v.

\xv Bj:Holm: nganyi nyahnyan wahlu 
\xe 'when you see me' 
\xv Bj:Holm: ganggalinyan 
\xe 'when (they) are singing out' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm -Ã±un , -Ã±an

\rfr

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx nyaram
\ps noun
\de bearded jew lizard, jew lizard, Bearded Dragon,
\re jew lizard, bearded ; jew lizard ; lizard, jew ; Bearded Dragon ; Dragon, Bearded
\do1 rep
\do2 bp 
\sf Amphiboluous barbatos 
\co See also gabugan. Sometimes frilled lizard, frilled neck lizard (however I'm reliably informed they do not exist on the East Coast); also 'vulva' Wa, 'blue-tongue lizard' B.
\rfg Y:Geyt:Culhm; Y:Holm:Fogty , Thmpsn prickly lizard , a lizard that sleeps on river banks; Ngr:Gresty nurrum frilled lizard; Y:Hanln n 'yerrum sleeping lizard (also loosely used for Frilled and Jew Lizard) 
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy njeram; Wa:Crowl; B:Crowl ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce nearram jew lizard (Agama) ; 
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx nyaram
\ps noun
\de blue-tongued lizard
\re lizard, blue-tongued
\do rep
\do 
\sf
\co Y:Hanln 'sleeping lizard', also loosely used for frilled and jew lizard; given as 'blue tongue' in Birihn (Rappville N.S.W. Dialect). See also gubagan. 
\rfg Y:Hanln n'yerrum sleeping lizard 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx nyaram, ngaram
\ps noun
\de frilled lizard 
\re lizard, frilled
\do rep 
\do 
\sf Clamydosaurus kingii 
\co Probably only nyaram, Y:Geyt:Culhm gives as 'bearded jew lizard', similar lizards, and note shift in meaning of nyaram in other dialects: frilled lizard (Wa), blue tongue (B), and Y:Hanln who says it is 'sleeping lizard' (blue tongue), also loosely used for 'Frilled and Jew Lizard'. See also gubagan, gabugan.
\rfg Y:Allen ngarun. Y:Watsn ngÌ¢rÌ_m , nga'rum (Cl. Kingii); GC:Nerang:police nurrum , GC:Nerang:Sc nurum frill lizard; Y:Hanln n'yerrum sleeping lizard (also loosely used for Frilled and Jew Lizard) 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx nyule, nyuli
\ps pronoun
\de he
\re he
\do 
\sf
\co nyuli 'him, over there' = moomali nulee; nyula also nyila (Y:Holm). 
\xv Y:Allen: Yili nyule?
\xe 'Where is he?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamali nyule bugallwubihn.
\xe 'He is good/an expert.'
\xv Y:Culhm: Yugambeh yan.gehn nyulabehn. Or Nyula yan.gehn nyulabehn.(?)
\xe 'He didn't go with me.(?)' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm; Y:Allen neule nom. , neulongi acc. , neulonga gen. ,  neulongaba dat. To , neulongago dat. For, neulongabaia abl. With ,  neulongabano abl. From; illi neule where is he; Y:Watsn nyule; Y:Hanln nula him; nulee he , him , male; M:Liv nyuly

\lx -nyun
\ps suffix 
\de while doing, simultaneous or synchronous action, synchronous verb suffix 
\re while doing ; simultaneous action ; synchronous action ; synchronous verb suffix 
\do 
\sf
\co Action of another clause happens within the time occupied by the action of the -nyun verb, although the verb can stand alone in a sequence. 
\xv Gd:Geyt: Muli gadjalehla jahna-nyun janbalinyun. 
\xe 'My back is aching while I am standing up washing clothes.'
\xv Gd: Nyule,g, gurgun mahny bulah ngali gahngaliwa-nyun. 
\xe '(I) will speak to him while we are bringing the cattle.'
\xv Gd: Nyah-nyun jahdjami bugal wan.gahny nyulangam. 
\xe 'While I watch the children they will be,g,od.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu ganngahla waymalinyun. 
\xe 'I hear speaking there.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu nyahni gawarinyun jadjami. 
\xe 'I saw children running away.' 
\xv Wa, Gd: gawarinyun 
\xe 'car' 
\rfg M:Liv nyun
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\ps proper noun

\re name, Aboriginal
\do pp
\do 
\sf
\co For an Aboriginal person (Fogarty).

\lx nyunduhwen-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de,g,ieve, worry
\re,g,ieve ; worry
\do 
\sf
\co From nyunduh 'lonely, feeling grief', wen- irregular.
\xv Wa: Mala baygal nyunduhwen banidjargangahya balahyanah(gaya). 
\xe 'The man is grieving for his wife who died.'
\xv Wa: Mala nyunduhwen banidjargangahya.
\xe 'He's worried about his wife.'
\xv Wa: Mala nyunduhwen wadjungdjargan malahgu jahdjamgu.
\xe 'The mother is grieving for her baby.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl nyungduhwen- , nyunduhwen (ng apparently a misprint)

\lx wadji-
\ps verb transitive 
\de speak, say, talk, tell (to do something), tell someone something, tell, inform, order, ask
\re speak ; say ; talk ; tell (to do something) ; tell someone something ; tell ; inform ; order ; ask
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co
\xv We: Ngambuhru wadjeh. 
\xe 'Say it slowly.' (slow speak)
\xv Wa: Wanah mununu yanah ngadju wadjehnyidjahng. 
\xe 'Don't go from there unless I tell you.'
\xv Wa: Nyang ngadji galahni wadjehny?
\xe 'What will we tell him?'
\xv Wa: Jiginehny galahni wadjehny? 
\xe 'How will we tell him?'
\xv Wa: Maliyu dandaygambu wadjini biridju nyulangi yanginiyah. 
\xe 'The old man told him to bring him some honey.'
\xv Wa: Nyahn.gandu wadjini yan.gahny ngay.
\xe 'She said, I will go.'
\xv Wa: Nyahn.gandu wadjini yan.gahny nyahn.gan.
\xe 'She said she would go.'
\xv Wa: Yagambeh mahnyuni wadji-wadjehnyi yagambeh mahnyulu ganngahny. 
\xe 'If you don't encourage them (to learn), they won't understand anything.'
\xv Cas: Nyang nyulamang wadjelehla? 
\xe 'What are they saying/talking about?'
\xv Cas: Ngihn.gur wadjelehla Bandjalang?
\xe 'Who can speak Bundjalung?'
\xv Cas: Wadje,g, malahni. 
\xe 'Ask/tell that fellow.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju malahni wadjeni. 
\xe 'I told him.' 
\xv Cas: Nyule ngalibay wadjilehny. 
\xe 'He'll talk to us.'
\xv Cas: Ngay wadjelehny nganyah-banybal bayahny. 
\xe 'I shall talk to my father today.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju wihnyi wadjeni ginehya. 
\xe 'I advised you to do it.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju nyulangi wadjeni "male,g,lgir garingahny."
\xe 'I told him, "the canoe would sink."' 
\rfg 
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn wajehla , wajilehla say , talk; Wa:Calley wadje: speak ; Cas:Smy wadj-e, wadjelela, wadje,g,, wadjeni, wadjilenj, wadjilja:

\dt 11/Mar/2015

\lx wagay
\ps noun
\de shadow of departed person, spirit (of dead), sign, shadow, photo
\re shadow of departed person ; spirit (of dead) ; sign ; shadow ; photo
\do1 lg
\do2 art
\sf
\co Shadow of a departed person M:Liv, sign Y:Alln, Y:Watsn. 'Has a more superstitious use than nguru' (M:Liv). 'When a person is ill, the warrima, 'wizard' is sent for to throw on him a good spell, called bunyarama warrima. The warrima takes something like a rope out of his stomach(!), and climbs up to waijong to have an interview with the wagai. On his return, if the man is to recover, he says 'Your wagai has come back and you will soon be well', but if he is to die, he says 'I could not get your wagai.' The wagai are also the spirits consulted when anyone dies suddenly, discover by whose means the death was brought about.' 
\xv Cas: Wagayngin gilahna baygalnah wandehn babar Balugahnba. 
\xe 'That man's spirit climbed up to the spirit world (Balugahn).' 
\rfg Y:Alln wogai sign; Y:Watsn wog'ai; M:Liv wagai ; 
\rfb Bj:Holm wagai shadow , photo 
\rfk Cas:Smy wogai, wogai ; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx wahngma-, wahng 
\ps noun, verb
\de work, work for something
\re work ; work for something
\do
\do 
\sf
\co wahng 'work', from English; also sometimes said [we:k] or 'work';  progressive wahngmalehla (Holmer). 
\xv Gd: Gurubu yabur dagay mahdja ngandurni wahngmalimahn. 
\xe 'Long ago one white man, a boss, was making others work.' 
\xv Wa: Wahngmalehla mala. 
\xe 'He's working.'
\xv Wa: Wahngmadjahn madji ngali guhl. 
\xe 'We used to work (for) gold.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju malahni nyahni wangmalinyun. 
\xe 'I saw that fellow working.'
\xv M:Liv: Wahng wiyah banyar. 
\xe 'Work is good for you.'
\xv M:Liv: Wahnggu wiya nguwinyin. 
\xe 'Working is making you tired.'
\xv M:Liv: Baygal wahngmalehn walenyun. 
\xe 'The man working is (sic) gone.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu yan.gehn workmaliyahgu. 
\xe 'I went to/for work.'
\xv M:Liv: Yan.gehn workmaliyah. 
\xe '(He)'s gone to work.'
\xv Bj:Holm: wahnggu 
\xe '(go) to work'. 
\rfg M:Liv wÃŒÃng , wamma , wÃŒ_ng; wanggo; wammullen
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, wa:ngma-, wa:ngmalila ; Bj:Holm:Fergn wa:ng(gu) 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy wangm-a, wangmÃŒÃlinjun 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ;

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx -wahr
\ps suffix
\de but
\re but
\do 
\sf
\co A sentence clitic: introduces a new clause with a change of topic, conjunction-like, and attached to the first word in a clause, contrasting such a clause with the preceding one; in other usage it occurs with something implied or stated earlier in the narrative, or by a previous speaker in a conversation Gd; sometimes only one sentence (or clause) is marked with -wahr, sometimes both Wa. 
\xv Gd: Nyule,g,h waybar gadji nyulaganah-war gahribeh. 
\xe 'His fire/camp is right here, but hers is way over there.'
\xv Gd: Nyuleyu gidjahn nyulagani yagambeh-war ngadjahbagi. 
\xe 'He said to her, But don't you want me?'
\xv Gd: Gaybe-wahr-e numgire yan.gahnbu. 
\xe 'They travelled yet another day.' 
\xv Wa: Ngaywahr jambanggehn ngalawalehn gurihbu wihnyi. 
\xe 'I tried to look for you a long time ago.'
\xv Wa: Malahna yiralingah deberwahr mahny yulany nganyahwar ngagu. 
\xe 'A whiteman's skin is white, but mine is dark.'
\xv Wa: Gadji ngay jugalehny ngaywahr yagambeh nguhndalehny blaganmihni. 
\xe 'I'm going to drink here, but I'm not going to wait for you.'
\xv Wa: Malahna yiralingah yulany mahnyu budjur baygalnah-ngu malahnawahr gadjangwahr. 
\xe 'A whiteman's skin is soft but an Aborigine's is hard.' 
\xv Wu: Galawahr baygal bugal. 
\xe 'This is a good man.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wa/Gd:Calley galwar this;
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\ps verb transitive 
\de carry, take
\re carry ; take

\co Hanlon lists wahra and wahbillon; the second is presumably wahra with a suffix, but not a recognisable one.

\lx wahri-
\ps verb transitive 
\de carry, take, wear, bring
\re carry ; take ; wear ; bring
\do
\do 
\sf
\co wahra- also recorded, also wahbilan Y:Hanln, wahribali- 'bring, carry' (Y:Holm:Logn); wahribalehn terminative, wahribalur pret. (Y:Holm:Logn).
\xv Wa: Gala ngadju behng dibahny wahriyah galahya nangany. 
\xe 'I'll sew this bag to carry the food in.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju wahrila bin.geh. 
\xe 'I'm wearing a hat.' 
\xv Gd: wahriny
\xe 'things which have been carried'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Wahra waybarah jumba(r).
\xe 'We'll carry him to the trees.' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu nyahni gahm juwan wahribalani. 
\xe 'I saw him carrying spears.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wahre baygalbahma gunu.
\xe 'Carry this with the man.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wahrani guruhmani jiman.gu jaliya.
\xe '(They) carried the kangaroo home to eat.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Wahra waybar jambar(?).
\xe 'Well, carry it to the wood/tree.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngayu nyahni gahmjuwan wahribalani.
\xe 'I saw him carrying spears.'
\xv M:Liv: Wahre baygalbahma gunu.
\xe 'Carry this with the man.'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm wahra(?) take; Y:Holm:Logn wahribali , wahribalin; Y:Alln pr warrei, p warreini, pf warreian, f warreila v. Carry;  Y:Watsn war'rÃŒÂ»ni; war'ÃŒÂ»ian; war'rÃŒÂ»ÃŒÂ¨la; M:Liv warre bulenne , warre paigaÃ¥Â¡l-baima konno; Tw:Curr:Bray warra; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray warra; Y:Hanln wahra, wahbillon

\lx wanah
\ps verb
\de don't, leave off
\re don't ; leave off
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Imperative, negative, indicates the action is prohibited; has all usual forms of a verb (M); goes with imperative tense of verb being negated, precedes the verb phrase it negates, whereas wan-/wen- 'be, become' follows the adjective it verbalises.
\xv Wa: Wanah yaruhma malahya nyabaydja. 
\xe 'Don't swim in the water.' 
\xv Gd: Wanah garahdja.
\xe 'Don't be too noisy.'
\xv Gd: Wanah nganyi bumah wahlu. 
\xe 'Don't kill me!'
\xv Gd: Wanah jang wanah. 
\xe 'Don't be wicked!'
\xv Wu: Wanah gineh. 
\xe 'Don't do that.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Wanah yana(h)!
\xe 'Don't go!' 
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Wanah malahni wijilimah. 
\xe 'Don't whistle at him.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Wanah wanah wanah 
\xe 'Don't! (emphatic) 
\xv Bj:Holm: (Wanah) banah! 
\xe '(Don't) fall!'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngayah wanani wahlu. 
\xe 'You left (it) for me.' 
\xv M: Wanah yanbah/wanah yanah. 
\xe 'Don't go.'
\xv M: Ngay wanalehn. 
\xe 'I left it alone.' 
\rfg M:Liv wana , wanalen (past); Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray wunna I don't know
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl wana:; Bj:TMcD:Morgn wanah don't; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, wana- , term. Wanani; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wa/Gd:Calley wana: gine: 'don't do that (leave do)' 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; 
\rfo

\lx wandi-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de climb, ascend, go up
\re climb ; ascend ; go up
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Inherently repetitive (Gd); old stem wa 'up' preservd here and in wayah(li-) 'to fly', etc, here combined with -ndi 'do while carrying'; climbing wandahla (Y:Hanln), cf, Dhanggati wandaya-, NG:Cudgn:Sc lists as 'headland', possibly 'climb', or possibly should be read wanday. NG:Cudgn:Sc lists as'headland', probably 'a climb'. 
\xv Wu:Calley: Wagaynin gilahni baygalnah wandehn baba balugahnba. 
\xe 'The man's spirit goes to the spirit-land (to Balugahn).'
\xv Wa: Ngadju wandini jali ngubuh. 
\xe 'I climbed the tree yesterday.'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal wandehla munahya jaliya. 
\xe 'The man is climbing the tree.'
\xv Wa: Ngay wandehni jalingu bugani nganyi. 
\xe 'I got stung as I was climbing down from the tree.' 
\xv Cas: Wandehn nyule (?) jambulgirgu. 
\xe 'He climbed the fig-tree.'
\xv Cas: Ngaywandehn gahny jaligu. 
\xe 'I climbed these trees.'
\xv Cas: Janah ngali wandeh guyahny-gu. 
\xe 'Let's go climbing for possums.'
\xv Cas: Wagayngin gilahna baygalnah wandehn babar Balugahnba. 
\xe 'That man's spirit climbed up to the spirit world (Balugahn).' 
\xv M:Liv: nguru wandehn 
\xe 'spirit of recently deceased man' (shade climbed)
\xv Bj: Wandehla wuya dugun.gu. 
\xe 'You climb the hill.' 
\rfg M:Liv wande ; Y:Alln pr wundei, p wunden, pf wundian, f wundeila climb; Y:Watsn wun'd ÃŒÂ»; wun'den; wun'dian; wun'ei'la climb; M:Liv wande; nguru wanden spirit, recently deceased man; NG:Cudgn:Sc wandi headland; Y:Hanln wundah, wohndeh climb, wundahla climbing ;

\rfk Wa/Gd:Calley wanden; Wa:Crowl wandi, wandeh-; Cas:Smy wand-e , wanden , , wande:n , wande: , wandÃŒÂ©n ;

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx wanyi
\ps adverb
\de perhaps, maybe, possibly
\re perhaps ; maybe ; possibly
\do
\do 
\sf
\co In Wa no apparent difference in meaning between ngalgir, guram and wahnyi (wanyi), similar meaning to guram (or gurambeh), but guram somewhat stronger, wanyi variable in position but rare as first word of a clause, wanyi well attested in Gd, Wa, Cas, wanyi and guram may occur together. 
\xv Gd:Geyt: Guy guy yahn.gany ngali gagadji wanyi. 
\xe 'We may stay here for a long time.'
\xv Gd:Geyt Guram wanyi ganngaliwayah gagadji.
\xe 'Perhaps I will hear (from you) while I am here.'
\xv Gd:Geyt: Yagambeh ngay wanyi yanggiwahnybu gagalah. 
\xe 'Perhaps I won't come this way again.'
\xv Gd:Geyt: Yile wanyi nyule.
\xe 'I wonder where he is.'
\xv Cas: Gale wanyi bugal bargan. 
\xe 'Perhaps this is a good boomerang.'
\xv Cas: Ngihn banyargandjang - baygal wanyi mirung wanyi? 
\xe 'Who is the fatter, the man or the woman?'
\xv Cas: Ngihndu guybahny nangany - baygalu wanyi guram dubadju wanyi?
\xe 'Who will cook the food, the man or the woman?'
\xv Cas: Nyanggahny ngay? - yehn.gany, jahnany wanyi? 
\xe 'What shall I do, sit or stand?'
\xv Ng: Wiya(?) wanyi ngalawalehla. 
\xe 'I believe she's getting (yams).' 
\rfg Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray wunye I believe ; Tw:Curr:Bray wunye
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy wanji ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx wanyi
\ps pronoun
\de you (object)
\re you (object)
\do
\do 
\sf
\co
\xv Bj: Baribunmani wanyi ngay. 
\xe 'I dreamt about you.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl wanji; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, wani

\dt 11/Mar/2015

\lx wan-, wana- 
\ps verb transitive 
\de leave, abandon, stop, cease, let alone, let go, release, don't, leave (it)
\re leave ; abandon ; stop ; cease ; let alone ; let go ; release ; don't, leave (it)
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Leave off, stop doing, abandon; has all usual forms of a verb, possibly wuna- in Y:Hanln. Apparently regular in Smythe's examples (wana-), though not elsewhere; cf, wara- 'go away and leave something behind' (Wa) (but probably one of the irregular forms of this verb). 
\xv All: Wanah! 
\xe 'Stop it, leave it!' 
\xv Gd: Gah nguy nyula wanani jumbuy. 
\xe 'He left his swag there.'
\xv Gd: Wanah nganyi bumah. 
\xe 'Don't kill me!' 
\xv Wu: Wanah gineh. 
\xe 'Don't do that.' 
\xv Wa: Mahnybe blaganibeh wanani. 
\xe 'Only you two were left behind.'
\xv Y:Hanln: Wanah yanbah! 
\xe 'Don't go!'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay wanalehn.
\xe 'I left it alone.' 
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: wana 
\xe 'don't, leave it'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyula wanani. 
\xe 'He left.'
\xv Cas: Nyulamanggu wanalehnbe yawahr. 
\xe 'The corroboree is finished.'
\xv Cas: Wanah ngabarwanah wadjeleh. 
\xe 'Don't speak fast.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju malahni wahnini. 
\xe 'I left that fellow.'
\xv Cas: Nyanggur wudjeh wanalehn wahng? 
\xe 'Have you stopped work yet?' 
\rfg Y:Holm:Logn wana-, pf wanani; Y:Alln pr wunna, p wunnani, pf wunnalian, f wunaleila leave alone; pr wunnalei, p wunnalen, pf w  unnalian, f wummaleila leave off; Y:Watsn wun'  ailÃŒÂ¨; wÃŒ_n'ailen; wÃŒ_n'ailien; wÃŒ_n'ailÃŒÂ»la leave off; wÃŒ_nai; wÃŒ_nainÃŒÂ¨; wÃŒ_nalldian, wÃŒ_nÃŒÂ¢la leave, abandon; M:Liv wana, wanalen (past); Tw:Curr:Bray wunna I don't know; AT:Talleb:police wona no; Y:Hanln wonah; wonah wobbah n'yunyee (= don't tell on me)
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy wan-a , wanalen , wana: , wa:nini ; Wa:Crowl; Wa/Gd:Calley wana: gine: 'don't do that (leave do)'; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx wan-, wana-, wara-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de be, become
\re be ; become
\do
\do 
\sf
\co wen- etc, in Wa; irreg; wan-/wen- follows adjective etc. It verbalises, wanah 'don't' precedes. 
\xv Gd: Male jubar bandjalahm wan.gahny ngulungmay. 
\xe 'That witchetty will be a butterfly soon.'
\xv Gd: Ning-wanah wahlu. 
\xe 'Be quiet!'
\xv Gd: Wanah jang wanah.
\xe 'Don't be wicked!' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 11/Mar/2015

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx wardjam
\ps noun
\de shark, whale, magic fish, mermaid, bunyip, mythical monster
\re shark ; whale ; fish, magic ; mermaid ; bunyip ; monster, mythical 
\do1 fsh
\do2 lg
\sf
\co Spirit-being which dwells in water (rivers or swamps), also 'eel' used for 'mythical monster', on coast also for 'whale'; English 'fearful whale' used for this Gd, 'serpent in the sea' Wa, 'extra big eel' We, plural wardjambil (Warrazambil Range). Probably somewhat like or same as the Rainbow Serpent in northern Aboriginal mythology; cf, wadjam, waryam, Hanln suggests /u/ in first syllable, see also buway, jargan, possibly wargam in Ng, the Warrazambil Ranges are so named presumably because they have these creatures. Gd:cp: I pray that the fearful whale won't get you on the road. (English statement)
\xv Wa: Mala wardjam mala burugara madji yehn.gala.
\xe 'The sea serpent lives in the sea.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm wadham , warjam shark; Y:Holm waryam eel or a monster (= mundangara QLong, bunyip , a spirit , 'sea monster' (Curry) , 'hippopotamus' Thmpsn;; M:Fingl warrajum; Mur:Sc:Hargrv worgum spark (sic); NG:Gresty wurrazum shark; NG:Cudgn:Sc warragum shark; GC:Coomera:police warriom; Y:Hanln Boiee , Jargun , and Woorajum sharks ; M:Fingl warrajum whale , magic fish , mermaid , Rainbow Serpent;  Ng:Sc:Cudgn3/1903 warragum shark; Ng:Sc:Mur worgum spark (sic) 
\rfb Bj:Holm wardjam; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 warragim shark; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn warjam; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx wardjam
\ps noun
\de species of shark
\re shark species
\do fsh
\co cf, wardjam 'eel, whale, mythical monster' in many dialects; only Hanlon suggests /u/ in first syllable, see wardjam, wadjam, waryam.
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm wadham, warjam shark; Y:Hanln Boiee, Jargun, and Woorajum sharks; GC:Coomera:police warriom
\rfb

\lx warima 
\ps noun
\de clever man
\re clever man ; man, clever
\do1 pp
\do2 lg
\sf
\co 'Has a more superstitious use than nguru' (Livingstone). 'When a person is ill, the warrima, 'wizard' is sent for to throw on him a good spell, called bunyarama warrima. The warrima takes something like a rope out of his stomach(!), and climbs up to waijong to have an interview with the wÃŒÃgai. On his return, if the man is to recover, he says 'Your wÃŒÃgai has come back and you will soon be well', but if he is to die, he says 'I could not get your wÃŒÃgai.'  The wÃŒÃgai are also the spirits consulted when anyone dies suddenly, discover by whose means the death was brought about.' (M:Liv). 
\xv M: Banyaramah warima. 
\xe 'Cast a good spell.' 
\rfg M:Liv warrima 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\lx waring, waring(gal) 
\ps adjective 
\de cold, cool, freezing, winter
\re cold ; cool ; freezing ; winter
\do1 ne
\do2 ti
\sf
\co m waringgali, f waringgalingahgan, arb waringgali, also waringbil (Wa), Turnbull also gave Sharpe waringgal 'cold'; cf, Kattang warang; 'winter' waringbil (Ng:Sc:Tweed), cf, wahgaru 'chilly'. Waringgal 'cold season'; 'winter' waringbil (Tw:Curr:Bray).
\xv Cas: Jagun gale waring bundahng. 
\xe 'This is a cold place.'
\xv Cas: Gale nangany waring.
\xe The food is cold.
\xv Cas: Ngay waring. 
\xe 'I am cold.'
\xv Bj: Ngay waring. 
\xe 'I am cold.'
\xv Cas: Waring gala bayahny.
\xe 'It's cold today.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gali yargeh waringgal. 
\xe 'This wind is nice and cold.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Waringgal. 
\xe 'It's cold.' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngulungmal waringan.gahla.
\xe 'It will get cool.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yugumbe waring.
\xe 'It's not cold.'
\rfg M:Liv wurring cold; M:Sc:Brunswk wurring cold; Ng:Curr:TwPt D:Bray wurring cold ; Y:Sha:Culhm waring(gal); Y:Holm:QLong waring cold; Y:Alln wogoru chilly, wuring cold; Y:Watsn wôg'ôrû, wôg' ôrû chilly, wâr'ing, war'ing cold; Y:Beaudst:Sc ;Y:Beaudst:police wurring cold; M:Liv wurring: M:Sc wurring cold; Mur:Sc:AndsFrench warring cold; Tw:Curr:Bray wurring; AT:Curr:Prior, O'Conn waring; AT:Curr:LandsWh warring; Nerang:Curr:Fowlr warrin 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl waringgal cold; Bj:TMcD:LWilsn , Cowl cold , winter; Bj:Holm:Turnbl waring cold , winter; Ny:Curr:Ballina warring; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 wuring winter , frost; Wi:Curr:Lismore wurring cold; Wi:Curr:Richmond worung; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl waring, waringbil; We:Gordn cold (temperature);  Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv war-ring winter ; Cas:Smy waring ; 
\rfr Gd:Calley waring; Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce warring cold; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng warring; 
\rfo Cop:Hargrv warring winter; 
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx wayah-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de fly
\re fly
\do
\do 
\sf
\co wayahli- listed in Wa; Calley form attests wayahliwahla (-wa suffix); wayalin terminative (probably wayalehn). 
\xv We: Gahgun mala wayahlin gilah babar. 
\xe 'The kookaburra flew up there.'
\xv We: wayahlelah 
\xe 'flying'
\xv Gd: wayahlimal 
\xe 'a thing which may be made to fly (eg boomerang)'
\xv Gd: wayahlimay 
\xe 'a thing being made to fly (eg aeroplane)'
\xv Bj: Wayahlen gila. 
\xe 'That (bird) flew.' 
\xv Bj: Yirariny wayahleny. 
\xe 'That bird is going to fly.'
\xv Bj: wayahlilur 
\xe 'used to fly across'
\rfg Y:Holm:Logn
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, waja-, prog. Wajala, rr term. Wajalin, imm. Wajalin past hab. Wajalilur 
\rfk Wa:Crowl;

\dt 18/Mar/2015

\lx waybar, wehbar
\ps noun
\de fire, camp, firewood, firestick, matches, spark, light of fire
\re fire ; camp ; firewood ; firestick ; matches ; spark ; light of fire
\do ff
\do 
\sf
\co Pronounced webbr, waybr, waybarr; northern dialects mostly use diman for camp; Y:Hanln spelling indicates [waibar], not [weibar]; waybarmir 'camp (pl.)' (Y:Holm); also camp (M:Liv) (and therefore a dwelling place like a house); also used as clan name at Lismore. Gd:Geyt meaning includes matches.
\xv Wa: Waybaramah mala bulang guybayah. 
\xe 'Put the meat on the fire to be cooked.'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal galgalehla waybar. 
\xe 'The man is chopping (fire)wood.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu galgani jali waybargu. 
\xe 'He chopped the tree down for firewood.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu waybaru guybani nganyi. 
\xe 'The fire burnt me.'
\xv Wa: Waybarmah madji guybayah mahny bulang.
\xe 'Make a fire to cook the meat (on top of the coals).'
\xv Wa: Barbilehn munah waybar. 
\xe 'The fire has been put out'
\xv Wa: Nguhnma madji waybara. 
\xe 'Heat it over the fire.'
\xv Cas: Waybar wahri. 
\xe 'Carry firewood'
\xv Cas: Yanah waybargu. 
\xe 'Go to the camp.'
\xv Cas: Yunamah nangany waybari. 
\xe 'Put the food on the fire.'
\xv M:Liv: Munu waybaru gandjilinibahny ngubu.
\xe 'That fire will be lit tomorrow.'
\xv M:Liv: Waybana gili way. 
\xe 'The camp is above.'
\xv M:Liv: Garandalehn waybar.
\xe 'The fire is hot.'
\xv M:Liv: Galgah jali waybargay. 
\xe 'Cut wood for the fire.'
\xv M:Liv: gandji waybar 
\xe 'light a fire.'
\xv M: Gawarileh waybanu. 
\xe 'Go round the camp.' 
\xv M: Galgah jali waybargay. 
\xe 'Cut wood for the fire.' 
\xv M: Gandjeh waybar. 
\xe 'Light a fire.' 
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Ngay bandjani gala waybar bagulu. 
\xe 'I cover my house with bark.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: waybargu 
\xe 'to the fire' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm waybar fire , firewood , matches; Y:Holm:Logn fire ,  camp , waibarmir camp fires or people?; Y:Alln waiburra;  Y:Watsn waybara ,  wai'b  ÃŒ_rra fire ; M:Liv wÃŒÂ©bÃŒÂ´ra nom, wÃŒÂ©bÃŒÂ´ro e,g, wÃŒÂ©bÃŒÂ´re dat, wÃŒÂ©bÃŒÂ´nna abll, wÃŒÂ©bÃŒÂ´ra ab12; webena killy wai; wib ÃŒÂ´ra; webÃŒÂ´nno from/into the camp ; M:Sc wyhera (sic) fire; NG:Gresty wyburra firewood; Y:Geyt , AT:Curr:Prior ,  AT:Curr:Prior wybara; AT:Curr:LandsWh wyebra; AT:Curr:O'Conn y-bur-a; Nerang:Curr:Fowlr wyburry; Ng:Sc:Mur+ 5/00 waybera fir e (Murwillmbah); NG:Cudgn:Sc whyburra fire; GC:Coomera:police weberra; GC:Nerang:police weybra; Tw:Curr:Bray wibra fire ,  trees (firewood) , wibrama make a fire; TW:Sc wybra fire; Mur:Sc:Martn wyborough fire; Mur:Sc:Hargrv wybera fire; GC:Coomera:Sc webberra , GC:Nerang:Sc woybra fire; Y:Hanln waiburra ; M:Sc:Brunswk wybera fire; Ng:Sc:Mur wybera fire; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray wibra fire (also Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray), wood; Ng:Sc:Tweedwybra fire; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn wyborough; TW:Sc:Bray fire wibra 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl waybar fire, firewood, house; Bj:TMcD:Cowln wehbara fire or wood for fire; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, waibar; Wi:Curr:Lismore wibbera; Wi:Sc:Lismore waibra blacks at Lismore call themselves; Wi:Curr:Richmond weebra; Bj:Sc:Coraki wybura fire, waybura headland; Ny:Sha:DCook weybar; Ny:Curr:Ballina wibra 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn fire; Wa/ Gd:Calley w ? ? :bara (a=schwa) fire; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv wi-va fire; Cas:Smy we:bar ; 
\rfr Gn:JMathew waibura fire , camp; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce waybora fire; Gd:Sci:Woodnbng wybera fire; Gd:Geyt
\rfo Cop:Hargrv wybah ;
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx wehl
\ps noun
\de The Saucepan, Orion's belt constellation
\re Saucepan, The ; Orion's belt constellation
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Possibly wahl or wihl, possibly from waril 'river' by r-loss; however Orion's belt (3 stars) is not river-shaped, although as an equatorial constellation (rising and setting due east and west) it may have had this type of significance. 
\rfg Y:Watsn werl Orion's belt constellation 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy we:lu

\lx wehn
\ps verb intransitive 
\de became, was
\re became ; was
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Incompletive of wan-, wen- (irregular) 'to be, become'; combines with adjectives, etc,

\xe '(I) became tired through the chopping.'

\lx wen-, wen.ga-, wi-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de become, be, get, have
\re become ; be ; get ; have
\do
\do 
\sf
\co cf, Kathang. 
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Guwang wen.gahla. 
\xe 'It is raining.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Mula wen.gahla. 
\xe '(He) is getting hungry.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Jarangwen.gahla. 
\xe '(He) is getting drunk (or drinking).'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Nguhnwen.gahla. 
\xe 'Now it is warm.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Garingi-wen.gahla ngay. 
\xe 'I am getting mad/wild.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Mula wen.gahla 
\xe 'getting hungry'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Guwangwehn. 
\xe 'It rains/it rained.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Yugambe mala burginy gijuhnywehn.
\xe 'The wind is not strong.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Jaranywehn. 
\xe '(He) got frightened.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Mulawehn. 
\xe '(He) is or was or got hungry.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Yalyalwehn.
\xe '(I) am sick.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Yalyalan.gahny ngali. 
\xe 'We will get sick.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Dubay jahgamgahl. 
\xe 'The woman just had a child.' 
\rfg
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, , winga- , prog. Wingala Fergn , Turnbl; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, , Turnbl wi- , win ; Bj:Holm wen.ga:la Fergn, win.gala Turnbl, yal yalan ga:ÃŒÂ± Fe,g,, gal Fergn; cf, KThga- 
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 19/Mar/2015

\lx werwa-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de be, become (Gd)
\re be (Gd) ; become (Gd)
\do 
\sf
\co Form wan-/wara-, see -wan; irregular, suffixed to adjectives, occasionally to nouns, e,g, manal(u)wen- 'to ripen', wuhlil(u)wen- 'be satisfied', jang(w)en- 'go'; can reduce to n.ga after /l/ or /r/.
\xv Wa:Crowl: bugaln.gahla 
\xe 'getting better'
\xv Wa: ngabarn.gahla 
\xe 'getting faster'
\xv Wa: guygahrwen.gahla, guygahnrun.gahla 
\xe 'be hollow' (progressive) (from guygahr 'hole')
\xv Wa: ngulahrwen, ngularun 
\xe 'be in flood' (incompletive)
\xv Wa: Munah dabahy janguywehn malahgaya janagan.gahya gahnganah mala darigan. 
\xe 'The dog got annoyed with the boy for taking his bone.'
\xv Wa: Mala janagan gunuhmbawehn malahya yaramani ngarnanggahya. 
\xe 'The boy got up on the stump (stump-loc-was) to mount the horse.'
\xv Wa: Yilahwen munah? 
\xe 'Where have they gone?'
\xv Wa: Gahriwen mala dabahy. 
\xe 'The dog disappeared over there (there-invisible-was/became).'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal-wen.gahla/baygalwerwahla.
\xe 'He has grown up (has become a man).' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crow
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx widjabal
\ps noun
\de Widjabal
\re Widjabal
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co i.e. A dialect or language in which 'you' (wuya/wiya) is pronounced widja; used today of the more northerly Wiyabal speakers, in contrast to Birihn Bandjalang, the Coraki dialect.

\do

\lx windji (winydji), yindji (yinydji)
\ps locative interrogative
\de somewhere, where?
\re somewhere ; where?
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co cf, wunda (possibly wundja). 
\xv Holm:Monsl: Yindjigu wiya?
\xe 'Where are you going to?'
\xv Holm:Monsl: Yindjigal wiya?
\xe 'Where are you coming from?'
\xv Holm:Monsl: Yindjigu wiya? 
\xe 'Where are you going?'
\xv Holm:Monsl: Windji wahlu? 
\xe 'Where are you going?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Wahlu jagul, windjigahl wahlu?
\xe 'You're a stranger, where you from?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Windjiguh nyule yan.gehn?
\xe 'Where did he,g,?'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Windjigahl wahlu? 
\xe 'Where were you?'
\xv M: Yindjigu wiya? 
\xe 'Where are you going to?'
\xv M: Yindjigal wiya? 
\xe 'Where are you coming from?'
\xv M: Yindjigu wiya? 
\xe 'Where are you going? 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm winyjigu; Holm:Monsl winji; M:Liv inji, winji; inji-go where to, inji-gÃŒÂ´l where from; other forms inji-gun(-na); injeo where to ; GC:Mestn winjee where
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo

\xv Tw:Bray: Garalbu mibiny wamginy. 
\xe 'A number of blacks are coming.' 
\rfg Tw:Curr:Bray worrigin , worngin coming

\lx wuh, uh
\ps conjunctive

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx wula-
\ps verb transitive 
\de,g,ve
\re,g,ve
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Either directly or in exchange for something; redup. Wula-wula (Wa); person/creature,g,ven to is accusative case; if a person given, the person is also accusative case Gd; cf, wulima- 'to find'; wulali- 'give something or anything' (Y:Holm) is probably reciprocal, cf,  also wiya- (M:Liv); person given to inflected as accusative, other unmarked (Cas). 
\xv Wa: Wulah nganyi mala 'ring'.
\xe 'Give me that ring.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju wulani nganyah janagani nyabay. 
\xe 'I gave my son some water.'
\xv Wa: Ngadju malahni wulani gala wagany gabaygu. 
\xe 'I gave him some catfish for some sugar.'
\xv Wa: Wulawulanibeh ngali mala mani. 
\xe 'We shared the kangaroo around.' 
\xv Gd: Nyuleyu ngagam wulani nganyi. 
\xe 'He,g,ve me a dog.'
\xv Gd: Nyuleyu yigam wulani ngagami. 
\xe 'He,g,ve meat to the dog.'
\xv Gd: Ngay wahnyi wulahny gandjabulni. 
\xe 'I will give you to the constable.'
\xv Cas: Wulah nganyi bargan. 
\xe 'Give me a boomerang.'
\xv Cas: Ngadju wulani nangany ngubuwarbu jananggani 
\xe 'I gave the boy food two days ago.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngehni wahlu wulani? 
\xe 'Whom did you give it to?'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyula yugambe wulaligi. 
\xe 'He does not want to give anything.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wulani wadjung-jargani guybayah.
\xe '(They) gave it to (their) mother to cook.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Wulani nganyi.
\xe '(He) gave (it) to me.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Ngayu wulani ngubu.
\xe 'I gave (it to her) yesterday.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyula wulahla nyulagani. 
\xe 'He will give it to her.'
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngahndu wulani? 
\xe 'Who gave (her to him)?' 
\xv Bj:Holm:Fe,g,: Nganyi (for ngayah) wulah. 
\xe 'Give me.' (Sharpe considers nganyi correct here)
\xv Bj:Holm:Fe,g,: Wulah malahni. 
\xe 'Give (it) to him.'
\xv Bj:Holm:Fe,g,: Wulani ngalingi. 
\xe '(God) gave us.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm wula, wulali; Y:Holm:Logn; Y:Alln pr wula, p wulani, pf wululian, f wulala; Y:Watsn wu'la, wu'lan  ÃŒÂ¨, wu'lali an, wil'ÃŒÂ¢la (sic); Tw:Curr:Bray woolangee, woolane,g,ve; TW:Sc:Bray woollar to give; Mur:Sc:Martn woollar to give ; Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray wool lar to give; Ng:Sc:11/1189:Bray wool-lar to give; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn wool-lar to give; Ng:Curr:TwPt D:Bray woolangee to give 
\rfb Bj:Sha:LWilsn; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, wula- imp wula , term. Wulani; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Cas:Smy wul-a , wulani ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo

\lx wungan jari- (wungandjari-)
\ps verb phrase
\de turn oneself over, fall over, capsize, turn around
\re turn oneself over ; fall over ; capsize ; turn around
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Inherently repetitive, and probably belongs with wungandjari-, spelling difference only reflects whether understood as one word or two; from wungan 'about, around'; wungandjari imper., wungandjarehla imperf., wungandjarehn term., wungandjarini pf, wungandjarigi intent.; wungandjarima- 'turn (something) round', cf,  wunganginggi-. 
\xv Cas: Mahny nyulamang behn wungandjarehn.
\xe 'They were all falling over one another.' 
\rfg Y:Holm:Logn wu ng anjarila etc, , wu n ganjarimala , mani , magi , ma (Logn)
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy wungandjer-e, wungandjeren fall over, capsize 
\rfr Gd:Geyt wungan jari- turn oneself over; 
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\re leaf ; tea ; tea leaves
\do1 ff
\do2 pl
\sf
\co Plural wurahng-bil.

\xe 'These (people) built this house of grass and leaves.'
\xv Wa: Wurahng mahnyu malahya jaliya buhmbila mala ngahndja. 
\xe 'The leaves high in the tree are blowing.'
\xv Wa: Bandjah mala jigay wurahngu. 
\xe 'Cover the sore with a leaf.'
\xv Cas: Guybah mahny wurahng. 
\xe 'Burn those leaves.'
\xv Cas: Wudjeh wurahnggi? 
\xe 'Would you like some tea?' 
\rfg

\lx -y
\ps suffix 
\de an action, act of...., doer of an action
\re an action ; act of.... (something) ; doer of an action ; actor (doer of an action)
\do 
\sf
\co One actually doing the action at the time of speaking, nominaliser, cf -l ; e,g, yanbay 'a walk' (act of walking).
\xv Gd: wayahlimay 
\xe 'a thing being made to fly' (eg an aeroplane)
\xv Gd: yanbay 
\xe 'traveller'
\xv Gd: gahdjay 
\xe 'one e,g,ged in chasing' (a cattle-dog that is always chasing things and will not stop)
\xv Gd: wayahlimay 
\xe 'aeroplane' (a thing being made to fly) 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gd:Geyt 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx yabur
\ps adjective 
\de one, only, alone
\re one ; only ; alone
\do
\do 
\sf
\co m yaburginy, f yaburginygan, arb yaburnah (not used with bulahbu to make higher numbers); Calley lists yabur as 'new' and yaburni 'one'. 
\xv Wa: Mala baygal yarbilehla yaburginy. 
\xe 'The man is singing alone.'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal yarbi-yarbilehla yaburginy.
\xe 'The man sometimes sings when he's on his own.' 
\xv Gd: Yaburginyganah jahdjam dungaliwahnbe
\xe 'One woman's child cried and cried.' (one-pers-fem-possessive)
\xv Gd: yabur-yabuhr-be 
\xe 'only one (one-one-only)'
\xv Cas: Maleyu gaba nyulangah yaburbe juwan wulani. 
\xe 'He,g,ve away his only spear.'
\xv Cas: Yaburburginygan gale ngay 
\xe 'I'm all alone. (woman speaking)'
\xv Cas: Yabur male balugahn barahygirdjahn ganngalehn. 
\xe 'One of the youths, the youngest, thought to himself.' 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv yabba ; Wa/Gd:Calley jabur new, jaburni one ; Cas:Smy jÃŒ_bur ; Wa/Gd:Calley jabur, jaburni (prob. Object) one, jabur new; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce yaborah one

\lx yagam, yagambeh
\ps interjection, adverb 
\de no, not, none
\re no ; not ; none
\do
\do 
\sf
\co General sentence negator, frequently has emphatic suffix (yagambeh); yagambehwen- (irregular) to disappear Wa; also an introducer; can take -beh suffix (mild intensifier), or -bu 'yet'; yagam baray 'not very' Gd; possibly yugam in Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv.
\xv Wa: Yagambeh ngadju ganngahla gumbaynggirnah nguyay 
\xe 'I don't understand Gumbaynggir'
\xv Gd: yagambu 
\xe 'not yet' 
\xv Gd: yagambeh 
\xe 'no!'
\xv Gd: Yalany nyulangamah yagam baray bugal ganngalihygu. 
\xe 'Their language is not very easy to understand.'
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Wa:Crowl; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv yo-cum 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ;
\rfo

\lx yahn-, yahna-, yahn.ga-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de sit, stop, live at, sit down
\re sit ; stop ; live at ; sit down
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Inflected form yahn.gali (M:Liv); yahnbay 'sitting down' (Y:Hanln); Y:Hanln: 'rest, repose, the place where one sits down'; also indicates friendship. Y:Holm notes yahnbi imper. (sometimes); yahnbigi 'want(s) to sit', yahyani 'sat'. 
\xv Y:Hanln: Yahna wahlu. 
\xe 'You stop here.'
\xv Y:Holm:QLong: yahnala ngumbinya (nyumbinya sic.) 
\xe 'sitting or staying at home'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yahn.galah ngaw waymalehla.
\xe 'I'm sitting talking.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yahna wahlu, wunah yan.geh. 
\xe 'Sit you down, don't go.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yahn.ga waymaliyah. 
\xe 'Sit down and talk.' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bulahbu yahn.galah janunggah yinangah. 
\xe 'Two are sitting close to each other.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm live at , sit; Y:Holm:QLong yahna , yahnala; M:Liv yana sit , yang ate; Tw:Sc:Bray yanna; AT:Curr:Prior yangalla; AT:Curr:O'Conn yaanbe (cf, 'walk' yanbe); GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr, Y:Hanln yahnah sit down (imp.) , sitting down yahnbai; yahngulla,  yahngla rest, repose, yahnawahloo I stay here (you stop here) 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo

\lx yalgan
\ps noun
\de sun
\re sun
\do ne
\do 
\sf
\co Also for 'summer' and 'daytime' (Y:Sha:Culhm); cf, also yalnan; nyangga also found in the more northerly parts with the same meaning range; see also numgir. 
\xv Wa: Mala yalgan bahn.gala numgir mala-ngu gibam jubunydja. 
\xe 'The sun comes out in the day and the moon comes out at night.'
\xv Wa: Mala yalgan birwahla. 
\xe 'The sun is setting.'
\xv Wa: Munah yalgan gayehn. 
\xe 'The sun has set.'
\xv Wa: Galiyu yangandu mahny gulalung bumgahnyi manalwehn. 
\xe 'If the sun shone on the peaches, they would ripen.'
\xv Gd:UClarnce: yalgan behni 
\xe 'sunrise'
\xv Gd:UClarnce: yalgan gayehn 
\xe 'sunset'
\xv Cas: Yalgan gayiwahla. 
\xe 'The sun is setting.'
\xv Cas: Yan.gahny ngali yalgan gayehna. 
\xe 'We'll go after the sun has set.'
\xv Cas: Yan.gahny ngali yalgan bayanah. 
\xe 'We'll go after the sun has risen.'
\xv Cas: Yalgan dandur. 
\xe 'The sun is strong, hot.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yalgan gahgiwahla. 
\xe 'The sun is going down.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gahgiwahla yalgan, ngandir ngulungmay. 
\xe 'The sun is setting, it'll be dark soon.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bahryilahla yalgan. 
\xe 'The sun is rising.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Gagalihn yalgan nguhn jang. 
\xe 'The sun is going down, it's really hot.'
\xv Bj:Holm: yalgan.gu 
\xe 'to the east' (literally to the sun) 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm sun (daytime), summer; Y:Holm sun yalgan (Logn), yalga (QLong); M:Sc yelkin sun; AT:Curr:Prior yalgan; AT:Curr:LandsWh yallgay; AT:Curr:O'Conn yalgun ; M:Sc:Brunswk yelkin sun
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl yalgan; Bj:TMcD:Gomes ye,g,n sun; Bj:Holm:Turnbl jalgan; Wi:Curr:Lismore yalkun; Wi:Curr:Richmond yalgun; Bj:Sc:Coraki yeljim sun; Ny:Curr:Ballina yelkin; Ny:Sc:Ballina3/1903 yelcan sun; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv yul-gun; Wa:Tabulm:Hargrv yul-gun ; Cas:Smy j  ÃŒ_lgan , jalgan , je,g,n; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gd:Sc:JThomas UClarnce yalgun sun; Calley ya:lgun sun; 
\rfo

\lx yalyal, yilyal, yelyel, yaljal
\ps adjective 
\de sick, ill
\re sick ; ill
\do bp
\do
\do 
\sf
\co yadal (Y:Holm) probably misheard; M:Liv has yilyal, yilyalma- 'to cause to be sick'; Hanlon also has danbiyan, Ng:Sc:Mur spelling suggests jeldjel, and Mur:Sc:Hargrv suggests initial fricative (spelling zell zelng) unless this is a misreading of handwriting, M:Sc:Brunswk listed as 'bad', probably 'sick, feeling bad'.

\xe 'He will make me sick.'

\xe 'big toe (?)'

\xe 'I am sick.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yalyal-wehn ngay. 
\xe 'I am sick.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yalyalan.gahny gim. 
\xe '(You) might get sick.'

\lx yan-
\ps intransitive verb
\de,g,, go away, travel
\re,g, ; go away ; travel
\co
\xv Cas: Yanah ngali yanbih wangmaliyah. 
\xe 'Let's go away to work.'
\xv Cas: Gahny nyulamang yehni magilgu. 
\xe 'They've,g,ne after lizards.'
\xv Cas: Yanah ngadjay. 
\xe 'Come (go) with me.'
\xv Cas: Yanah ngali buruwar(gu). 
\xe 'Let's go to the beach.'
\xv Cas: Nyule yehni wudjanggi.
\xe 'He went (across) the,g,ass.'
\xv Cas: Ngay yan.gahny yan.gahny. 
\xe 'I shall go walkabout.'
\xv Cas: Bamu! Ngali yagam yan.gehn 
\xe 'Well, we just didn't go.'
\xv Cas: Yehnibe nyulamang bulngarinyi.
\xe 'They went away because of the heat.'
\xv Cas: Mirunggan gile bigabindah ngirihny mudjumdjargan yan.giluhr. 
\xe 'That woman was alone with (except for) her daughter.'
\xv Cas: Ginyehrgu wahlu yan.giluhr bigabindi.
\xe 'That's what happens when you travel alone.'
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk Cas:Smy jan-a , jana: , jeini , j ÃŒÂ¬n.gainjan.gÃŒÃinj ,  jan.gÃŒÃinj; jÃŒÃnbaliwalÃŒÂ¬nj , jan.gilu:r ;

\lx yan-, yana-, yanba-, yan.ga- 
\ps intransitive verb
\de,g,, walk
\re,g, ; walk
\co Irregular; yan.gahla prog. Aspect; imperative yanbay; yanda recorded once by Holmer; bah/bih (yuonbay) and yanah; used with verb sequences e,g, 'go hunt'; used in compounds with e.g. Dagay ('go to death, die'); but possibly confused with -ana/-an.ga (M:Liv); inflected forms yan.ga-, yanbali (M:Liv); yanbahla 'go' (M:Sc:Brunswk); yan.gah imper. (Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray).
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Yila wuhye yanbalehla ngargu?
\xe 'Where are you going to hunt?'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Yanbalehla dugurimba. 
\xe 'I'm going to Lismore.'
\xv Bj:Turnbl: Ngay yan.gahny ngahrgu. 
\xe 'I'm going hunting.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yanah wuya. 
\xe 'You go away.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ba yanah. 
\xe 'Go then.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngali yanah. 
\xe 'Let us go.'
\xv Bj:Holm: yanbi jabaygu 
\xe 'to go for a feed'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay yanbihgi. 
\xe 'I must go.'
\xv Bj:Holm: yanbihgu buralihgu 
\xe 'to go to fish' 
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Yanbahla wuya. 
\xe 'You go away.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Yanda wuya ngaya barin.gu. 
\xe 'You go and fetc, me bread.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Ngay yanbaleh
\xe 'I will go now.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Yanbalehla ngay wahnggu. 
\xe 'I am going to work.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Yanbalehny ngay jabaygu. 
\xe 'I will go and have a feed.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Yanda wuya ngayah barehn.gu. 
\xe 'You go to fetc, me bread.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Biralihgu ngay yangahla. 
\xe 'I like to go fishing.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: Yan.gilur 
\xe '(We) used to go.'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: yan.giyan 
\xe 'when (we) went'
\xv Bj:Fe,g,: yan.giwanybu bayahny 
\xe 'will come again today.' 
\xv M:Liv: Wanah yanbah/yanah! 
\xe 'Don't go!'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay yanbalehla waybarah. 
\xe 'I'm going to the camp.'
\xv M:Liv: Yanah ngali jalum gahnggaleh. 
\xe 'Let's go and catch fish.'
\xv M:Liv: Dagayanah! 
\xe 'May you die!'
\xv M:Liv: Dagayangahny. 
\xe '(I) will kill myself/go to death.' 
\xv M:Liv: Yugam ngay yangngahny bambambu. 
\xe 'I cannot go with swollen feet.' 
\xv Ng:Bray: Yanbalehla. 
\xe '(I)'m going now.'
\xv Ng:Bray: Yanbalahndji. 
\xe 'Let's go home.'
\xv Ng:Bray: yan.gehn jagun 
\xe 'gone to ground' 
\xv Wi:Curr: Richmd: Yanagay(?) 
\xe 'walk on' 
\rfg M:Liv yuÃ¥Â¡na go, yuÃ¥Â¡nbailyuÃ¥Â¡na (imper); dukkaiyunggan go to death, dukkaianna go to death, die; yunggan cannot go; yuÃ¥Â¡na; yungga, yuÃ¥Â¡nbale ; M:Sc:Brunswk words transposed: egra or yen bulla is prob. Go; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray yanbar, I'm going now yÃŒÂ¢nbalala, (let's go home yan-ba-alan-je); Ng:Sc:TweedR:Bray tan-ba la to walk, tanba-lala to go away; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn yan-ba-la to walk, yan-ba-la-la to go away; Ng:Sc:Mur yangin jackum bora ground ;
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl yana (irreg), yanga:nj; Bj:TMcD:Cowln yena, ye,g,la, yenbalehla go, going; Bj:Holm:Fe,g,, Turnbl jana-, jana, janbi, janbigi, janbi:gu; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, janba-, janbala, janbali, janbalila, janbalin, janda; janga-, jangala, jan.gilur, jan.gijan; Wi:Curr:Richmond yangarla; yenna ki walk on; Ny:Sha:DCook Ny:Curr:Ballina yenna walk;
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx yan-, yana-, yan.ga- 
\ps intransitive verb
\de,g,, walk
\re,g,, walk
\co Irregular, inflected forms yanga-, yanbali- (M:Liv); irregular: imperative yanbaylbahlbih (yuOnbai) and yanah; used with verb sequences e,g, 'go hunt'; used in compounds with e.g. Dagay (go to death, die); but possibly confused with -ana-/-an.ga- ; yangah imperative (AT:Curr:LandsWh); listed as 'walk' in Curr lists, irregular forms shown by tp/jo (yanba-) and AT:Curr:LandsWh (yanga-); Y:Hanln forms include yena- forms, possible misreading forms yanbay (n.), yangahla; spelling ye,g,hla (Y:Hanln).
\xv M:Liv: Wanah yanbah/yanah. 
\xe 'Don't go.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay yanbalehla waybarah. 
\xe 'I'm going to the camp.'
\xv M:Liv: Yanah ngali jalum gahnggaleh. 
\xe 'Let's go and catch fish.'
\xv M:Liv: Yugam ngay yangngahny bambambu. 
\xe 'I cannot go with swollen feet.'
\xv Y:Allen: Ngayu gunybaneh yanah bulangi. 
\xe 'I invite you to go.'
\xv Y:Allen: Nyule yanah barang. 
\xe 'He,g,es now.'
\xv Y:Allen: Mulam-walal yana. 
\xe 'The boys go.'
\xv Y:Allen: Yanah!
\xe 'Go!' (imper.)
\xv Y:Hanln: Yan.gahla ngayu. 
\xe 'I'm going.'
\xv Y:Hanln: Yangah! 
\xe 'Get up, arise!'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Baygal gila ya(h)n. 
\xe 'A man (is) coming.' 
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: Nyula yehni. 
\xe 'He went.'
\xv Y:Holm:Curry: Wahlu yanbaleh. 
\xe 'You go.'
\xv Y:Holm:Curry: Ngayu yanbalehla. 
\xe 'I am going' 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw yan.gahla town.gu nunganygu. 
\xe 'I'm going to town for tucker.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yahna wahlu, wuna yan.geh, waymalah ngalingih. 
\xe 'Sit down, don't go, talk with us.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu yan.gehn workmaliyahgu. 
\xe 'I'm going to work.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngay yan.gehn yan.gehn. 
\xe 'I walked a long way.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: wuginyehn yan.gehn 
\xe 'went quickly'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: jangmaleh yan.gehn 
\xe 'went slowly' 
\xv Tw:Curr:Bray: Ngayu-nguhr yanbalehla. 
\xe 'I will go too.'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yana; Y:Holm yana-, yanga-, yavg a variant, yanbali imper., yanbalila imperf; Y:Allen pr yana, p yani, pfyangian, fyangala go, walk; ngaio goenbunnei yana bullungi; neule yana barang molumm-wallull yana; yana!; Y:Watsn yan'ii, yan'l, yan'ian, yan '-gal'a; M:Liv yuÃ¥Â¡na go, yuÃ¥Â¡nbailyuÃ¥Â¡na (imper); dukkaiyunggan go to death, dukkaianna go to death, die; ; M:Liv YuDgan can not go; yuOna; yungga, yuOnbale ; Ngr:Gresty yangballala walkabout; AT:Curr:Prior yamba; AT:Curr:LandsWh yingalla; AT:Curr:O'Conn yanbe; GC:Mestn yangan gone away; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlryanbela; Tw:Sc:Bray yanbar, yanbalala I'm going now; yan-ba-alan-je let's go home; Tw:Sc:Bray tanbalala to go away; Mur:Sc:Martn yan-ba-la-la to go away; Y:Hanln Yangahlar-n'gaio get up and go away, yangah get up, arise, yunga depar t, yahnbai, ye,g,hla (yen.gahla);
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr Gn:Mathew yena go, yauna walk
\rfo
\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx yan-, yana-, yan.ga-, yanba- 
\ps verb intransitive 
\de,g,, go away, travel, walk
\re,g, ; go away ; travel ; walk
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Irregular; yanbali- 'to walk around'; yan.gahla 'going, walking', yanbalehla 'going' (We); yanbay 'walk, visitor' (Wa), 'traveller' (Gd); possibly yen- in Gn, but yauna given for 'walk'; present participle in Wu:Calley ya (yanyun) can take,g,nder suffixes m -gali, f -galigan, no arb form, as can other present participles. 
\xv Wa: Ngali yan.gahn dahbalamna bulahbu jubuny yunahny. 
\xe 'We used to go to Tabulam, and we would stay two nights.'
\xv Wa: Yilah wudja yangahla? 
\xe 'Where are you going?'
\xv Wa: Gumar yehyani muruya nganyahya. 
\xe 'My nose is bleeding.'
\xv Wa: Nyugum yan.gahla 
\xe '(He's) got a runny nose.'
\xv Wa: Wulah nganyi mala dugul-duguhl yanbali-nyun. 
\xe 'Give me the dilly-bag while we're walking around.' 
\xv We: Yanbalehla nyule muli yuri dabahydju. 
\xe 'He's going along the hill with his dog.' 
\xv Wu: Gabalgu nyule (yehni). 
\xe 'He went to the scrub.' (yehni can be omitted)
\xv Wu: Yehni yaramanbah 
\xe 'he went towards the horse.' 
\xv Wu: Gile ngihn yanbalehla. 
\xe 'Who is that walking there?' 
\xv Gd: yanbaybilahm 
\xe 'has learnt to walk'
\rfb 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wu?:Calley janjun, gilerjin yenbelela 'who's that walking?', yunggain going (plur.); 
\rfr Gd:Geyt; Gn:JMathew yena go, yauna walk ; 
\rfo

\lx yarbi-
\ps verb transitive 
\de sing, chant
\re sing ; chant
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co yarbil 'song' (Wa, Gd, Bray), cf, also yalbi-; yarbi- can be reduplicated yarbi-yarbi-; yarbindi- 'to sing with a baby in one arm'; takes e,g,tive subject, object (which can only be a song) is usually omitted, but the object can also be something sung about; yarbilah listed as 'marriage' (Ng:Sc:Cudgn), yarbil 'song' listed (Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray). 
\xv Wa: Maliyu dandaygambu yarbini. 
\xe 'The old man sang (a song).'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal yarbilehla yaburginy. 
\xe 'The man is singing alone.'
\xv Wa: Mala baygal yarbi-yarbilehla yaburginy. 
\xe 'The man sometimes sings when he's on his own.'
\xv Wa: Ngay yagam yarbilehla. 
\xe 'I can't sing.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu dandaygambu yarbidjahn yarbil. 
\xe 'The old man used to sing songs.'
\xv Wa: Nyuliyu yarbini miruhngmirni. 
\xe 'He sang about the old ladies.'
\xv Cas: Yarbini ngali yawahr. 
\xe 'We sang a corroboree.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yarbileh wuya. 
\xe 'You sing.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yarbilehny ngay. 
\xe 'I will sing.' 
\xv M:Liv: Janabi yarbiluru waybarabu. 
\xe 'They were singing in the camp.' 
\rfg M:Liv yerrube, yerrubilloro; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray yerrabil song; Ng:Sc:Cudgn yarraballah marriage
\rfb Bj:Holm:Turnbl-Turnbl yarbi-, yarbili, yarbili ÃŒÂ±; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn yarbilehla singing; Cas:Smy jerb-i, jerbini, jÃŒ_rb-i, jerbÃŒÂ©nj sing, chant; Wu?:Calley jerbile,g, to sing ;
\rfr Gd:Geyt;

\co 'Fly as a bird, creep'; yaruhli- probably yaruh- 'fly' + antipassive/continuous; also see bihra- (bira-) 'throw, fly', gayi 'swim' (etc,). 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngaw yaruhlen gunggih barundi, gayeni balundi. 
\xe 'I swam in the water in the river, I entered the river.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yaruhlilah nunganybil. 
\xe 'The birds are flying.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Mamali yaruhlelah nunganybil.
\xe 'The bird is flying.' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yaruh- swim , fly; Y:Allen pr yarole , p yarolen , pf yarolian , f yaro-yarolala fly, creep; Y:Watsn yar' ÃŒÂ«le; yarÃŒÂ«len; yar'ÃŒÂ«lian; yar'ÃŒÂ«lÃŒÂ¢la fly as a bird ,  creep , fly away; Y:Hanln yarroolay 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx yaw
\ps interjection 
\de alright, yes
\re alright ; yes
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Shortened from yaway, same as 'yes' (Watson); yaw yaw yaw 'come back' (interjection to call dogs) (Y:Holm:Curry). See under yaway, see also ngeh.
\rfg Y:Holm jau 1. Yes , 2. Interjection to call dogs (gc); Y:Allen yau as 'yes'; Y:Watsn yau adv. All-right (same as yes); Tw:Sc:Bray yo , yoe;

\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx yawahr
\ps noun
\de corroboree, corroboree song
\re corroboree ; corroboree song
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co Corroboree type with action and mass participation (Gd); three types listed by Livingstone, associated with The Three Brothers, yawahr with Berrung, girahny with Mommom, and waguy with Yar Birain. Cf, girin, wagaya.
\xv Wa: Yarbilidjahndu yawahrgu yagambu yirali yang giwa-nyun. 
\xe 'They used to sing the coroboree before the whiteman came.'
\xv Wa: Gandehn ngay wadjiyah blaganmirni yawahr gilah ngahrila. 
\xe 'I came to tell you there is a corroboree there.'
\xv Cas: Yawahr gale jeyir bahn.gala. 
\xe 'A big corroboree is starting.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngaydju nyulangi bahnbinymani yawahrgu. 
\xe 'I got him up for the corroboree.'
\xv M:Liv: yawahr berungah 
\xe 'Berrung's corroboree.'
\rfg M:Liv youara 
\rfb Bj:TMcD yawahr corroboree (?); Bj:Holm:Fe,g,, Turnbl jawar; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn corr. Dance; Cas:Smy jauwa:r, jawa:r ; Wu?:Calley jo:ar: corroboree ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt corr.; 
\rfo

\lx yawun
\ps noun
\de sunset, afternoon, late afternoon, evening, night
\re sunset ; afternoon ; afternoon, late ; evening ; night
\do1 ne
\do2 ti
\sf
\co yawun, yawungahl 'afternoon' (Wa); from midday till dark, Gd 'late afternoon till dark', yawun-yawuhn 'late afternoon till dark, evening' Wa, Gd; see also ngularun. 
\xv Gd: Gunah yawunde nyahni nyule,g,. 
\xe '(I) saw him yesterday evening.'
\xv Cas: Yang! Ngali yawun! 
\xe 'Look! We're late!'
\xv Cas: Ngay yan.gahny yawundi ngubu. 
\xe 'I shall go tomorrow afternoon.'
\xv Cas: Ngay yangguwani yawundjang/ yawundidjang. 
\xe 'I came late, in the evening'
\xv Cas: Ngay yehni yawundi ngubu. 
\xe 'I left yesterday afternoon.'
\xv Cas: Ngay yan.gahny yawundi bayahny. 
\xe 'I'll go this afternoon.' 
\rfg Y:Allen yau-ull afternoon; Y:Watsn yau'-un' afternoon; M:Liv yan sunset; AT:Curr:Prior youan , AT:Curr:O'Conn woolaroon ; M:Liv yan 
\rfb Bj:Sha:LWilsn yawun
\rfk Wa:Crowl ; Cas:Smy jÃŒ_wun , joun , jouwun , jouwundjan (prob. Final ng misprint) ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ;

\lx yehn-, yehn- (yehna-, yehn.ga-) (Wi, Ny)
\ps verb intransitive
\de sit, sit down, stay, live, dwell
\re sit (down) ; stay ; live ; dwell
\co yahn- (M) ; Wi:Curr:Lismore forms probably variant pronunciations: yehn- and yahn: first sugests yehna-, second yahndur; with -dur a past tense suffix; inflected form yahn.gali- (M:Liv) ; sit or sit down, stay, live, stop, irreg; stay in one place, be seated or be in process of sitting down; yehn.galah 'sitting' (We). Yahn- etc, in northern dialects.
\xv Bj:Holm:Fe,g,: Wuya yehna.
\xe 'Sit down.'
\xv Wa: Ngay gala marahng yeh-nyun gilah gabala.
\xe 'I'm tired of staying out there in the scrub.'
\rfg M:Liv yana; yangale
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl ye:na; Bj:TMcD:Cowln yehn.ga sit , yehnala sitting down; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, yina- , yinbigu , yinbi; yinga- , yingani ,  yingan , yingin , yingala , yingan , yingilur , yinginan;  Wi:Curr:Lismore yelna , yundur sit; Ny:Sha:DCook yehna , yehnalah , yehnan ngay; Ny:Curr:Ballina yeanna sit; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn; Wu:Calley jena? sit down, jein.gala sit down ; Cas:Smy je:n-a, jen.gÃŒÃinj, je:jani

\co banggil in Y:Beaudst:Sc list; widal (probably widjang) in Y:Holm; wudjang in south. Yidjanggam 'long grass' in GC:Talleb:Sc, 'wet grassy flats' in Ngr:Gresty. Cf. Widjang-. 
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Bugani ngayu yidjanggu ngumbiny nganyah (mamali).
\xe 'I built my house (there) of grass.'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yihjang; Y:Allen ijun; Y:Watsn ÃŒÂ¨dhun; Ngr:Gresty eejungum wet grassy flats; AT:Curr:Prior yethung; AT:Curr:LandsWh yeechang; AT:Curr:O'Conn eedung; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr, Tw:Sc:Bray ejung; Y:Beaudst:Sc ,  Y:Beaudst:police bungil; GC:Talleb:Sc ejuncum long grass; Y:Hanln eejung 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 09/Apr/2015

\lx yila (Bj), yile (Ny), yili (M)
\ps interrogative locative 
\de where (to), somewhere, in what place?, some place
\re where (to), somewhere, in what place?, some place
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co Wi:Curr:Lismore possibly yube; M lists as what place?, some place.

\xv Bj:Holm: Yila nyula? 
\xe 'Where is he?'
\xv Bj:Holm:Turnbl: Yila wuhye yanbalehla ngargu?
\xe 'Where are you going to hunt?'

\xe 'Where are the Aborigines?'
\xv M:Liv: Yilijabalgan gilagubi gandalgubi?
\xe 'Where is the paddle of that canoe?
\xv M:Liv: Yili bandahn? 
\xe 'Where is the tomahawk?'
\xv Ng:Curr:Bray: Yili mibiny? 
\xe 'Where are the blacks?' 
\rfg M:Liv yilly what place , same place; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray ille where ; Y:Holm yila where 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl yila; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, yila; Wi:Curr:Lismore yubae bygal? Where are the Blacks?; Ny:Curr:Ballina ille bygle? Where are the Blacks? ;

\lx yindji, windji
\ps interrogative locative
\de where?, somewhere
\re where? ; somewhere
\do loc
\do 
\sf
\co An answer when the speaker does not know what the questioner wants to know (Sharpe's conclusion from other examples).
\xv Ng:Curr:Bray: Yindjigu wiya? 
\xe 'Where are you going to?'
\xv Ng:Curr:Bray: Yindjigal wiya? 
\xe 'Where are you coming from?'
\xv Ng:Curr:Bray: Yindjigu wiya? 
\xe 'Where are you going?'
\xv Ng:Curr:Bray: Windjigu wahlu? 
\xe 'Where are you going?' 
\rfg M:Liv inji , winji; inji-go where to, inji-gal where from; Ng:Sc:11/1899:Bray ingee I do not know; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray winge,g, 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr

\co Irregular. Watsn lists also nyingga-; yingilehla 'biting' (We), ying(g)ahla 'biting'; see also yingan. 
\xv Wa: Maliyu ngagambu yingani ngalingi. 
\xe 'The dog bit us.'
\xv Wa: Mahny bulahbu dabahy yingalehla nyulamangibu. 
\xe 'Those two dogs are biting each other.'
\xv Wa: Maliyu gihnydju yingani nganyi. 
\xe 'I got stung by an ant.'
\xv Cas: Dabayu nganyi yingani. 
\xe 'The dog bit me.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Ngayu waymani ngagami yugambeh yingiliyah mibinyi, jalganyi jahdjami. 
\xe 'I told that dog not to bite any man, woman or child.'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: Yingilehla ngagam. 
\xe 'The dogs are biting (each other?).' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yinga; Y:Allen pr inga, p ingani, pf inganian, f ingala; Y:Watsn yingahla 'biting, bite', n. Nyin'gan; nyÃŒÂ¨n'ga; nyÃŒÂ¨n'ganÃŒÂ¨; nyill'ganian; nyin'giila; M:Liv v.t. ingga 
\rfb Bj:Holm:Fe,g, yinga-; 
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn ; Cas:Smy jing-a, jingani ; 
\rfr Gd:Geyt ; 
\rfo

\lx yugam, yagam, jugam, yugam(beh)
\ps adverb
\de no, not
\re no ; not
\do
\do 
\sf
\co yugam-djam emphatic negative probably (M:Liv); cf, wunah (imperative) 'don't' (Y:Sha:Culhm); also cf, yugum. Older form was probably yugumbir or yugambir; cf, yugumbi. GC:Mestn has yagumba.
\xv AT:Curr:Prior: Yagam ganngahba. 
\xe '(I) don't know.'
\xv M:Liv: Yugam ngay yangngahny bambambu. 
\xe 'I cannot go with swollen feet.'
\xv Y:Holm:Logn: yugambeh giyalehla 
\xe 'never tells'
\xv Y:Sha:Culhm: yugambeh nyahla 
\xe 'can't see (it)' 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yugambeh (occasionally yugumbeh); Y:Holm:Logn , Curry , Fogty yugam no , none , not , yugambe nothing , no , none , never (Paulsn , Wzl , Logn , Curry) , yugum no , not (Fogty ,  Monsl); Y:Allen yugumm no; Y:Watsn yÃŒÃˆ'gÃŒ_m no ,  yÃŒÃˆ'gÃŒ_m not; M:Liv yoguÃ¥Â¡m; AT:Curr:Prior yagam (yagam canaba); AT:Curr:LandsWh ugum , yoogum; AT:Curr:O'Conn yacum; GC:Mestn yakoomba; GC:Nerang:Curr:Fowlr gucum (prob. Misread y); Tw:Sc:Bray ukum, ucum; Y:Hanln yugum; 
\rfb
\rfk 
\rfr Gn:Mathew yukumbi I don't know 
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\lx yugam, yugambe
\ps negative 
\de no, not
\re no ; not
\do
\do 
\sf
\co Used as negative with verbs and nouns (Sharpe); yugam -djam emphatic negative (M:Liv). 
\xv Bj:Holm: Yugumbe ngangani. 
\xe '(I) did not make it.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yugumbe ngay mibiny. 
\xe 'I do not know.'
\xv Bj:Holm: yugumbe nyahla 
\xe 'blind' (literally not seeing)
\xv Bj:Holm: Yugam nyula dabay. 
\xe 'He is not a dog.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yugam giligiwaya yanbi. 
\xe '(Do) not to go there.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yugam yanbigi. 
\xe '(He) does not want to go (home).'
\xv Ny: Yugambeh ganngahla (?) 
\xe 'I don't know.'
\xv M:Liv: Yugam ngay yangngahny bambambu. 
\xe 'I cannot go with swollen feet.' 
\rfg M:Liv yoguÃ¥Â¡m; M:Sc:Brunswk ucum no; Ng:Sc:11/1899:Bray you-cum no; Ng:Sc:Mur:Martn yoo-kum none; Ng:Curr:TwPtD:Bray ukum , ucum no 
\rfb Bj:Sha:Turnbl yugambe no , not; Bj:Holm:Fe,g, jugumba; Bj:TMcD:Morgn yogam , yogambeh no; Bj:Holm:Turnbl jugum ,  jugumi; Wi:Curr:Lism yukkum; Wi:Curr:Richmond ughun; Ny:Curr:Ballina yucumba no , yueombe nonygumble I don't know 
\rfk 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\co Probably nyugay and probably generic word, as nyugay given as generic by Y:Allen, Y:Watsn; nyugay bargal literally 'bee painful' - bee that stings (Y:Watsn). See nyugay, nyugay bargal. 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yugay Italian bee; Y:Watsn nyo'gai p  ÃŒ_rragÃŒ_l English bee - lit. Bee that stings; Y:Beaudst:Sc Nuki English bee 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr

\lx yugir
\ps noun
\de mussel, pipis, ugarie, e,g,rie
\re mussel ; pipis ; ugarie ; e,g,rie
\do1 fsh
\do2 ne
\sf
\co ugarie, e,g,rie, called "pippie" at Tweed River (Y:Hanln), also shell (Y:Sha:Culhm), cockle (Y:Watsn); probably shellfish; cf, place name Ukerebagh Island (yugirbah) (near Tweed Heads South) 'place of cockles'. Possibly yugari. 
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yugir shell; Y:Allen e,g,ri mussel; Y:Watsn yÃŒÃˆ'garÃŒÂ¨ mussel , cockle; Tw:Sc:Bray ugurybah pippie shell fish; Y:Hanln Eugarie = Yugaree; cockle yug'ÃŒÂ¢rÃŒÂ¨; Ng:Sc:Tweed ugurybah pi ppie shell fish

\lx yuh

\re soon ; later ; later on ; by and by
\do ti
\do 
\sf
\co Also occurs in Gd, Wa, see also yuhdjang; yuhgir 'much later, a long time ahead' (Gd); cf, yuhdji- 'to move away' (Wa).

\xe 'Let's go later when the wind stops.'

\xe 'It might rain later.'
\xv Wa: Mala jahdjam walanggehny yuh.
\xe 'That baby will soon be crawling.'
\xv Cas: Yuh ngadju wihnyi nyahny. 
\xe 'I'll see you later.'
\xv Cas: Nyule yangguwani yuhdjang. 
\xe 'He came later, afterwards.' 
\rfg Y:Allen yeu , Y:Watsn yÃŒÂ¨-ÃŒÃˆ by-and-bye

\lx yuna-
\ps verb intransitive 
\de lie down, sleep, camp, stay
\re lie down ; sleep ; camp ; stay
\do
\do 
\sf
\co See also yina-; lie down, whether or not you go to sleep, be lying, camp, be (where something lies flat; yuna-ngurahm 'to sleep' is a common expression (Wa); yunahla 'sleeping, lying down', yunah (imper) (We); inflected form yunali- (M:Liv). 
\xv Wa: Ngali yan.gahn dahbalamna bulahbudjubuny yunahny. 
\xe 'We used to go to Tabulam, and we would stay two nights.'
\xv Wa: Ngay gala yunahny gadji. 
\xe 'I will lie down here/I will sleep here.'
\xv Wa: Gala ngahnydja gilah bagarah bagah yunahla bahmbinydja. 
\xe 'That shield up there is on the hillside.'
\xv Cas: Balun yunahla gihla dugundah. 
\xe 'The river runs between the hills.'
\xv Cas: Yanah ngali yunah galahnyi guwangnyi.
\xe 'Let's go and camp somewhere out of this rain.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Wuya yunah. 
\xe 'Lie down.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Nyula yunani. 
\xe 'He lay down.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Yunahla mala. 
\xe 'He is having a rest.'
\xv Bj:Holm: Ngay yunahny 
\xe 'I will lie down.' 
\xv Bj:Holm: Yunalehny. 
\xe 'He is having a rest.' (this function of -liny recalls Kattang durative-habitual forms in -liny)
\xv M:Liv: Yunahgir ngay. 
\xe 'I should like to lie down.'
\xv M:Liv: Ngay ngurahm yunahny. 
\xe 'I will lie down and sleep.' 
\rfg M:Liv yuÃ¥Â¡nai-gerry; yÃŒÂ¼na lie down; yÃŒÂ¼nalÃŒÂ© , yunan (fut) 
\rfb Bj:TMcD:Cowln yuna , yunala lie down to sleep; Bj:Holm:Turnbl juna- , juna , junala , junan , junalin
\rfk Wa:Crowl; We:Gordn ; Cas:Smy jun-a ; 
\rfr
\rfo
\dt 10/Apr/2015

\co See also jahdjam.

\dt 28/Apr/2015

\lx yuranggay
\ps numeral
\de five
\re five
\do
\do 
\sf
\co yuranggay nyugumbil 'toes' (five toes); some dialects use their word for 'hand' for 'five', e,g, danggan in Gd, Yugambeh. 
\rfg
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo Cop:Hargrv urangi 'five' , urangi nugumbil 'toes'

\lx yuwahr
\ps noun
\de corroboree, corroboree song
\re corroboree ; corroboree song
\do lg
\do 
\sf
\co See yawahr. In Livingstone it is associated with Berrung, one of the Three Brothers, cf, girin, wagaya. In Gd, Wa yawahr is a corroboree type with action and mass participation. 
\xv M:Liv: yawar Berungna
\xe 'Berrung's corroboree'
\rfg Y:Sha:Culhm yuwahr , yawahr , yawar corroboree song; M:Liv youara 
\rfb
\rfk
\rfr
\rfo
